The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved the construction of 1,143.2 km of pipeline from the Bozoi gas metering station in the Shalkar region of Aktobe Region to Akbulak gas metering station in Sairam of South Kazakhstan Region (now known as the Turkistan Region). It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-1 and Bozoy shift camp in Shalkar region of Aktobe Region, emergency-response centers in Saksaulsk, Aksuat and Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region and an emergency-response center in Shornak within the South Kazakhstan Region, as well as construction of the automated process control system (SCADA) and telecommunication (fiber-optic communication line) for the gas pipeline in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project was initiated on July 17, 2012 (see pg.29 of "JSC NC "KazMunayGas" Annual Report 2013"). The project was expected to be completed by the end of 2012 (see "China and Kazakhstan begin construction of the second stage of the gas pipeline"). It was completed on September 7, 2013, resulting in a throughput capacity of up to 10 bcm per year (see "First section of China-Kazakstan gas pipeline II starts operation").

The second phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved 306.3 km of gas pipeline construction from Beineu settlement in the Mangystau Region to Bozoi settlement in the Aktobe Region. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-4 Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region, Beineu gas metering station in Mangystau Region, the SCADA central dispatch control in Kyzylorda, and gas pipeline construction in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). It was completed on December 30, 2016 (see "PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES").

Between 2014 and 2017, over 9.0 bcm of gas was transported via the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent gas pipeline, providing the southern regions with Kazakhstani gas. Then, in November 2017, a head compressor station at Bozoi and a line compressor station at Karaozek were put into operation, increasing the capacity of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline to 10 bcm per year. In October 2017, Kazakhstan began exporting gas to China pursuant to a contract concluded between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina for the supply of bcm from October 15, 2017 until October 14, 2018. The price of the gas exported to China pursuant to this agreement was linked to the price of Brent crude oil and determined quarterly. As of December 31, 2017, negotiations were ongoing with respect to a long-term gas supply agreement between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina. BSGP and KazMunayGas expected that the export of gas to China would increase in the future and made plans to construct three new compressor stations on the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline between 2018 and 2019 to handle this (see pg.151-152 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In order to fund Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) on December 11, 2012 (see linked project ID#39562). This loan bears interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 2.7% margin per annum for the duration of the guarantee period (until December 31, 2019) and, thereafter, at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 3.2% margin per annum. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in December 2017 until March 11, 2028 implying a grace period of 5 years and a maturity period of 15.25 years). The loan was secured by corporate guarantees from KazMunayGas and CNPC. Unspecified amendments to the facility were made in February 2016 (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus" and pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In February 2016 and September 2017, amendments were signed because of BSGP's non-compliance with certain project milestones provided for in the facility agreement; the milestones were extended until September 30, 2019. These amendments required BSGP's prepayment of $400 million USD of the outstanding indebtedness, which KazMunayGas provided to BSGP for repayment. The loan was secured by additional security, including an offshore account charge, an onshore account pledge and security assignment of BSGP's rights under the shareholder support agreement in favor of the security agent. As of June 30, 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under the loan was $1.462 billion USD (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus"). As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1 billion USD (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

Then, on September 17, 2015, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $700 million USD syndicated loan with CDB and BOC for Phase II of the project to supplement their $1.8 billion USD loan. CDB and BOC each contributed $350 million USD. This loan reportedly carries a maturity period of 15 years; the maturity date was September 17, 2030. The interest rate of the loan is unknown (see “Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Phase2 Additional Financing”). This project captures the CDB contribution; for the BOC contribution, see linked project ID#73384.

This 1,454 km pipeline runs through the Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.dropbox.com/s/8j082veud49pzvb/_i%20class%3D_fa%20fa-map%20fa-lg____i_%20Pipeline%20map%20%E2%80%93%20Beineu%20Shymkent.pdf?dl=0 and https://bsgp.kz/en_US/%d0%ba%d0%b0%d1%80%d1%82%d0%b0-%d0%b3%d0%b0%d0%b7%d0%be%d0%bf%d1%80%d0%be%d0%b2%d0%be%d0%b4%d0%b0/ and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/
name: Qyzylorda

title: ICBC participates in a $1.18 billion USD loan facility for the 794 km Kenkiyak-Kumkol Section of the Kazakhstan-China Oil Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#39605 and #54523)
description:
On August 12, 2008, Chinese-Kazakh joint venture Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP entered into a $1.18 billion USD credit facility with the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited (ICBC) and the ING Bank N.V. for a term of ten years, subject to extension for up to five additional years. This credit facility was entered into for the purpose of financing the construction of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. KCP had the right to draw down the loan in four tranches. It drew down three in 2008 in an aggregate principal amount of $1 billion USD. The availability period of this credit facility expired at the end of 2011. The borrowed funds bore an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 2% margin per annum until February 2013 and 6-month LIBOR + a 4% margin per annum thereafter. CNPC provided a guarantee from the loan. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this facility was $403.9 million USD (including the capitalised interest) (₸134.3 billion KZT) (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). Based on the information above, the interest rate was recorded as 6-Month LIBOR in August 2008 (3.108%) + 2%, or 5.108%, while the maturity period is 10 years and the grace period is zero. 

JSC KazTransOil (KTO) and China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development Corporation (CNODC) formed a joint venture Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) called Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP (KCP) on July 6, 2004 (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP History"). KCP was created to construct and operate the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline and the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. These pipelines are two of three pipeline systems of the Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network, which was built to create a transport corridor for the export of Kazakhstani oil to China. KTO and CNODC each owned 50% of the joint venture (see pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). 

This project sought to the construct the Kenkiyak–Kumkol pipeline, which was intended to transport oil from West Kazakhstan and Aktobe oilfields. It began in Kenkiyak and ended in Kumkol. The pipeline was 794.263 km long and it had a maximum capacity of10 million tons a year. It included relay pump stations to increase the volume of oil transported (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline About"). The pipe had diameters ranging between 0.5 and 1.8 meters (see pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline passed through the Aktobe, Kyzylorda and Karaganda regions, with its oil destined for the Chinese market. JSC OGCC KazStroyService was responsible for the construction of the 483 km section from Kenkiyak to Aralsk, while China Petroleum Pipeline Engineering Co., Ltd. (CPPE) was responsible for the construction of a 311 km section to Kumkol. Construction of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline began on December 11, 2007 (see "Kenkiyak - Kumkol"). The pipeline went into operation on October 6, 2009 (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline").

As of 31 December 31, 2017, the pipeline had a throughput capacity of 9.2 million tonnes of crude oil per year. In 2017, 5.2 million tonnes of crude oil were transported through the pipeline. Pursuant to an agreement between the KTO and CNODC, the capacity of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline was increased from 10.0 million tonnes of crude oil per year to 20.0 million tonnes in
2015 so as to take advantage of expected increased production at Tengiz Field and Kashagan Field. Ten companies supply oil to the pipeline, which KCP has continued to own (pg.158 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

The Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network is comprised of three systems: (i) the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline, from Kenkiyak in western Kazakhstan to Atyrau on the Caspian Sea; (ii) the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China; and (iii) the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan. All three systems are operational (pg.249 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The Atasu-Alashankou pipeline project is captured by linked project ID#39605, while the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline is captured by linked project ID#54523.

STAFF_NOTE: As the loan financiers include a non-Chinese financier (ING Bank N.V.) and the breakdown of loan amounts between the 2 financiers are not known, a transaction amount has not been recorded for this project. This project is sometimes called “Second stage of Kazakhstan-China oil pipeline construction."

The 794 km Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline runs from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan and runs through three regions (Aktobe, Kyzylorda and Karaganda). A 483 km segment runs from the Kenkiyak station to the Aralsk area, and a 311 km segment to the Kumkol station. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.energycharter.org/fileadmin/DocumentsMedia/Presentations/CBP-KZ-CN.pdf and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/
name: Qyzylorda

title: China National Petroleum Corporation donates $4 million USD to the Kyzylorda Region (Linked to Project ID#73456)
description: In 2007, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) donated $4 million USD to the Kyzylorda Region. This donation, alongside a $1.8 million USD donation to the South Kazakhstan Region (as captured by linked project ID#73456), funded the construction of a railway, a community park, a school and library, and improvements to drinking water and power supply (see 'CNPC in Kazakhstan'). STAFF_NOTE: Project status was coded as 'Completion' because it is evident that the funds were completely disbursed. 'Year uncertain' box was checked because it is not confirmed that this donation was committed to in 2007.
GEO_sources: https://www.cnpc.com.cn/en/Kazakhstan/country_index.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.cnpc.com.cn/cnpc/Kazakhstan/country_index.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.cnpc.com.cn/ru/sqjs/hjysh_common.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
name: Qyzylorda

title: Bank of China provides a $64.5 million USD in a syndicated loan to Gezhouba Shieli Cement Company LLC for the construction of a cement production plant (Linked to Project ID#70845)
description:
In 2017, Bank of China (BOC) and the Export-Import Bank of China provided a $129 million USD syndicated loan to Gezhouba Shieli Cement Company LLC to finance the construction of the cement production plant in Kazakhstan. The loan carried a maturity period of nine years. China Gezhouba Group Cement Co., Ltd. proved a guarantee for the loan, while China Export & Credit Insurance (Sinosure) provided overseas investment insurance that covered political risk up to 95%. The project had a total cost of $178.03 million USD (see "33. Daily Cement Production Capacity of 2500 Tons in Kazakhstan"). BOC provided 50% of the loan, or $64.5 million USD (see "汇聚金融力量 布局“一带一路” 中行银团贷助葛洲坝水泥落籍哈萨克斯坦建厂兴业【人民网】"). The China Eximbank contribution is captured by linked project ID#70845.

This cement plant was located in Shieli of the Shieli District within the Kyzylorda Region. The plant was designed to have daily production of 2,500 tons of clinker cement and an annual production of 1 million tons of cement (see "Energy China Group-built Cement Project in Kazakhstan Put into Production"). It was also designed to produce nine different nine types of cement. Its major product was oil well cement, which was expected to help reduced Kazakhstan's reliance on imports (see "New Chinese-Kazakh cement plant put into operation in SW Kazakhstan"). The plant was expected to be completed before the end of 2018. China Triumph International Engineering Co., Ltd. (CTIEC) won the engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) contract in April 2017. Its subsidiary Beijing Triumph International Engineering Co., Ltd. assumed responsibility for design work (see "Steppe Cement revenue rises by 20% to US$65.6m in 2017"). Construction began on April 7, 2017 (see "Energy China Group-built Cement Project in Kazakhstan Put into Production"). The official opening ceremony of the plant was on December 11, 2018 (see "Shuttered at home, cement plants bloom along China's new Silk Road"). The plant was officially put into operation on October 18, 2019 (see "Energy China Group-built Cement Project in Kazakhstan Put into Production").

Gezhouba Shieli Cement Company LLC (葛洲壩西里水泥有限公司) was a three-party joint venture (special purpose vehicle) between China Gezhouba Group Corporation Limited (CGGC) (50%), China Gezhouba Group Overseas Investment Co., Ltd (20%), a subsidiary of CGGC, and a local cement company called DANAKE Corporation (sometimes called Kazakhstan Darnak Co., Ltd.) (30%) (see "Steppe Cement revenue rises by 20% to US$65.6m in 2017" and pg.7 of "China Gezhouba Group Stock Company Limited Summary of 2016 Interim Report").
GEO_sources: http://kz.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201811/20181102803459.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://en.trend.az/business/economy/2853862.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.globalcement.com/news/item/6647-gezhouba-shieli-invites-investors-for-kazakh-project, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.bankofchina.com/aboutboc/ab8/201812/t20181210_14393368.html?keywords=%B9%FE%C8%F8%BF%CB%CB%B9%CC%B9, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/x2trg55u47oas9x/Daily%20Cement%20Production%20Capacity%20of%202500%20Tons%20in%20Kazakhstan%20--%20Kazakhstan.pdf?dl=0, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/q2eekyv8uuingft/34_04.doc?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.gzbgj.ceec.net.cn/art/2019/9/11/art_7615_1975619.html, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.china.org.cn/world/Off_the_Wire/2019-10/20/content_75320680.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.cemnet.com/News/story/167606/china-gezhouba-group-cement-s-shieli-plant-put-into-operation.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www1.hkexnews.hk/listedco/listconews/sehk/2016/0830/ltn201608301287.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://en.sasac.gov.cn/2019/11/01/c_2705.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-silkroad-cement-insight/shuttered-at-home-cement-plants-bloom-along-chinas-new-silk-road-idUSKCN1PO35T, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2019-10/20/c_138487805.htm, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://kknews.cc/finance/r5lq4mx.html, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://www.dropbox.com/s/5v1tqnslgsvaqjp/Kazakhstan%20-%20Cement%20industry%20news%20from%20Global%20Cement.pdf?dl=0, Media Report, including Wikileaks
name: Shieliyskiy

title: Bank of China Kazakhstan contributes $120 million USD to loan syndicate for Shalkiya Zinc and Lead Mine Expansion Project
description:
On December 29, 2017, JSC AB Bank of China Kazakhstan, a subsidiary bank of Bank of China (Beijing), and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) signed a $295 million USD syndicated loan contract with ShalkiyaZinc Ltd. JSC - a 100% subsidiary of Kazakh state-owned JSC Tau-Ken Samruk, National Mining Company of Kazakhstan - to partially finance the Shalkiya Zinc and Lead Mine Expansion Project. The EBRD was the lead arranger of the loan syndicate; Bank of China Kazakhstan provided $120 million USD and EBRD provided $175 million USD respectively. (see "Bank of China to participate in EBRD Shalkiya Zinc syndicated loan"). Under the terms of this syndicated loan agreement, the principal debt was to be repaid in equal installments every six months beginning on June 20, 2021. The loan must be fully repaid as of December 20, 2029. Therefore, the loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 12 years and a grace period of 3.5 years, in addition to an interest rate of LIBOR plus a 2.5 % annual interest margin. National Welfare Fund Samruk-Kazyna JSC provided an irrevocable guarantee for the loan. The commission and reservation fees, paid by ShalkiyaZink Ltd. to EBRD in 2017, totaled ₸1,153,624 thousand KZT (see pg.167 of "Annual Report 2017").

The Zinc Mine Reconstruction and Expansion Project sought to expand the mining operations at the existing Shalkiya lead-zinc mine and construct a beneficiation plant at
the facility. Shalkiya lead-zinc deposit was one of the largest in Kazakhstan and was expected to produce 4 million tons of ore per year. The project intended to to introduce the latest technologies in the field of extraction and production, including a vertical ore hoisting conveyor, to the project. A new concentrating mill, tailing dump, intrasite networks, ore-issuing complex and carrying out mining and capital works at the Shalkiya mine were all included (see pg.3 and 167 of "Annual Report 2017"). After completion of the reconstruction and expansion of the mine, it was expected that ShalkiyaZink Ltd. JSC would become the top zinc mining company in Kazakhstan, and one of the world's top zinc mining companies, developing the local economy, offering employment, and inducing development in upstream and downstream industries in Kazakhstan. The Ministry of Energy of Kazakhstan was to provide infrastructure services for the smooth implementation of the project (see "哈萨克中国银行向哈锌矿项目提供1.2亿美元贷款【哈通社中文网】"). The EPC contractor responsible for project implementation was German company Engineering Dobersek GmbH. In 2018, construction was scheduled to begin in 2020 (see "SOVEREIGN WEALTH FUND SAMRUK-KAZYNA SIGNS...")

The Shalkiya Mine is located in the territory of the Zhanakorgan District of Kyzylorda Region in Kazakhstan. The Shalkiya mining site is rather flat with some decline to the west towards the Syr Darya River. Code fixes of the mine are 67 degrees 25 minutes of east longitude and 44 degrees 01 minutes of north latitude. The mine is 15 kilometers north-west from Zhanakorgan settlement. The regional center of Zhanakorgan is connected by roads and railways to the rest of Kazakhstan, through the city of Shymkent – with Uzbekistan and China and through Kyzylorda – with Russia (see pg.12 of "ShalkiyaZinc N.V. Annual Report and Accounts for the year ended 31 December 2009"). More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.ebrd.com/documents/environment/esia-48347-nts.pdf.

STAFF_NOTE: The LIBOR rate was assumed to be 6-month. The six-month LIBOR rate in December 2017 was 1.768%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as 1.768% + 2.5%, or 4.268%.
name: Zhanakorganskiy

title: CDB and Bank of China provide a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan for Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#40362 and #73384)
description:
On January 18, 2011, a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) called Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP (BSGP) was established in Kazakhstan to oversee the financing, design, and implementation of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project. JSC KazTransGas (KTG) and China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) (acting through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) each held a 50% ownership stake in BSGP (see JV formation date at “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”; see rest at pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

The Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline was a 1454 km long gas pipeline that running through the Mangistau, Aktyubinsk, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. It has a pipe diameter of 1067 mm (see “Beineu-Bozoy-Shymkent gas pipeline is the largest pipeline project...” and pg.149 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The purpose of the project was to ensure stable gas demand in the southern Kazakhstan, reduce dependence on imported gas and ensure the energy security of Kazakhstan. Construction of the pipeline was split into two phases (see “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”).

The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved the construction of 1,143.2 km of pipeline from the Bozoi gas metering station in the Shalkar region of Aktobe Region to Akbulak gas metering station in Sairam of South Kazakhstan Region (now known as the Turkistan Region). It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-1 and Bozoy shift camp in Shalkar region of Aktobe Region, emergency-response centers in Saksaulsk, Aksuat and Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region and an emergency-response center in Shornak within the South Kazakhstan Region, as well as construction of the automated process control system (SCADA) and telecommunication (fiber-optic communication line) for the gas pipeline in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project was initiated on July 17, 2012 (see pg.29 of "JSC NC "KazMunayGas" Annual Report 2013"). The project was expected to be completed by the end of 2012 (see "China and Kazakhstan begin construction of the second stage of the gas pipeline"). It was completed on September 7, 2013, resulting in a throughput capacity of up to 10 bcm per year (see "First section of China-Kazakstan gas pipeline II starts operation").

The second phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved 306.3 km of gas pipeline construction from Beineu settlement in the Mangystau Region to Bozoi settlement in the Aktobe Region. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-4 Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region, Beineu gas metering station in Mangystau Region, the SCADA central dispatch control in Kyzylorda, and gas pipeline construction in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). It was completed on December 30, 2016 (see "PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES").

Between 2014 and 2017, over 9.0 bcm of gas was transported via the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent gas pipeline, providing the southern regions with Kazakhstani gas. Then, in November 2017, a head compressor station at Bozoi and a line compressor station at Karaozek were put into operation, increasing the capacity of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline to 10 bcm per year. In October 2017, Kazakhstan began exporting gas to China pursuant to a contract concluded between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina for the supply of bcm from October 15, 2017 until October 14, 2018. The price of the gas exported to China pursuant to this agreement was linked to the price of Brent crude oil and determined quarterly. As of December 31, 2017, negotiations were ongoing with respect to a long-term gas supply agreement between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina. BSGP and KazMunayGas expected that the export of gas to China would increase in the future and made plans to construct three new compressor stations on the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline between 2018 and 2019 to handle this (see pg.151-152 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In order to fund Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) on December 11, 2012 (captured by this project). This loan bears interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 2.7% margin per annum for the duration of the guarantee period (until December 31, 2019) and, thereafter, at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 3.2% margin per annum. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in December 2017 until March 11, 2028 (implying a grace period of 5 years and a maturity period of 15.25 years). The loan was secured by corporate guarantees from KazMunayGas and CNPC. Unspecified amendments to the facility were made in February 2016 (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus" and pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In February 2016 and September 2017, amendments were signed because of BSGP's non-compliance with certain project milestones provided for in the facility agreement; the milestones were extended until September 30, 2019. These amendments required BSGP's prepayment of $400 million USD of the outstanding indebtedness, which KazMunayGas provided to BSGP for repayment. The loan was secured by additional security, including an offshore account charge, an onshore account pledge and security assignment of BSGP's rights under the shareholder support agreement in favor of the security agent. As of June 30, 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under the loan was $1.462 billion USD (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus"). As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1.0 billion USD (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

Then, on September 17, 2015, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $700 million USD syndicated loan with CDB and BOC for Phase II of the project to supplement their $1.8 billion USD loan. CDB and BOC each reportedly contributed $350 million USD. This loan reportedly carries a maturity period of 15 years; the maturity date was September 17, 2030. The interest rate of the loan is unknown (see “Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Phase2 Additional Financing”). For the BOC contribution, see linked project ID#73384; for the CDB contribution, see linked project ID#40362.

STAFF_NOTE: The 3-month LIBOR rate in December 2012 was 0.309%. The interest rate, therefore, was coded as 0.309% + 2.7%, or 3.009%.

This 1,454 km pipeline runs through the Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.dropbox.com/s/8j082veud49pzvb/_i%20class%3D_fa%20fa-map%20fa-lg____i_%20Pipeline%20map%20%E2%80%93%20Beineu%20Shymkent.pdf?dl=0 and https://bsgp.kz/en_US/%d0%ba%d0%b0%d1%80%d1%82%d0%b0-%d0%b3%d0%b0%d0%b7%d0%be%d0%bf%d1%80%d0%be%d0%b2%d0%be%d0%b4%d0%b0/ and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/
name: South Kazakhstan

title: CDB and Bank of China provide a $4.7 billion USD syndicated loan for the Kazakhstani Section of Line C of the Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline (Linked to Project ID#40833, #39955, #54489, #54528, and #70616)
description:
The Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline, also known as the China-Central Asia Gas Pipeline or, simply, the Asia Gas Pipeline, is a 1,873-km long gas pipeline connecting Turkmenistan to China via Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan, delivering gas equal to approximately 20% of China’s annual natural gas consumption. It consists of 4 lines (A/B/C/D). A, B, and C run parallel to each other. The pipelines begin at Gedaim on the Turkmen-Uzbek border, run through central Uzbekistan and southern Kazakhstan, and end at Khorgas in China's Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region. Line A (#40833 and #54489) of this pipeline became operational in 2009 while the other two lines — Line B (ID#40834 and #54489) and Line C (ID#39997) — started their operations in 2010 and 2014, respectively. Line A and B will be connected to the Second West-East Gas Pipeline, while Line C will be connected to the Third West-East Gas Pipeline. Line D (ID#39955 and #70616), which is under construction, will run through Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, and Kyrgyzstan to Wuqia County in China, where it will be connected to the Fifth West-East Gas Pipeline. Line A, B, and C provide 55 billion cubic meters of gas to China per annum (see "中国-中亚天然气管道简介").

JSC KazTransGas formed a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) with China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) (through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) called Asia Gas Pipeline LLP (AGP) to construct and operate the Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline in Kazakhstan. JSC KazTransGas and CNPC each held a 50% equity stake in AGP (see pg.37 of “JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus”).
 
This project records the financing of the Kazakhstani segment of Line C, which is sometimes referred to as a part of the Kazakhstan-China Gas Pipeline. The financing of the Uzbek section is captured by linked project ID#54528. The 1,830 km long pipeline begins at the Turkmen-Uzbek border and ends at Khorgas in Xinjiang. Construction of Line C began in September 2012. The overall welding work of the pipeline was completed at the end of 2013. Line C went into operation on May 31, 2014 (see "Flow of natural gas from Central Asia"). It began transferring gas to China in June 2014 (see "Gas trade for the better"). Line C successfully transmitted gas to Khorgas on June 15, 2017 (see "中国-中亚天然气管道简介"). Line C has a designed capacity of 25 billion cubic meters per annum, and its pipe diameter is 1,219 mm, 152 mm larger than Line A/B. Upon completion of all supporting facilities of Line C, the overall delivery capacity of the Central Asia-China Gas Pipeline was expected to reach 55 billion cubic meters per annum, equaling approximately 20% of China’s annual natural gas consumption while annually substituting 73 million tons of coal and cutting carbon dioxide and sulfur dioxide emissions by 78 million tons and 1.21 million tons respectively. Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan contribute each 10 bcm of gas to Line C, while Kazakhstan supplies 5 bcm of gas (see "Flow of natural gas from Central Asia"). 

In December 2012, AGP entered into a $4.7 billion USD syndicated loan facility with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) to finance the construction of Line C of the Turkmenistan-China Gas Pipeline. The loan bears interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 2.35% margin per annum during the guarantee period and 3-month LIBOR + a 3.45% per annum thereafter. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in June 2017 until December 27, 2027. The loan was secured by a "ship or pay" transportation agreement pledge, account charges, insurance and reinsurance policies assignments, and a guarantee from CNPC. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount from this loan was $2.9 billion USD (see pg.110 and 151 of “JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus” and pg.85 of “JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus”). Based on this information, the interest rate was recorded as 3-Month LIBOR in December 2012 (0.309%) + 2.35%, or 2.659%, while the grace period was 4.5 years, the repayment period was 10.5 years, and the maturity period was 15 years.
name: South Kazakhstan

title: China Eximbank provides a $43.668 million USD loan to BTA Bank for the construction of South Kazakhstan cement plant
description:
On October 31, 2008, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $43.680 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with BTA Bank (Turan-Alem Bank) to finance construction of a cement plant in the South Kazakhstan Region (see "BTA Bank (Kazakhstan) and Export-Import bank of China sign credit agreement..."). The loan carried a maturity period of six years and a "substantial grace period." It covered 80% of the cost of the project; the remainder was co-financed (see "Cement project strengthens trade co-operation"). BTA Bank then used the proceeds of the PBC loan to on-lend to Standard Cement LLP, the company responsible for the cement plant (see "BTA Bank (Kazakhstan) and Export-Import bank of China sign credit agreement...").

The plant was to have a production capacity of the plant of 1 million tons of Portland cement per year. It was expected to meet the needs of southern Kazakhstan and export to other Central Asia countries (see "Cement project strengthens trade co-operation"). The plant used dry process to create cement, an environmentally-friendly process (see "Standard Cement Company history"). The project included the construction of a cement production line with a daily capacity of 2,500 tons. Tianjin Cement Industry Design & Research Institute Co., Ltd. — a unit of Sinoma International Engineering Co., Ltd. — won the contract from Standard Cement for the design and equipment for the cement production line (see "China’s Sinoma unit wins US$55m Kazakhstan cement plant contract"). The project commenced on May 8, 2012. The project was handed over to Standard Cement on June 25, 2013. After the expiration of the defects notification period, all construction on the project was complete on August 25, 2014 (see "FAC for Kazakhstan Slag Grinding Project of Standard Cement").
name: South Kazakhstan

title: CDB provides $350 million USD via a $700 million USD syndicated loan for Phase II of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project (Additional Financing) (Linked to Project ID#39562 and #73384)
description:
On January 18, 2011, a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) called Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP (BSGP) was established in Kazakhstan to oversee the financing, design, and implementation of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project. JSC KazTransGas (KTG) and China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) (acting through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) each held a 50% ownership stake in BSGP (see JV formation date at “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”; see rest at pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

The Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline was a 1454 km long gas pipeline that running through the Mangistau, Aktyubinsk, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. It has a pipe diameter of 1067 mm (see “Beineu-Bozoy-Shymkent gas pipeline is the largest pipeline project...” and pg.149 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The purpose of the project was to ensure stable gas demand in the southern Kazakhstan, reduce dependence on imported gas and ensure the energy security of Kazakhstan. Construction of the pipeline was split into two phases (see “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”).

The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved the construction of 1,143.2 km of pipeline from the Bozoi gas metering station in the Shalkar region of Aktobe Region to Akbulak gas metering station in Sairam of South Kazakhstan Region (now known as the Turkistan Region). It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-1 and Bozoy shift camp in Shalkar region of Aktobe Region, emergency-response centers in Saksaulsk, Aksuat and Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region and an emergency-response center in Shornak within the South Kazakhstan Region, as well as construction of the automated process control system (SCADA) and telecommunication (fiber-optic communication line) for the gas pipeline in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project was initiated on July 17, 2012 (see pg.29 of "JSC NC "KazMunayGas" Annual Report 2013"). The project was expected to be completed by the end of 2012 (see "China and Kazakhstan begin construction of the second stage of the gas pipeline"). It was completed on September 7, 2013, resulting in a throughput capacity of up to 10 bcm per year (see "First section of China-Kazakstan gas pipeline II starts operation").

The second phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved 306.3 km of gas pipeline construction from Beineu settlement in the Mangystau Region to Bozoi settlement in the Aktobe Region. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-4 Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region, Beineu gas metering station in Mangystau Region, the SCADA central dispatch control in Kyzylorda, and gas pipeline construction in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). It was completed on December 30, 2016 (see "PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES").

Between 2014 and 2017, over 9.0 bcm of gas was transported via the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent gas pipeline, providing the southern regions with Kazakhstani gas. Then, in November 2017, a head compressor station at Bozoi and a line compressor station at Karaozek were put into operation, increasing the capacity of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline to 10 bcm per year. In October 2017, Kazakhstan began exporting gas to China pursuant to a contract concluded between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina for the supply of bcm from October 15, 2017 until October 14, 2018. The price of the gas exported to China pursuant to this agreement was linked to the price of Brent crude oil and determined quarterly. As of December 31, 2017, negotiations were ongoing with respect to a long-term gas supply agreement between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina. BSGP and KazMunayGas expected that the export of gas to China would increase in the future and made plans to construct three new compressor stations on the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline between 2018 and 2019 to handle this (see pg.151-152 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In order to fund Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) on December 11, 2012 (see linked project ID#39562). This loan bears interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 2.7% margin per annum for the duration of the guarantee period (until December 31, 2019) and, thereafter, at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 3.2% margin per annum. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in December 2017 until March 11, 2028 implying a grace period of 5 years and a maturity period of 15.25 years). The loan was secured by corporate guarantees from KazMunayGas and CNPC. Unspecified amendments to the facility were made in February 2016 (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus" and pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In February 2016 and September 2017, amendments were signed because of BSGP's non-compliance with certain project milestones provided for in the facility agreement; the milestones were extended until September 30, 2019. These amendments required BSGP's prepayment of $400 million USD of the outstanding indebtedness, which KazMunayGas provided to BSGP for repayment. The loan was secured by additional security, including an offshore account charge, an onshore account pledge and security assignment of BSGP's rights under the shareholder support agreement in favor of the security agent. As of June 30, 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under the loan was $1.462 billion USD (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus"). As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1 billion USD (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

Then, on September 17, 2015, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $700 million USD syndicated loan with CDB and BOC for Phase II of the project to supplement their $1.8 billion USD loan. CDB and BOC each contributed $350 million USD. This loan reportedly carries a maturity period of 15 years; the maturity date was September 17, 2030. The interest rate of the loan is unknown (see “Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Phase2 Additional Financing”). This project captures the CDB contribution; for the BOC contribution, see linked project ID#73384.

This 1,454 km pipeline runs through the Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.dropbox.com/s/8j082veud49pzvb/_i%20class%3D_fa%20fa-map%20fa-lg____i_%20Pipeline%20map%20%E2%80%93%20Beineu%20Shymkent.pdf?dl=0 and https://bsgp.kz/en_US/%d0%ba%d0%b0%d1%80%d1%82%d0%b0-%d0%b3%d0%b0%d0%b7%d0%be%d0%bf%d1%80%d0%be%d0%b2%d0%be%d0%b4%d0%b0/ and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/
name: South Kazakhstan

title: China National Petroleum Corporation donates $1.8 million USD to the South Kazakhstan Region (Linked to Project ID#73455)
description: In 2007, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) donated $1.8 million USD to the South Kazakhstan Region (now known as the Turkestan Region). This donation, alongside a $4 million USD donation to the Kyzylorda Region (as captured by linked project ID#73455), funded the construction of a railway, a community park, a school and library, and improvements to drinking water and power supply (see 'CNPC in Kazakhstan'). STAFF_NOTE: Project status was coded as 'Completion' because it is evident that the funds were completely disbursed. 'Year uncertain' box was checked because it is not confirmed that this donation was committed to in 2007.
GEO_sources: https://www.cnpc.com.cn/en/Kazakhstan/country_index.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.cnpc.com.cn/cnpc/Kazakhstan/country_index.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.cnpc.com.cn/ru/sqjs/hjysh_common.shtml, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
name: South Kazakhstan

title: CDB provides $607 million loan USD for Phase II of Shymkent Oil Refinery Reconstruction and Modernization Project (Linked to Project ID#72399)
description:
On June 9, 2017, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $607 million USD term facility loan agreement with the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (DBK) for phase 2 of the reconstruction and modernization of the Shymkent Oil Refinery. DBK then used the proceeds from the CDB loan to on-lend to a project company (special purpose vehicle) called PetroKazakhstan Oil Products LLP (PKOP). The CDB loan facility had a maturity date of April 25, 2030 and carried an interest of rate of 2.7% per annum plus LIBOR. No amounts were outstanding under the facility as of June 30, 2017. As of September 2017, DBK had drawn down $100 million USD under the CDB facility (see pg.47 of "Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017"). 

PKOP contributed some of its own funds towards the project (see "PetroKazakhstan Oil Products LLP information"). Additionally, China Export & Credit Insurance Corporation (Sinosure) organized a bank syndicate of CA-Bank, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, and Deutsche Bank (see "十八年服务新中国对外开放 新战略助力中国信保再启航"). The syndicate provided $225 million USD to DBK for on-lending, while Sinosure provided export buyer’s credit insurance (see "中石油工程建设公司 向信用保险“借力”发展").

The Export-Import Bank of China pledged $1 billion USD for the first phase of the modernization of the refinery as captured by linked project ID#72399. The project sought to increase annual production from 5.25 million to 6 million tons and improve refining levels.  After the modernization (including Phase I , the plant was to be more environmentally friendly and able to produce Euro-4 and Euro-5 products (see "Shymkent Oil Refinery completes modernisation, improves fuel and environmental standard"). The project also included the construction of a complex of catalytic cracking units with a capacity of 2 million tons a year, an alkali treatment unit, a amine recovery unit, a sour water stripper, a pressure swing absorption unit, a unsaturated LPG desulfurization unit, a saturated LPG desulfurization unit, a sulfur production unit, and a revamping of the CDU of LK-6U complex. China Petroleum Engineering and Construction Corporation (CPEEC) was the general contractor responsible for project implementation (see "The Shymkent Refinery is the model of successful partnership"). Phase II was completed on August 15, 2018 (see "哈萨克斯坦奇姆肯特炼厂二期改造工程开工成功 ").

The shareholders of PetroKazakhstan Oil Products LLP were CNPC Exploration and Development Company Ltd. (50%) and JSC Exploration & Production KazMunayGas (50%) (see "China's CNPC completes upgrade at Kazakh's Shymkent refinery"). CNPC Exploration and Development Company Ltd. was a subsidiary of PetroChina Company Ltd. and a 50/50 joint venture between PetroChina and CNODC. JSC Exploration & Production KazMunaiGas (EP KMG) was engaged into production of crude oil at the oil fields in western and southern Kazakhstan, and was a subsidiary of JSC National Company KazMunayGas (see "Shareholders").

STAFF_NOTE: The LIBOR rate was not specified, so the 6-month LIBOR was assumed. In June 2017 the average 6-month LIBOR rate was 1.432%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as 1.432% + 2.7%, or 4.132%. The Chinese name of this project is 哈萨克斯坦奇姆肯特炼厂二期.

This oil refinery was located in Shymkent in the Sayramskiy region. Its exact locational coordinates can be found at http://globalenergyobservatory.org/geoid/6696.
name: Shymkent

name: Zhambyl

title: China donates school supplies to Kazakhstan
description: In May 2017, China donated school supplies to the Hadong people in Kazakhstan. Ambassador Zhang Hanhui met with Anhusai, President of the Association of East Asian People in Kazakhstan in Astana. Through the association, China donated money and 500 sets of textbooks including 2,500 teaching books and 500 reading pens to the Hadong people. The books are meant to teach Chinese to schoolchildren.

title: China Eximbank provides a $253.3 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for 266 km Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (BRI) (Linked to Project ID#54991, #55016, and #54990)
description:
On May 15, 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China and KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) signed a $253.3 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the reconstruction of the 262 km Merke-Burylbaytal highway (also known as the Merke-Shu-Burylbaytal highway) (see loan value at "Об утверждении перечня инвестиционных проектов, предлагаемых..."; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"; see rest at "新兴集团承接的哈萨克斯坦两段公路改造项目贷款协议签约"). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The Government of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan (see "О внесении изменения в постановление Правительства..."). 

The total project cost was approximately $297 million USD; co-financiers are unknown (see "新兴集团承接的哈萨克斯坦两段公路改造项目贷款协议签约"). The reconstruction of the Merke-Burylbaytal highway was divided into 4 sections totaling 262 km in the Jambyl Region of Kazakhstan. The road section from Merke to Shu, 86 km long, was to be for four-lane traffic. The remaining 3 sections from the town of Shu to the village of Burybaytal,176 km long in total, was to be for two-lane traffic. The highway was to pass through the settlements of Tatti, Shu, and Birlik. The project included the construction of six bridges, three overpasses over rail lines, 11 illuminated traffic intersections, 276 culverts, recreation areas, and auto pavilions. The project was expected to be completed in June 2022 (see "В Жамбылской области началась реализация..."). China XinXing Construction Development Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The groundbreaking ceremony was held on March 26, 2019 (see "新兴建设承建的哈萨克斯坦MB266国家级公路改造项目举行开工典礼").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#55016), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by this project), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#54991) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

STAFF_NOTE: The official Chinese project name for the road is 梅尔克-布鲁拜塔尔公路改造. The Russian project title is Реконструкция автомобильной дороги республиканско-го значения «Мерке –Бурылбайтал» км 7-273. This project and Kalbatau-Maykapshagai Road Project's combined cost was $808 million USD. Kalbatau-Maykapshagai Road Project's individual cost of $511 million USD was known. Therefore, to calculate the cost of this project, AidData substracted $511 million USD from $808 million USD and got $297 million USD.
name: Merkenskiy

title: China Eximbank provides a $253.3 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for 266 km Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (BRI) (Linked to Project ID#54991, #55016, and #54990)
description:
On May 15, 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China and KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) signed a $253.3 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the reconstruction of the 262 km Merke-Burylbaytal highway (also known as the Merke-Shu-Burylbaytal highway) (see loan value at "Об утверждении перечня инвестиционных проектов, предлагаемых..."; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"; see rest at "新兴集团承接的哈萨克斯坦两段公路改造项目贷款协议签约"). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The Government of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan (see "О внесении изменения в постановление Правительства..."). 

The total project cost was approximately $297 million USD; co-financiers are unknown (see "新兴集团承接的哈萨克斯坦两段公路改造项目贷款协议签约"). The reconstruction of the Merke-Burylbaytal highway was divided into 4 sections totaling 262 km in the Jambyl Region of Kazakhstan. The road section from Merke to Shu, 86 km long, was to be for four-lane traffic. The remaining 3 sections from the town of Shu to the village of Burybaytal,176 km long in total, was to be for two-lane traffic. The highway was to pass through the settlements of Tatti, Shu, and Birlik. The project included the construction of six bridges, three overpasses over rail lines, 11 illuminated traffic intersections, 276 culverts, recreation areas, and auto pavilions. The project was expected to be completed in June 2022 (see "В Жамбылской области началась реализация..."). China XinXing Construction Development Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The groundbreaking ceremony was held on March 26, 2019 (see "新兴建设承建的哈萨克斯坦MB266国家级公路改造项目举行开工典礼").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#55016), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by this project), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#54991) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

STAFF_NOTE: The official Chinese project name for the road is 梅尔克-布鲁拜塔尔公路改造. The Russian project title is Реконструкция автомобильной дороги республиканско-го значения «Мерке –Бурылбайтал» км 7-273. This project and Kalbatau-Maykapshagai Road Project's combined cost was $808 million USD. Kalbatau-Maykapshagai Road Project's individual cost of $511 million USD was known. Therefore, to calculate the cost of this project, AidData substracted $511 million USD from $808 million USD and got $297 million USD.
name: Moyynkumskiy
