name: Shuskiy

title: China Development Bank provides a $100 million USD loan to Chem-Plus LLP for the production of caustic soda in the Chemical Park Taraz Special Economic Zone
description:
In June 2017, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $100 million loan agreement with Chem-Plus LLP to finance the production of caustic soda. The loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 10 years and an interest of 4.7% per annum (pg.27 of "ГОДОВОЙ ОТЧЕТ 2017 год"). The project had a total cost of ₸47.6 billion KZT (approximately $142.8 million USD in 2017); thus, this project was co-financed (see "Айдын Рахимбаев возглавил ренкинг крупнейших получателей господряда в Казахстане").

The project was located in Chemical Park Taraz Special Economic Zone in the Shu District of the Jambyl Region (see "Astana hosts fourth meeting of Kazakhstan-China Business Council"). The project sought to construct a caustic soda line at the Formulation Complex, intended for the production and sale of plant protection products (herbicides) for the Kazakhstani market (see "Actual projects - Chem-Plus LLP"). It was to be capable of producing 40,000 tons. The commissioning was planned for 2020. Construction had begun by 2017, but it had been suspended until a decision was made on the further implementation of the project's fourth start-up glyphosate complex (pg.34 of "ГОДОВОЙ ОТЧЕТ 2017 год").

A consortium led by Kazakhstani company Construction Corporation Kulager LLP was awarded the engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contract for the project on November 20, 2017 (see pg.19 of "Chem-plus LLP Financial statements For the year ended 31 December 2018 together with independent auditor's report"). In addition to Kulager LLP, the consortium featured German company Chemieanlagenbau Chemnitz GmbH, Kazakhstani company Promstroyproekt Design Institute LLP and Kazakhstani company Aral Service LLP (pg.8 of "ГОДОВОЙ ОТЧЕТ 2017 год"). The construction was on-going as of December 31, 2018 (see pg.16 of "Chem-plus LLP Financial statements For the year ended 31 December 2018 together with independent auditor's report"). The complex was commissioned in January 2019, but it appears that the caustic soda line had not gone into production (see "Actual projects - Chem-Plus LLP").

The shareholders of Chem-Plus LLP were Kazakh state-owned enterprises: United Chemical Company LLP (99.87% ownership stake) and Samruk-Kaazyna Invest LLP (.13% ownership stake) (see pg.14 of "ГОДОВОЙ ОТЧЕТ 2017 год").

STAFF_NOTE: Chem-Plus LLP is sometimes also called "KHIM-Plus" LLP or ТОО «ХИМ-плюс». Chem-Plus refers to this project in Russian as «Производство каустической соды и хлора» or Проект «Производство каустической соды».
name: Shuskiy

title: ICBC arranges a $1.5 billion USD syndicated loan to Samruk-Kazyna for the acquisition of a 50% stake in KMG Kashagan B.V. (Linked to Project ID#73437)
description:
In 2015, National Welfare Fund Samruk-Kazyna JSC signed a $1.5 billion USD syndicated term loan facility to partially finance the purchase of 50% of the shares of KMG Kashagan B.V. The Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) was one of the mandated lead arrangers. The loan captured a maturity period of five years (see "Samruk-Kazyna and ICBC agree to extend loan term on KMG Kashagan B.V. project"). On October 16, 2015, Samruk-Kazyna purchased 50% of the shares in KMG Kashagan B.V. from Coöperatieve KazMunaiGaz U.A for $4.7 billion USD; thus, this project was co-financed (pg.62 "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus"). In June 2018, Samruk-Kazyna and ICBC agreed to extend the the loan term to 2022 (thereby increasing the maturity period to seven years) and to reduce the interest rate (see "Samruk-Kazyna and ICBC agree to extend loan term on KMG Kashagan B.V. project"). This initial loan is captured by this project.

In July 2018, Samruk-Kazyna repaid $900 million USD of the $1.5 billion USD syndicated loan early. The remaining $600 million USD was refinanced by a new syndicated loan coordinated by Japanese bank MUFG Bank, Ltd. The Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Almaty) JSC (ICBC Almaty) participated in this syndicated loan alongside Mizuho Bank, Ltd., Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation, JSC “Halyk Savings Bank of Kazakhstan”, and Citibank Kazakhstan. The maturity date of this loan was extended until the end of 2022 (for a maturity period of seven years) because of the postponement of the option agreement for the repurchase of shares of KMG Kashagan B.V. by KazMunayGas (see "Samruk-Kazyna and KazMunayGaz repaid 2.5 billion U.S. loans ahead of schedule"). ICBC Almaty's participation in this loan refinancing is captured by linked project ID#73437.

STAFF_NOTE: AidData has not coded a transaction amount to avoid capturing any potential non-Chinese financial flows because the members of this syndicated loan beyond ICBC is unknown.
name: Tselinogradskiy

title: China National Petroleum Corporation provides $95.08 million USD for the construction of the Kazakh National Academy of Choreography
description:
On December 4, 2013, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) signed a memorandum with the Kazakhstani Ministry of Education and Science for the establishment of the Kazakh National Academy of Choreography in Astana (see "乐玉成大使出席哈萨克斯坦教育和科学部长与各国驻哈使节座谈会"). CNPC provided funds for the academy at the request of President of Kazakhstan Nursultan Nazarbayev as a gift for the 25th anniversary of Kazakhstan's independence (see "Kazakhstan opens Central Asia's first graduate dance school"). CNPC provided $95.08 million USD for the academy (pg.66 of "2016 China National Petroleum Corporation Corporate Social Responsibility Report"). The construction of the academy had a total cost of $153 million USD; Kazakhstani-state owned National Welfare Fund Samruk-Kazyna JSC provided the remaining $58 million USD (see "Oil major puts dance in spotlight").

Some of the funds provided by CNPC were used on the construction of the main stage of the Astana Ballet Theater, which included a 783-seat auditorium and a modern and innovative lighting system for performance. The academy consisted of a school building, an office building, a residential building, and the Astana Ballet Theater (see "Oil major puts dance in spotlight"). The educational building had classrooms, a teachers’ room, an indoor garden, a cafeteria, a library, a sports hall, and other rooms. There were 21 rehearsal rooms. The residential building consisted  of dormitories and rent-free staff apartments (see "Kazakhstan opens Central Asia's first graduate dance school"). The academy had an area of 9.5 hectares (see "Благотворительность").

The academy was the first institution of higher education in Central Asia to have a full cycle of choreographic education (see "Kazakh National Academy of Choreography"). The academy was designated as a national institution of higher education. It had programs ranging from the basics of dance and ballet training to master’s and doctoral programs (see "Kazakh National Academy of Choreography Opens in Astana"). The academy taught classical ballet, traditional Kazakh dance, and modern dance. Once the students were enrolled, the Government of Kazakhstan would cover all expenses (see "Oil major puts dance in spotlight").

Kazakhstani construction company Bazis-A was responsible for project implementation (see "KAZAKH NATIONAL CHOREOGRAPHY ACADEMY BUILT AT EXPENSE OF EXTRA-BUDGETARY FUNDS"). Swedish company Gustafs Scandinavia AB and Russian firm Eurostroysoyuz provided materials and designs for the interior of the theatre (see "Kazakh National Academy of Choreography"). Construction had begun by June 2014, and the school was expected to be open in April 2016 (see "National Academy of Choreography to Open in 2016 in EXPO Complex"). President Nazarbayev opened the academy on August 31, 2016 (see "Kazakhstan opens Central Asia's first graduate dance school").

CNPC later donated ₸10 million KZT ($27,117 USD) in 2018 to help finance the academy's purchase medical rehabilitation facilities (see "Oil major puts dance in spotlight").

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese name of the academy is 哈萨克斯坦国家舞蹈学院. A Chinese project title (using an alternative version of the school name) is 阿斯塔纳兴建国立舞蹈学院的工作. The Chinese name of the agreement signed in December 2013 was《关于在阿斯塔纳建设民族舞蹈与芭蕾舞学院的备忘录》. There are many alternative names for the academy in English. They include the National Academy of Dance, the High School of Choreography, the Higher School of National Dance and Ballet, the Astana National Dance Academy, and the National Dance Academy of Kazakhstan.

No source used the phrase "donated" or "granted" to describe CNPC's contribution, instead they used "provided" or "invested"; however, concerning the nature of this project, the flow type was clearly a grant and was coded as such. "Year uncertain" box was checked because the memorandum signed in December 2013 may have been a memorandum of understanding, and therefore not a complete commitment. 2013 remained the commitment year in the absence of another instance of an agreement made in a different year.

The Kazakh National Academy of Choreography was located in Astana (now Nur-Sultan). More detailed locational information can be found at: https://balletacademy.edu.kz/en/home-en/.
name: Tselinogradskiy

title: China completes Confucius Institute at Eurasian National University
description:
In July 2005, the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan Nursultan Nazarbayev when meeting with Chairman Hu Jintao proposed intentions to establish Confucius Institute in Kazakhstan. On December 20, 2006, Hanban and Eurasian national university from Kazakhstan signed a cooperation agreement to establish a Confucius Institute with Xi'an International Studies University become Chinese side’s executive body. In August 2007, Xi'an International Studies University and Eurasian National University signed "Implementation Agreement" of cooperation in the establishment of Confucius Institute and set up a board of directors of Confucius Institute at Eurasian National University.
December 5th, 2007, Confucius Institute at the Eurasian National University held the opening ceremony. Minister of Education and Science of the Republic of Kazakhstan Zhanseit Tuimebayev, Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the People’s Republic of China in Kazakhstan Zhang Xiyun and representatives of the governments of Kazakhstan and China attended opening ceremony and made a speech. Tuimebaev said, with becoming closer in the political, economic, cultural and other areas of cooperation with China, Kazakhstan will need more and more well-trained Chinese language personnel. Confucius Institute established in Kazakhstan will make a great contribution promoting bilateral cooperation in various fields.
name: Tselinogradskiy

title: CDB provides a $73 million USD syndicated loan to refinance JSC Lokomotiv's loan
description: In 2014, a group of banks, including HSBC Bank and China Development Bank (CDB) provided a $73 million USD syndicated loan to Joint Stock Company (JSC) Lokomotiv to refinance a loan that was previously obtained for the acquisition of 22 electric locomotives. STAFF_NOTE: Because the specific breakdown of this loan syndicate is unknown and it included a non-Chinese institution, the transaction amount has been left blank to avoid capturing non-Chinese financial flows.
name: Tselinogradskiy

title: Bank of China provides a $49.2 million loan to Kazakhtelecom to purchase Huawei equipment
description:
On April 15, 2009, Kazakhtelecom JSC, Kazakhstan's largest fixed-line telecommunication operator, which is 51% owned by Kazakhstani state-owned National Welfare Fund Samruk-Kazyna, the Bank of China (BOC), and Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. signed tripartite mutual understanding memorandum for the financing of telecommunication development projects in Kazakhstan (see "Kazakhtelecom (Kazakhstan), Bank of China and Huawei Technologies sign three-side memo"). Then, in 2011, BOC loaned Kazakhtelecom $49.2 million USD to purchase Huawei equipment (see pg.12 of "Results as of 2011 and 1Q 2012"). Per the loan agreement, BOC transferred the loan proceeds of directly to Huawei (see pg.49 of "Kazakhtelecom 2011 Annual Report"). Loan details are unknown.

STAFF_NOTE: "Project status" was set to "Completion" because it appears that the entirety of the funds were disbursed. Some sources claim this was a $25.6 million USD in the first half of 2011 (for example, pg.12 of "Результаты за 1 полугодие 2011 года"); in all likelihood, this was the first tranche of this larger loan. Kazakhtelecom reported the loan as ₸7,236,607,00 KZT ($49,344,629.18 in USD-2011 terms), but this transaction amount was not used because official sources reported a USD amount and it is highly unlikely that BOC would directly transfer funds denominated in KZT to Huawei (see this loan amount at pg.49 of "Kazakhtelecom 2011 Annual Report").
name: Tselinogradskiy

title: China Eximbank provides a $183.95 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for 33 km Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (BRI) (Linked to Project ID#54989, #54990, and #55016)
description:
On May 15, 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China and KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) signed a $183.95 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the 33 km Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (also called the 33 km Astana Ring Road Project, the Southwest Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project, or the XH33 Project) (see loan value at "Об утверждении перечня инвестиционных проектов, предлагаемых..."; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"; see rest at "新兴集团承接的哈萨克斯坦两段公路改造项目贷款协议签约"). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The Government of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan (see "О внесении изменения в постановление Правительства...").

China XinXing Construction Development Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation (see "新兴集团承接的哈萨克斯坦两段公路改造项目贷款协议签约"). The project sought to construct the 33 km long southwest bypass of Astana, giving it an asphalt and concrete surface of category I (see pg.38 of "Logistics and Transport Competitiveness in Kazakhstan"). Once completed, the road would allow freight vehicles to travel around the city, reducing urban traffic and enabling the development of of logistics centers and service facilities along the ring road. Construction began in December 2017 and the road was expected to be fully operational by 2019 (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"). The construction was suspended for a month due to the COVID-19 pandemic; it restarted in May 2020, with an expected handover dating now falling in August 2020 (see "Feature: Ring road construction resumes as Kazakh capital partially reopens").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#55016), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (captured by this project) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

This project supported the construction of a 33 km southwest section of the ring road (bypass road) around the city of Astana -- from the road to the airport to the M36 highway. Further locational details are provided at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/astana-southwest-bypass-road-construction/38a208f4-305f-4a0c-891b-4ab678753cdd/ and page 38 of http://www.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/trans/publications/Report_-_Kazakhstan_as_a_transport_logistics_centre_Europe-Asia.pdf.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 努尔苏丹市西南环城公路. The Kazakh project title is «Астана қаласының айналма жолы». The Russian project title is Строительство автомобильной дороги Юго-Западный обход города Астаны.
name: Tselinogradskiy

title: CDB and Bank of China provide a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan for Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#40362 and #73384)
description:
On January 18, 2011, a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) called Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP (BSGP) was established in Kazakhstan to oversee the financing, design, and implementation of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project. JSC KazTransGas (KTG) and China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) (acting through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) each held a 50% ownership stake in BSGP (see JV formation date at “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”; see rest at pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

The Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline was a 1454 km long gas pipeline that running through the Mangistau, Aktyubinsk, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. It has a pipe diameter of 1067 mm (see “Beineu-Bozoy-Shymkent gas pipeline is the largest pipeline project...” and pg.149 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The purpose of the project was to ensure stable gas demand in the southern Kazakhstan, reduce dependence on imported gas and ensure the energy security of Kazakhstan. Construction of the pipeline was split into two phases (see “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”).

The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved the construction of 1,143.2 km of pipeline from the Bozoi gas metering station in the Shalkar region of Aktobe Region to Akbulak gas metering station in Sairam of South Kazakhstan Region (now known as the Turkistan Region). It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-1 and Bozoy shift camp in Shalkar region of Aktobe Region, emergency-response centers in Saksaulsk, Aksuat and Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region and an emergency-response center in Shornak within the South Kazakhstan Region, as well as construction of the automated process control system (SCADA) and telecommunication (fiber-optic communication line) for the gas pipeline in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project was initiated on July 17, 2012 (see pg.29 of "JSC NC "KazMunayGas" Annual Report 2013"). The project was expected to be completed by the end of 2012 (see "China and Kazakhstan begin construction of the second stage of the gas pipeline"). It was completed on September 7, 2013, resulting in a throughput capacity of up to 10 bcm per year (see "First section of China-Kazakstan gas pipeline II starts operation").

The second phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved 306.3 km of gas pipeline construction from Beineu settlement in the Mangystau Region to Bozoi settlement in the Aktobe Region. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-4 Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region, Beineu gas metering station in Mangystau Region, the SCADA central dispatch control in Kyzylorda, and gas pipeline construction in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). It was completed on December 30, 2016 (see "PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES").

Between 2014 and 2017, over 9.0 bcm of gas was transported via the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent gas pipeline, providing the southern regions with Kazakhstani gas. Then, in November 2017, a head compressor station at Bozoi and a line compressor station at Karaozek were put into operation, increasing the capacity of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline to 10 bcm per year. In October 2017, Kazakhstan began exporting gas to China pursuant to a contract concluded between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina for the supply of bcm from October 15, 2017 until October 14, 2018. The price of the gas exported to China pursuant to this agreement was linked to the price of Brent crude oil and determined quarterly. As of December 31, 2017, negotiations were ongoing with respect to a long-term gas supply agreement between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina. BSGP and KazMunayGas expected that the export of gas to China would increase in the future and made plans to construct three new compressor stations on the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline between 2018 and 2019 to handle this (see pg.151-152 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In order to fund Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) on December 11, 2012 (captured by this project). This loan bears interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 2.7% margin per annum for the duration of the guarantee period (until December 31, 2019) and, thereafter, at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 3.2% margin per annum. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in December 2017 until March 11, 2028 (implying a grace period of 5 years and a maturity period of 15.25 years). The loan was secured by corporate guarantees from KazMunayGas and CNPC. Unspecified amendments to the facility were made in February 2016 (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus" and pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In February 2016 and September 2017, amendments were signed because of BSGP's non-compliance with certain project milestones provided for in the facility agreement; the milestones were extended until September 30, 2019. These amendments required BSGP's prepayment of $400 million USD of the outstanding indebtedness, which KazMunayGas provided to BSGP for repayment. The loan was secured by additional security, including an offshore account charge, an onshore account pledge and security assignment of BSGP's rights under the shareholder support agreement in favor of the security agent. As of June 30, 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under the loan was $1.462 billion USD (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus"). As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1.0 billion USD (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

Then, on September 17, 2015, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $700 million USD syndicated loan with CDB and BOC for Phase II of the project to supplement their $1.8 billion USD loan. CDB and BOC each reportedly contributed $350 million USD. This loan reportedly carries a maturity period of 15 years; the maturity date was September 17, 2030. The interest rate of the loan is unknown (see “Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Phase2 Additional Financing”). For the BOC contribution, see linked project ID#73384; for the CDB contribution, see linked project ID#40362.

STAFF_NOTE: The 3-month LIBOR rate in December 2012 was 0.309%. The interest rate, therefore, was coded as 0.309% + 2.7%, or 3.009%.

This 1,454 km pipeline runs through the Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.dropbox.com/s/8j082veud49pzvb/_i%20class%3D_fa%20fa-map%20fa-lg____i_%20Pipeline%20map%20%E2%80%93%20Beineu%20Shymkent.pdf?dl=0 and https://bsgp.kz/en_US/%d0%ba%d0%b0%d1%80%d1%82%d0%b0-%d0%b3%d0%b0%d0%b7%d0%be%d0%bf%d1%80%d0%be%d0%b2%d0%be%d0%b4%d0%b0/ and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/
name: Aqtöbe

title: CNPC AktobeMunaiGas donates sports equipment to the children of the Aktobe Seagull Children Recovery Center
description: On International Children's Day, June 1, 2006, at the Aktobe Seagull Children Recovery Center, employees of CNPC AktobeMunaiGas (CNPC AMG), a Kazakhstan-based subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, presented gifts to the children at the center. The children suffered from chronic diseases and were at the center for long-time isolated treatment. The gifts provided to them included soccer balls, basketballs, and badminton rackets (see pg.41 of 'CNPC in Kazakhstan Sustainability Report 2008'). STAFF_NOTE: While there are several children's rehabilitation centers in the Aktobe Region, there does not appear to be one that goes by the name Aktobe Seagull Children Recovery Center, which may be due to translation issues. AidData has chosen the Aktobe regional government as the recipient in light of this.
name: Aqtöbe

title: CDB provides $350 million USD via a $700 million USD syndicated loan for Phase II of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project (Additional Financing) (Linked to Project ID#39562 and #73384)
description:
On January 18, 2011, a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) called Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP (BSGP) was established in Kazakhstan to oversee the financing, design, and implementation of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project. Construction of the pipeline was split into two phases (see “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”).

The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved the construction of 1,143.2 km of pipeline from the Bozoi gas metering station in the Shalkar region of Aktobe Region to Akbulak gas metering station in Sairam of South Kazakhstan Region (now known as the Turkistan Region). The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project was initiated on July 17, 2012 (see pg.29 of "JSC NC "KazMunayGas" Annual Report 2013"). The project was expected to be completed by the end of 2012 (see "China and Kazakhstan begin construction of the second stage of the gas pipeline"). It was completed on September 7, 2013, resulting in a throughput capacity of up to 10 bcm per year (see "First section of China-Kazakstan gas pipeline II starts operation").

The second phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved 306.3 km of gas pipeline construction from Beineu settlement in the Mangystau Region to Bozoi settlement in the Aktobe Region. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-4 Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region, Beineu gas metering station in Mangystau Region, the SCADA central dispatch control in Kyzylorda, and gas pipeline construction in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). It was completed on December 30, 2016 (see "PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES").

Between 2014 and 2017, over 9.0 bcm of gas was transported via the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent gas pipeline, providing the southern regions with Kazakhstani gas. Then, in November 2017, a head compressor station at Bozoi and a line compressor station at Karaozek were put into operation, increasing the capacity of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline to 10 bcm per year. In October 2017, Kazakhstan began exporting gas to China pursuant to a contract concluded between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina for the supply of bcm from October 15, 2017 until October 14, 2018. The price of the gas exported to China pursuant to this agreement was linked to the price of Brent crude oil and determined quarterly. As of December 31, 2017, negotiations were ongoing with respect to a long-term gas supply agreement between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina. BSGP and KazMunayGas expected that the export of gas to China would increase in the future and made plans to construct three new compressor stations on the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline between 2018 and 2019 to handle this (see pg.151-152 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In order to fund Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) on December 11, 2012 (see linked project ID#39562). This loan bears interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 2.7% margin per annum for the duration of the guarantee period (until December 31, 2019) and, thereafter, at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 3.2% margin per annum. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in December 2017 until March 11, 2028 implying a grace period of 5 years and a maturity period of 15.25 years). The loan was secured by corporate guarantees from KazMunayGas and CNPC. Unspecified amendments to the facility were made in February 2016 (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus" and pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In February 2016 and September 2017, amendments were signed because of BSGP's non-compliance with certain project milestones provided for in the facility agreement; the milestones were extended until September 30, 2019. These amendments required BSGP's prepayment of $400 million USD of the outstanding indebtedness, which KazMunayGas provided to BSGP for repayment. The loan was secured by additional security, including an offshore account charge, an onshore account pledge and security assignment of BSGP's rights under the shareholder support agreement in favor of the security agent. As of June 30, 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under the loan was $1.462 billion USD (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus"). As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1 billion USD (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

Then, on September 17, 2015, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $700 million USD syndicated loan with CDB and BOC for Phase II of the project to supplement their $1.8 billion USD loan. CDB and BOC each contributed $350 million USD. This loan reportedly carries a maturity period of 15 years; the maturity date was September 17, 2030. The interest rate of the loan is unknown (see “Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Phase2 Additional Financing”). This project captures the CDB contribution; for the BOC contribution, see linked project ID#73384.

This 1,454 km pipeline runs through the Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.dropbox.com/s/8j082veud49pzvb/_i%20class%3D_fa%20fa-map%20fa-lg____i_%20Pipeline%20map%20%E2%80%93%20Beineu%20Shymkent.pdf?dl=0 and https://bsgp.kz/en_US/%d0%ba%d0%b0%d1%80%d1%82%d0%b0-%d0%b3%d0%b0%d0%b7%d0%be%d0%bf%d1%80%d0%be%d0%b2%d0%be%d0%b4%d0%b0/ and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/

title: ICBC participates in a $1.18 billion USD loan facility for the 794 km Kenkiyak-Kumkol Section of the Kazakhstan-China Oil Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#39605 and #54523)
description:
On August 12, 2008, Chinese-Kazakh joint venture Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP entered into a $1.18 billion USD credit facility with the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited (ICBC) and the ING Bank N.V. for a term of ten years, subject to extension for up to five additional years. This credit facility was entered into for the purpose of financing the construction of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. KCP had the right to draw down the loan in four tranches. It drew down three in 2008 in an aggregate principal amount of $1 billion USD. The availability period of this credit facility expired at the end of 2011. The borrowed funds bore an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 2% margin per annum until February 2013 and 6-month LIBOR + a 4% margin per annum thereafter. CNPC provided a guarantee from the loan. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this facility was $403.9 million USD (including the capitalised interest) (₸134.3 billion KZT) (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). Based on the information above, the interest rate was recorded as 6-Month LIBOR in August 2008 (3.108%) + 2%, or 5.108%, while the maturity period is 10 years and the grace period is zero. 

JSC KazTransOil (KTO) and China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development Corporation (CNODC) formed a joint venture Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) called Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP (KCP) on July 6, 2004 (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP History"). KCP was created to construct and operate the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline and the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. These pipelines are two of three pipeline systems of the Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network, which was built to create a transport corridor for the export of Kazakhstani oil to China. KTO and CNODC each owned 50% of the joint venture (see pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). 

This project sought to the construct the Kenkiyak–Kumkol pipeline, which was intended to transport oil from West Kazakhstan and Aktobe oilfields. It began in Kenkiyak and ended in Kumkol. The pipeline was 794.263 km long and it had a maximum capacity of10 million tons a year. It included relay pump stations to increase the volume of oil transported (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline About"). The pipe had diameters ranging between 0.5 and 1.8 meters (see pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline passed through the Aktobe, Kyzylorda and Karaganda regions, with its oil destined for the Chinese market. JSC OGCC KazStroyService was responsible for the construction of the 483 km section from Kenkiyak to Aralsk, while China Petroleum Pipeline Engineering Co., Ltd. (CPPE) was responsible for the construction of a 311 km section to Kumkol. Construction of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline began on December 11, 2007 (see "Kenkiyak - Kumkol"). The pipeline went into operation on October 6, 2009 (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline").

As of 31 December 31, 2017, the pipeline had a throughput capacity of 9.2 million tonnes of crude oil per year. In 2017, 5.2 million tonnes of crude oil were transported through the pipeline. Pursuant to an agreement between the KTO and CNODC, the capacity of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline was increased from 10.0 million tonnes of crude oil per year to 20.0 million tonnes in
2015 so as to take advantage of expected increased production at Tengiz Field and Kashagan Field. Ten companies supply oil to the pipeline, which KCP has continued to own (pg.158 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

The Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network is comprised of three systems: (i) the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline, from Kenkiyak in western Kazakhstan to Atyrau on the Caspian Sea; (ii) the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China; and (iii) the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan. All three systems are operational (pg.249 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The Atasu-Alashankou pipeline project is captured by linked project ID#39605, while the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline is captured by linked project ID#54523.

STAFF_NOTE: As the loan financiers include a non-Chinese financier (ING Bank N.V.) and the breakdown of loan amounts between the 2 financiers are not known, a transaction amount has not been recorded for this project. This project is sometimes called “Second stage of Kazakhstan-China oil pipeline construction."

The 794 km Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline runs from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan and runs through three regions (Aktobe, Kyzylorda and Karaganda). A 483 km segment runs from the Kenkiyak station to the Aralsk area, and a 311 km segment to the Kumkol station. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.energycharter.org/fileadmin/DocumentsMedia/Presentations/CBP-KZ-CN.pdf and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/
name: Aqtöbe

title: CNPC AktobeMunaiGas donates computers to seconday schools in the Aktobe Region
description:
Before 2007, CNPC AktobeMunaiGas (CNPC AMG), a Kazakhstan-based subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, signed a memorandum of mutual cooperation with the Akimat of Aktobe region to donate personal computers to secondary schools in the Aktobe Region (see "Внешняя благотворительность"). CNPC AMG annually provided the computers to the schools (see "Стратегия компании: мировые стандарты и благотворительность"). As of May 2007, CNPC AMG had donated 400 computers (see "№ 16, 4 мая 2007 г."). The amount of donated computers later increased to 500 (see "Внешняя благотворительность").

STAFF_NOTE: It is unclear what year the memorandum was signed in; it was after 2000, the year when CNPC began signing memorandums with the Aktobe Akimat (see "Внешняя благотворительность"), and before 2007, because 400 computers had been donated by then (see "№ 16, 4 мая 2007 г.").
name: Aqtöbe
