title: Confucius Institute at Aktobe Regional State University
description: In 2011, a Confucius Institute was opened at Aktobe Jubanov National University in Kazakhstan.
name: Aqtobe

title: CNPC AktobeMunaiGas donates 57 ambulances to medical institutions in the Aktobe Region
description:
Since 2002, CNPC AktobeMunaiGas (CNPC AMG), a Kazakhstan-based subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, has purchased ambulances for medical institutions and hospitals in the Aktobe Region (see "№ 16, 4 мая 2007 г." and "Внешняя благотворительность"). By 2004, CNPC AMG had donated 24 ambulances (see "Seven Years of Honest Co-Operation"). By 2008, the company had donated 57 ambulances (see pg.41 of "CNPC in Kazakhstan Sustainability Report 2008"). By 2007, the company had donated 45 ambulances (see "№ 16, 4 мая 2007 г."). The ambulances were Russian-made (see "Внешняя благотворительность"). The value of the ambulances is unknown.

STAFF_NOTE: It is unclear when CNPC AMG agreed to donate ambulances; AidData has chosen 2002 because it is the earliest known year for the implementation of this project and checked "Year uncertain" to handle this. "Project status" was coded as "Completion" because the ambulances were clearly handed over.
name: Aqtobe

title: CNPC AktobeMunaiGas finances the construction of a museum and monument of Kazakhstani World War II veteran Aliya Moldagulova
description:
In 2004, CNPC AktobeMunaiGas (CNPC AMG), a Kazakhstan-based subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, financed the construction of a museum and a memorial monument to Kazakhstani national hero Aliya Moldagulova (see "Внешняя благотворительность"). Moldagulova was a female Soviet sniper born in the Aktobe Region killed in action in 1944 during World War II (see "Aliya Moldagulova Memorial Day marked in Aktobe"). The monument was reportedly a statue (see "中国石油中亚油气合作项目履行社会责任纪实").

STAFF_NOTE: "Project status" was coded as "Completion" because it appears that all Chinese funds were disbursed. Based on the details, AidData has assumed this was a donation and coded it as such. "Year uncertain" box was checked because it is not confirmed that this donation was committed to in 2004. Furthermore, one source, ("中国石油中亚油气合作项目履行社会责任纪实") names 2005 as the year of donation, while others name 2004. AidData has chosen the earlier year as the commitment year.
name: Aqtobe

title: CNPC AktobeMunaiGas provides ₸175 million KZT for the construction of the Nur-Gasyr Mosque
description:
In mid-2007, CNPC AktobeMunaiGas (CNPC AMG), a Kazakhstan-based subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, allocated funds for the construction of a new regional mosque in the city of Aktobe (see "Стратегия компании: мировые стандарты и благотворительность"). CNPC AMG provided ₸175 million KZT for the mosque (see "№ 16, 4 мая 2007 г."). The mosque, the Nur-Gasyr Mosque (Russian: Мечеть Нур Гасыр), was also financed by donations from numerous other organizations in Kazakhstan. Construction began in April 2006 and was completed on September 22, 2008 (see "Nur-Gasyr Mosque Book").

STAFF_NOTE: "Year uncertain" box was checked because it is not confirmed that this flow was committed to in 2007. While "donated" is not used to describe this flow, this was clearly a grant/donation and AidData has coded it accordingly.
name: Aqtobe

title: CNPC AktobeMunaiGas provides ₸159 million KZT to repair Aktobe airport road
description:
In 2006, CNPC AktobeMunaiGas (CNPC AMG), a Kazakhstan-based subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, provided ₸159 million KZT to repair the road from the Aktobe International Airport to the city of Aktobe. The repair was succesfully repaired (see "Внешняя благотворительность").

STAFF_NOTE: While the source does not explicitly say "grant" or "donate," this project is mentioned on a page about "External charity" and described the project as being financed "at the expense of [CNPC AMG]." In light of this, AidData has determined that this project was a grant and has coded it as such. "Year uncertain" box was checked because it is not confirmed that this project was committed to in 2016.
name: Aqtobe

title: CNPC AktobeMunaiGas provides $793,100 USD to build a monument and museum and hold a nationwide commemoration for Kazakhstani composer Akhmet Zhubanov
description:
In 2006, CNPC AktobeMunaiGas (CNPC AMG), a Kazakhstan-based subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation, provided $793,100 USD for the construction of a monument and museum and nationwide commemoration in honor of the Soviet-era Kazakhstani composer Akhmet Zhubanov (see pg.42 of "CNPC in Kazakhstan Sustainability Report 2008"). The commemorations also honored Kazakhstani agronomist Shyganak Bersiev (see "Стратегия компании: мировые стандарты и благотворительность").

STAFF_NOTE: Sources in Russian report that CNPC AMG spent ₸125 million KZT on this project, while CNPC sources in English and Chinese report the $793,100 USD figure. AidData has coded the latter as the transaction amount. "Year uncertain" box was checked because it is not confirmed that this flow was committed to in 2006. "Project status" was coded as "Completion" because it is clear that all Chinese financing was disbursed.
name: Aqtobe

title: Bank of China provides $350 million USD via a $700 million USD syndicated loan for Phase II of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project (Additional Financing) (Linked to Project ID#39562 and #40362)
description:
On January 18, 2011, a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) called Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP (BSGP) was established in Kazakhstan to oversee the financing, design, and implementation of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project. JSC KazTransGas (KTG) and China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) (acting through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) each held a 50% ownership stake in BSGP (see JV formation date at “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”; see rest at pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

The Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline  was a 1454 km long gas pipeline that running through the Mangistau, Aktyubinsk, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. It has a pipe diameter of 1067 mm (see “Beineu-Bozoy-Shymkent gas pipeline is the largest pipeline project...” and pg.149 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The purpose of the project was to ensure stable gas demand in the southern Kazakhstan, reduce dependence on imported gas and ensure the energy security of Kazakhstan. Construction of the pipeline was split into two phases (see “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”).

The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved the construction of 1,143.2 km of pipeline from the Bozoi gas metering station in the Shalkar region of Aktobe Region to Akbulak gas metering station in Sairam of South Kazakhstan Region (now known as the Turkistan Region). It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-1 and Bozoy shift camp in Shalkar region of Aktobe Region, emergency-response centers in Saksaulsk, Aksuat and Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region and an emergency-response center in Shornak within the South Kazakhstan Region, as well as construction of the automated process control system (SCADA) and telecommunication (fiber-optic communication line) for the gas pipeline in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project was initiated on July 17, 2012 (see pg.29 of "JSC NC "KazMunayGas" Annual Report 2013"). The project was expected to be completed by the end of 2012 (see "China and Kazakhstan begin construction of the second stage of the gas pipeline"). It was completed on September 7, 2013, resulting in a throughput capacity of up to 10 bcm per year (see "First section of China-Kazakstan gas pipeline II starts operation").

The second phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved 306.3 km of gas pipeline construction from Beineu settlement in the Mangystau Region to Bozoi settlement in the Aktobe Region. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-4 Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region, Beineu gas metering station in Mangystau Region, the SCADA central dispatch control in Kyzylorda, and gas pipeline construction in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). It was completed on December 30, 2016 (see "PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES").

Between 2014 and 2017, over 9.0 bcm of gas was transported via the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent gas pipeline, providing the southern regions with Kazakhstani gas. Then, in November 2017, a head compressor station at Bozoi and a line compressor station at Karaozek were put into operation, increasing the capacity of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline to 10 bcm per year. In October 2017, Kazakhstan began exporting gas to China pursuant to a contract concluded between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina for the supply of bcm from October 15, 2017 until October 14, 2018. The price of the gas exported to China pursuant to this agreement was linked to the price of Brent crude oil and determined quarterly. As of December 31, 2017, negotiations were ongoing with respect to a long-term gas supply agreement between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina. BSGP and KazMunayGas expected that the export of gas to China would increase in the future and made plans to construct three new compressor stations on the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline between 2018 and 2019 to handle this (see pg.151-152 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In order to fund Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) on December 11, 2012 (see linked project ID#39562). This loan bears interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 2.7% margin per annum for the duration of the guarantee period (until December 31, 2019) and, thereafter, at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 3.2% margin per annum. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in December 2017 until March 11, 2028 implying a grace period of 5 years and a maturity period of 15.25 years).  The loan was secured by corporate guarantees from KazMunayGas and CNPC. Unspecified amendments to the facility were made in February 2016 (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus" and pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In February 2016 and September 2017, amendments were signed because of BSGP's non-compliance with certain project milestones provided for in the facility agreement; the milestones were extended until September 30, 2019. These amendments required BSGP's prepayment of $400 million USD of the outstanding indebtedness, which KazMunayGas provided to BSGP for repayment. The loan was secured by additional security, including an offshore account charge, an onshore account pledge and security assignment of BSGP's rights under the shareholder support agreement in favor of the security agent. As of June 30, 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under the loan was $1.462 billion USD (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus"). As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1.0 billion USD (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

Then, on September 17, 2015, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $700 million USD syndicated loan with CDB and BOC for Phase II of the project to supplement their $1.8 billion USD loan. CDB and BOC each reportedly contributed $350 million USD. This loan reportedly carries a maturity period of 15 years; the maturity date was September 17, 2030. The interest rate of the loan is unknown (see “Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Phase2 Additional Financing”). This project captures the BOC contribution; for the CDB contribution, see linked project ID#40362.

This 1,454 km pipeline runs through the Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.dropbox.com/s/8j082veud49pzvb/_i%20class%3D_fa%20fa-map%20fa-lg____i_%20Pipeline%20map%20%E2%80%93%20Beineu%20Shymkent.pdf?dl=0 and https://bsgp.kz/en_US/%d0%ba%d0%b0%d1%80%d1%82%d0%b0-%d0%b3%d0%b0%d0%b7%d0%be%d0%bf%d1%80%d0%be%d0%b2%d0%be%d0%b4%d0%b0/ and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/
name: Bayganinskiy

title: China Development Bank provides a $2 billion USD loan for the Atyrau Petrochemical Complex Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#40266)
description:
In 2009, Kazakhstan Petrochemical Industries (KPI) LLP signed an Engineering, Procurement, and Construction (EPC) contract with Sinopec Engineering Co., Ltd. (through Sinopec Group subsidiary China Petroleum & Chemical Corporation) for the first stage of construction of Atyrau petrochemical project (see "哈萨克斯坦石油加工领域发展和炼厂改造情况" and "Sinopec to build gas chemicals plant in Kazakhstan"). On February 22, 2011, the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (DBK) entered into a $1.4 billion USD credit agreement with the Export-Import Bank of China to finance the construction of an integrated petrochemical project in the Atyrau Region of Kazakstan. However, as of 2017, no amounts had been drawn down under this credit agreement (see pg.67 of "Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017"). This was due to the mutual termination of the EPC contract between KPI and Sinopec in 2014 (see "Polypropylene plant will be built by the Chinese, but not by Sinopec Engineering"). Therefore, AidData has assumed that the China Eximbank loan was cancelled (since the proceeds of this loan were to be used to fund the EPC contract with Sinopec). For this cancelled loan, see linked project ID#40266.

Then on, December 2015, China National Chemical Engineering Corporation (CNCEC) signed a contract to construct an integrated gas-chemical complex in the Atyrau Region on a turnkey basis (see "Kazakhstan intends to continue construction of PP production in Atyrau..."). Then, on September 3, 2016, China Development Bank (Xinjiang Branch) (CDB) signed a $2 billion USD loan agreement with KPI for the construction of the complex (see "Atyrau Petrochemical Complex"). The loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 5.8%. National Welfare Fund Samruk-Kazyna JSC provided a guarantee for this loan on February 13, 2017. On November 24, 2017, CDB sent an advance payment of $409 million USD to CNCEC (see "Technopark phase"). The project had a total cost of $2.6 billion USD; the CDB bank covered the entire cost of the $1.795 billion USD EPC contract with CNCEC; the remainder of the financing of the project was provide by its organizers of the project; KPI and its ownership (see "Kazakhstan intends to continue construction of PP production in Atyrau...").

KPI was the project company (special purpose vehicle) responsible for the financing, design, and construction of the Atyrau Petrochemical Complex Construction Project. KPI was 99% owned by United Chemical Company LLP, a subsidiary of JSC Sovereign Wealth Fund Samruk-Kazyna; the remaining 1% of KPI LLP was owned by a private investor, "Firm Almex Plus” LLP (see "About company"). Almex reportedly had a 49% ownership in November 2017, but this was either incorrect, or an indication that it sold the majority of its shares to United Chemical Company LLP (see "Kazakhstan intends to continue construction of PP production in Atyrau...").

42 construction and installation companies were involved in the construction and installation work; 39 of which were Kazakhstani and 3 of which were foreign. The Kazakhstani companies included AtyrauNefteMash LLP, which produced the propane and propylene splitter, "Petropavlovsk Plant of Heavy Machine Building" JSC and Sewon-Vertex Heavy Industries received orders for the production of 35 units and heat exchangers with a total weight  (see "Қазақстандық компаниялар мұнай-химия зауытын салуға қатысады ма"). Imstalcon JSC participated in the manufacture of equipment for the project, while the Kazakh Institute of Oil and Gas JSC participated in the design of the complex (see "Integrated Gas Chemical Complex Construction Update"). Chicago Bridge & Iron Company (CB&I) received the PMC contract for project management (see "History of the company"). The project was transferred from Samruk-Kazyna to the trust management of JSC NC KazMunayGas (KMG) in June 2018 (see "Integrated Gas Chemical Complex Construction Update").

Upon completion, the petrochemical complex was expected to produce 500,000 tons of polypropylene per year and be the first integrated gas-chemical complex in Kazakhstan (see "White & Case Advises Kazakhstan Petrochemical Industries..."). The plant was expected to go online in 2020 (see "中国国家开发银行与哈萨克斯坦石油化学工业公司签署阿特劳天然气化工项目第一阶段建设融资协议"). On November 27, 2017, KPI sent a notice of the start of construction work to the general contractor (see "Technopark phase"). The message was received and work began on December 11, 2017 (see "CB&I Gets Go-ahead for Kazakhstan Petchem Project"). In October 2020, the project was 77% complete and expected to be complete in 2021 (see "Large petrochemical complex to be launched in western Kazakhstan in 2021").

STAFF_NOTE: This project is sometimes referred to as "Construction of the first integrated gas chemical complex in Atyrau oblast," "Construction of an integrated gas chemical complex in the Atyrau region - the first phase (polypropylene), or "Integrated Gas Chemical Complex (Phase I – polypropylene production)."

The complex is located in the National Industrial Petrochemical Technopark Special Economic Zone (see "Technopark phase"). The special economic zone is 33 km to the northeast of the city of Atyrau, and 8-9 km north to north of Karabatan (see "Kazakhstan Petrochemical Industries Inc. Ltd"). More detailed locational information can be found at http://www.wraconferences.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/10.10-Raushan-Samurzina-eng.pdf
name: Atyrau

title: China Development Bank provides a $409 million USD loan for Methanol and Ammonia Complex Project in National Industrial Petrochemical Technopark Special Economic Zone
description: On June 8, 2017, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $409 million USD loan agreement with the United Chemical Company LLP for the production of methanol and ammonia in the National Industrial Petrochemical Technopark Special Economic Zone (SEZ) in the Atyrau Region (see signing date at 'Kazakhstan-China Business Council starts in Kazakhstan'; see loan details at pg.84 of '13th National Report On the implementation of the Extractive Industries...'). United Chemical Company LLP was a subsidiary of JSC National Welfare Fund Samruk-Kazyna JSC (see 'History of Company'). This methanol and ammonia complex was located in the National Industrial Petrochemical Technopark Special Economic Zone (SEZ NIPT), which is 33 km to the northeast of the city of Atyrau, and 8-9 kilometers north of Karabatan. More detailed locational information can be found at http://www.wraconferences.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/10.10-Raushan-Samurzina-eng.pdf.
name: Atyrau

title: China Eximbank provides a $1.13 billion USD buyer’s credit loan for the KazMunayGas Atyrau Oil Refinery Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#54798 and #54797)
description:
On December 29, 2011, Atyrau Refinery LLP — a project company and subsidiary of Kazakh state-owned KazMunayGas — signed an EPC turnkey contract for the KazMunayGas Atyrau Refinery Project (also known as the Advanced Oil Refining Complex Construction Project and the Deeper Oil Conversion Complex Construction Project) with a consortium of contractors consisting of Sinopec Engineering Group (SEG), Marubeni Corporation, and JSC OGCC KazStroyService. SEG was the leader of the consortium; Marubeni Corporation participated in the logistics and procurement, as well as organizing financing from the Japan Bank for International Cooperation, while JSC OGCC KazStroyService participated in construction and local procurement under SEG's leadership (see "Implementation of the project 'Construction of a deep oil refining complex'").

Then, on June 6, 2012, Atyrau Refinery LLP entered into a $1,130,408,642 USD buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement (#BLA201201) with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Construction of Advanced Oil Refining Center at the Atyrau Refinery, as captured by this project (see "Deep oil refining complex"). The BCL bears interest at a rate of six-month LIBOR plus 4.1% per annum and matures on November 6, 2025 (see pg.109 of "2018 Base Prospectus"). China Export & Credit Insurance Corporation (Sinosure) provided $1.7 billion USD of buyer’s credit insurance (covering the loan loan principal and interest). The BCL received an official guarantee from the Government of Kazakhstan’s Ministry of Finance (see slide 161 of "Brief Summary/Kesimpulan Singkat Working Group on Oil, Gas and Coal"). JSC NC “KazMunayGas” also provided a guarantee for the loan. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1.1 million USD (see pg.109 of "2018 Base Prospectus").

Then, on October 15, 2012, the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (DBK) entered into a $199.5 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Construction of Advanced Oil Refining Center at the Atyrau Refinery, as captured by linked project ID#54798. The PBC's maturity date was October 15, 2025, and it carried an interest rate of 3% per annum. This loan agreement was amended on October 30, 2014; however, the terms of the revision are unknown. Nor is it clear if DBK on-lent the proceeds of the PBC loan to Atyrau Refinery LLP. As of June 30, 2017, the aggregate principal amount outstanding under the PBC loan was $179.5 million USD (see pg.67 of "Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017").

The total cost of the KazMunayGas Atyrau Refinery Project was $1,679,892,000.52 USD. It was also financed by a $251,983,878 USD loan dated on August 17, 2012 (№DBZI 241-E / 05-01) from the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC, a $297,500,000 USD loan dated August 8, 2012 from the Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC), and three loans dated July 27, 2012, November 13, 2012, and December 29, 2012 that collectively amounted to ₸20,790,000 KZT from JSC KazMunayGaz - Refining and Marketing. The loans also covered commissions for arranging loans and insurance premiums (see "Deep oil refining complex"). The loans from Eximbank, JBIC (which may have involved the Bank of Tokyo Mitsubishi UFJ, Ltd.), and DBK were all guaranteed by JSC NC “KazMunayGas” (see pg.108-109 of "2018 Base Prospectus").

Sinopec subsidiary Sinopec Luoyang Engineering Co., Ltd. was involved in the implementation of the project (see "哈国阿特劳石油深加工项目“交钥匙"). Atyrau Refinery is one of the largest refineries in Kazakhstan and in 2011 refined 100,000 bbl of crude oil every day (see "Awarded Contract for Atyrau Refinery Modernization Project Phase 3 in Kazakhstan").

The project sought to increase the productivity of Atyrau Refinery to 5.5 million tons per year and oil refining efficiency to 87%, gaining the yield of motor fuel up to 77%, corresponding to the international standards of Euro-4 and Euro-5 (see "Information on Atyrau Refinery LLP"). The project included the construction of 12 individual process units, a main facility with a catalytic cracking unit, designed for the conversion by delayed coking of the atmospheric distillation residues, heavy gas oil, vacuum gas oil and heavy gas oil into liquified petroleum gas, gasoline, and light cracking gas oil. The complex was set to include LPG desulfurization facilities, oligomerization, a naphtha hydro-treating unit, a gasoline and gas oil catalytic cracking unit, hydrogen production, isomerization units, etc. (see "Atyrau refinery LLP (AR)").

The project's groundbreaking ceremony was held on September 10, 2012 (see "哈萨克斯坦2012年石油工业发展简况"). It was expected that the implementation period would be 41 months (41 months from the groundbreaking ceremony is February 2016) and that construction would be completed in 2016 (see "Deep oil refining complex"). The turnkey project was formally handed over to the project owner on May 30, 2019 (see "哈国阿特劳石油深加工项目“交钥匙"").

STAFF_NOTE: The average 6-month LIBOR in June 2012 was 0.736%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as 0.736% + 4.1%, or 4.836%. The Chinese name of this project is 哈萨克斯坦阿特劳炼油厂石油项目. AidData suspects that the PBC captured by project ID#54798 partially financed DBK's earlier $251,983,878 USD loan dated on August 17, 2012 (№DBZI 241-E / 05-01); while the PBC came two months after this loan, DBK may have made that loan knowing that China Eximbank planned to contribute. If this is the case, it would explain how the project cost was reported as $1,679,892,000.52 USD despite the existence of this loan, which would have otherwise substantially increased the amount of financing. However, as stated earlier, it is unclear if this PBC was used to on-lend by DBK; this is merely informed speculation.

The $1.13 billion USD China Eximbank BCL to Atyrau Refinery LLP for the Deeper Oil Conversion Complex Construction Project is separate from the $884 million USD China Eximbank loan to Atyrau Refinery LLP for the Aromatic Hydrocarbons Complex Construction Project (see project ID#54066). It is very likely that the KazMunayGas Atyrau Oil Refinery Construction Project was funded through the $3.5 billion USD restricted portion of a China Eximbank Master Loan Facility (MLF) to the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC, as captured in project ID#54797.

This oil refining complex was located in Atyrau. Its exact locational coordinates can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/%D0%90%D1%82%D1%8B%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%83+%D0%BC%D2%B1%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%B9+%D3%A9%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%96%D1%80%D1%83+%D0%B7%D0%B0%D1%83%D1%8B%D1%82%D1%8B/@47.0735428,51.9255886,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x76a517422e249e73?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwibgdCYjZjpAhXzlHIEHXQjBZMQ_BIwCnoECBEQCg.
name: Atyrau

title: China Eximbank provides a $884 million USD loan for the Aromatic Hydrocarbons Complex Construction Project at the Atyrau Refinery via the restricted portion of a master loan facility with Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (Linked to Project ID#54797)
description:
On August 1, 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China entered into a master facility agreement with the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (DBK). China Eximbank permitted DBK to draw down up to $5 billion USD from a master facility agreement (MFA), which included an unrestricted $1.5 billion USD tranche and a restricted $3.5 billion USD tranche. The agreement was for a period of up to 15 years and it prohibited DBK from incurring indebtedness exceeding 25% of its assets or disposing of over 25% of its assets, in addition to a change of control clause favoring China Eximbank. The restricted portion of the MFA was for projects with a Chinese component, whereas the unrestricted portion was for DBK’s general purposes. The restricted portion of the China Eximbank MFA was aimed at the development of energy, transport and communication infrastructure and the funding of strategic projects in the metallurgy, chemical, and oil industries. The proceeds from this credit facility were also be used for investment projects of Kazakhstan companies, including the exporting of industrial output, services and equipment to China (see pg.57-58 of "DBK 2010 Base Prospectus").

Under the restricted portion of the China Eximbank MFA (as captured by linked project ID#54797), DBK entered into a $884 million USD individual credit agreement with China Eximbank on December 12, 2009. The maturity date of this individual credit agreement was July 21, 2023. Principal and interest under the agreement was to be paid semi-annually (see pg.67 of "Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017").

DBK then used these loan proceeds to on-lend to Atyrau Refinery LLP (a project company and special purpose vehicle responsible for the financing, design, and construction of the Aromatic Hydrocarbons Complex Construction Project at the Atyrau Refinery) as part of a larger $1.63 billion USD loan agreement. This loan agreement with Atyrau Refinery LLP, which is a subsidiary of KazMunayGas, was divided into a $691.4 million USD tranche with an interest rate rate an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR plus a 4.5% margin, a $40.4 million USD tranche with an interest rate of 7.72% per annum (payable in KZT), and a ₸58.536 million KZT tranche with an interest rate of 10.99% per annum (payable in KZT). DBK also offered a ₸26.401 million KZT credit line for the project, while Atyrau Refinery LLP contributed $66.63 million USD (see "Information on Atyrau Refinery LLP").

The purpose of the Aromatic Hydrocarbons Complex Construction Project was to construct an aromatic hydrocarbons complex at the Atyrau Refinery capable of producing benzol and paraxylene. It also sought to increase the plant's balanced capacity to 5 million tons per year and produce motor fuels that meet K3 environmental requirements. Sinopec Engineering was the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. JSC OGCC KazStroyService served as its subcontractor, while KazMunayGas was also a participant (see pg.16-17 of "Annual report of “KazMunayGas – Refinery and Marketing” Joint-Stock Company for 2014"). Construction was set to begin in January 2010 (see "Kazakhstan industry: China's Sinopec to finance hydrocarbons plant"). However, the construction of the complex began in October 2010 (see "Implementation of the project..."). It was completed on December 25, 2014 (see "The ceremony of the beginning of commissioning at a complex for production of aromatic hydrocarbons").

STAFF_NOTE: The DBK credit agreement with China Eximbank was revised three times (on December 19, 2013, May 8, 2014 and October 30, 2014); however, the terms of these revisions are unknown (see pg.67 of "Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017"). Also,China Eximbank provided a separate $1,130,408,642 USD buyer’s credit loan in 2012 to Atyrau Refinery LLP for a Deeper Oil Conversion Complex Project at the Atyrau Refinery (see project ID#39556).

This aromatic hydrocarbons complex is located in Atyrau. Its locational coordinates can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/%D0%90%D1%82%D1%8B%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%83+%D0%BC%D2%B1%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%B9+%D3%A9%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%96%D1%80%D1%83+%D0%B7%D0%B0%D1%83%D1%8B%D1%82%D1%8B/@47.0735428,51.9255886,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x76a517422e249e73?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwibgdCYjZjpAhXzlHIEHXQjBZMQ_BIwCnoECBEQCg.
name: Atyrau

title: China Eximbank provides a $199.5 million USD preferential buyer’s credit for the KazMunayGas Atyrau Refinery Project (Linked to Project ID#39556 and #54797))
description:
On December 29, 2011, Atyrau Refinery LLP  — a project company and subsidiary of Kazakh state-owned KazMunayGas — signed an EPC turnkey contract for the KazMunayGas Atyrau Refinery Project (also known as the Advanced Oil Refining Complex Construction Project and the Deeper Oil Conversion Complex Construction Project) with a consortium of contractors consisting of Sinopec Engineering Group (SEG), Marubeni Corporation, and JSC OGCC KazStroyService. SEG was the leader of the consortium; Marubeni Corporation participated in the logistics and procurement, as well as organizing financing from the Japan Bank for International Cooperation, while JSC OGCC KazStroyService participated in construction and local procurement under SEG's leadership (see "Implementation of the project "Construction of a deep oil refining complex").

Then, on June 6, 2012, Atyrau Refinery LLP entered into a $1,130,408,642 USD buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement (#BLA201201) with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Construction of Advanced Oil Refining Center at the Atyrau Refinery, as captured by linked project ID#39556 (see "Deep oil refining complex"). The BCL bears interest at a rate of six-month LIBOR plus 4.1% per annum and matures on November 6, 2025 (see pg.109 of "2018 Base Prospectus"). Sinosure provided $1.7 billion USD of buyer’s credit insurance (covering the loan loan principal and interest). The BCL received an official guarantee from the Government of Kazakhstan’s Ministry of Finance (see slide 161 of "Brief Summary/Kesimpulan Singkat Working Group on Oil, Gas and Coal"). JSC NC “KazMunayGas” also provided a guarantee for the loan. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1.1 million USD (see pg.109 of "2018 Base Prospectus").

Then, on October 15, 2012, the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (DBK) entered into a $199.5 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Construction of Advanced Oil Refining Center at the Atyrau Refinery, as captured by this project. The loan's maturity date was October 15, 2025, and it carried an interest rate of 3% per annum. This loan agreement was amended on October 30, 2014; however, the terms of the revision are unknown. Nor is it clear if DBK on-lent the proceeds of the PBC loan to Atyrau Refinery LLP. As of June 30, 2017, the aggregate principal amount outstanding under the PBC loan was $179.5 million USD (see pg.67 of "Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017").

The total cost of the KazMunayGas Atyrau Refinery Project was $1,679,892,000.52 USD. It was also financed by a $251,983,878 USD loan dated on August 17, 2012 (№DBZI 241-E / 05-01) from the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC, a $297,500,000 USD loan dated August 8, 2012 from the Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC), and three loans dated July 27, 2012, November 13, 2012, and December 29, 2012 that collectively amounted to ₸20,790,000 KZT from JSC KazMunayGaz - Refining and Marketing. The loans also covered commissions for arranging loans and insurance premiums (see "Deep oil refining complex"). The loans from Eximbank, JBIC (which may have involved the Bank of Tokyo Mitsubishi UFJ, Ltd.), and DBK were all guaranteed by JSC NC “KazMunayGas” (see pg.108-109 of "2018 Base Prospectus").

Sinopec subsidiary Sinopec Luoyang Engineering Co., Ltd. was involved in the implementation of the project (see "哈国阿特劳石油深加工项目“交钥匙"). Atyrau Refinery is one of the largest refineries in Kazakhstan and in 2011 refined 100,000 bbl of crude oil every day (see "Awarded Contract for Atyrau Refinery Modernization Project Phase 3 in Kazakhstan"). 

The project sought to increase the productivity of Atyrau Refinery to 5.5 million tons per year and oil refining efficiency to 87%, gaining the yield of motor fuel up to 77%, corresponding to the international standards of Euro-4 and Euro-5 (see "Information on Atyrau Refinery LLP"). The project included the construction of 12 individual process units, a main facility with a catalytic cracking unit, designed for the conversion by delayed coking of the atmospheric distillation residues, heavy gas oil, vacuum gas oil and heavy gas oil into liquified petroleum gas, gasoline, and light cracking gas oil. The complex was set to include LPG desulfurization facilities, oligomerization, a naphtha hydro-treating unit, a gasoline and gas oil catalytic cracking unit, hydrogen production, isomerization units, etc. (see "Atyrau refinery LLP (AR)").

The project's groundbreaking ceremony was held on September 10, 2012 (see "哈萨克斯坦2012年石油工业发展简况"). It was expected that the implementation period would be 41 months (41 months from the groundbreaking ceremony being February 2016) and that construction would be completed in 2016 (see "Deep oil refining complex"). The turnkey project was formally handed over to the project owner on May 30, 2019 (see "哈国阿特劳石油深加工项目“交钥匙").

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese name of this project is 哈萨克斯坦阿特劳炼油厂石油项目. AidData suspects that the PBC captured by this project partially financed DBK's earlier $251,983,878 USD loan dated on August 17, 2012 (№DBZI 241-E / 05-01); while the PBC came two months after this loan, DBK may have made that loan knowing China Eximbank planned to contribute. If this is the case, it would explain how the project cost was reported as $1,679,892,000.52 USD despite the existence of this loan, which would have otherwise substantially increased the amount of financing. However, as stated earlier, it is unclear if this PBC was used to on-lend by DBK; this is merely AidData's informed speculation.

The $1.13 billion USD China Eximbank BCL to Atyrau Refinery LLP for the Deeper Oil Conversion Complex Construction Project is separate from the $884 million USD China Eximbank loan to Atyrau Refinery LLP for the Aromatic Hydrocarbons Complex Construction Project (see project ID#54066). It is very likely that the KazMunayGas Atyrau Oil Refinery Construction Project was funded through the $3 billion USD restricted portion of a China Eximbank Master Loan Facility (MLF) to the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC, as captured in project ID#54797.

The oil refining complex was located in Atyrau. Its exact locational coordinates can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/%D0%90%D1%82%D1%8B%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%83+%D0%BC%D2%B1%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%B9+%D3%A9%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%96%D1%80%D1%83+%D0%B7%D0%B0%D1%83%D1%8B%D1%82%D1%8B/@47.0735428,51.9255886,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x76a517422e249e73?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwibgdCYjZjpAhXzlHIEHXQjBZMQ_BIwCnoECBEQCg.
name: Atyrau

title: China grants 396,000 USD in equipment for Kazakh Police
description: In 2007 the Chinese Ministry of Public Security provided aid worth 396,000 dollars to the Kazakh Ministry of Internal Affairs. The donation included equipment for Kazakh police.
name: East Kazakhstan

title: China Eximbank provides a $434.5 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for 415 km Kalbatau-Maykapshagai Road Project (BRI) (Linked to Project ID#54989, #54991, and #55016)
description:
On May 15, 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China and KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) signed a $434.5 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the reconstruction of the 415 km Kalbatau-Maykapshagai Road Project (see loan value at "Об утверждении перечня инвестиционных проектов, предлагаемых..."; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"; see signing date at "KazAvtoZhol Company signed a bilateral agreement..."). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The Government of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan (see "О внесении изменения в постановление Правительства...").

The total cost of this project was $511 million USD; co-financiers are unknown. China XinXing Construction Development Co., Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Work on the 415 km road from Kalbatau to Maykapshagai began in May 2019 and was expected to be completed in June 2022 (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by this project), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#55016), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54991) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 卡尔巴套-麦卡普沙盖公路改造. Another Chinese name is 卡尔巴套-麦卡普沙盖公路. The project is sometimes known as the "KM415 Project" in English.
name: Tarbagatayskiy

title: China Eximbank provides a $796 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for the Ceconstruction of the 763 km Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk Segment of the Almaty-Oskemen Road Project (Linked to Project ID#54989, #54990, and #54991)
description:
In May 2016, CITIC Construction Co., Ltd. signed a EPC agreement with KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) for the reconstruction of the 763 km Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk segment of the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project (see "Kazakh Reconstruction Project of State-owned Highways").

Then, in 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $796 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with JSC NC KazAvtoZhol for the Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk (763 km) Road Project (see loan value at "Постановление Правительства 204 17.04.2017..."; see year at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). On April 24, 2017, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan on behalf of KazAvtoZhol (see "Постановление Правительства 204 17.04.2017..."). The loan legally entered into force in June 2017 (see "Кредитное соглашение по реконструкции автодороги вступило в силу"). The total cost of the project was $936 million USD; co-financers are unknown (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

This project involved a reconstruction of a 763 km long segment of Kazakhstan's national highway network, stretching from Taldykorgan, capital of the Almaty Region, to Oskemen (formerly Ust-Kamenogorsk), the administrative center of the East Kazakhstan Region (see pg.46 of "CITIC Group Annual Report 2018"). The project sought to widen the carriageway by up to 9 meters, allowing the speed limit to be up to 120 km/h. In addition to CITIC Construction, Todini Central Asia LLP and JSC K-Dorstroy performed work on the project (see "Reconstruction Works on Taldykorgan – Kalbatau – Ust-Kamenogorsk Road km 615-1073 in Eastern-Kazakhstan Oblast"). On June 7, 2017, CITIC Construction accepted an order from the Government of Kazakhstan to commence work (see "CITIC Construction Sign Multiple Cooperation Documents with Kazakhstan"). The contract period was 54 months. Construction began in November 2017. As of the end of 2018, the project was 8% complete (see pg.46 of "CITIC Group Annual Report 2018"). The project was expected to be completed in May 2022 (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (captured by this project), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#54991) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

This is a 763 km road segment along the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project that runs from Taldykorgan to Kalbatau and then to Ust and Kamenogorsk. More locational information can be found at https://web.archive.org/web/20200219065153/http://www.aksuakimat.gov.kz/ru/zhkh_1111.

STAFF_NOTE: Note that Ust-Kamenogorsk is also referred to as Oskemen, and some reports have referred to this road as Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Öskemen. The Chinese official name for the project is 塔尔迪库尔干- 乌斯季卡缅诺戈尔斯克764 公里国家级公路改造项目. The Russian name of the project is проекту реконструкции автомобильной дороги республиканского значения Талдыкорган – Калбатал - Усть-Каменогорск км 287-1073; another Russian name is Реконструкция автомобильной дороги республиканского значения "Талдыкорган – Калбатау – Усть-Каменогорск" км 287-1073. The project is sometimes also referred to in English as the Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk (615-1073 km) Project. TKU Expressway is another alternative name in English.
name: Ulanskiy

The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 卡尔巴套-麦卡普沙盖公路改造. Another Chinese name is 卡尔巴套-麦卡普沙盖公路. The project is sometimes known as the "KM415 Project" in English.
name: Zharminskiy

title: China Eximbank provides a $796 million USD preferential buyer’s credit loan for the Ceconstruction of the 763 km Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk Segment of the Almaty-Oskemen Road Project (Linked to Project ID#54989, #54990, and #54991)
description:
In May 2016, CITIC Construction Co., Ltd. signed a EPC agreement with KazAvtoZhol National Company Joint Stock Company (JSC NC KazAvtoZhol) for the reconstruction of the 763 km Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk segment of the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project (see "Kazakh Reconstruction Project of State-owned Highways").

Then, in 2017, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $796 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with JSC NC KazAvtoZhol for the Taldykorgan-Ust-Kamenogorsk (763 km) Road Project (see loan value at "Постановление Правительства 204 17.04.2017..."; see year at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"; see PBC at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目"). This loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). On April 24, 2017, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Kazakhstan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan on behalf of KazAvtoZhol (see "Постановление Правительства 204 17.04.2017..."). The loan legally entered into force in June 2017 (see "Кредитное соглашение по реконструкции автодороги вступило в силу"). The total cost of the project was $936 million USD; co-financers are unknown (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

This project involved a reconstruction of a 763 km long segment of Kazakhstan's national highway network, stretching from Taldykorgan, capital of the Almaty Region, to Oskemen (formerly Ust-Kamenogorsk), the administrative center of the East Kazakhstan Region (see pg.46 of "CITIC Group Annual Report 2018"). The project sought to widen the carriageway by up to 9 meters, allowing the speed limit to be up to 120 km/h. In addition to CITIC Construction, Todini Central Asia LLP and JSC K-Dorstroy performed work on the project (see "Reconstruction Works on Taldykorgan – Kalbatau – Ust-Kamenogorsk Road km 615-1073 in Eastern-Kazakhstan Oblast"). On June 7, 2017, CITIC Construction accepted an order from the Government of Kazakhstan to commence work (see "CITIC Construction Sign Multiple Cooperation Documents with Kazakhstan"). The contract period was 54 months. Construction began in November 2017. As of the end of 2018, the project was 8% complete (see pg.46 of "CITIC Group Annual Report 2018"). The project was expected to be completed in May 2022 (see "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目").

In 2017, JSC NC KazAvtoZhol signed 4 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements with China Eximbank in 2017 worth $1,667,577,000 USD to support 4 road reconstruction projects: the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54990), the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project (captured by this project), the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project (captured by linked project ID#54989), and the Astana Bypass Road Reconstruction Project (see linked project ID#54991) (see that the loans were PBCs at "哈萨克斯坦总理马明视察中国企业承建公路项目": see rest at pg.14 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018"). The projects had the following contributions from Eximbank: $434.5 million USD for the Kalbatau–Maikapshagai Road Reconstruction Project, $796 million USD for the Taldy-Korgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk Road Reconstruction Project, $253.3 million USD for the Merke-Burylbaital Highway Reconstruction Project, and $183.95 million USD for Astana Bypass Road. The sum of these 4 loans is $1,667,750,000 USD, which is very close to $1,667,577,000 USD figure provided by JSC NC KazAvtoZhol. All four of these loans carried a maturity period of 20 years and an interest rate of 2% (see pg.14 and 47 of "Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2018").

This is a 763 km road segment along the 1003 km Almaty-Oskemen road project that runs from Taldykorgan to Kalbatau and then to Ust and Kamenogorsk. More locational information can be found at https://web.archive.org/web/20200219065153/http://www.aksuakimat.gov.kz/ru/zhkh_1111.

STAFF_NOTE: Note that Ust-Kamenogorsk is also referred to as Oskemen, and some reports have referred to this road as Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Öskemen. The Chinese official name for the project is 塔尔迪库尔干- 乌斯季卡缅诺戈尔斯克764 公里国家级公路改造项目. The Russian name of the project is проекту реконструкции автомобильной дороги республиканского значения Талдыкорган – Калбатал - Усть-Каменогорск км 287-1073; another Russian name is Реконструкция автомобильной дороги республиканского значения "Талдыкорган – Калбатау – Усть-Каменогорск" км 287-1073. The project is sometimes also referred to in English as the Taldykorgan-Kalbatau-Ust-Kamenogorsk (615-1073 km) Project. TKU Expressway is another alternative name in English.
name: Zharminskiy

title: CDB provides $300 million USD via credit line for Third Phase of Sulphide Ore Processing Plant Project at the Aktogay Mine (Linked to Project ID#39557 and #41941)
description:
In 2016, China Development Bank (CDB) provided a $300 million USD loan via credit line to the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (DBK) for the third phase of the construction of a sulphide ore processing plant at the Aktogay deposit in East Kazakhstan Region (pg.4 of "DBK 2016 Annual Report"). DBK then used these loan proceeds to on-lend to KAZ Minerals Aktogay LLP (a project company and special purpose vehicle responsible for the financing, design, and construction of the Sulphide Ore Processing Plant Project at the Aktogay Mine). This loan agreement with AKAZ Minerals Aktogay LLP carried the following terms: a maturity period of 8.5 years and an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + 4.50% (see "KAZ Minerals: Credit line approval"). DBK additionally provided $600 million USD for the project, while KAZ Minerals added $963 million USD. The plant was expected to have a capacity of 25 million tons annually (see "Information on KAZ Minerals Aktogay LLP"). In 2014, China Nonferrous Metal Industry's Foreign Engineering and Construction Co., Ltd. (NFC) was granted the contract to construct the sulphide concentrator (see "Chinese Projects Bring New Opportunities to Aktogay in Kazakhstan"). The main sulphide concentrator was commissioned on December 6, 2016 (see "NEW $300 MILLION CREDIT FACILITY WITH DEVELOPMENT BANK OF KAZAKHSTAN AND PXF UPDATE"). Production began in February 2017 (see "Completion of Koksay Project Investment By NFC").

STAFF_NOTE: Because the exact date of signing of the CDB-DBK deal was unknown, the average 6-month LIBOR for the year 2016 was used instead, 1.058%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as 1.058% + 4.5%, or 5.558%. This loan is linked to two previous loans for the Aktogay Mine (Kazakh: Ақтоғай мыс кен орны), a large scale, open pit mine with an average copper grade of 0.36% (oxide) and 0.33% (sulphide). In 2011, CDB committed two loans (see Project ID#41941 and #39557) worth $1.5 billion USD: a $1.34 billion USD and an RMB 1 billion loan to develop the Aktogay mine for copper cathode production.

The Aktogay mine is located in south eastern Kazakhstan in East Kazakhstan Province approximately 250 km from the Kazakhstan-China border.  Its exact locational coordinates can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Mestorozhdeniye+Aktogay/@46.9524266,79.9318158,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x21c2027241e0b5c9?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiEgqWXqJvpAhUhYTUKHWKYCJQQ_BIwFXoECBQQCg and https://www.mindat.org/maps.php?id=208333.
name: Ayagozskiy

title: China Development Bank provides a $1.34 billion USD loan for the Aktogay Copper Mine Development Project (Linked to Project ID #39557 and #53580)
description:
On June 13, 2011, Kazykhmys PLC (now called KAZ Minerals PLC) signed a memorandum of understanding with China Development Bank (CDB) for a $1.5 billion USD loan to develop its, Aktogay Copper Mine Project (see "中方贷款给哈15亿美元开发铜矿"). On December 16, 2011, CDB signed two bilateral agreements with KAZ Minerals Aktogay LLP, a subsidiary of Kazykhmys, to set up loan facilities worth $1.5 billion USD for the mine (pg.105 of "From Promise to Performance - KAZ Minerals PLC Annual Report and Accounts 2016"). 

Then, on February 16, 2012 the loan was finalized and signed as two tranches, to be available for draw down for three years: one for RMB 1 billion ($158 million USD), the other for $1.34 billion USD (see "Kazakhmys announces $1.5 billion loan facility to fund Aktogay project"). The maturity period was 15 years from the date of first draw down and the grace period is 3 years for both loan tranches. The interest rate for the USD-denominated loan tranche (as captured by this project) is LIBOR + a 4.20% margin and the interest rate for the RMB tranche (captured by linked project ID#39557) was based on the applicable benchmark lending rate published by the People's Bank of China (PBoC). KAZ Minerals PLC provided a guarantee for these loans. As of December 31, 2015, the RMB facility was fully drawn down. To protect against currency risks, KAZ Minerals swapped the interest basis from a RMB interest rate into a USD LIBOR interest basis. As of December 31, 2016, the USD facility was fully drawn down. Arrangement fees with an amortized cost of $15 million, were netted off against these borrowings in accordance with IAS 39 (see pg.137 of "From Promise to Performance - KAZ Minerals PLC Annual Report and Accounts 2016"). The USD facility was repayable in half-yearly installments beginning in March 2018 (see pg.45 of "KAZ MINERALS PLC AUDITED RESULTS FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2017").

 The 2016 audited KAZ Minerals financial report identified the interest rates of the USD-denominated and RMB-denominated loan tranches as 5.12% and 4.33% (as of December 31, 2016) and 5.12% and 3.93% (as December 31, 2015), respectively (see pg.136 of "From Promise to Performance - KAZ Minerals PLC Annual Report and Accounts 2016"). The 2017 report identified the interest rates of the USD-denominated and RMB-denominated loan tranches as 5.60% and 4.54% (as of December 31, 2017) respectively (see pg.45 of "KAZ MINERALS PLC AUDITED RESULTS FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2017"). AidData has used this most recent information to code the interest rates of these projects.
The development cost of the copper mine was $2 billion USD, with KAZ Minerals seeking to fund the remaining $500 million USD. The mine was eventually expected to produce up to 100,000 tons of copper concentrate annually beginning in 2015 (see "中方贷款给哈15亿美元开发铜矿"). The project was comprised of an open-pit mine and an on-site concentrator to produce copper cathode from oxide ore and copper concentrate from the sulphide ore, with molybdenum as a by-product. Alarko was the engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contractor responsible for the processing plant at Aktogay. BIR provided engineering and consultancy services for architectural, civil, mechanical and electrical works for the project. ABB provided complete electrification and automation solutions and three gearless mill drive systems, while Ausenco was contracted to work on the open-pit mine. China Nonferrous Metal Industry’s Foreign Engineering and Construction Co., Ltd. (NFC) was awarded the contract for the construction of the sulphide concentrator. Construction began in 2013 (see "Aktogay Copper Mine"). Copper cathode production from oxide began on December 1, 2015 (see slide 16 of "2015 Full Year Results"). CDB would later commit $300 million USD in 2016 specifically for the construction of the sulphide concentrator by NFC, as captured by linked project ID#53580.

The Aktogay mine is located in southeastern Kazakhstan in East Kazakhstan Region approximately 250 km from the Kazakhstan-China border (see "Aktogay Copper Mine"). Its exact locational coordinates can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Mestorozhdeniye+Aktogay/@46.9524266,79.9318158,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x21c2027241e0b5c9?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiEgqWXqJvpAhUhYTUKHWKYCJQQ_BIwFXoECBQQCg and https://www.mindat.org/maps.php?id=208333.
name: Ayagozskiy

title: CDB and Bank of China provide a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan for Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#40362 and #73384)
description:
On January 18, 2011, a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) called Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP (BSGP) was established in Kazakhstan to oversee the financing, design, and implementation of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project. JSC KazTransGas (KTG) and China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) (acting through Trans-Asia Gas Pipeline Company Limited) each held a 50% ownership stake in BSGP (see JV formation date at “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”; see rest at pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

The Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline was a 1454 km long gas pipeline that running through the Mangistau, Aktyubinsk, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. It has a pipe diameter of 1067 mm (see “Beineu-Bozoy-Shymkent gas pipeline is the largest pipeline project...” and pg.149 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The purpose of the project was to ensure stable gas demand in the southern Kazakhstan, reduce dependence on imported gas and ensure the energy security of Kazakhstan. Construction of the pipeline was split into two phases (see “PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES”).

The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved the construction of 1,143.2 km of pipeline from the Bozoi gas metering station in the Shalkar region of Aktobe Region to Akbulak gas metering station in Sairam of South Kazakhstan Region (now known as the Turkistan Region). It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-1 and Bozoy shift camp in Shalkar region of Aktobe Region, emergency-response centers in Saksaulsk, Aksuat and Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region and an emergency-response center in Shornak within the South Kazakhstan Region, as well as construction of the automated process control system (SCADA) and telecommunication (fiber-optic communication line) for the gas pipeline in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). The first phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project was initiated on July 17, 2012 (see pg.29 of "JSC NC "KazMunayGas" Annual Report 2013"). The project was expected to be completed by the end of 2012 (see "China and Kazakhstan begin construction of the second stage of the gas pipeline"). It was completed on September 7, 2013, resulting in a throughput capacity of up to 10 bcm per year (see "First section of China-Kazakstan gas pipeline II starts operation").

The second phase of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project involved 306.3 km of gas pipeline construction from Beineu settlement in the Mangystau Region to Bozoi settlement in the Aktobe Region. It also involved the installation of pipeline facilities, such as: compressor station CS-4 Karaozek in the Kyzylorda Region, Beineu gas metering station in Mangystau Region, the SCADA central dispatch control in Kyzylorda, and gas pipeline construction in Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions (see "About the company"). It was completed on December 30, 2016 (see "PROJECTS OF EXPORT GAS PIPELINES").

Between 2014 and 2017, over 9.0 bcm of gas was transported via the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent gas pipeline, providing the southern regions with Kazakhstani gas. Then, in November 2017, a head compressor station at Bozoi and a line compressor station at Karaozek were put into operation, increasing the capacity of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline to 10 bcm per year. In October 2017, Kazakhstan began exporting gas to China pursuant to a contract concluded between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina for the supply of bcm from October 15, 2017 until October 14, 2018. The price of the gas exported to China pursuant to this agreement was linked to the price of Brent crude oil and determined quarterly. As of December 31, 2017, negotiations were ongoing with respect to a long-term gas supply agreement between JSC KazTransGas and PetroChina. BSGP and KazMunayGas expected that the export of gas to China would increase in the future and made plans to construct three new compressor stations on the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline between 2018 and 2019 to handle this (see pg.151-152 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In order to fund Phase I of the Beineu-Bozoi-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Project, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $1.8 billion USD syndicated loan with China Development Bank (CDB) and Bank of China (BOC) on December 11, 2012 (captured by this project). This loan bears interest at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 2.7% margin per annum for the duration of the guarantee period (until December 31, 2019) and, thereafter, at a rate of 3-month LIBOR + a 3.2% margin per annum. The loan was to be repaid in several installments beginning in December 2017 until March 11, 2028 (implying a grace period of 5 years and a maturity period of 15.25 years). The loan was secured by corporate guarantees from KazMunayGas and CNPC. Unspecified amendments to the facility were made in February 2016 (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus" and pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

In February 2016 and September 2017, amendments were signed because of BSGP's non-compliance with certain project milestones provided for in the facility agreement; the milestones were extended until September 30, 2019. These amendments required BSGP's prepayment of $400 million USD of the outstanding indebtedness, which KazMunayGas provided to BSGP for repayment. The loan was secured by additional security, including an offshore account charge, an onshore account pledge and security assignment of BSGP's rights under the shareholder support agreement in favor of the security agent. As of June 30, 2017, the outstanding indebtedness under the loan was $1.462 billion USD (see pg.85 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2017 Base Prospectus"). As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1.0 billion USD (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

Then, on September 17, 2015, Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline LLP signed a $700 million USD syndicated loan with CDB and BOC for Phase II of the project to supplement their $1.8 billion USD loan. CDB and BOC each reportedly contributed $350 million USD. This loan reportedly carries a maturity period of 15 years; the maturity date was September 17, 2030. The interest rate of the loan is unknown (see “Beineu-Shymkent Gas Pipeline Phase2 Additional Financing”). For the BOC contribution, see linked project ID#73384; for the CDB contribution, see linked project ID#40362.

STAFF_NOTE: The 3-month LIBOR rate in December 2012 was 0.309%. The interest rate, therefore, was coded as 0.309% + 2.7%, or 3.009%.

This 1,454 km pipeline runs through the Mangystau, Aktobe, Kyzylorda and South Kazakhstan regions. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.dropbox.com/s/8j082veud49pzvb/_i%20class%3D_fa%20fa-map%20fa-lg____i_%20Pipeline%20map%20%E2%80%93%20Beineu%20Shymkent.pdf?dl=0 and https://bsgp.kz/en_US/%d0%ba%d0%b0%d1%80%d1%82%d0%b0-%d0%b3%d0%b0%d0%b7%d0%be%d0%bf%d1%80%d0%be%d0%b2%d0%be%d0%b4%d0%b0/ and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/
name: Mangghystau

name: Mangghystau

title: China National Petroleum Corporation funds the repair and maintenance of kindergartens in the Mangystau Region
description:
In 2010, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) funded the repair and maintenance of community kindergartens in the Mangystau Region (see "CNPC in Kazakhstan").

STAFF_NOTE: Project status was coded as "Completion" because it is evident that the funds were completely disbursed. "Year uncertain" box was checked because it is not confirmed that this donation was committed to in 2010. Some sources ("Китайская Национальная Нефтегазовая корпорация (CNPC) - это") claim that JSC MangistauMunaigas, a 50/50 joint venture between CNPC and KazMunayGas, funded this, while others say CNPC. AidData has chosen CNPC as the funder for the time being, because it was involved either way.
name: Mangghystau

title: Bank of China provides a $232 million USD loan for the Bitumen (Asphalt) Plant Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#55030 and #73404)
description:
On September 28, 2010, the Bank of China (BOC) signed a $232 million USD loan agreement for the construction of a bitumen (asphalt) plant in Aktau (see "Bank of China to provide $232 ml loan to finance construction of an asphalt plant in Aktau"). The loan carried a maturity period of seven years, and JV Caspi Bitum LLP pledged the plant as a guarantee for the loan. JV Caspi Bitum LLP was a project company (special purpose vehicle) that established in October 2009 to assume responsible for the financing, design, and implementation of the Bitumen Asphalt Plant Construction Project. Its owners were Kazakhstan Petrochemical Industries JSC (KPI) (50%), a subsidiary of KazMunay Gas, and CITIC Kazakhstan LLP (50%), a subsidiary of CITIC Group (see "НЕФТЬ"). The proceeds of the BOC loan were meant to cover 80% of the cost of the bitumen (asphalt) plant (see "National Company KazMunayGas (Kazakhstan) informed about signing Loan Agreement..."). The total cost of the project was $290 million USD; KPI and CITIC Kazakhstan each contributed the remaining 10% ($29 million USD) (see pg.73 of "KMG Annual Report 2010"). For CITIC Kazakhstan's contribution, see linked project ID#73404.

This bitumen asphalt plant was located in the city of Aktau, at the former Aktau Plastics Plant in the Mangystau Region. The project sought to construct a plant enable to produce high quality road bitumen in order to satisfy the Kazakhstan's requirements for road construction. The plant was expected to produce 406,500 tons of road bitumen, 225,400 tons of petrol-diesel fraction, and 330,300 tons of vacuum gas oil per year (see pg.35 of "KMG Annual Report 2011"). The plant was planned to use up to 1 million tons of oil per year from the Mangystau Karazhanbas as feedstock. The plant was also intended to reduce Kazakhstan's reliance on Russian bitumen imports (see "НЕФТЬ"). JSC OGCC KazStroyService and CITIC Construction Co., Ltd. were contractors responsible for project implementation (see "Bank of China to provide $232 ml loan to finance construction of an asphalt plant in Aktau")

Work on the project was expected to be completed in December 2012 (see pg.35 of "KMG Annual Report 2011"). Construction was launched on June 9, 2010 (see "Kazakh President launches construction of Aktau bitumen plant"). However, the official commissioning of the plant took place on December 12, 2013 (pg.35 of "JSC NC "KazMunayGas" Annual Report 2013"). The project completion ceremony was held on December 20, 2013 (see "Ambassador to Kazakhstan Le Yucheng Attends the Commissioning Ceremony...").

This loan was refinanced by BOC in June 2016, as captured by linked project ID#55030.
name: Aqtau

title: Bank of China provides two loans worth a combined $208 million USD to refinance 2010 loan to JV Caspi Bitum LLP (Linked to Project ID#40265 and #73404)
description:
On September 28, 2010, the Bank of China (BOC) signed a $232 million USD loan agreement with JV Caspi Bitum LLP, a Kazakh-Chinese joint venture between Kazakhstan Petrochemical Industries JSC and CITIC Kazakhstan LLP, for the construction of a bitumen (asphalt) plant in Aktau, captured by linked project ID#40265 (see "Bank of China to provide $232 ml loan to finance construction of an asphalt plant in Aktau"). CITIC Kazakhstan also contributed $29 million USD for this project, as captured by linked project ID#73404.

Then, on June 17, 2016, JV Caspi Bitum LLP entered into two additional loan agreements with BOC in an aggregate principal amount of $208 million USD, to refinance the 2010 loan. The funds were drawn down and the 2010 loan was fully repaid as of 2018 (see pg.109 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

STAFF_NOTE: AidData did not include a transaction amount so as to avoid double-counting with the 2010 loan. Additionally, normally AidData would create two separate projects to capture each loan However, because they were signed on the same day, and no information on the new terms could be found, AidData has elected to let this project count for both.
name: Aqtau
