name: Beyneuskiy

title: China donates 1million yuan worth equipment to Kazakh police
description: On February 19, 2003 China's Public Security Ministry donated police equipment to the Kazakh Interior Ministry in Almaty. The total cost was 1mil yuan. The police equipment and technology supplied by China includes night vision devices, metal detectors, microscopes, tape recorders, computers, scanners, printers, photo equipment, telephones and flashlights. The agreement on the supply of special equipment by the Chinese Public Security Ministry as technical no-strings aid to the Kazakh Interior Ministry was signed by the sides in Beijing on November 18, 2002.
name: North Kazakhstan

title: CDB provides $2.3 billion USD in debt facilities for the development of Bozshakol and Bozymchak copper deposits - Drawn Down Amount (Linked to Project ID#40241 and #61142)
description:
In December 2009, KAZ Minerals PLC secured debt facilities worth $2.7 billion USD by a loan from China Development Bank (CDB) and JSC Sovereign Wealth Fund Samruk-Kazyna for the development of copper deposits Bozshakol, Bozymchak and other growth projects. The breakdown of these debt facilities was as follows: $2.1 billion USD signed on December 30, 2009 for Bozshakol, Bozymchak, and other development projects; $200 million USD signed on January 12, 2010 for Bozshakol, Bozymchak, and other development projects; two facilities of $200 million USD each for the Akbastau-Kosmurun and Zhomart projects signed on June 11, 2012. KAZ Minerals and a subsidiary of Samruk-Kazyna, provided a guarantee for these obligations. The funds were fully drawn in January 2013. They attracted interest semi-annually at an annualized rate of USD LIBOR + a 4.80% margin. The loans under this credit line had a final maturity date falling between January 2022 and August 2025. The first repayment commenced in January 2013. The $400 million USD that had been allocated to Akbastau-Kosmurun and Zhomart projects was repaid early, in January 2014, because these projects were unlikely to proceed in the medium term (see pg.53 and 96 of "RELEASE OF FINAL RESULTS FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2014 AND RESUMPTION OF TRADING").

For the remaining $2.3 billion USD, KAZ Minerals signed an amendment to the debt facilities with CDB and Samruk-Kazyna on December 29, 2014. The changes made by the amendment include the following: the facilities became bilateral between KAZ Minerals and CDB; the interest rate was lowered from USD LIBOR + a 4.80% margin to USD LIBOR + a 4.50% margin; and an arrangement fee of 0.5% was agreed to, of which 60% was paid in December 2014 and 40% was paid in January 2016. The loan’s maturity and grace period were left unchanged; KAZ Minerals PLC continued to guarantee this CDB facility (pg.135 of "From Promise to Performance - KAZ Minerals PLC Annual Report and Accounts 2016" and "Amendment to CDB facilities"). The amount outstanding on the previous facility when the amendment was signed was $2.1 billion USD. As of December 31, 2016, $1.7 billion had been drawn down under the facility agreements. Arrangement fees with an amortised cost of $20 million USD were netted off against these borrowings in accordance with IAS 39 (pg.135 of "From Promise to Performance - KAZ Minerals PLC Annual Report and Accounts 2016").

To calculate the interest rate at time of commitment, the 6-month LIBOR rate as of December 2009 was used (0.453%); total interest rate equals 0.453% + 4.8%, or 5.253%. The grace period was set to 3 years (as the loan was first contracted on December 30, 2009 and the first repayment began in January 2013), and the maturity period was set to 15.66 years (as the loan was contracted on December 30, 2009 and the final loan maturity date was in August 2025). The bilateral amendment between CDB and KAZ Minerals also clarified the loan proceeds were to be used “principally for the development of the Bozshakol and Bozymchak [mine] projects." As of November 30, 2014, the principal balance outstanding on the facilities was $2.086 billion USD. This project records the transaction amount $2.3 billion USD, as it appears to have been fully drawn down (see "Amendment to CDB facilities").

Bozymchak is an open-pit copper mine and concentrator in Ala-Bukinsky region of the Jalal-Abad Region, Kyrgyzstan. China Nonferrous Metal Industry’s Foreign Engineering and Construction Co., Ltd. (NFC) was the EPC contractor for the Bozymchak mine project (see "NFC In Central Asia"). The completion ceremony for the Bozymchak mine took place on August 5, 2015 (see "Kazakhmys Gold opens new copper, gold and silver mine in Kyrgyzstan"). Detailed locational information about this mine can be found at https://www.mindat.org/loc-297492.html.

The Bozshakol mine is a large copper mine located in the North Kazakhstan Region. NFC was the EPC contractor for the Bozshakol mine project, with a contract valued at $486 million USD. The project sought to establish facilities able to mine 30 million tonnes per year. It was planned to be complete on June 30, 2015. (see "NFC Signs Contract on Bozshakol Copper Concentrator Project with Kazakhmys"). The completion of construction and the commencement of commissioning works was held on September 29, 2016 (see "Bozshakol Clay Plant Completion"). Detailed locational information about this mine can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Bozshakol+Copper+Mine/@51.8469877,74.2913709,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0xee5b22335ffe85b1?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiJ2IKl0ZvpAhV2hHIEHQkhDH0Q_BIwFXoECBEQCg.
name: Ekibastuz

title: [Refinancing] CDB debt facilities for development of Bozshakol and Bozymchak copper deposits (linked to #61056 and #40241)
description: In December 2009, KAZ Minerals secured debt facilities of $2.7 billion loan from China Development Bank and JSC Sovereign Wealth Fund Samruk-Kazyna for the development of copper deposits Bozshakol, Bozymchak and other growth projects. In January, $400 Million allocated to projects that were unlikely to proceed in the medium term was repaid early. For the remaining $2.3 billion debt, KAZ signed an amendment to the debt facilities with CDB and Samruk-Kazyna in December 2014. The changes made by the amendment include the following changes: the facilities will become bilateral between KAZ Minerals and the CDB, Interest rate lowered from USD LIBOR plus 4.80% to USD LIBOR plus 4.50%, Arrangement fee of 0.5%, 60% payable in December 2014 and 40% payable in January 2016. To calculate the interest rate at time of commitment, the 6 Month LIBOR Rate as of December 2009 is used - 0.453%. Total interest rate = 0.453% + 4.5% = 4.953%. As at 30 November 2014, the principal balance outstanding on the facilities was $2,086 million. This project captures the rescheduling of the debt in 2014. The grace period is 3 years, and the maturity period is between 12 and 15 years. STAFF_NOTE: Transaction value is not recorded as amount is already captured in #61056
name: Ekibastuz

title: China Development Bank provides a $400 million USD loan for the 630 MW Third Unit of the Ekibastuz GRES-2 Power Plant Project (Linked to Project ID#66481)
description:
On October 22, 2013, China Development Bank (CDB) and Russia's Vnesheconombank (VEB) signed a $400 million USD loan agreement to finance the construction of the Third Unit of the Ekibastuz GRES-2 Power Station in Kazakhstan (see "Eighteenth regular meeting between the heads of the Russian and Chinese governments"). The loan had a maturity period of 10 years; its other terms are unknown. This loan was often lumped together with a $800 million USD CDB loan to VEB for a multifunctional complex in Moscow, signed at the same time (captured by linked project ID#66481), as a "$1.2 billion USD loan" (see pg.50 of "VEB Annual Report 2013"). 

VEB used the proceeds of the CDB $400 million USD loan to on-lend to the "Ekibastuz GRES-2" Joint Stock Company (JSC) for the construction of the third unit of Ekibastuz GRES-2 coal power plant in Ekibastuz. Ekibastuz GRES-2 was a coal-power thermal power plant with an installed capacity of 1 GW, located in the city of Ekibastuz in the north of Kazakhstan (see "3-й энергоблок Экибастузской ГРЭС-2 и др. проекты. Самрук-Энерго озвучил планы на среднесрочную перспективу"). VEB led a consortium, that included the Eurasian Bank of Kazakhstan, were to provide a $700 million USD syndicated loan for the project (see "DEWEY & LEBOEUF REPRESENTS EKIBASTUZ GRES-2 POWER STATION ON A $770 MILLION SECURED FINANCING"). The project had a total cost of $700 million USD (see "China and Russia to spend $400 million on Kazakhstan power plant"). VEB's finances were drained because of its financing of Olympic facilities in Sochi, making it look to CDB to partially finance the project (see "Taming the Dragon: How Can Russia Benefit From China’s Financial Ambitions in the SCO?").

"Ekibastuz GRES-2" Joint Stock Company (JSC), an energy company located in Kazakhstan, managed the plant. Until December 2019, Russian energy company Inter RAO UES owned 50% and Samruk-Energy (JSC) owned 50% of Ekibastuz GRES-2. In December 2919, Samruk-Kazyna JSC purchased the 50% Inter RAO's shares for $25 million USD, transferring the plant entirely to Kazakhstan through the management of Samruk-Energy (JSC). Ekibastuz GRES-2 was a coal-power thermal power plant with an installed capacity of 1 GW, located in the city of Ekibastuz in the north of Kazakhstan (see "3-й энергоблок Экибастузской ГРЭС-2 и др. проекты. Самрук-Энерго озвучил планы на среднесрочную перспективу").

The two existing power units at GRES-2 currently produce about 12% of all electricity produced in Kazakhstan in 2010. The CDB-financed project involved the construction, development and operation of a third unit, which, once completed, would seek to increase the power station’s installed capacity by 50% (see "DEWEY & LEBOEUF REPRESENTS EKIBASTUZ GRES-2 POWER STATION ON A $770 MILLION SECURED FINANCING"). The capacity of the third unit was expected to be 630 MW. Construction began on October 21, 2014. The project was planned to be completed in 2017 (see "На Экибастузской ГРЭС-2 началось строительство 3-го энергоблока").  Construction was apparently delayed in 2016, but it has since returned (see "3-й энергоблок Экибастузской ГРЭС-2 и др. проекты. Самрук-Энерго озвучил планы на среднесрочную перспективу").

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is 3-го блока Экибастузской ГРЭС.

The GRES-2 Power Station (or Power Station Ekibastuz) is a coal-fueled power generating station in the town of Ekibastuz within Pavlodar Region. More detailed locational information can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ekibastuz_GRES-2_Power_Station#/map/0 and https://latitude.to/satellite-map/kz/kazakhstan/15146/ekibastuz-gres-2-power-station and http://globalenergyobservatory.org/geoid/40122 and https://www.google.com/maps/place/Ekibastuz+GRES-2+Power+Station,+Gres-2+140000,+Kazakhstan/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x4257917c05aaeefb:0x1106a87977b9d7ae?sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwj0uOak1pvpAhVUkHIEHTxjBNUQ8gEwC3oECBQQBg.
name: Ekibastuz

title: China Eximbank provides a $400 million USD loan for the Pavlodar Aluminium Smelter Construction Project
description:
In May 2010, the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (DBK) entered into a $400 million USD loan agreement with the Export-Import Bank of China for the aluminium smelter construction project in Pavlodar. The loan accrued the following terms: a maturity period of 15 years (the maturity date was May 21, 2025) and an interest rate of 4%. The principal and interest were to be repaid semiannually. As of June 30, 2017, the principal amount outstanding under this loan was $324 million USD (see pg.67 of "Development Bank of Kazakhstan Base Prospectus 2017" and “Information on Kazakhstan Electrolytic plant JSC”). Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation (ENRC) provided a guarantee for the loan, which was reportedly a line of credit (see “Overview of key developments from analysts of Asyl Invest JSC (Kazakhstan) on April 16, 2010”).
 
DBK then used the proceeds of the China Eximbank loan to on-lend to Kazakhstan Aluminium Smelter JSC (KAS) (also known as Kazakhstan Electrolytic Plant JSC), the project company and a subsidiary of ENRC and responsible for the Pavlodar Aluminium Smelter Construction Project. The entire project cost $1.0183 billion USD, and KAS contributed $618.3 million USD (see pg.67 of “Information on Kazakhstan Electrolytic plant JSC” and "Kazakhstan Aluminium Smelter JSC").

The Pavlodar Aluminium Smelter project sought to construct a primary aluminum smelter in Pavlodar with a capacity of 250,000 tons per year (see “Information on Kazakhstan Electrolytic plant JSC”). In addition to financing the smelter, the loan was intended to pay for costs incurred during the first and second phases of the electrolysis plant (see “Overview of key developments from analysts of Asyl Invest JSC (Kazakhstan) on April 16, 2010”). China Nonferrous Metal Industry’s Foreign Engineering and Construction Co., Ltd. (NFC) was the EPC contractor. Construction began in 2014 (see “President of Kazakhstan Inspects CPC Plant Undertaken by NFC in Pavlodar”). The project was accepted as complete on December 11, 2015 (see "Two Projects Undertaken by NFC Passed Kazakhstan National Unified Acceptance").

The Pavlodar aluminium smelter site was located to the south-east of the Pavlodar residential zone: 13.5 km away from its boundary and 10 km away from the operating alumina refinery and from the heat power plant of the JSC Aluminium of Kazakhstan (see pg.4 of “COMPOSITION OF THE PROJECT.”). More detailed locational information is available at https://www.google.com/maps/search/%D0%9F%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80+%D0%90%D0%BB%D1%8E%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B9/@52.2603189,77.040134,16z and https://www.agaportal.de/_Resources/Persistent/f6d7a1fe4da7c0a59acaafa041c2e96408d4d75f/eia_kasachstan_aluminium.pdf.
name: Pavlodarskiy

title: ICBC participates in a $1.18 billion USD loan facility for the 794 km Kenkiyak-Kumkol Section of the Kazakhstan-China Oil Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#39605 and #54523)
description:
On August 12, 2008, Chinese-Kazakh joint venture Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP entered into a $1.18 billion USD credit facility with the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited (ICBC) and the ING Bank N.V. for a term of ten years, subject to extension for up to five additional years. This credit facility was entered into for the purpose of financing the construction of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. KCP had the right to draw down the loan in four tranches. It drew down three in 2008 in an aggregate principal amount of $1 billion USD. The availability period of this credit facility expired at the end of 2011. The borrowed funds bore an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 2% margin per annum until February 2013 and 6-month LIBOR + a 4% margin per annum thereafter. CNPC provided a guarantee from the loan. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this facility was $403.9 million USD (including the capitalised interest) (₸134.3 billion KZT) (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). Based on the information above, the interest rate was recorded as 6-Month LIBOR in August 2008 (3.108%) + 2%, or 5.108%, while the maturity period is 10 years and the grace period is zero. 

JSC KazTransOil (KTO) and China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development Corporation (CNODC) formed a joint venture Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) called Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP (KCP) on July 6, 2004 (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP History"). KCP was created to construct and operate the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline and the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. These pipelines are two of three pipeline systems of the Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network, which was built to create a transport corridor for the export of Kazakhstani oil to China. KTO and CNODC each owned 50% of the joint venture (see pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). 

This project sought to the construct the Kenkiyak–Kumkol pipeline, which was intended to transport oil from West Kazakhstan and Aktobe oilfields. It began in Kenkiyak and ended in Kumkol. The pipeline was 794.263 km long and it had a maximum capacity of10 million tons a year. It included relay pump stations to increase the volume of oil transported (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline About"). The pipe had diameters ranging between 0.5 and 1.8 meters (see pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline passed through the Aktobe, Kyzylorda and Karaganda regions, with its oil destined for the Chinese market. JSC OGCC KazStroyService was responsible for the construction of the 483 km section from Kenkiyak to Aralsk, while China Petroleum Pipeline Engineering Co., Ltd. (CPPE) was responsible for the construction of a 311 km section to Kumkol. Construction of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline began on December 11, 2007 (see "Kenkiyak - Kumkol"). The pipeline went into operation on October 6, 2009 (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline").

As of 31 December 31, 2017, the pipeline had a throughput capacity of 9.2 million tonnes of crude oil per year. In 2017, 5.2 million tonnes of crude oil were transported through the pipeline. Pursuant to an agreement between the KTO and CNODC, the capacity of the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline was increased from 10.0 million tonnes of crude oil per year to 20.0 million tonnes in
2015 so as to take advantage of expected increased production at Tengiz Field and Kashagan Field. Ten companies supply oil to the pipeline, which KCP has continued to own (pg.158 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

The Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network is comprised of three systems: (i) the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline, from Kenkiyak in western Kazakhstan to Atyrau on the Caspian Sea; (ii) the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China; and (iii) the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan. All three systems are operational (pg.249 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The Atasu-Alashankou pipeline project is captured by linked project ID#39605, while the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline is captured by linked project ID#54523.

STAFF_NOTE: As the loan financiers include a non-Chinese financier (ING Bank N.V.) and the breakdown of loan amounts between the 2 financiers are not known, a transaction amount has not been recorded for this project. This project is sometimes called “Second stage of Kazakhstan-China oil pipeline construction."

The 794 km Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline runs from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan and runs through three regions (Aktobe, Kyzylorda and Karaganda). A 483 km segment runs from the Kenkiyak station to the Aralsk area, and a 311 km segment to the Kumkol station. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.energycharter.org/fileadmin/DocumentsMedia/Presentations/CBP-KZ-CN.pdf and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/
name: Qaraghandy

title: ICBC provides $300 million USD to refinance notes issued in 2005 for the Atasu-Alashankou Section of Kazakhstan-China Oil Pipeline Project (Linked to Project ID#39605 and #72865)
description:
JSC KazTransOil (KTO) and China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development Corporation (CNODC) formed a joint venture Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) called Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP (KCP) on July 6, 2004 (see "Kazakhstan-China Pipeline LLP History"). KCP was created to construct and operate the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline and the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline. These pipelines are two of three pipeline systems of the Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network, which was built to create a transport corridor for the export of Kazakhstani oil to China. KTO and CNODC each owned 50% of the joint venture (see pg.37 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus").

To finance the 965 km Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, CNODC and KTO contributed $50 million USD of their own funds (as captured by linked project ID#39605; in addition, $600 million USD was raised through the issuing of Eurobonds by JP Morgan Bank (see "Atasu-Alashankou project"). Then, in August 2013, KCP entered into a $300 million facility agreement with the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited (ICBC) and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Almaty) JSC (ICBC Almaty) to refinance notes that it had issued in 2005 for the Atasu-Alashankou Section of Kazakhstan-China Oil Pipeline Project. This loan facility bears interest at a rate of 6-month LIBOR + a 3.75% margin per annum. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $180 million USD (₸59.8 billion KZT) (see pg.110 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). Based on this information, interest rate was recorded as 6-month LIBOR in August 2013 (0.395%) + 3.75%, or 4.145%; the maturity and grace periods are unknown.

The Kazakhstan-China Pipeline network is comprised of three systems: (i) the Kenkiyak-Atyrau pipeline, from Kenkiyak in western Kazakhstan to Atyrau on the Caspian Sea; (ii) the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline, from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China; and (iii) the Kenkiyak-Kumkol pipeline, from Kenkiyak to Kumkol in south Kazakhstan. All three systems are operational (pg.249 of "JSC NC “KazMunayGas” 2018 Base Prospectus"). The original financing of the Atasu-Alashankou pipeline project is captured by linked project ID#39605.

The 965 km Atasu-Alashankou pipeline runs from Atasu in eastern Kazakhstan to Alashankou in western China. It passes through the Karaganda, East-Kazakhstan and Almaty regions of Kazakhstan. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.energycharter.org/fileadmin/DocumentsMedia/Presentations/CBP-KZ-CN.pdf and https://www.kaztransoil.kz/en/about_the_company/main_pipelines_scheme/.
name: Aktogayskiy

title: China opens Confucius Institute at National Technical University of Karaganda of Kazakhstan
description: In 2011, a Confucius Institute was opened at Karganda State Technical University (KSTU). After an opening ceremony in 2012, the institute promotes Chinese culture and teaching the Chinese language.
name: Bukhar-Zhyrauskiy

title: CDB provides RMB 2.255 million credit line facility to RSK Bank OJSC for on-lending to SMEs, trade, and infrastructure (Linked to Project ID#70929, #70924, #70946, #70935, and #70934)
description: On January 21, 2011, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a RMB 2,255,000 credit line facility with RSK Bank OJSC. This loan was intended to be used for various on-lending activities, including the development of small and medium size enterprises, trade and commerce between Chinese and Kyrgyz entrepreneurs, and the construction and rehabilitation of infrastructure in the Southern cities and regions of the Kyrgyz Republic. The loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 3 years and 10 months (the exact maturity date was November 20, 2014) and an interest rate of 7%. By December 31, 2013, RMB 2,255,000 had been drawn down from the credit line (see pg.40-41 of 'RSK Bank OJSC Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2013'). This project is linked with a $3.1 million credit line facility also signed on January 21, 2011 (see linked project ID#70929), a RMB 1,754,041 credit line facility from CDB signed on June 7, 2012 (see linked project ID#70946), a $8 million credit line facility from CDB also signed on June 7, 2012 (see linked project ID#70924), a $900,000 credit line facility from CDB signed on August 13, 2007 (see linked project ID#70935), and a $2.5 million credit line facility from CDB signed on August 28, 2008 (see linked project ID#70934). STAFF_NOTE: There were 1,399 days between the signing date and maturity period; 1,399 divided by 365 days (a year), equals 3.8 approximately, and this was coded to be as precise as possible. The project status was coded as 'Implementation' because MB 2,255,000 had been drawn down.
GEO_sources: http://www.rsk.kg/en/about, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://www.rsk.kg/uploads/files/ru/2b1b09026fedbbef491a6a6f5dbb0122f7f6db72.pdf, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; https://www.dropbox.com/s/a93lcmkjiuhwnk3/2b1b09026fedbbef491a6a6f5dbb0122f7f6db72.pdf?dl=0, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: CDB provides $2.2 million loan for Bishkek Osh-Batken Fiber Optic Network Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#70878, #70881, #70884, and #70886)
description:
On October 16, 2012, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $2,200,000 loan agreement with KyrgyzTelecom. This loan was intended to be used for the Bishkek Osh-Batken Fiber Optic Network Construction Project. The loan terms are as follows: 5-year maturity, a grace period of 0.5 years, interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 2.5% margin (see pg.18 of "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2015").

title: CDB provides $2 million loan for Bishkek Osh-Batken Fiber Optic Network Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#70878, #70881, #70884, and #70889)
description:
In September, 2012, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $2,000,000 loan agreement with KyrgyzTelecom. This loan was intended to be used for the Bishkek Osh-Batken Fiber Optic Network Construction Project. The loan carried the following terms: a 5-year maturity, a grace period of 0.5 years, and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 2.5% margin (see pg.18 of "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2015").

This project is linked to a $8.7 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in September 2009 for this project (see linked project ID#70878), a $4.9 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in February 2011 for this project (see linked project ID#70881), a $4 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in June 2011 (see linked project ID#70884), and a $2.2 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in October 2012 (see linked project ID#70889).

STAFF_NOTE: The 6 month LIBOR in 2012 was .672%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as .672% + 2.5%, or 3.172%. Project status was coded as completion because all Chinese financing was disbursed; as of January 1, 2016, KyrgyzTelecom had a remaining debt of $642,378.3. The Russian project title is Проект «ВОЛС Бишкек – Ош – Баткен».

It appears that KyrgyzTelecom actually received $1,766,540.38 on February 2, 2012 (before the loan was signed; this date was reported by KyrgyzTelecom), The lower disbursement amount may be caused by losses from currency exchange (see pg.23 of "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2012"). 

Additionally, the 2015 report states that the signing date was September 29, 2012, but the 2012 report states September 25, 2012.
name: Kyrgyzstan

This loan was intended to be used for the Bishkek Osh-Batken Fiber Optic Network Construction Project. The loan carried the following terms: a 5-year maturity, a grace period of 0.5 years, and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 2.5% margin (see pg.18 of "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2015").

This project is linked to a $8.7 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in September 2009 for this project (see linked project ID#70878), a $4.9 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in February 2011 for this project (see linked project ID#70881), a $4 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in June 2011 (see linked project ID#70884), and a $2.2 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in October 2012 (see linked project ID#70889).

STAFF_NOTE: The 6 month LIBOR in 2012 was .672%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as .672% + 2.5%, or 3.172%. Project status was coded as completion because all Chinese financing was disbursed; as of January 1, 2016, KyrgyzTelecom had a remaining debt of $642,378.3. The Russian project title is Проект «ВОЛС Бишкек – Ош – Баткен».

It appears that KyrgyzTelecom actually received $1,766,540.38 on February 2, 2012 (before the loan was signed; this date was reported by KyrgyzTelecom), The lower disbursement amount may be caused by losses from currency exchange (see pg.23 of "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2012"). 

Additionally, the 2015 report states that the signing date was September 29, 2012, but the 2012 report states September 25, 2012.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China donates 1.8 million USD worth of cars to Kyrgyzstan
description: The signing ceremony of an agreement was held today. According to the agreement, the Chinese government will provide as a grant cars worth 1.8 dollars to the Kyrgyz government for state protocol needs. The document was signed by Kyrgyz Foreign Minister Alikbek Dzhekshenkulov and Chinese Ambassador to Kyrgyzstan Hong Jiuyin. Staff_note: some other sources indicate that this is a loan. Need further research to figure out.
GEO_sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&NS=16&AID=9VIV000400&an=BBCCA00020060930e29u0018h&cat=a&ep=ASI, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://books.google.com/books?id=wkyiAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT197&lpg=PT197&dq=CHina+fiber+optic+loan+turkmenistan&source=bl&ots=t-cXWhRupb&sig=yGacJ6jg9t6bylAzU1B3_SjvNsE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiMtOCazrTfAhXHxlkKHaORDh4Q6AEwCHoECAYQAQ#v=onepage&q=CHina%20fiber%20optic%20loan%20turkmenistan&f=false, Academic Journal Article
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China grants Kyrgyz Republic 60 million RMB for China-Kyrgyzstan-Uzbekistan highway construction (Linked to project ID#73072)
description: In March 2004, an agreement stipulating numerous cooperation initiatives was signed between China and the Kyrgyz Republic. The agreement included an extradition clause as well as a Chinese pledge to expand infrastructure in the Kyrgyz Republic. Such projects included reconstruction of China-Kyrgyzstan-Uzbekistan Highway, construction of a railway under ODANAEA project, and creating a network of Silk Road transportation. To facilitate such projects, China granted the Kyrgyz Republic 60 million RMB. The China-Kyrgyzstan-Uzbekistan Highway starts from Kashgar, Xinjiang, China in the east, passes through the China-Kyrgyzstan port, passes through the south of Kyrgyzstan, and ends in Tashkent, Uzbekistan in the west. The funds needed to repair 258 kilometers of roads in Kyrgyzstan were solved in three ways: one was to use China's 60 million yuan free assistance to repair the 17.74 kilometers of roads (captured in project ID#40315, completed); the second was to use ADB and Islamic Development Bank loans to repair 121 kilometers (ADB loans to 77-kilometer section construction and the Islamic Development Bank loans to 44-kilometer section construction); the third is to repair the remaining sections through the Sino-Kyrgyzstan 'resource for project' cooperation model. On March 13, 2007, China Road and Bridge Engineering Co., Ltd., and Kyrgyzstan Minister of Transport and Communications Suleymanov signed the China-Kyrgyzstan-Uzbekistan Highway construction contract. The contract value is 27 million US dollars. The length of the section is 77 kilometers (Osh-Quelcea) and the construction period is 36 months. In order to initiate the ADB loan, the Kyrgyz side needs to contribute US$4 million in matching funds. At the request of the Kyrgyz government, the China Development Bank will provide the Kyrgyz side with this matching fund loan (captured in project ID#73072).
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China grants Kyrgyzstan 70 million RMB for agricultural development and construction of schools
description: On June 12, 2006, China allocated Kyrgyzstan a grant of 70 million yuans to be directed for purchasing agricultural technique, construction of schools, reconstruction and construction of roads as well as acquiring technique for the state institutions. No further information can be found to confirm the grant, and the flow class is uncertain.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China offers technical assistance to Kyrgyz's Border Service
description: In 2017, China's Ministry of Public Security agreed to provide technical assistance worth 1 million yuan to the Kyrgyz Border Service. This agreement was signed in context of strengthening cooperation between the two countries in the fields of counter-terrorism and personnel support. China additionally proposed training cooperation between Chinese and Kyrgyz personnel.
GEO_sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=XNEWS00020170413ed4d00bvu&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://english.pladaily.com.cn/view/2017-04/14/content_7562701.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://english.gov.cn/news/international_exchanges/2017/04/14/content_281475626351376.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China commits technical assistance to Kyrgyz pension fund
description: In 2003, the Chairman of the Social Fund of Kyrgyzstan met with the Minister of Labor and Social Protection of China and signed a cooperation agreement. The Chinese side will render assistance to develop a system of social insurance and hold pension reform. Officials will also exchange information and jointly research issues.
GEO_sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=kabnew0020030301dz2s0005o&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=kabnew0020030306dz3300005&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China Donates Equipment to Kyrgyz Police
description: On October 13th 2003, the Ministry of Public Security in China made a donation to Kyrgyzstan police, and it is the third donation from China since 2001. This donation includes 50 Beijing jeeps and an equipment used in detective experiments. It is to help maintain social security in Kyrgyzstan and better protect Kirghiz and Chinese citizens living in the central Asian country from crime.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China Finances Telecommunication Installation at 15 Medical Facilities in Kyrgyzstan
description: In July 2017, the Chinese government granted computers for the installation of a video telecommunications network for 15 medical facilities in Kyrgyzstan. To implement this project, the Chinese government provided computers and network equipment to the Kyrgyz medical facilities. The Urumqi government of the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region agreed to the installation in accordance with the Cross-Border Remote Medical Services on the Silk Road Platform.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China grants Kyrgyz Republic 300,000 USD in technical assistance
description: In 2004, China agreed to send technical aid worth 300,000 USD to the Interior Ministry of the Republic of Kyrgyzstan. Furthermore, China also pledged to hand over 30,000 off-road vehicles.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: CDB provides $8 million credit line facility to RSK Bank OJSC for on-lending to SMEs, trade, and infrastructure (Linked to Project ID#70946, #70938, #70935, #70934, and #70929)
description: On June 7, 2012, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $8,000,000 credit line facility with RSK Bank OJSC. This loan was intended to be used for for various on-lending activities, including the development of small and medium size enterprises, trade and commerce between Chinese and Kyrgyz entrepreneurs, and the construction and rehabilitation of infrastructure in the Southern cities and regions of the Kyrgyz Republic. This facility carried the following terms: a 5-year maturity (the exact maturity date was June 7, 2017) and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 4.88% margin. By December 31, 2013, $8,000,000 had been drawn down from the credit line (see pg.40-41 of 'RSK Bank OJSC Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2013'). This project is linked with a RMB 1,754,041 credit line facility from CDB also signed on June 7, 2012 (see linked project ID#70946), a RMB 2,255,000 credit line facility from CDB signed on January 21, 2011 (see linked project ID#70938), a $3.1 million credit line facility also signed on January 21, 2011 (see linked project ID#70929), a $900,000 credit line facility from CDB signed on August 13, 2007 (see linked project ID#70935), and a $2.5 million credit line facility from CDB signed on August 28, 2008 (see linked project ID#70934). STAFF_NOTE: The 6 month LIBOR in 2012 was .736%. Therefore, interest rate was coded as .736% + 4.88%, or 5.616%. The project status was coded as 'Implementation' because $8 million had been drawn down.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: CDB provides $3.1 million credit line facility to RSK Bank OJSC for on-lending to SMEs, trade, and infrastructure (Linked to Project ID#70924, #70938, #70935, #70934, and #70946)
description: On January 21, 2011, China Development Bank (CDB) signed $3,100,000 credit line facility with RSK Bank OJSC. This loan was intended to be used for for various on-lending activities, including the development of small and medium size enterprises, trade and commerce between Chinese and Kyrgyz entrepreneurs, and the construction and rehabilitation of infrastructure in the Southern cities and regions of the Kyrgyz Republic. The loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 8 years and 3 months (the exact maturity period was April 22, 2019) and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 4.5% margin. By December 31, 2013, $3,100,000 had been drawn down from the credit line (see pg.40-41 of 'RSK Bank OJSC Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2013'). This project is linked with a RMB 2,255,000 credit line facility from CDB also signed on January 21, 2011 (see linked project ID#70938), and a $8 million credit line facility from CDB signed on June 7, 2012 (see linked project ID#70924), a RMB 1,754,041 credit line facility from CDB also signed on June 7, 2012 (see linked project ID#70946), a RMB 2,255,000 credit line facility from CDB signed on January 21, 2011 (see linked project ID#70938), a $900,000 credit line facility from CDB signed on August 13, 2007 (see linked project ID#70935), and a $2.5 million credit line facility from CDB signed on August 28, 2008 (see linked project ID#70934). STAFF_NOTE: The 6 month LIBOR in 2012 was .455%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as .455% + 4.5%, or 4.955%. The project status was coded as 'Implementation' because $3.1 million had been drawn down. For precision, the maturity period was based on the number of days between the signing date and the maturity date (3,013) divided by 365, or 8.3 approximately.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: Chinese Government provides $25 million loan to RSK Bank for agricultural projects
description: In 2014, the Chinese provided a $25 million loan to RSK Bank for agricultural projects in the Kyrygz Republic. $15 million of the loan proceeds were to be set aside for projects that would help farmers to develop greenhouses.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: CDB provides $3.5 million loan for Digital Horizon Transformation Project (Linked to Project ID#70873)
description:
On November 12, 2007, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $3,500,000 loan agreement with KyrgyzTelecom. This loan was intended to be used for the Digital Horizon Transformation Project. The loan carried the following terms: a 6-year maturity period (the exact maturity date was December 12, 2013), a grace period of 1.5 years, and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 1.8% margin. The loan was repaid before December 31, 2015 (see pg.15 of "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2015").

Huawei Technologies provided related equipment for the project. Digital Horizon Transformation Project sought to upgrade the fixed network of KyrgyzTelecom from an analog network to a digital network (see "国家开发银行融资支持吉电信改造项目"). It provided for the parallel implementation of two projects: the modernization and development of the Bishkek telecommunication network and modernization and development of the regional telecommunication networks. It included the introduction of the expansion BGTS networks and an increase in KyrgyzTelecom's subscriber lines capacity to 250,000 (see "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2006").

This project is linked to a $6.6 million loan from CDB for Digital Horizon Transformation Project in June 2006 (see linked project ID#70873).

STAFF_NOTE:  The interest rate of 6-month LIBOR in 2007 was 4.832%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as 4.832% + 1.8%, or 6.632%. The Russian project title is Телекоммуникационный проект «Цифровое будущее». 

Only $3,340,054.6 was actually received. This may be due to losses from the exchange rate difference, which was KGS 1,370,758.40.

According to the KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2007, the $3.5 million loan signed on November 12, 2007 had the following terms: a 9-year maturity period, a grace period of 1 year and 1 month, and an interest rate of LIBOR + 1.8%. The KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2008 provides a 9-year maturity period, a grace period of 1 year and 1 month, and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 1.8%. However, the KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2009 provides a 6-year maturity period, a grace period of 1.5 years, and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 1.8%. We accepted the 2015 protocol.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China grants humanitarian aid worth 3 Million RMB to Kyrgyzstan following riots
description: In early June of 2010, ethnic violence broke out in the south of the Kygryz Republic between ethnic Kyrgyz and Uzbeks. On June 30, 2010, China decided to provide a batch of humanitarian aid materials worth of 3 million RMB yuan to Kyrgyzstan. The aid materials were delivered to the southern city of Osh in Kyrgyzstan by China's relevant departments on the early morning of July 28, Beijing time. The representatives from both sides signed the transfer list at the Osh Airport. The aid materials include rice, edible oil, biscuits, black tea, milk powder, blankets, clothes, stationary and daily sanitary necessities. China hopes the aid will help Kyrgyzstan to resettle the refugees. This aid package follows a similar donation of 5 million RMB yuan on June 15, 2010 for the same purpose, which is recorded in project #40411.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China provided 1205 sets of farming YTO-X904 tractors to Kyrgyzstan
description: In August 2006, China provided in total 1,205 sets of farming YTO-X904 tractors to Kyrgyzstan on a short notice. President Askar Akayew of Kyrgyzstan wrote twice to President Hu Jintao expressing his thanks. STAFF_NOTE: very little information was found during stage 2.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: CDB provides $8.7 million loan for Osh-Irkeshtam Fiber Optic Network Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#70881, #70884, #70886, and #70889)
description:
On September 28, 2009, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $8,700,000 loan agreement with KyrgyzTelecom. This loan was intended to be used for the Osh Irkeshtam Fiber Optic Network Construction Project. The loan carried the following terms: a 8-year maturity, grace period of 1.5 years, and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 1.8% margin (see pg.17 of "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2015").

This project is linked to a $4.9 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in February 2011 for this project (see linked project ID#70881), a $4 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in June 2011 (see linked project ID#70884), a $2 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in September 2012 (see linked project ID#70886), and a $2.2 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in October 2012 (see linked project ID#70889).

STAFF_NOTE: The 6 month LIBOR in 2009 was .677%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as .677% + 1.8%, or 2.477%. Project status was coded as completion because all Chinese financing was disbursed; as of January 1, 2016, KyrgyzTelecom had a remaining debt of $2,174,756.6. The Russian project title is Проект «Цифровое будущее. Фаза «Региональные сети» «Строительство ВОЛС «Ош – Иркештам». According to 2010, 2011, and 2012 KyrgyzTelecom Financial Reports, the actual amount received from the loan was $8,699,026.3.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: CDB provides $6.6 million loan for Digital Horizon Transformation Project (Linked to Project ID#70874)
description:
On June 9, 2006, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $6,640,258 loan agreement with KyrgyzTelecom. This loan was intended to be used for the Digital Horizon Transformation Project. The loan carried the following terms: 7-year maturity (the exact maturity date was June 7, 2013), 2-year grace period, interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 1.8% margin. The loan was repaid before December 31, 2015 (see pg.15 of "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2015"). This loan is the first project loan issued by China Development Bank through commercial operation within the framework of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization since the establishment of the SCO Bank Consortium.

Huawei Technologies provided related equipment for the project. Digital Horizon Transformation Project intended to upgrade the fixed network of KyrgyzTelecom from an analog network to a digital network. It provided for the parallel implementation of two projects: the modernization and development of the Bishkek telecommunication network and modernization and development of the regional telecommunication networks. It included the introduction of the expansion BGTS networks and an increase in KyrgyzTelecom's subscriber lines capacity to 250,000.

This project is linked to a $3.5 million USD loan from CDB for Digital Horizon Transformation Project in November 2007 (see linked project ID#70874).

STAFF_NOTE: The interest rate of 6-month LIBOR in 2006 was 5.490%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as 5.490% + 1.8% = 7.29%. 

The Russian project title is Цель: Телекоммуникационный проект «Цифровое будущее». The Chinese title of the project is 吉尔吉斯斯坦电信改造项目. The original pledged amount for the project is approximately $8 million. However, only $6,594,764.1 was actually received from this loan, but it may be due to the exchange rate difference loss of KGS 1,831,432.12 (see pg.19 of "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2012")

According to the 2006 and 2007 KyrgyzTelecom Financial Reports, the loan carried the following terms: a 7-year maturity period, a grace period of 2.5 years, and an interest rate of LIBOR + 1.8%. However, the 2008 KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report reported a 7-year maturity period, a grace period of 2 years, and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 1.8% (see pg.10 of "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2008"). It appears that the grace period was adjusted in 2008.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: CDB provides RMB 1.7 million credit line facility to RSK Bank OJSC for on-lending to SMEs, trade, and infrastructure (Linked to Project ID#70924, #70938, #70935, #70934, and #70929)
description: On June 7, 2012, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a RMB 1,754,041 credit line facility with RSK Bank OJSC. This loan was intended to be used for various on-lending activities, including the development of small and medium size enterprises, trade and commerce between Chinese and Kyrgyz entrepreneurs, and the construction and rehabilitation of infrastructure in the Southern cities and regions of the Kyrgyz Republic. This facility carried the following terms: a 4-year maturity (the exact maturity date was June 7, 2016) and an interest rate of 6.4%. By December 31, 2013, RMB 1,754,041 had been drawn down from the credit line (see pg.40-41 of 'RSK Bank OJSC Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2013'). This project is linked with a $8 million credit line facility from CDB also signed on June 7, 2012 (see linked project ID#70924), a RMB 2,255,000 credit line facility from CDB signed on January 21, 2011 (see linked project ID#70938), a $3.1 million credit line facility also signed on January 21, 2011 (see linked project ID#70929), a $900,000 credit line facility from CDB signed on August 13, 2007 (see linked project ID#70935), and a $2.5 million credit line facility from CDB signed on August 28, 2008 (see linked project ID#70934). STAFF_NOTE: The project status was coded as 'completion' because RMB 1,754,041 had been drawn down.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China Commits 20 Jeeps to Kyrgyz Interior Ministry
description: On September 20, 2002, the Ministry of Public Security of China agreed to hand over 1.4 million CNY worth of Jeeps and technical assistance to the Ministry of Interior Affairs of the Kyrgyz Republic. The agreement was signed by the Minister of Public Security Jia Chunvan and Ambassador of the Kyrgyz Republic to China Erlan Abdyldaev.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: CDB provides $2.5 million credit line facility to RSK Bank OJSC for on-lending to SMEs, trade, and infrastructure (Linked to Project ID#70924, #70946, #70938, #70935, and #70929)
description: On August 28, 2008, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $2,500,000 credit line facility with RSK Bank OJSC. This loan was intended to be used for for various on-lending activities, including the development of small and medium size enterprises, trade and commerce between Chinese and Kyrgyz entrepreneurs, and the construction and rehabilitation of infrastructure in the Southern cities and regions of the Kyrgyz Republic. The loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 7 years and 9 months (the exact maturity date was May 20, 2016) and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 3% margin. By December 31, 2013, $2,500,000 had been drawn down from the credit line (see pg.40-41 of 'RSK Bank OJSC Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2013'). This project is linked with a $8 million credit line facility from CDB also signed on June 7, 2012 (see linked project ID#70924), a RMB 1,754,041 credit line facility from CDB also signed on June 7, 2012 (see linked project ID#70946), a RMB 2,255,000 credit line facility from CDB signed on January 21, 2011 (see linked project ID#70938), a $3.1 million credit line facility also signed on January 21, 2011 (see linked project ID#70929), and a $900,000 credit line facility from CDB signed on August 13, 2007 (see linked project ID#70935). STAFF_NOTE: The 6 month LIBOR in 2008 was 3.108%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as 3.108% + 3%, or 6.108%. The project status was coded as 'Implementation' because $2.5 million had been drawn down. For precision, the maturity period was based on the number of days between the signing date and the maturity date (2,822) divided by 365, or 7.7 years approximately.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: CDB provides $4 million loan for Osh-Irkeshtam Fiber Optic Network Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#70878, #70881, #70886, and #70889)
description:
On June 27, 2011, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $4,000,000 loan agreement with KyrgyzTelecom. This loan was intended to be used for the Osh Irkeshtam Fiber Optic Network Construction Project. The loan carried the following terms: a 6-year maturity, a grace period of 0.5 years, and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 2.5% margin (see pg.18 of "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2015").

This project is linked to a $8.7 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in September 2009 for this project (see linked project ID#70878), a $4.9 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in February 2011 for this project (see linked project ID#70881), a $2 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in September 2012 (see linked project ID#70886), and a $2.2 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in October 2012 (see linked project ID#70889).

STAFF_NOTE: The 6 month LIBOR in 2011 was .398%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as .398% + 2.5%, or 2.898%. Project status was coded as completion because all Chinese financing was disbursed; as of January 1, 2016, KyrgyzTelecom had a remaining debt of $2,174,756.6. The Russian project title is  Проект «Цифровое будущее. Фаза «Региональные сети» «Строительство ВОЛС «Ош – Иркештам».

According to KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2011, the $4 million loan was signed on June 27, 2011 had a maturity period of 12 years, a grace period of 1.5 years, and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 2.5%. $1,358,520.44 had been received by December 31, 2011. According to KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2012, the $4 million loan was signed on June 27, 2011 had a maturity period of 12 years, a grace period of 1.5 years, and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 1.8%. $1,358,520.44 had been actually received, and throughout 2012, it appears that a combined $2,985,409.57 was retrieved.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China commits 10 million USD grant of communications equipment
description: Summary: In 2001, China sent communication equipment worth 10m dollars to Kyrgyzstan. The head of the communication and information science directorate of the Ministry of Transport and Communication, K. Talypov, said equipment [telephone station] for 10,000 subscribers would be installed in Bishkek and then in other regions. China's ZTE company, and Kyrgyztelekom, a joint-stock company, concluded a cooperation agreement to deliver and assemble the equipment.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China grants Kyrgyzstan 5 million RMB for training civil servants
description: On July 5, 2012 a signing ceremony took place for a Chinese grant of 5 million RMB to Kyrgyzstan for training civil servants. The grant supports a program established by presidential decree in 2011 that would expand opportunities for Kyrgyz civil servants to study and train abroad. The current state of this project is unclear.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: CDB provides $9.3 million loan for CDMA-450 Wireless Access Network Project
description:
In June, 2008, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $9,335,270.7 loan agreement with KyrgyzTelecom. This loan was intended to be used for the CDMA-450 Wireless Access Network Project. The loan carried the following terms: a 8-year maturity, a grace period of 1.5 years, and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 1.8% margin (see pg.28 of "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2010").

STAFF_NOTE: The 6 month LIBOR in 2008 was 3.104%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as 3.104% + 1.8%, or 4.904%. Project status was coded as completion because all Chinese financing was disbursed; as of January 1, 2016, KyrgyzTelecom had a remaining debt of $773,727.9. The Russian project title is Социальный проект «Построение сети беспроводного доступа CDMA-450». KyrgyzTelecom actually received $9,284,735.3.

KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2015 claims that this loan was signed on June 12, 2008; however, the 2009, 2010, 2011, and 2012 reports all say June 9, 2008.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: Chinese Government forgives outstanding debt obligations from an RMB 50 million loan contracted in 1994
description: On August 15, 2007, the Chinese Government agreed to convert an RMB 50 million loan that it had signed with the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic on April 23, 1994 into a grant. This write-off of the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic's outstanding debt obligations effectively represented an act of debt forgiveness. This write-off came after the Ministry of Finance of the Kyrgyz Republic repeatedly asked the Chinese Government between 2005 and 2007 to convert the loan into a grant. Staff Note: The outstanding balance of this loan at the time that it was converted into a grant is unknown.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China grants humanitarian aid worth 5 Million RMB to Kyrgyzstan following riots
description: In early June of 2010, ethnic violence broke out in the south of the Kygryz Republic between ethnic Kyrgyz and Uzbeks. The Chinese government responded with emergency humanitarian aid materials worth 5 million RMB to help restore order and peace following the violence. The aid package contained medicine, medical equipment, food, drinking water, blankets, tents, and other aid items. The aid arrived at Osh airport on June 15, 2010. This donation is captured in the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service in flow ID #76396. On June 30, 2010, China donated a second batch of humanitarian aid materials worth of 3 million RMB to Kyrgyzstan which is recorded in project #73653.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China grants Kyrgyz Republic 5 million USD for reconstruction of south
description: On Apr.7 2011, an agreement has been signed on China allocating 5m dollars in no-strings financial aid to Kyrgyzstan to restore the south of the country. On Dec.13, 2012, the Parliament of Kyrgyzstan ratified the exchange letters between the Governments of Kyrgyzstan and China on $5 million aid for Kyrgyzstan for reconstruction of southern parts of Kyrgyzstan affected during June 2010 events. The multi-storied residential building of 66 apartments was to be built from China’s funds in Osh city under the agreement.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China grants Kyrgyz Republic 5 million USD for reconstruction of south
description: On Apr.7 2011, an agreement has been signed on China allocating 5m dollars in no-strings financial aid to Kyrgyzstan to restore the south of the country. On Dec.13, 2012, the Parliament of Kyrgyzstan ratified the exchange letters between the Governments of Kyrgyzstan and China on $5 million aid for Kyrgyzstan for reconstruction of southern parts of Kyrgyzstan affected during June 2010 events. The multi-storied residential building of 66 apartments was to be built from China’s funds in Osh city under the agreement.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China provides 9.3mil som worth of emergency construction materials to Kyrgyzstan for emergency relief
description: Summary: On October 7, 2014 the Ministry of Emergency Situations received building materials in the amount of 9.3mil som($171.1thousand). The building materials were received through the Chinese grant in the framework of the agreement on economic and technical cooperation between the Government of Kyrgyzstan and the Government of China signed on 13 September, 2005. The Ministry of Emergency Situations was instructed to use the materials while carrying out emergency repair works and other emergency operations in the areas and settlements.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: CDB provides $900,000 credit line facility to RSK Bank OJSC for on-lending to SMEs, trade, and infrastructure (Linked to Project ID#70924, #70938, #70946, #70934, and #70929)
description: On August 13, 2007, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $900,000 credit line facility with RSK Bank OJSC. This loan was intended to be used for various on-lending activities, including the development of small and medium size enterprises, trade and commerce between Chinese and Kyrgyz entrepreneurs, and the construction and rehabilitation of infrastructure in the Southern cities and regions of the Kyrgyz Republic. The loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 7 years and 7 months (the exact maturity date was April 20, 2015) and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 1.5% margin. By December 31, 2013, $900,000 had been drawn down from the credit line (see pg.40-41 of 'RSK Bank OJSC Financial Statements for the year ended 31 December 2013'). This project is linked with a $8 million credit line facility from CDB signed on June 7, 2012 (see linked project ID#70924), a RMB 1,754,041 credit line facility from CDB also signed on June 7, 2012 (see linked project ID#70946), a RMB 2,255,000 credit line facility from CDB signed on January 21, 2011 (see linked project ID#70938), a $3.1 million credit line facility also signed on January 21, 2011 (see linked project ID#70929), and a $2.5 million credit line facility from CDB signed on August 28, 2008 (see linked project ID#70934). STAFF_NOTE: The 6 month LIBOR in 2007 5.376%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as 5.376% + 1.5%, or 6.876%. The project status was coded as 'Implementation' because $900,000 had been drawn down. For precision, the maturity period was based on the number of days between the signing date and the maturity date (2,807) divided by 365, or 7.7 years approximately.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China provided 267 YTO tractors to Kyrgyzstan
description: On July 29, 2011, the handover ceremony of 267 YTO tractors from China to Kyrgyzstan was held in the square in front of the Kyrgyz government building.
name: Kyrgyzstan

title: China Eximbank provides $208 million loan for Southern Power Grid Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project #39619)
description:
On June 2, 2011, China Eximbank provided a $208 million loan to the Ministry of Finance of the Kyrgyz Republic for the Southern Power Grid Reconstruction Project. The Kyrgyz Parliament ratified the loan agreement on June 13, 2011. This loan agreement carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 7 year grace period, and 2% interest rate. The maturity date of the loan is September 21, 2031. 

Then, on August 3, 2011, Ministry of Finance of the Kyrgyz Republic entered into a subsidiary loan agreement (on-lending arrangement) with OJSC Natsionalnaya Elektricheskaya set Kyrgyzstana (OJSC NES of Kyrgyzstan).  The proceeds from this loan agreement are to support an October 15, 2009 commercial contract between TBEA and OJSC Natsionalnaya Elektricheskaya set Kyrgyzstana (OJSC NES of Kyrgyzstan). The Southern Power Grid Reconstruction 

On August 30, 2011, project construction commenced. The project was completed on June 20, 2013. According to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic’s Aid Management Platform, $197.5 million of the face value of the loan (the original commitment amount) had been disbursed as of 2018. 

Project will support the construction of a 500 kV Datka power station in Jalal-Abad (captured in project ID#39619) and the construction of 220 kV power transmission lines in Batken, Jalal-Abad, and Osh stretching for 256.5 km. More detailed locational information can be found within the source "Проект «Модернизация линий электропередачи на юге Кыргызстана»."

Staff Note: The Russian project title is проекта модернизации линий электропередачи на юге Кыргызстана. The Chinese project title is 南方电网改造项目.
name: Batken

title: Chinese Government provides $32 million grant for the Phase I of Agricultural Irrigation Reconstruction Project
description:
On September 11, 2015, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed an agreement providing a $32 million grant for the Phase I of Agricultural Irrigation Reconstruction Project. This grant will be used to renovate irrigation systems in Kyrgyzstan. The contractor for the project is PowerChina Huadong. Implementation of the project began on May 3, 2018, with an opening ceremony at Issyk Lake (the site of Irrigation District #3). In attendance were President Gehnbenkov, Chinese Embassy Business Counsellor Sun He.

The Irrigation System Rehabilitation Project has three main components: construction of a 16.4 km new irrigation canal and a 29.9 km extension of an existing irrigation canal in Batken district; construction of a 21.3 irrigation canal in the village of Kara-O within the Issyk-Kul region; and reconstruction of the 19km Ak-Olen canal in the Tonsky District. Power Construction Corporation of China (PowerChina) is the contractor responsible for project implementation. On May 3, 2018, project construction began. The project will reportedly put 5410 hectares of new irrigated lands into operation, increase the supply of water to ​​22100 hectares of land, and create jobs for 40,000 rural residents.

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 援吉灌溉系统改造工程. Phase II of the Agricultural Irrigation Reconstruction Project was launched in 2019 and implemented by SinoHydro Bureau 16 CO., LTD. The total cost of Phase II is 113.8 million yuan.
name: Batken

title: China Eximbank provides $129.8 million loan for the Two Sections of Highway Rehabilitation Project (Osh-Batken-Isfana 127 km Section and Bishkek-Balykchy 25 km Section)
description:
On December 4, 2012, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed a $129,825,916 preferential buyer's credit (PBC) loan agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC NO. (2012) 54 TOTAL NO. (242)] for the Two Sections of Highway Rehabilitation Project. The loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 2% interest, 9 year grace period, 0.25% management fee, and 0.25% commitment fee.  On April 1, 2013, Kyrgyz Parliament approved this loan agreement. 

The project sought to rehabilitate the Osh-Batken-lsfana road (specifically, a road section from 220km to 232 km and a road section from 248 km to 360 km) and the Bishkek-Balykchi road (specifically, a road section from 147 km to 172 km). More detailed locational information can be found in the source "Kyrgyzstan and the Belt and Road Initiative." Its goal was to significantly reduce trade barriers caused by the poor condition of the roads and help increase regional trade. China Road and Bridge Corporation was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The first loan disbursement (worth $32,456,479) took place on September 30, 2013. Construction began in July 2013.  The Bishkek-Balykchy road segment was completed on July 22, 2015. The 127 km Osh-Batken-Isfana road section was completed on November 10, 2016. The section from kilometer 271 to kilometer 360 was completed in October 2018. 

This project rehabilitated a road from Osh to Batken and lsfana (specifically, the road segment from 220km to 232 km and the road segment from 248km to 360 km) and the Bishkek-Balykchi road (specifically, the road segment from 147 km to 172 km). More locational details can be found at https://www.uca.int/Content/Downloads/UCA-IPPA-WP50_Kyrgyzstan%20and%20Belt%20Road%20Initiative_ENG.pdf.

Staff Note: The Russian name of this project is Реабилитация двух участков автодорог в КР. Balykchi is sometimes also referred to as Balykchy. CRBC reports on its website that the length of the Osh-Batken-Isfana road being rehabilitated is 123.06 km, and the length of the Bishkek-Balykchy road being rehabilitated is 23.66 km.
name: Batken

title: China Eximbank provides $70 million preferential buyer's credit for the South Kyrgyz Cement Factory Construction Project in Kyzyl-Kiya City
description: In 2006 China Eximbank provided a $70 million preferential buyer's credit (PBC) loan to BTA Bank for the construction of the South Kyrgyz Cement Factory in Kyzyl-Kiya City. Turan-Alem Bank (or BTA Bank) used the proceeds of this loan to on-lend to the project company (South Kyrgyz Cement CJSC) responsible for the construction of the cement factory. This loan was also guaranteed by BTA Bank. This project officially broke ground on March 25, 2006, with China CAMC Engineering Co Ltd implementing the project (as the EPC contractor) in partnership with South Kyrgyz Cement CJSC. The plant was expected to have an output of 2500 tons of cement per day and it was slated for completion in 2008. The cement production line was successfully put into operation in September 2009. The plant was officially commissioned on July 12, 2009. Although there was turmoil in the country including riots near the factory, a technical team successfully completed the performance evaluation of the production line and handed over the factory to the owner for management. STAFF_NOTE: This project is the first Chinese government provided a preferential credit within the framework of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO). Some sources indicate that the face value of the loan was $77.8 million. However, for the time being, we use the more conservative $70 million estimate from BTA Bank, which is the guarantor of the loan.
name: Kadamjai

title: China Eximbank provides $129.8 million loan for the Two Sections of Highway Rehabilitation Project (Osh-Batken-Isfana 127 km Section and Bishkek-Balykchy 25 km Section)
description:
On December 4, 2012, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed a $129,825,916 preferential buyer's credit (PBC) loan agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC NO. (2012) 54 TOTAL NO. More locational details can be found at https://www.uca.int/Content/Downloads/UCA-IPPA-WP50_Kyrgyzstan%20and%20Belt%20Road%20Initiative_ENG.pdf.
