CRBC reports on its website that the length of the Osh-Batken-Isfana road being rehabilitated is 123.06 km, and the length of the Bishkek-Balykchy road being rehabilitated is 23.66 km.
name: Lailak

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 50 million grant for Opera and Ballet Theater
description: In 2001, the government of the Chinese People's Republic allocated 50 million yuans to the Kyrgyz Opera and Ballet Theater named after Abdylas Maldybaev. First Deputy Prime Minister of Kyrgyzstan Kurmanbek Osmonov, Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary Ambassador of China to Kyrgyzstan Hong Jiuyin attended the ceremony dedicated to this event. In his speech, K. Osmonov noted that 'this event testifies our ancient and lasting friendly relations with China'. Two years ago, Kyrgyzstan and China signed bilateral agreement to allocate by the Chinese government gratuitous aid worth 50 million yuans, he said. According to him, the aid aimed to modernize equipment and reconstruct the building of the Opera and Ballet Theater, which is the leading and unique cultural building of Kyrgyzstan.
name: Biškek

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 278.73 million grant for the rehabilitation of Bishkek asphalt pavement project (Linked to project ID#52924)
description:
In December 2017, the Chinese Ambassador to Kyrgyzstan signed letters of exchange with Kyrgyzstan's Minister of Economy for asphalting the pavement of 23 streets with a total length of 38km as well as carrying out road rehabilitation. Media reports note that the total project will cost 278.73 million yuan to execute. 

The project is implemented by China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) on a grant provided by the Chinese government. The groundbreaking ceremony for the project was held on May 25, 2018. According to a news report on August 26, 2018 by Xinhua News, a Chinese state media outlet, the project had been underway at that time and parts of the road network had been finished. The same report says that the project utilizes a grant from the Chinese government, and is scheduled to be finished by November 2019. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese title of the project is 中国路桥承建比什凯克沥青路面修复项目. This project should not be confused with project #52924, which is another Bishkek Municipal Road reconstruction project.
name: Biškek

title: Chinese Government provides grant for the Confucius Classroom at the 31st Middle School in Bishkek
description:
On May 14, 2015, the opening ceremony for the Confucius Classroom at the 31st Middle School in Bishkek was held. The classroom was to host small seminars, competitions, cultural training and other activities related to Chinese culture and was fully authorized by Hanban to hold classes. The Confucius Classroom was managed by the Confucius Institute at the National University of Kyrgyzstan.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 第31中学孔子课堂. "Year uncertain" box was checked because it is not confirmed that the construction of the Confucius Classroom was agreed to 2015.
name: Biškek

title: Chinese Donation to Deaf-Mutism School
description: On November 19th 2014, the Ambassador of Kyrgyzstan, Qi Dayu, led the diplomat of the embassy to the Bishkek Deaf School to sympathize with the teachers and students of the school, and presented the children with computers, projectors, daily necessities, and books on Chinese history and culture.
GEO_sources: http://kg.china-embassy.org/chn/dssghd/t1213131.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://old.kabar.kg/eng/society/full/11484, Media Report, including Wikileaks
name: Biškek

title: China opens Confucius Institute at Kyrgyz National University
description: On November 6, 2007, a Confucius Institute was established at Kyrgyz National University with the help of Xinjiang Normal University. It is unknown how long it took to set up the project, but the Institute was running by 2008.
name: Biškek

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 52.5 million grant for the Three-Segment Road Repair Project
description:
In 2014, the Chinese Government provided a RMB 52.5 million grant to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic for the Three-Segment Road Repair Project. The project involved the restoration and reconstruction of three roads in Bishkek for a total length of 7.48 kilometers. 

China Road and Bridge Corporation was contracted to implementing this project, while China International Engineering Consulting Corporation was the project's managing company. Construction was completed on December 9, 2015. The handover certificated was signed on December 18, 2015.

STAFF_NOTE: One of the Chinese project titles, per CRBC, is 援吉比什凯克市政道路修复项目 or 比什凯克三段路项目.
name: Biškek

title: Chinese Government provides a grant for the Bishkek 95th Middle School and Chinese School Project
description:
In 2014, the Chinese Government agreed to provide a grant to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic for the construction of the Bishkek 95th Middle School and Chinese School Project. The contractor of the project is the Chinese Yanjian Group. This project entered implementation on September 3, 2015. It was completed on September 1, 2017. 

Bishkek No. 95 Middle School covers an area of more than 23,000 square meters, with modern teaching buildings, auditoriums, basketball halls, outdoor sports fields and other facilities. The school offers Chinese language teaching and establishes a sister school partnership with the High School Affiliated to Northwest University in China. As of 2019, there are 2100 students studying in campus, and Chinese is a compulsory course for students above the second grade.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese title of the project is 比什凯克第95中学暨我援吉中文学校.
GEO_sources: https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=CEASEN0020170731ed7v000jh&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; http://kg.mofcom.gov.cn/article/zxhz/201601/20160101240611.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://english.yanjian.com.cn/Article/ShowArticle.asp?ArticleID=156, Implementing/Intermediary Agency Source; http://kg.chineseembassy.org/chn/dssghd/t1489230.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://kg.mofcom.gov.cn/article/zxhz/201508/20150801090004.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://kg.mofcom.gov.cn/article/jmxw/201509/20150901103323.shtml, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://kg.china-embassy.org/chn/dssghd/t1669622.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient); http://kg.china-embassy.org/chn/dssghd/t1489230.htm, Government Source (Donor/Recipient)
name: Biškek

title: Hanban provides grant for the Confucius Classroom at the Diplomatic Academy of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Kyrgyz Republic
description:
On October 26, 2012, Hanban signed an agreement for the Conficus Clasroom at the Diplomatic Academy of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Kyrgyz Republic. Hanban funded the construction of the classroom. The opening ceremony was held on April 3, 2013. The classroom included modern teaching equipment.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 吉外交部直属外交学院孔子课堂.
name: Biškek

title: Chinese Government provides a RMB 489.5 million grant for Phase I of the Bishkek Municipal Road Network Reconstruction Project (Phase I) (Linked to Project ID#54376)
description:
On June 20, 2016, letters of exchange were signed by the Chinese Government and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic for Bishkek Municipal Road Network Reconstruction Project (Phase I). As part of this agreement, the Chinese Government agreed to provide a RMB 489.5 million grant for Phase I of the project. The project involves the restoration of 49 streets in Bishkek, which are 95 kilometers in length. 

China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor. Construction began on May 25, 2018. CRBC has completed the first phase of the Bishkek municipal road network reconstruction project, built 7 bridges, and repaired about 95 kilometers of roads. According to report issued in August 2020, CRBC will undertake the construction of he Bishkek Municipal Road Network Reconstruction Project (Phase II) . According to the Bishkek City Hall, the Bishkek Municipal Road Network Reconstruction Project (Phase II) will last for two years and plan to build 5 bridges and repair 60 roads over 70 kilometers in length. Many roads in the project list will be repaired and expanded, and all roads will be equipped with sidewalks and irrigation networks. Relevant repair work will be carried out with the assistance of China. 

This project is linked to project ID#54376, which is a stand-alone project for the rehabilitation of of Bishkek asphalt pavement. 

Staff Note: the Russian project title is 1 фаза проекта «Развитие улично-дорожной сети города Бишкек». The Chinese title is 吉尔吉斯斯坦比什凯克市政路网改造（一期）.
name: Biškek

title: China delivers 5 million RMB of equipment to Kyrgyz National TV and Radio Broadcasting Corporation
description: On May 1, 2004, China delivered and installed equipment at the Krygryz National TV and Radio Broadcasting Corporation. These equipment is worth 5 million Yuan. STAFF_NOTE: linked to #39994
name: Biškek

title: China Eximbank provides $200 million preferential buyer’s credit for Section 1 of Bishkek–Naryn–Torugart Road Rehabilitation Project (9km-272km)
description:
On October 15, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [China Eximbank PBC NO. (2009) 25 TOTAL NO. (87)] worth $199,999,703 for the Section 1 of Bishkek–Naryn–Torugart Road Rehabilitation Project (from kilometer 9 to kilometer 272). The PBC loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 2% interest rate, and a 5 year grace period. According to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the first loan disbursement ($189,999,717.85) took place on July 1, 2013, and the loan was fully disbursed by December 31, 2014. 

This project sought to upgrade rehabilitate a 223 km stretch along the Bishkek–Naryn–Torugart Road between kilometer 9 to kilometer 272 (9km-272km). The Bishkek-Naryn-Torugart road is one of the main transport routes within Kyrgyzstan and comprises part of "Europe-East Asia" CAREC Transport Corridor. More detailed locational information can be found within the sources "Due Diligence Report" and "Km 9 to 272 of the CAREC Transport Corridor 1 Rehabilitation Project." China Road and Bridge Corporation was the contractor responsible for project implementation. A “notice to commence” was issued to the contractor on May 1, 2010. Section 1 (from kilometer 9 to km 103) was completed on December 31, 2012.  

Staff Note: The Russian project title is проекту реабилитации  дороги Бишкек-Нарын-Торугарт  (участок  с  9 по 272 км,  протяженностью 223 км).
name: Biškek

title: China launchs a Multimedia Chinese Training Center for the Confucius Institute at Bishkek Humanities University (Linked to project ID#43845)
description:
On March 22nd 2013, the establishment ceremony of the Multimedia Chinese Training Center was held at the Confucius Institute in the campus of Bishkek Humanities University in Kyrgyzstan. Qi Dayu, the ambassador to Kyrgyzstan, and Kyrgyzstan’s Minister of Education, Sadkov, jointly unveiled the center. Hanban invested in the construction of the Chinese language training center. 

The project is linked to project ID#43845, which captured the establishment of the Confucius Institute at Bishkek Humanities University. 

STAFF_NOTE: "Year uncertain" was checked as 2013 is the opening ceremony for the Multimedia Chinese Training Center. It is clear what is the exact funding year.
name: Biškek

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 60 million grant for the Bishkek Hospital Building Construction Project
description:
In 2007, the Chinese Government provided a grant to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic for the Bishkek Hospital Building Construction Project. This project involved the construction of a six-story urology and ophthalmology center — including an outpatient ward and an operating room — at the Republican Hospital in Bishkek. The total construction area was 5661.6 square meters and it added 150 beds to the existing capacity of the hospital. 

China Civil Engineering Construction Corporation and China Railway No. 5 Engineering Group Co., Ltd. were the contractors responsible for project implementation. A groundbreaking ceremony took place on June 9, 2011. Then, on July 2, 2013, a project completion ceremony took place. The hospital put to use on June 29, 2014. The new urology and ophthalmology  center was opened for use on June 29, 2014. 

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 新建泌尿科医疗楼项目 or 立医院新建泌尿科医疗楼项目 or 吉尔吉斯斯坦项目国立医院新建医疗楼正 or 尔吉斯斯坦国立医院医疗楼项目. The Kyrgyz project title is Урология борборунун. The Russian project title is строительству нового здания лечебного корпуса Нацгоспиталя КР, or Научный центр урологии на базе Национального госпиталя Кыргызстана.
name: Biškek

title: China Eximbank provides $386 million preferential buyer’s credit for Bishkek Thermal Power Plant Modernization Project
description:
On September 11, 2013, China Eximbank and the Government of Kyrgyz Republic’s Ministry of Finance signed a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC NO. (2013) 38 TOTAL NO. (282)] for the Bishkek Thermal Power Plant Modernization Project. The loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 11 year grace period, 2% interest rate, 0.25% commitment fee, and 0.18% management fee.  

The proceeds from this loan were to be used to finance a commercial contract (number D-166-21/322) between the Joint Stock Company (JSC) “Electric Power Plants of Kyrgyzstan” and Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock Co., Ltd. (TBEA). This project sought to install two turbines (units 12 and 13) with a capacity of 150 megawatts at the Bishkek Thermal Power Plant (TPP). As a result, the capacity of Bishkek TPP was expected to increase by 125 megawatts. Prior to project completion, the annual output of electricity at the TPP was one billion kWh. After its modernization through the China Eximbank-financed project, the production of the TPP was expected to reach 1.8 billion kWh. Heat production was also expected to increase from two million gigacalories to three million gigacalories per year.  The project began implementation on April 26, 2014 and it was successfully completed on August 30, 2017. 

However, this project was plagued by controversy. The project was completed and put into production at the end of August 2017, but major failures occurred within less than 5 months of operation, and some boilers collapsed, causing power outages and stopping heating. In 2015, the Chamber of Audits, a state body tasked with overseeing government spending, issued a report questioning why the TBEA contract was not put out to tender when other companies were interested in bidding. Auditors also found that no technical feasibility study was undertaken to evaluate the needs and costs of the project. Nurlan Omurkul, who was chief of the Bishkek TPP, said that he had harbored strong doubts about hiring a company with no track record of building power stations, but that he had been badgered by senior Kyrgyz officials to endorse a decision that he said had obviously already been made. He told the New York Times that “I’ve worked my whole life in power and heating plants and knew all along that the Chinese price of $386 million was too expensive.” Another Chinese company, China Machinery Engineering Corporation, offered a lower bid, $356 million, according to a parliamentary commission. But the Chinese Embassy reportedly insisted that its offer be dismissed. Eventually, the country’s former Prime Minister (Jantoro Satybaldiev), former mayor of Bishkek (Kubanychbek Kulmatov), and former Energy Minister (Osmonbek Artykbaev) were arrested on corruption charges and accused of using their positions to lobby for the interests of a Chinese company (TBEA) in the selection process of the contractor for the project. Prosecutors in the case claimed that rigged bidding and inflated pricing would cost the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic as much as $111,252,797. 

Staff Note: The Bishkek TPP is also known as the Bishkek Combined Heat and Power Plant (CHP).  The Chinese project title is 比什凯克热电厂改造项目.
name: Biškek

title: China grants Kyrgyz Republic 5 million RMB for food and other materials
description: On April 11, 2002, China agreed to grant 5 million RMB (~600,000 USD) to the Kyrgyz Defense Ministry for material and technical facilities and foodstuff during a meeting between Kyrgyz Defence Minister Col-Gen Esen Topoyev and Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary Ambassador of the People's Republic of China (PRC) to Kyrgyzstan Hong Jiuyin.
name: Biškek

title: Chinese Government donates 183 buses worth RMB 50 million to the Kyrgyz Republic (Linked to Project ID#70960)
description: On September 3, 2009 in Bishkek, the Chinese Government donated 183 buses worth RMB 50 million to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic. President of Kyrgyzstan Kurmanbek Bakiyev attended the handover ceremony. The buses were produced by Yangzhou Yaxing Motor Coach Co., Ltd. This project is linked to another donation of buses by the Chinese Government in 2010 (see linked project ID#70960).
name: Biškek

title: China opens Confucius Institute at Bishkek Humanities University (Linked to project ID#54001)
description: In 2008, a Confucius Institute was established at the Bishkek Humanities University with the help of Xinjiang University. The Institute began teaching students the same year. The Confucius Institute is responsible for teaching Chinese and Chinese culture to Kyrgyz students. The opening date for the Confucius Institution was on June 15, 2008. The project is linked to project ID#54001, which captured a establishment project for a Multimedia Chinese Training Center in Confucius Institute at Bishkek Humanities University.
name: Biškek

title: Expansion of Chinese Culture and Education Center
description: On December 18 2015, the National Cultural Education Center of the National Library of Kyrgyzstan held an opening ceremony for the China Cultural Education Center. The Center was established by the Chinese Embassy in Kyrgyzstan. The Ministry of Culture, and the National Library of Kyrgyzstan attended and hosted the opening ceremony. After the expansion funded by Chinese Embassy and reopening to the outside world, it will regularly host a variety of cultural exchanges in China.
name: Biškek

title: Chinese Government donates 161 buses to the Kyrgyz Republic (Linked to Project ID#70964)
description: On December 1, 2010, the Chinese Government donated 161 buses to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic. The value of the donated buses is unknown. The buses were intended to alleviate a shortage of vehicles in Osh and Bishkek, increase the economic development of Kyrgyzstan, and improve transit for the Kyrgyz people. The most of the buses were intended to be used by the Bishkek city government, while a few others would be sent to the city of Osh. The agreement for the buses was made 'not long ago' before late October 2010, and followed up on the Chinese Government's donation of buses in 2009 (captured by linked project ID#70964).
name: Biškek

title: China Eximbank provides $200 million preferential buyer’s credit for Section 1 of Bishkek–Naryn–Torugart Road Rehabilitation Project (9km-272km)
description:
On October 15, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [China Eximbank PBC NO. (2009) 25 TOTAL NO. (87)] worth $199,999,703 for the Section 1 of Bishkek–Naryn–Torugart Road Rehabilitation Project (from kilometer 9 to kilometer 272). The PBC loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 2% interest rate, and a 5 year grace period. According to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the first loan disbursement ($189,999,717.85) took place on July 1, 2013, and the loan was fully disbursed by December 31, 2014. 

This project sought to upgrade rehabilitate a 223 km stretch along the Bishkek–Naryn–Torugart Road between kilometer 9 to kilometer 272 (9km-272km). The Bishkek-Naryn-Torugart road is one of the main transport routes within Kyrgyzstan and comprises part of "Europe-East Asia" CAREC Transport Corridor. More detailed locational information can be found within the sources "Due Diligence Report" and "Km 9 to 272 of the CAREC Transport Corridor 1 Rehabilitation Project." China Road and Bridge Corporation was the contractor responsible for project implementation. A “notice to commence” was issued to the contractor on May 1, 2010. Section 1 (from kilometer 9 to km 103) was completed on December 31, 2012.  

Staff Note: The Russian project title is проекту реабилитации  дороги Бишкек-Нарын-Торугарт  (участок  с  9 по 272 км,  протяженностью 223 км).
name: Alamüdün

title: China Eximbank provides $389.7 million preferential buyer’s credit for Datka-Kemin 500kv Transmission Line Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#40431)
description:
On June 5, 2012, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed a $389,795,000.00 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC NO. (2012) 20 TOTAL NO. (208)] for the Datka-Kemin 500kv Transmission Line Construction Project. The loan agreement was the ratified by the Kyrgyz Parliament June 19, 2012. The PBC loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period, 2% interest rate, 0.25% management fee, and 0.25% commitment fee. The proceeds from the loan were to be used to support a February 23, 2012 commercial contract between The Joint Stock Company “National Grid of Kyrgyzstan” and Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock Co., Ltd. (TBEA). 

The purpose of the project was construct a 288km, 500kv power transmission line from Datka to Kemin and a substation in Kemin.  The project started on August 1, 2012 and it reached completion on August 28, 2015. The official inauguration of the transmission line took place on September 1, 2015. According to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic’s Aid Management Platform, 88% of the face value of the loan (total commitment amount) had been disbursed as of 2015. 

The project is linked to a Southern Power Grid Reconstruction Project (captured in project ID#40431), which support the the construction of the 500 kV Datka power station. 

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 达特卡—克明输变电项.
name: Chui

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 100 million loan for the Kyrgyz-Chinese Paper Factory Project (Linked to project ID#40305)
description:
On April 12, 2001, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a Governmental Concessional Loan Agreement (GCL) with the Ministry of Finance of the Kyrgyz Republic (see "The Supplemental agreement on the Government concessional loan agreement on the paper mill project (July 11, 2003)"). In the loan, China Eximbank agreed to loan the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic RMB 100 million for the Kyrgyz-Chinese Paper Factory Project. This loan carried the following terms: an interest rate of 3% and a maturity period of 15 years (see slide 16 of JICA's "China’s Foreign Aid: Current Status and Future Challenges").

The paper mill itself was the product of a joint Sino-Kyrgyz venture. The plans for the paper mill began in the 1990s with agreements between China and Kyrgyzstan. Construction reportedly began in August 2000 (see pg.18, 27 of "China as an Emerging Donor in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan"). It was completed at the end of August 2002. After it went into production, it experienced a series of disturbances, investigations, and inspections, to the detriment of normal operations. The factory, located in Tokmok, went bankrupt within three years. There had been serious financial wrongdoings and violations of the migration regime by the plant's Chinese employees.

This loan was first restructured in 2003. This refinancing is recorded in Project ID#40305. The maturity date (June 6, 2017) and the interest rate (3%) were left unchanged, but the lender China Eximbank waived the requirement that the Ministry of Finance of the Kyrgyz Republic make principal and interest repayments until September 20, 2007. This amendment effectively represented the provision of a grace period of 4.25 years (see "The Supplemental agreement on the Government concessional loan agreement on the paper mill project (July 11, 2003)"). 

In December 2014, this second-time refinancing for the loan was under discussion. Kyrgyzstan announced that it owed a debt of approximately 9.8 million U.S. dollars to the Export-Import Bank of China on the construction project of the paper factory. Prior to the second restructuring, the Kyrgyz authorities had repeatedly requested that China Eximbank convert the loan into a grant (i.e. write off their oustanding debt obligations for the Kyrgyz-Chinese Paper Mill Project), but China Eximbank declined. Both sides agreed to reschedule the loan a second time and signed another amendment to the loan agreement to codify the terms of the second rescheduling. 

On March 16, 2015, Kyrgyzstan announced that the paper factory has gone through bankruptcy procedures and is evaluating its assets to sell for debt repayment. According to the results of negotiations between the Ministry of Finance of Kyrgyzstan and China at the end of 2014, the debt of RMB 60.2 million will be repaid in five installments before June 20, 2017, with an annual interest rate of 2% during the period.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 托克马克造纸厂项目. The loan agreement number was CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO. (2001) 9 (82) (see "The Supplemental agreement on the Government concessional loan agreement on the paper mill project (July 11, 2003)"). According to the TUFF methodology, only one refinancing was recorded as an individual project. The second refinancing was recorded in this description.
name: Chui

title: China Eximbank reschedules loan for Kyrgyz-Chinese Paper Mill Project (Linked to project ID#71092)
description:
On April 21, 2001, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed an RMB 100 million government concessional loan agreement (GCL) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO. (2001) 9 (82)] for the Kyrgyz-Chinese Paper Factory Project (Linked to Project ID#71092). This GCL carried the following terms: a 15 year maturity, no grace period, and a 3% interest rate.

Then, on July 11, 2003, China Eximbank and the Ministry of Finance of the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic agreed to reschedule the loan and signed an amendment to the loan agreement to codify the terms of the rescheduling. The maturity date (June 6, 2017) and the interest rate (3%) were left unchanged, but the lender (China Eximbank) waived the requirement that the borrower (Ministry of Finance of the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic) make principal and interest repayments until September 20, 2007. This amendment effectively represented the provision of 4.25 years of grace. 

In December 2014, this second-time refinancing for the loan was under discussion. Kyrgyzstan announced that it owed a debt of approximately 9.8 million U.S. dollars to the Export-Import Bank of China on the construction project of the paper factory. Prior to the second restructuring, the Kyrgyz authorities had repeatedly requested that China Eximbank convert the loan into a grant (i.e. write off their oustanding debt obligations for the Kyrgyz-Chinese Paper Mill Project), but China Eximbank declined. Both sides agreed to reschedule the loan a second time and signed another amendment to the loan agreement to codify the terms of the second rescheduling. 

On March 16, 2015, Kyrgyzstan announced that the paper factory has gone through bankruptcy procedures and is evaluating its assets to sell for debt repayment. According to the results of negotiations between the Ministry of Finance of Kyrgyzstan and China at the end of 2014, the debt of RMB 60.2 million will be repaid in five installments before June 20, 2017, with an annual interest rate of 2% during the period.

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 造纸厂项目. According to the TUFF methodology, only one refinancing was recorded as an individual project. The second refinancing was recorded in this description.
name: Chui

title: CDB provides $300 million loan for Kara-Balta Oil Refinery Project
description:
In September 2013, China Development Bank signed a framework loan agreement agreement with China Petrol Company Junda LLC (also known as Zhongda China Petrol Company or «Чайна Петроль компании Джунда») for the Kara-Balta Oil Refinery Project. By the end of 2015, China Development Bank had disbursed $300 million to China Petrol Company Junda LLC through this framework agreement. 

China Petrol Company Junda LLC is a project company established to manage the financing, design, and implementation of the Kara-Balta Oil Refinery Project (also known as the Zhongda Oil Refinery Project in Kara-Balta). China Petrol Company Junda LLC is owned by Central Asia Energy Co., Ltd, which in turn is owned by Shaanxi Dade Investment Group Co., Ltd and Shaanxi Coal and Chemical Industry Group (a Chinese state-owned enterprise). 

Kara-Balta Oil Refinery Project was initiated on September 9, 2013. The refinery produced its first barrel of oil was produced in January 2014. The refinery was officially put into operation on January 1, 2017.  It processes crude oil that is imported by rail from Russia and Kazakhstan, as well as a small amount from Kyrgyzstan itself. The refinery paid the Kyrgyz government $43 million U.S. dollars in 2018, making it the country's second-largest taxpayer. It is also one of the nation's largest employers, hiring over 2,000 locals. 

However, the project has also been plagued by controversy. It was forced to suspend operations in 2015 temporarily after local demonstrations against pollution. Activists in Kara-Balta said residents living close to the refinery were not able to open their windows due to a heavy thick industrial smell and pollution. The plant resumed production in 2016. 

This oil refinery is located in Kara-Balta. Its exact locational coordinates are available at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Neftepererabatyvayushchiy+Zavod+%22Dzhunda%22/@42.7939521,73.8803959,15z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0xb66bf4c6f3e76781!8m2!3d42.7952117!4d73.8900948.”

Staff Note: The Russian project title is  НПЗ «Джунда» or Нефтеперерабатывающий завод "Джунда". The Chinese project title is 中亚能源有限责任公司吉尔吉斯斯坦年产80万吨炼油厂项目.
name: Jaiyl

title: China Eximbank provides $208 million loan for Southern Power Grid Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project #39619)
description:
On June 2, 2011, China Eximbank provided a $208 million loan to the Ministry of Finance of the Kyrgyz Republic for the Southern Power Grid Reconstruction Project. The Kyrgyz Parliament ratified the loan agreement on June 13, 2011. This loan agreement carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 7 year grace period, and 2% interest rate. The maturity date of the loan is September 21, 2031. 

Then, on August 3, 2011, Ministry of Finance of the Kyrgyz Republic entered into a subsidiary loan agreement (on-lending arrangement) with OJSC Natsionalnaya Elektricheskaya set Kyrgyzstana (OJSC NES of Kyrgyzstan).  The proceeds from this loan agreement are to support an October 15, 2009 commercial contract between TBEA and OJSC Natsionalnaya Elektricheskaya set Kyrgyzstana (OJSC NES of Kyrgyzstan). The Southern Power Grid Reconstruction 

On August 30, 2011, project construction commenced. The project was completed on June 20, 2013. According to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic’s Aid Management Platform, $197.5 million of the face value of the loan (the original commitment amount) had been disbursed as of 2018. 

Project will support the construction of a 500 kV Datka power station in Jalal-Abad (captured in project ID#39619) and the construction of 220 kV power transmission lines in Batken, Jalal-Abad, and Osh stretching for 256.5 km. More detailed locational information can be found within the source "Проект «Модернизация линий электропередачи на юге Кыргызстана»."

Staff Note: The Russian project title is проекта модернизации линий электропередачи на юге Кыргызстана. The Chinese project title is 南方电网改造项目.
name: Jalal-Abad

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 697 million government concessional loan for the Aral-Kazarman Section (195 km-291 km) of the Alternative North-South Road Project (Linked to Project ID#40491 and #53585)
description:
On June 15, 2015, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic's Ministry of Finance signed a RMB 697,562,608.76 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK GCL NO. (2015) 9 TOTAL NO. 548] for the construction of the Aral-Kazarman Section (195 km-291 km) of the Alternative North-South Road Project. This project is also known as Phase 2 of the Alternative North-South Road Project (or “Строительство альтернативной автомобильной дороги Север-Юг, фаза 2”). The loan carried the following terms: 25 year maturity, 11 year grace period, 1.5% interest rate, 0.18% management fee, and 0.18% commitment fee. 

The proceeds from the loan were used to support a May 4, 2014 commercial contract [EXMB/KG/NS-05] between the Ministry of Transport and Communications of the Kyrgyz Republic and China Road and Bridge Corporation. The aim of this international North-South transport corridor is to reduce trade costs and connect Russia, Central Asia, Iran, and India. This road section runs from Aral to Kazarman (195 km to 291 km). More locational details can be found within the sources "Kyrgyzstan and the Belt and Road Initiative," "Static.AkiPress," "Alternative North-South Road Aral - Kazarman (Construction)," "Financing the Construction of an Alternative North-South Road in Kyrgyzstan" and "Министерство транспорта и дорог Кыргызской Республики." Construction began on August 10, 2015. As of 2019, this project was still implementation. It was scheduled for completion on April 10, 2020. 

This project has been plagued by controversy. According to a 2018 investigation, former Minister of Transport and Communications Kalykbek Sultanov and the Minister of Transport and Communications at the time (Zhamshitbek Kalilov) may have colluded with the contractor responsible for project implementation (CRBC) to embezzle funds that were allocated for the Alternative North-South Road by China Eximbank. The investigation found the project input costs were inflated by several orders of magnitude — from paying $1.1 per kilogram of cement (while the cost on the local market was $0.07) to paying $2,000 a month to provide office space to an engineer on the construction site. 

Staff Note: The Alternative North-South Road Project (Russian: строительства альтернативной дороги Север—Юг; Chinese: “北-南公路”) is being implemented in three parts and financed with 3 different China Eximbank loans: Phase 1 of the project [Kazarman-Jalal Abad Section (km291-km433) and Balykchy-Aral Section (km183+500-195+486)] is being financed with a $399,989,041 PBC from China Eximbank (Project ID# 40491). Phase 2 of the project [the Aral-Kazarman Section (195 km-291 km)] is being financed with a RMB 697,562,608.76 government concessional loan (GCL) from China Eximbank (Project ID#46350) and a 185,254,119 PBC from China Eximbank (Project ID#53585). Phase 3 of the project [the Balykchy-Kyzyl-Zhyldyz Section (0-183km) was funded by the Asian Development Bank.
name: Suzak

title: China Eximbank provides loan for the Kuru-Tegerek Copper and Gold Resources Development Project in the Kyrgyz Republic
description:
In July 2017, the China Eximbank signed a loan agreement with Kichi Chaarat gold mining company (also known as Kichi-Chaarat Closed Joint Stock Company), a subsidiary of China National Gold Group Corporation, to provide financing support for Kuru-Tegerek Copper and Gold Resources Development Project (or Kuru-Tegerek Copper and Gold Resources Development Project). The amount of the loan is unclear. 

In January 2012, CNGC had acquired the Kuru-Tegerek Copper-Gold deposit. This project is located in in Jalalabad, Kyrgyzstan. After completion, the mine is expected to have an annual processing capacity of about 1.8 million tons, including an annual output of 11,000 tons of copper, 600 kg of gold and 4.6 tons of silver. Estimated annual sales income from the mine is $100 million. The mine is also expected to be the largest copper-gold mine and the largest underground mine in Kyrgyzstan. No sovereign guarantee was provided by the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic for this project.  On August 14th, 2019, the Kuru-Tegerek project was put into operation. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 库鲁-捷盖列克铜金矿项目.
name: Suzak

title: China Eximbank provides $399.9 million preferential buyer’s credit for Kazarman-Jalal Abad Section and Balykchy-Aral Section of Alternative North-South Road Project (Linked to Project ID #46350 and #53585)
description:
On September 11, 2013, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic's Ministry of Finance signed a $399,989,041 preferential buyer credit (PBC) loan agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC No (2013) 37 TOTAL No (281)] for the construction of the Kazarman-Jalal Abad Section (km291-km433) and Balykchy-Aral Section (km183+500-195+486) of the Alternative North-South Road Project. This project is also known as Phase 1 of the Alternative North-South Road Project (or “Строительство альтернативной автомобильной дороги Север-Юг, фаза 1”). The loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 11 year grace period, 2% interest rate, 0.18% management fee, and 0.25% commitment fee. The proceeds from the loan were used to support a July 8, 2013 commercial contract between the Ministry of Transport and Communications of the Kyrgyz Republic and China Road and Bridge Corporation. 

The aim of this international North-South transport corridor is to reduce trade costs and connect Russia, Central Asia, Iran, and India. Construction began on May 2, 2014. As of 2019, this project was still implementation. 

This project has also been plagued by controversy. According to a 2018 investigation, former Minister of Transport and Communications Kalykbek Sultanov and the Minister of Transport and Communications at the time (Zhamshitbek Kalilov) may have colluded with the contractor responsible for project implementation (CRBC) to embezzle funds that were allocated for the Alternative North-South Road by China Eximbank. The investigation found the project input costs were inflated by several orders of magnitude — from paying $1.1 per kilogram of cement (while the cost on the local market was $0.07) to paying $2,000 a month to provide office space to an engineer on the construction site. 

Staff Note: The Alternative North-South Road Project (Russian: строительства альтернативной дороги Север—Юг; Chinese: “北-南公路”) is being implemented in three parts and financed with 3 different China Eximbank loans: Phase 1 of the project [Kazarman-Jalal Abad Section (km291-km433) and Balykchy-Aral Section (km183+500-195+486)] is being financed with a $399,989,041 PBC from China Eximbank (Project ID# 40491). Phase 2 of the project [the Aral-Kazarman Section (195 km-291 km)] is being financed with a RMB 697,562,608.76 government concessional loan (GCL) from China Eximbank (Project ID#46350) and a 185,254,119 PBC from China Eximbank (Project ID#53585). Phase 3 of the project [the Balykchy-Kyzyl-Zhyldyz Section (0-183km) was funded by the Asian Development Bank. Since Project ID#40491 is an export buyer’s credit provided on concessional terms, it is coded as having mixed intent.
name: Suzak

title: China Eximbank provides $389.7 million preferential buyer’s credit for Datka-Kemin 500kv Transmission Line Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#40431)
description:
On June 5, 2012, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed a $389,795,000.00 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC NO. (2012) 20 TOTAL NO. (208)] for the Datka-Kemin 500kv Transmission Line Construction Project. The loan agreement was the ratified by the Kyrgyz Parliament June 19, 2012. The PBC loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period, 2% interest rate, 0.25% management fee, and 0.25% commitment fee. The proceeds from the loan were to be used to support a February 23, 2012 commercial contract between The Joint Stock Company “National Grid of Kyrgyzstan” and Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock Co., Ltd. (TBEA). 

The purpose of the project was construct a 288km, 500kv power transmission line from Datka to Kemin and a substation in Kemin.  The project started on August 1, 2012 and it reached completion on August 28, 2015. The official inauguration of the transmission line took place on September 1, 2015. According to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic’s Aid Management Platform, 88% of the face value of the loan (total commitment amount) had been disbursed as of 2015. 

The project is linked to a Southern Power Grid Reconstruction Project (captured in project ID#40431), which support the the construction of the 500 kV Datka power station. 

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 达特卡—克明输变电项.

title: China Eximbank provides $185 million preferential buyer’s credit for Aral-Kazarman Section (195 km-291 km) of the Alternative North-South Road Project  (Linked to Project ID #40491 and #46350)
description:
On June 15, 2015, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic's Ministry of Finance signed a $185,254,119 preferential buyer credit (PBC) loan agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC NO. (2015) 4 TOTAL NO. (346)] for the construction of the Aral-Kazarman Section (195 km-291 km) of the Alternative North-South Road Project. This project is also known as Phase 2 of the Alternative North-South Road Project (or “Строительство альтернативной автомобильной дороги Север-Юг, фаза 2”). The loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 11 year grace period, 2% interest rate, 0.18% management fee, and 0.18% commitment fee. 

The proceeds from the loan were used to support a May 4, 2014 commercial contract [EXMB/KG/NS-05] between the Ministry of Transport and Communications of the Kyrgyz Republic and China Road and Bridge Corporation. The aim of this international North-South transport corridor is to reduce trade costs and connect Russia, Central Asia, Iran, and India. This road section runs from Aral to Kazarman (195 km to 291 km). More locational details can be found within the sources "Kyrgyzstan and the Belt and Road Initiative," "Static Akipress," "Alternative North-South Road Aral - Kazarman (Construction)", "Министерство транспорта и дорог Кыргызской Республики," and "Financing the Construction of an Alternative North-South Road in Kyrgyzstan." Construction began on August 10, 2015. As of 2019, this project was still implementation. It was scheduled for completion on April 10, 2020. 

This project has also been plagued by controversy. According to a 2018 investigation, former Minister of Transport and Communications Kalykbek Sultanov and the Minister of Transport and Communications at the time (Zhamshitbek Kalilov) may have colluded with the contractor responsible for project implementation (CRBC) to embezzle funds that were allocated for the Alternative North-South Road by China Eximbank. The investigation found the project input costs were inflated by several orders of magnitude — from paying $1.1 per kilogram of cement (while the cost on the local market was $0.07) to paying $2,000 a month to provide office space to an engineer on the construction site.   

Staff Note: The Alternative North-South Road Project (Russian: строительства альтернативной дороги Север—Юг; Chinese: “北-南公路”) is being implemented in three parts and financed with 3 different China Eximbank loans: Phase 1 of the project [Kazarman-Jalal Abad Section (km291-km433) and Balykchy-Aral Section (km183+500-195+486)] is being financed with a $399,989,041 PBC from China Eximbank (Project ID# 40491). Phase 2 of the project [the Aral-Kazarman Section (195 km-291 km)] is being financed with a RMB 697,562,608.76 government concessional loan (GCL) from China Eximbank (Project ID#46350) and a 185,254,119 PBC from China Eximbank (Project ID#53585). Phase 3 of the project [the Balykchy-Kyzyl-Zhyldyz Section (0-183km) was funded by the Asian Development Bank.

title: China Eximbank provides $200 million preferential buyer’s credit for Section 1 of Bishkek–Naryn–Torugart Road Rehabilitation Project (9km-272km)
description:
On October 15, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [China Eximbank PBC NO. (2009) 25 TOTAL NO. (87)] worth $199,999,703 for the Section 1 of Bishkek–Naryn–Torugart Road Rehabilitation Project (from kilometer 9 to kilometer 272). The PBC loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 2% interest rate, and a 5 year grace period. According to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the first loan disbursement ($189,999,717.85) took place on July 1, 2013, and the loan was fully disbursed by December 31, 2014. 

This project sought to upgrade rehabilitate a 223 km stretch along the Bishkek–Naryn–Torugart Road between kilometer 9 to kilometer 272 (9km-272km). The Bishkek-Naryn-Torugart road is one of the main transport routes within Kyrgyzstan and comprises part of "Europe-East Asia" CAREC Transport Corridor. More detailed locational information can be found within the sources "Due Diligence Report" and "Km 9 to 272 of the CAREC Transport Corridor 1 Rehabilitation Project." China Road and Bridge Corporation was the contractor responsible for project implementation. A “notice to commence” was issued to the contractor on May 1, 2010. Section 1 (from kilometer 9 to km 103) was completed on December 31, 2012.  

Staff Note: The Russian project title is проекту реабилитации  дороги Бишкек-Нарын-Торугарт  (участок  с  9 по 272 км,  протяженностью 223 км).
name: Kochkor

title: China Eximbank provides $389.7 million preferential buyer’s credit for Datka-Kemin 500kv Transmission Line Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#40431)
description:
On June 5, 2012, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed a $389,795,000.00 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC NO. (2012) 20 TOTAL NO. (208)] for the Datka-Kemin 500kv Transmission Line Construction Project. The loan agreement was the ratified by the Kyrgyz Parliament June 19, 2012. The PBC loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period, 2% interest rate, 0.25% management fee, and 0.25% commitment fee. The proceeds from the loan were to be used to support a February 23, 2012 commercial contract between The Joint Stock Company “National Grid of Kyrgyzstan” and Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock Co., Ltd. (TBEA). 

The purpose of the project was construct a 288km, 500kv power transmission line from Datka to Kemin and a substation in Kemin.  The project started on August 1, 2012 and it reached completion on August 28, 2015. The official inauguration of the transmission line took place on September 1, 2015. According to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic’s Aid Management Platform, 88% of the face value of the loan (total commitment amount) had been disbursed as of 2015. 

The project is linked to a Southern Power Grid Reconstruction Project (captured in project ID#40431), which support the the construction of the 500 kV Datka power station. 

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 达特卡—克明输变电项.
name: Kochkor

title: China Eximbank provides $399.9 million preferential buyer’s credit for Kazarman-Jalal Abad Section and Balykchy-Aral Section of Alternative North-South Road Project (Linked to Project ID #46350 and #53585)
description:
On September 11, 2013, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic's Ministry of Finance signed a $399,989,041 preferential buyer credit (PBC) loan agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC No (2013) 37 TOTAL No (281)] for the construction of the Kazarman-Jalal Abad Section (km291-km433) and Balykchy-Aral Section (km183+500-195+486) of the Alternative North-South Road Project. This project is also known as Phase 1 of the Alternative North-South Road Project (or “Строительство альтернативной автомобильной дороги Север-Юг, фаза 1”). The loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 11 year grace period, 2% interest rate, 0.18% management fee, and 0.25% commitment fee. The proceeds from the loan were used to support a July 8, 2013 commercial contract between the Ministry of Transport and Communications of the Kyrgyz Republic and China Road and Bridge Corporation. 

The aim of this international North-South transport corridor is to reduce trade costs and connect Russia, Central Asia, Iran, and India. Construction began on May 2, 2014. As of 2019, this project was still implementation. 

This project has also been plagued by controversy. According to a 2018 investigation, former Minister of Transport and Communications Kalykbek Sultanov and the Minister of Transport and Communications at the time (Zhamshitbek Kalilov) may have colluded with the contractor responsible for project implementation (CRBC) to embezzle funds that were allocated for the Alternative North-South Road by China Eximbank. The investigation found the project input costs were inflated by several orders of magnitude — from paying $1.1 per kilogram of cement (while the cost on the local market was $0.07) to paying $2,000 a month to provide office space to an engineer on the construction site. 

Staff Note: The Alternative North-South Road Project (Russian: строительства альтернативной дороги Север—Юг; Chinese: “北-南公路”) is being implemented in three parts and financed with 3 different China Eximbank loans: Phase 1 of the project [Kazarman-Jalal Abad Section (km291-km433) and Balykchy-Aral Section (km183+500-195+486)] is being financed with a $399,989,041 PBC from China Eximbank (Project ID# 40491). Phase 2 of the project [the Aral-Kazarman Section (195 km-291 km)] is being financed with a RMB 697,562,608.76 government concessional loan (GCL) from China Eximbank (Project ID#46350) and a 185,254,119 PBC from China Eximbank (Project ID#53585). Phase 3 of the project [the Balykchy-Kyzyl-Zhyldyz Section (0-183km) was funded by the Asian Development Bank. Since Project ID#40491 is an export buyer’s credit provided on concessional terms, it is coded as having mixed intent.
name: Kochkor

title: China Eximbank provides $200 million preferential buyer’s credit for Section 1 of Bishkek–Naryn–Torugart Road Rehabilitation Project (9km-272km)
description:
On October 15, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [China Eximbank PBC NO. (2009) 25 TOTAL NO. (87)] worth $199,999,703 for the Section 1 of Bishkek–Naryn–Torugart Road Rehabilitation Project (from kilometer 9 to kilometer 272). The PBC loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 2% interest rate, and a 5 year grace period. According to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the first loan disbursement ($189,999,717.85) took place on July 1, 2013, and the loan was fully disbursed by December 31, 2014. 

This project sought to upgrade rehabilitate a 223 km stretch along the Bishkek–Naryn–Torugart Road between kilometer 9 to kilometer 272 (9km-272km). The Bishkek-Naryn-Torugart road is one of the main transport routes within Kyrgyzstan and comprises part of "Europe-East Asia" CAREC Transport Corridor. More detailed locational information can be found within the sources "Due Diligence Report" and "Km 9 to 272 of the CAREC Transport Corridor 1 Rehabilitation Project." China Road and Bridge Corporation was the contractor responsible for project implementation. A “notice to commence” was issued to the contractor on May 1, 2010. Section 1 (from kilometer 9 to km 103) was completed on December 31, 2012.  

Staff Note: The Russian project title is проекту реабилитации  дороги Бишкек-Нарын-Торугарт  (участок  с  9 по 272 км,  протяженностью 223 км).
name: Naryn

title: China sends volunteers to teach Chinese at educational institutes in Osh
description: In 2017, the Confucius Institute began offering Chinese language classes at Osh Technological University, Osh Humanitarian Pedagogical Institute and at the Bilim Lyceum. Two volunteers from China will help teach the language and prepare students who will sit for Chinese language exams.
name: Osh

title: China opens Confucius Institute at Osh State University
description: The Confucius Institute at Osh State University opened in January, 2013 as the third Confucius Institute in Kyrgyzstan and the first to focus on BA programs in the Chinese language. In 2017, it was awarded a gold medal and recognized as the 'best institute' of the year for its contributions towards Kyrgyz-Chinese relations. The award was presented during a meeting of all 625 Confucius Institutes in the city of Xian on December 12.
name: Osh

title: Chinese Government donates 161 buses to the Kyrgyz Republic (Linked to Project ID#70964)
description: On December 1, 2010, the Chinese Government donated 161 buses to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic. The value of the donated buses is unknown. The buses were intended to alleviate a shortage of vehicles in Osh and Bishkek, increase the economic development of Kyrgyzstan, and improve transit for the Kyrgyz people. The most of the buses were intended to be used by the Bishkek city government, while a few others would be sent to the city of Osh. The agreement for the buses was made 'not long ago' before late October 2010, and followed up on the Chinese Government's donation of buses in 2009 (captured by linked project ID#70964).
name: Osh

title: CDB provides Kyrgyz Republic US$4 million for China-Kyrgyzstan-Uzbekistan highway construction (Linked to project ID#40315)
description: On March 13, 2007, China Road and Bridge Engineering Co., Ltd., and Kyrgyzstan Minister of Transport and Communications Suleymanov signed the China-Kyrgyzstan-Uzbekistan Highway construction contract. The contract value is 27 million US dollars. The length of the section is 77 kilometers (Osh-Quelcea) and the construction period is 36 months. In order to initiate the ADB loan, the Kyrgyz side needs to contribute US$4 million in matching funds. At the request of the Kyrgyz government, the China Development Bank would provide the Kyrgyz side with this matching fund loan (captured in project ID#73072). The loan details are unknown. The China-Kyrgyzstan-Uzbekistan Highway starts from Kashgar, Xinjiang, China in the east, passes through the China-Kyrgyzstan port, passes through the south of Kyrgyzstan, and ends in Tashkent, Uzbekistan in the west. The funds needed to repair 258 kilometers of roads in Kyrgyzstan were solved in three ways: one was to use China's 60 million yuan free assistance to repair the 17.74 kilometers of roads (captured in project ID#40315, project completed); the second was to use ADB and Islamic Development Bank loans to repair 121 kilometers (ADB loans to 77-kilometer section construction and the Islamic Development Bank loans to 44-kilometer section construction); the third is to repair the remaining sections through the Sino-Kyrgyzstan 'resource for project' cooperation model.
name: Osh

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 181 million grant for Osh Hospital Construction Project
description:
In 2012, the Kyrgyz Deputy Minister of Health proposed to the Kyrgyz Parliamentary Subcommittee on Social Affairs that the Kyrgyz Government request grant funding from the Chinese Government for the construction of a 150-bed hospital in the city of Osh. Then, in March 2013, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed letters of exchange for the Osh Hospital Construction Project. This initial amount of grant funding that was committed was RMB 42 million, but this amount was later increased to RMB 181 million (or approximately $26.4 million). 

The Kyrgyz Ministry of Health then signed a hospital design contract with (China New Era International Engineering Corporation) Nerin Engineering Co., Ltd. on April 11, 2013. Nerin successfully completed the design of the hospital in August 2014. Shanxi Huashan International Construction Corporation was the contractor for the construction implementation. Hospital construction began on October 10, 2016 and the hospital handover ceremony took place on April 22, 2019. 

The Osh City Clinic Hospital is located in located in Ak-Tilekneighborhood of Osh. More detailed locational information is within the source "Osh City Clinic Hospital". The hospital building area is 12,500 square meters. It is a 150-bed hospital that includes administrative, outpatient, stationary and auxiliary buildings with modern medical equipment and ambulances. 

This hospital is located in Ak-Tilek neighborhood of Osh. More detailed locational information can be found at http://ogkb.kg/contacts/ and https://www.google.com/maps/place/Osh+City+Clinic+Hospital/@40.5201072,72.7729775,13z/data=!4m8!1m2!2m1!1sOsh+hospital!3m4!1s0x38bdac18b61e9223:0xcad2a313e07cd796!8m2!3d40.5223261!4d72.7979275.

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 奥什医院 or 吉尔吉斯斯坦奥什外科医院项目. The Russian project title is ‘Ошская городская клиническая больница’ or ‘Строительство больничного комплекса на 150 мест в Оше’.
name: Osh

title: Guangdong Province donates $30,000 USD for earthquake relief in Kyrgyzstan
description: On 17 November 2015, an earthquake hit the southern parts of Kyrgyzstan. According to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service (flow ID #136927), on 15 December 2015, the Guangdong Provincial Government committed $30,000 USD for earthquake relief. AidData assumes these goods were delivered.
name: Osh

title: Chinese government provides a $7.5 million grant for the Osh-Sarytash-Irkeshtam Road Rehabilitation Project (Linked to project ID#40359)
description: In 2008, Chinese government agreed to provide US$7.5 million in grants (captured in project ID#73074) and US$75 million in loans provided by China Eximbank (captured in project ID#40359) to rebuild the Osh-Sary Tash-Irkeshtam road that connects southern Kyrgyzstan with Xinjiang. China Road and Bridge Corporation was the contractor. The project was completed on December 20, 2013. STAFF_NOTE: One English report presents that the Chinese grant is 50 million CNY, AidData adopted the USD grant amount issued by Chinese reports.
name: Osh

title: China Eximbank provides $208 million loan for Southern Power Grid Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project #39619)
description:
On June 2, 2011, China Eximbank provided a $208 million loan to the Ministry of Finance of the Kyrgyz Republic for the Southern Power Grid Reconstruction Project. The Kyrgyz Parliament ratified the loan agreement on June 13, 2011. This loan agreement carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 7 year grace period, and 2% interest rate. The maturity date of the loan is September 21, 2031. 

Then, on August 3, 2011, Ministry of Finance of the Kyrgyz Republic entered into a subsidiary loan agreement (on-lending arrangement) with OJSC Natsionalnaya Elektricheskaya set Kyrgyzstana (OJSC NES of Kyrgyzstan).  The proceeds from this loan agreement are to support an October 15, 2009 commercial contract between TBEA and OJSC Natsionalnaya Elektricheskaya set Kyrgyzstana (OJSC NES of Kyrgyzstan). The Southern Power Grid Reconstruction 

On August 30, 2011, project construction commenced. The project was completed on June 20, 2013. According to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic’s Aid Management Platform, $197.5 million of the face value of the loan (the original commitment amount) had been disbursed as of 2018. 

Project will support the construction of a 500 kV Datka power station in Jalal-Abad (captured in project ID#39619) and the construction of 220 kV power transmission lines in Batken, Jalal-Abad, and Osh stretching for 256.5 km. More detailed locational information can be found within the source "Проект «Модернизация линий электропередачи на юге Кыргызстана»."

Staff Note: The Russian project title is проекта модернизации линий электропередачи на юге Кыргызстана. The Chinese project title is 南方电网改造项目.
name: Osh

title: CDB provides $4.9 million loan for Osh-Irkeshtam Fiber Optic Network Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#70878, #70884, #70886, and #70889)
description:
On February 17, 2011, China Development Bank (CDB) signed a $4,964,729.28 loan agreement with KyrgyzTelecom. This loan was intended to used for the Osh Irkeshtam Fiber Optic Network Construction Project. The loan carried the following terms: a 6-year maturity, a grace period of 1.5 years, and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 1.8% margin (see "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2015").

This project is linked to a $8.7 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in September 2009 for this project (see linked project ID#70878), a $4 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in June 2011 (see linked project ID#70884), a $2 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in September 2012 (see linked project ID#70886), and a $2.2 million CDB loan to KyrgyzTelecom in October 2012 (see linked project ID#70889).

STAFF_NOTE: The 6 month LIBOR in 2011 was .464%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as .464% + 1.8%, or 2.264%. Project status was coded as completion because all Chinese financing was disbursed; as of January 1, 2016, KyrgyzTelecom had a remaining debt of $1,240,805.4 . The Russian project title is Проект «Цифровое будущее. Фаза «Региональные сети» «Строительство ВОЛС «Ош – Иркештам» (see pg.17 of "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2015").

According to KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2011, the $4,964,729.28 loan signed on February 17, 2011 had a maturity period of 12 years, a grace period of 1.5 years, and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 1.8%. Only $4,963,221.45 had been received by December 31, 2011, however it reported an exchange rate difference profit of KGS 2,491,428,72 (see pg.35-36 of "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2011"). According to KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2012, the $4,964,729.28 loan signed on February 17, 2011 had a maturity period of 12 years, a grace period of 1.5 years, and an interest rate of 6 month LIBOR + 1.8%. $4,963,221.45 had been actually received. It reported an exchange rate difference loss of KGS 181,141.83 (see pg.22-23 of "KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2012"). However, according to KyrgyzTelecom Financial Report 2015, the $4,964,729.28 loan had a maturity period of 6 years, a grace period of 0.5 years.
name: Osh

title: China grants Kyrgyzstan 150,000 USD for earthquake relief
description: On Oct.13, 2008, Chinese government gave US$150 thousand in assistance to victims of the earthquake (happened in Oct.5) in the south of Kyrgyzstan, according to press service of the Chinese Embassy in Bishkek. 'We sincerely share pain and grief of family members of those who died in the quake and wish the soonest recovery to the injured,' said in the message of the Chinese Embassy.
name: Osh

title: CDB provides $25.3 million commodity-backed loan for Rehabilitation of the 50 km Osh-Sarytash-Irkeshtam Road Project (190 km to 240 km Section)
description:
On January 15, 2008, the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic and the Chinese Government came to agreement on a ‘Resources in Exchange for Investment’ Project. This agreement facilitated the Rehabilitation of the 50 km Osh-Sarytash-Irkeshtam Road Construction Project (190 km to 240 km Section) as well as the the development of the Ishtamberdy gold field. The agreement included a China Development Bank loan of $25.3 million. 

A Chinese company called Full Gold Mining LLC was the entity responsible for project implementation. The proceeds from a gold mining investment by Full Gold Mining Limited Liability Company (LLC) in Ishtamberdy were to be used to repay the CDB loan. Full Gold Mining Limited Liability Company (LLC) is a subsidiary of Lingbao Gold Company Limited, which is a Chinese state-owned mining company. This road was completed and opened for use on November 22, 2012. The Asian Development Bank later conducted an impact evaluation of the Osh-Sarytash-Irkeshtam Road Construction Project and the Sarytash–Karamyk Road Construction Project found that they "had a positive effect on poverty reduction and retail trade growth, which was especially evident in the sample of two mountainous districts." 

Staff Note: The Russian project title is Реабилитация автодороги Ош-Сарыташ-Иркештам. The Chinese project title is 伊尔克什坦至奥什路段50公里项目 or 国家开发银行新疆分行吉尔吉斯斯坦“资源换项目”-伊士坦贝尔德金矿和中吉乌公路项目.
name: Alai

title: China Eximbank provides $75.29 million preferential buyer's credit for the Osh-Sarytash-Irkeshtam Road Rehabilitation Project (Linked to project ID#73074)
description:
On December 10, 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed a $75,290,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC NO. 2008 (21) TOTAL NO. ( 61)] for the Osh-Sarytash-Irkeshtam Road Rehabilitation Project (Section from 123 km to 190 km). The loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 2% interest, 5 year grace period, 0.25% management fee, and 0.25% commitment fee. China Road and Bridge Corporation was the contractor. The project was completed on December 20, 2013. The first loan disbursement (of $37,640,315) took place on December 31, 2009 and the last loan disbursement (or $3,764,100) took place on December 31, 2014. Total loan disubrsements amounted to $75,280,699.

This project is supporting the construction of a road segment that runs from Osh to Sarytash and Irkeshtam (the 123 km to 190 km segment). More locational details can be found within the source "Kyrgyzstan and the Belt and Road Initiative." The project is linked to a Chinese grant funded for the Osh-Sarytash-Irkeshtam Road Rehabilitation Project (captured in project ID#73074).
name: Alai

description: On March 13, 2007, China Road and Bridge Engineering Co., Ltd., and Kyrgyzstan Minister of Transport and Communications Suleymanov signed the China-Kyrgyzstan-Uzbekistan Highway construction contract. The China-Kyrgyzstan-Uzbekistan Highway starts from Kashgar, Xinjiang, China in the east, passes through the China-Kyrgyzstan port, passes through the south of Kyrgyzstan, and ends in Tashkent, Uzbekistan in the west. The funds needed to repair 258 kilometers of roads in Kyrgyzstan were solved in three ways: one was to use China's 60 million yuan free assistance to repair the 17.74 kilometers of roads (captured in project ID#40315, project completed); the second was to use ADB and Islamic Development Bank loans to repair 121 kilometers (ADB loans to 77-kilometer section construction and the Islamic Development Bank loans to 44-kilometer section construction); the third is to repair the remaining sections through the Sino-Kyrgyzstan 'resource for project' cooperation model.

title: China donates 5000 USD to Kyrgyz Republic for Landslide Relief
description: On May 20 2003, the Chinese Embassy in Kyrgyz handed over 5K USD to the Red Crescent Society of Kyrgyzstan as a landslide relief. This money will be used to purchase food and other necessities to the 300 families of Sogot village, Uzgen region of Osh Oblast.
GEO_sources: https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=KABNEW0020030520dz5k00003&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks; https://global.factiva.com/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=OANA000020030520dz5k001mg&cat=a&ep=ASE, Media Report, including Wikileaks
name: Uzgen

title: Guangdong Province donates $30,000 USD for earthquake relief in Kyrgyzstan
description: On 17 November 2015, an earthquake hit the southern parts of Kyrgyzstan. According to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service (flow ID #136927), on 15 December 2015, the Guangdong Provincial Government committed $30,000 USD for earthquake relief. AidData assumes these goods were delivered.
name: Uzgen

title: Chinese Government provides $32 million grant for the Phase I of Agricultural Irrigation Reconstruction Project
description:
On September 11, 2015, the Chinese Government and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed an agreement providing a $32 million grant for the Phase I of Agricultural Irrigation Reconstruction Project. This grant will be used to renovate irrigation systems in Kyrgyzstan. The contractor for the project is PowerChina Huadong. Implementation of the project began on May 3, 2018, with an opening ceremony at Issyk Lake (the site of Irrigation District #3). In attendance were President Gehnbenkov, Chinese Embassy Business Counsellor Sun He.

The Irrigation System Rehabilitation Project has three main components: construction of a 16.4 km new irrigation canal and a 29.9 km extension of an existing irrigation canal in Batken district; construction of a 21.3 irrigation canal in the village of Kara-O within the Issyk-Kul region; and reconstruction of the 19km Ak-Olen canal in the Tonsky District. Power Construction Corporation of China (PowerChina) is the contractor responsible for project implementation. On May 3, 2018, project construction began. The project will reportedly put 5410 hectares of new irrigated lands into operation, increase the supply of water to ​​22100 hectares of land, and create jobs for 40,000 rural residents.

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 援吉灌溉系统改造工程. Phase II of the Agricultural Irrigation Reconstruction Project was launched in 2019 and implemented by SinoHydro Bureau 16 CO., LTD. The total cost of Phase II is 113.8 million yuan.
name: Ak-Suu

title: China Eximbank provides $129.8 million loan for the Two Sections of Highway Rehabilitation Project (Osh-Batken-Isfana 127 km Section and Bishkek-Balykchy 25 km Section)
description:
On December 4, 2012, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed a $129,825,916 preferential buyer's credit (PBC) loan agreement [CHINA EXIMBANK PBC NO. (2012) 54 TOTAL NO. (242)] for the Two Sections of Highway Rehabilitation Project. The loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 2% interest, 9 year grace period, 0.25% management fee, and 0.25% commitment fee.  On April 1, 2013, Kyrgyz Parliament approved this loan agreement. 

The project sought to rehabilitate the Osh-Batken-lsfana road (specifically, a road section from 220km to 232 km and a road section from 248 km to 360 km) and the Bishkek-Balykchi road (specifically, a road section from 147 km to 172 km). More detailed locational information can be found in the source "Kyrgyzstan and the Belt and Road Initiative." Its goal was to significantly reduce trade barriers caused by the poor condition of the roads and help increase regional trade. China Road and Bridge Corporation was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The first loan disbursement (worth $32,456,479) took place on September 30, 2013. Construction began in July 2013.  The Bishkek-Balykchy road segment was completed on July 22, 2015. The 127 km Osh-Batken-Isfana road section was completed on November 10, 2016. The section from kilometer 271 to kilometer 360 was completed in October 2018. 

This project rehabilitated a road from Osh to Batken and lsfana (specifically, the road segment from 220km to 232 km and the road segment from 248km to 360 km) and the Bishkek-Balykchi road (specifically, the road segment from 147 km to 172 km). More locational details can be found at https://www.uca.int/Content/Downloads/UCA-IPPA-WP50_Kyrgyzstan%20and%20Belt%20Road%20Initiative_ENG.pdf.

Staff Note: The Russian name of this project is Реабилитация двух участков автодорог в КР. Balykchi is sometimes also referred to as Balykchy. CRBC reports on its website that the length of the Osh-Batken-Isfana road being rehabilitated is 123.06 km, and the length of the Bishkek-Balykchy road being rehabilitated is 23.66 km.
name: Ton

title: China Eximbank provides $200 million preferential buyer’s credit for Section 1 of Bishkek–Naryn–Torugart Road Rehabilitation Project (9km-272km)
description:
On October 15, 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic signed a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [China Eximbank PBC NO. (2009) 25 TOTAL NO. (87)] worth $199,999,703 for the Section 1 of Bishkek–Naryn–Torugart Road Rehabilitation Project (from kilometer 9 to kilometer 272). The PBC loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 2% interest rate, and a 5 year grace period. According to the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the first loan disbursement ($189,999,717.85) took place on July 1, 2013, and the loan was fully disbursed by December 31, 2014. 

This project sought to upgrade rehabilitate a 223 km stretch along the Bishkek–Naryn–Torugart Road between kilometer 9 to kilometer 272 (9km-272km). The Bishkek-Naryn-Torugart road is one of the main transport routes within Kyrgyzstan and comprises part of "Europe-East Asia" CAREC Transport Corridor. More detailed locational information can be found within the sources "Due Diligence Report" and "Km 9 to 272 of the CAREC Transport Corridor 1 Rehabilitation Project." China Road and Bridge Corporation was the contractor responsible for project implementation. A “notice to commence” was issued to the contractor on May 1, 2010. Section 1 (from kilometer 9 to km 103) was completed on December 31, 2012.  

Staff Note: The Russian project title is проекту реабилитации  дороги Бишкек-Нарын-Торугарт  (участок  с  9 по 272 км,  протяженностью 223 км).
name: Ton
