The aid materials, consisting mainly of tents, woolen blankets, cotton-padded quilts, and waterproof canvass, are provided by Daguang Woolen Mill of Aksu, Urumqi Carpet Making Factory in Xinjiang, Beijing Canvass-Making Factory and Beijing Shuangyang Textiles Co. Ltd. The particular job is handled by Xinjiang Corporation for International Cooperation and Xintian International Eco-tech Cooperation (Group) Co. Ltd.
name: Pakistan

title: China contributes USD1 million through UN World Food Programme to help combat hunger in Pakistan
description: The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service records that on 23/08/2017, Chinese government made a contribution of USD1 million for the 'Transition: Towards Resilience and Zero Hunger in Pakistan' project.
name: Pakistan

title: Bank of China provides US$500 million to Pakistan for balance of payment obligations
description: In the 2001 fiscal year, the Pakistani government needed to generate US$3.58 billion to plug the resource gap in the external finance sector. According to an official in the Ministry of Finance, the resource gap would mainly be bridged by rolling over different existing loans and credits currently deposited with the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP). A sum of US$500 million had been received by the Bank of China as a rollover facility to be utilised for balance of payment obligations. Additionally, US$250 million has been provided by the government of Kuwait, US$300 million by the government of United Arab Emirates.
name: Pakistan

title: China Development Bank provides $700 million loan for balance of payments support
description: On September 20, 2016, China Development Bank and the Government of Pakistan signed a $700 million short-term loan agreement to prevent a balance of payments crisis. This loan carried the following terms: 3 year maturity and an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (1.058%) plus 302 basis points. STAFF_NOTE: The interest_rate field was calculated for the 6-month LIBOR in 2016 (1.058%) and adding that to 302 basis points (3.02%).
name: Pakistan

title: China provides $500 million to Pakistan via a SAFE deposit loan in 2009 (linked to #73340)
description: In January 2009, the People's Bank of China loaned 500,000,000 USD to Pakistan through State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE) deposits. The full terms of the loan are unclear, however it reached maturity in January 2017 and was repaid in full by Pakistan. This project is a subproject of #73340, which encapsulates several SAFE deposits made by China in Pakistan. The loan was earmarked for the shoring up of foreign currency reserves, however it remains unclear if it was used for this purpose.
name: Pakistan

title: Chinese Government provides $500 million loan to boost Pakistan's foreign exchange reserves
description: In November 2008, following the visit of President Asif Ali Zardari to Beijing, the Chinese Government agreed to provide a $500 million loan to address an acute balance of payments crisis and help the Government of Pakistan pay for its imports and repay its debts. The deposit was set aside build foreign reserves. It was not to be used for budgetary purposes. The maturity of the loan was 18 months. The Government of Pakistan received the loan on January 23, 2009. Staff_Note: This $500 million loan (deposit) is separate from the one that the Chinese Government provided to the State Bank of Pakistan in June 2008.
name: Pakistan

title: China provides $500 million to Pakistan via a SAFE deposit loan in 2012 (linked to #73340)
description: In June 2012, the People's Bank of China loaned Pakistan 500 million USD through a State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE) deposit in the State Bank of Pakistan. The loan was supposed to be earmarked for the increase of Pakistan's foreign currency reserves, although there is no confirmation that it was used for this purpose. The maturity date was originally set for the first week of June 2018, however China agreed to roll over the maturity date for another year. For this additional year, the interest rate on the loan was set at 1%, although the original interest rate remains unclear. In 2020, Pakistani official sources indicated that the loan had been repaid in full.
name: Pakistan

title: Bank of China fulfills $300 million Loan to Pakistan in Facility Agreement (Linked to project #50486 and #54158)
description: On May 24, 2017, Bank of China signed a facility agreement of 300 million USD with Pakistan in order for Pakistan to continue to improve its foreign reserves holdings and other banking and macroeconomic conditions. The loan has an interest rate of LIBOR 3 Months + 2.93%, no grace period and a 3-year maturity period. Two other loans have been made by Chinese banks as facility agreement to help Pakistan balance its payment account. Linked to project #50486, #54158.
name: Pakistan

title: China Development Bank signs $300 million Facility Agreement with Pakistan (Linked to project #50486 and #54159)
description: According to a Monthly Disbursement Report from the Economic Affairs Division, on May 15, 2017, China Development Bank signed an agreement for a project titled 'US $1 Billion Term Facility' . However, only 300 million USD was eventually committed. The agreement was intended for Pakistan to continue to improve its foreign reserves holdings and other banking and macroeconomic conditions. According to the IMF, the loan has an interest rate of LIBOR rate (6 months) plus 3.02%, no grace period and a 3-year maturity period. Two other facility agreements have been signed by Chinese banks to help Pakistan with its balance of payments. Linked to project #50486, #54159.
name: Pakistan

title: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China signs $300 million Facility Agreement with Pakistan (linked to project #54158 and #54159)
description: On January 17, 2017, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) signed an agreement to give Pakistan a $300 million (USD) loan in order for Pakistan to continue to improve its foreign reserves holdings and other banking and macroeconomic conditions. The amount was disbursed on January 31, 2017. The loan has an interest rate of 3-month LIBOR (1.263%) plus 2.75%, no grace period and a 2-year maturity period. Two other loans have been made by Chinese banks as facility agreement to help Pakistan balance its payment account, captured in projects #54158 and #54159.
name: Pakistan

title: China Development Bank loans $196 Million to Habib Bank Limited in Pakistan
description: On June 15, 2017, the China Development Bank loaned $196 million USD to Habib Bank Limited (HBL), a commercial bank in Pakistan. The principal amount is payable in six installments from December 2017 to June 2020. The interest rate for the loan has been set at LIBOR (1.16%) + 2.45% and is payable semi-annually. The purpose of the loan was to expand Habib Bank's offshore operations and to finance energy projects. According to the financial report, Habib Bank began paying off its installments from December 2017. HBL is the only bank in Pakistan having branches in China (Urumqi) and in Gwadar, Pakistan. The bank has been working actively in China with plans to leverage maximum opportunities of projects under China Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). Staff_Note: The 6-month LIBOR rate is calculated as the average LIBOR for the sixth months following June 2017.
name: Pakistan

title: Donfang Electric Corporation provides supplier’s credit worth RMB 680 million for the acquisition of 69 locomotives (Linked to projects #35120 and #56552)
description:
In 2001, China and Pakistan signed an agreement to supply 69 locomotives and 175 passenger coaches worth $100 million to Pakistan to modernize its railway system. Under the agreement, China Eximbank agreed to provide export seller’s credits to cover 87.5% of the financial requirements of the supplier credits that two Chinese firms would offer to Pakistan Railways (PR). The remaining 12.5% would be arranged by Pakistan Railways. The terms of the lending package were as follows: 18 year maturity, 3 year grace period, and an interest rate of approximately 5%. 
 
 China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation agreed to sell 175 passenger carriages to PR, while Dongfang Electric Corporation (DEC) agreed to sell 69 modern locomotive engines to PR (with 15 locomotives being manufactured in China and the remaining 54 being assembled in Pakistan). China was to provide both spare parts and technology. According to a 2003 China Eximbank annual report, it agreed in March of 2003 to provide RMB 650 million (roughly the equivalent of $100 million at the conversion rate of the time) in export seller’s credits to China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation. Then, in July of 2003, its two export seller’s credits to Donfang Electric Corporation worth RMB 680 million and $4.6 million, respectively, to support the firm’s sale and export of 69 locomotives to PR. 
 
 This project captures the RMB 680 million supplier credit from Donfang Electric Corporation for the acquisition of 69 locomotives. For the $4.6 million supplier credit from from Donfang Electric Corporation, see project #56552. For details of the other supplier credit from CMC involving the acquisition railway coaches, see project #35120. These are linked together because they were signed and implemented simultaneously. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: China Eximbank offers export seller’s credits to Chinese companies that are implementing overseas projects. These companies may, in turn, use the proceeds of an export seller's credit to make equity investments or provide loans to the host government or other entities in the host country. In this case, China Eximbank provided an RMB 680 million export seller's credit to Donfang Electric Corporation, and Donfang Electric Corporation then used the proceeds of the export seller's credit to lend to Pakistan Railways.
name: Pakistan

title: China provides 650 million RMB in supplier's credit for China National Machinery Co to export 175 railway coaches to Pakistan (Linked to projects #56551 and #56552)
description:
In 2001, China and Pakistan signed an agreement to supply 69 locomotives and 175 passenger coaches worth 100 million USD to Pakistan to modernize its railway system. Under the contract, the Exim Bank of China will meet 87.5 per cent of the financial requirements of the export supplier credit basis, while the rest will be arranged by Pakistan Railways. The repayment period for the credit is 15 years. The grace period will be three years and the interest rate will be about five per cent. China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation will export the 175 passenger carriages. Another Chinese Company, Dongfang Electric Corporation (DEC) will provide altogether 69 modern locomotive engines worth 100 million USD to Pakistan within a period of two years. Under the agreement, 15 complete locomotives are to be manufactured in China, while the rest of 54 will be assembled in Pakistan. China will provide both spare parts and technology. 
 
 According to the annual report by EXIM Bank of China of 2003, in March 2003, China Eximbank agreed to provide 650 million RMB (roughly the equivalent of USD100 million at the conversion rate of the time) in supplier's credits for China National Machinery, and later in July, the bank signed a similar deal with Donfang Electric Corporation for two lines of supplier's credit, one of CNY680 million and the other of USD4.6 million, to support the latter's export of 69 locomotives. 
 
 This project captures the supplier credit from China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation (CMC) for the acquisition of 175 railway carriages. For details of the other project, see projects #56551 and #56552. These records are linked together because they were signed and implemented simultaneously.
 
 Staff Note: Note that China Eximbank offers export seller’s credits to Chinese companies that are implementing overseas projects. These companies may, in turn, use the proceeds of an export seller's credit to make equity investments or provide loans to the host government or other entities in the host country. In this case, China Eximbank provided an RMB 650 million export seller's credit to CMC, and CMC then used the proceeds of the export seller's credit to lend to Pakistan Railways.
name: Pakistan

title: China Eximbank provides $153 million government concessional loan for Remote Sensing Satellite System (RSSS)
description:
On May 16, 2017, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a governmental concessional loan (GCL) for the Remote Sensing Satellite System (RSSS) Project. The Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division records the face value of the loan [ID#GCL-2017-08-613] as $153 million. GCLs are RMB-denominated loans; however, the RMB value of the loan for this project is unknown. The terms of the loan are also unknown. As June 30, 2017, no disbursement had been made through this loan. 
 
 The 1,200 kg Pakistan Remote Sensing Satellite (PRSS-1), also called Remote Sensing Satellite System (RSSS), will operate at an altitude of 640 kilometres and will enable Pakistan to meet its imagery requirements in the areas of land mapping, agriculture classification and assessment, urban and rural planning, environmental monitoring, natural disaster management and water resource management for socio-economic development. It will also reportedly be used to provide remote sensing information for CPEC and Belt and Road projects in the region. 
 
 The project contract was signed by China Great Wall Industry Group Co., Ltd. ('Great Wall Company') of China Aerospace Science and Technology Corporation Limited and the Pakistan Space and Outer Atmosphere Research Committee (SUPARCO) on April 20, 2016. According to the contract, China Great Wall Company was to provide a remote sensing satellite to Pakistan in the form of on-orbit delivery, along with a ground application system, ground monitoring and control system, as well as on-orbit testing, on-site support, training, insurance and related technical support services. 
 
 The PRSS-1 satellite was successfully launched from the Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre, China, on July 9, 2018. After successful tests in the orbit, PRSS-1 became fully operational on August 14, 2018. The control of PRSS-1 Satellite was successfully transferred to ground control stations in Pakistan, according to a statement issued by the Pakistan’s Planning Commission. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 将巴基斯坦遥感卫星一号. Another satellite called PakTES-1A was simultaneously launched with the PRSS on the same rocket. It is the scientific experimental satellite independently developed by Pakistan, which mainly carries out technical verification work on satellite platforms. Chinese side was not involved in its development except for the launch.
name: Pakistan

title: China Eximbank provides governmental concessional loan (GCL) of RMB 800 million for the PAKSAT-1R Satellite Project (Linked to Project ID #36953 and #72713)
description:
In October 2008, a contract for the construction and launch of Paksat-1R, a DFH-4-type satellite, was signed between Pakistan's Space and Upper Atmosphere Research Commission (SUPARCO) and China Great Wall Industry Corporation (CGWIC). The communication satellite was to be constructed with 30 year transponders, 12 in C-Band and 18 in Ku-Band, each of 36 MHz Bandwidth. Then, in September 2009, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a framework agreement. Under the terms of the framework agreement, China Eximbank agreed to provide up to RMB 1.385 billion for the Paksat-1R Project. Any subsidiary loans under this framework agreement would bear the following terms: a 2% interest rate, 20 year maturity, and a 5 year grace period. 
 
 Shortly thereafter, on October 15, 2009, Deputy Director of the China Eximbank and the Pakistani Ambassador to China signed a RMB 800 million loan agreement for the Paksat-1R Project (Project ID#43298). China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan also signed an RMB 86.5 million loan agreement for the construction of a ground control facility on October 29, 2010 (see Project ID #36953). Paksat-1R, a DFH-4-type satellite, was constructed by the Pakistan Space and Upper Atmosphere Research Commission (SUPARCO) and the China Great Wall Industry Corporation (CGWIC). 
 
 On August 12, 2011, at the Chinese Xichang Satellite Launch Center, Pakistan’s first Communications Satellite PAKSAT-1R, as part of Pakistan’s Space Programme 2040, was launched. The launch was witnessed by Pakistani Secretary Defence Lt Gen Syed Athar Ali (R), Secretary Foreign Affairs, Salman Bashir, Director General, Strategic Plans Division Lt Gen Khalid Ahmed Kidwai (R) and Ambassador of Pakistan to China, Muhammad Masood Khan. Launched on the Long March 3B rocket, the Paksat-1R satellite has a design life of 15 years with initial goals to provide broadband internet access, digital television broadcasting, remote and rural telephony, emergency communications, tele-education and tele-medicine services across South and Central Asia, Eastern Europe, East Africa and the Far East. The satellite successfully took over the operations of its predecessor, the PakSat-1E satellite leased by Pakistan, in geostationary orbit at 38° East. The commercial services of the satellite were inaugurated by the Prime Minister of Pakistan on November 5, 2011 from the satellite ground station located near Lahore. On November 11, 2011, the ground control center was transferred to the Pakistani side for its use.
name: Pakistan

title: China Eximbank provides $114.28 million buyer’s credit loan for purchase of 202 locomotives (Linked to Project ID#35901)
description:
On December 14, 2009, Pakistan Railways signed a $114,284,494 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement with China Eximbank for the purchase of 202 locomotives. Under the terms of the buyer’s credit loan agreement [ID#BLA0928], Pakistan Railways agreed to purchase 205 coaches from China Machinery Import and Export Corporation (CMC). 
 
 According to a 2012/2013 status report from Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division, the amount disbursed through this loan as of March 31, 2013 was $59.94 million. In April 2013, CMC exported the sixth batch of 202 locomotives to Pakistan. As of September 30, 2014, only $200,000 had not been disbursed through this loan.
 
 Staff_Note: This project is linked to #35901, which is a cancelled BCL for locomotives also signed on December 14, 2009.
name: Pakistan

title: China Eximbank provides $54.2 million loan for acquisition of 1300 freight wagons
description: On April 23, 2002, the China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a $54,236,875 loan agreement to facilitate the acquisition of 1,300 freight wagons by Pakistan Railways according to Pakistan's Ministry of Economic Affairs. Under the terms of the agreement, 420 wagons would be manufactured in China, and the remaining 880 would be produced at the Moghalpura Railway Workshops in Lahore. This loan reportedly carried an interest rate of 5.25%. The Government of Pakistan's identification number for the loan is PR/2003/1300. China State Railway Group Company, Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation. As of April 2005, 130 out of 1300 freight wagons had been delivered, and another 130 were slated for arrival in June 2005. As of 2010, all 1300 freight wagons had been delivered.
name: Pakistan

title: Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries donates USD 10,000 to All Pakistan China Friendship Association for quake relief
description: In October 2005, following the eartquake in Azad Kashmir and NWFP, the Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries donated to Pakistan US$ 10,000. Shan Bao-xiang, cultural counsellor of the Embassy of the Peoples Republic of China presented a cheque of US $10,000 to Main Habib Ullah, Acting President, All Pakistan China Friendship Association during a meeting in Islamabad. STAFF_NOTE: The project is coded ODA, as the Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries (CPAFFC) is officially affiliated.
name: Azad Kashmir

title: China provides 13,000 tents to quake-hit Pakistan
description: Following the flood that hit Pakistan, China donated 13,000 tents as a contribution to flood relief operations. The materials reached Peshawar on 17 November 2005 through a convoy of 163 trucks which had been travelling via Karakoram Highway. The materials were handed over to Pakistan Army: A 13-member Chinese delegation handed over relief goods to military authorities at Besham. 7000 tents were dispatched to the quake hit areas of Azad Kashmir whereas 6000 tents will be distributed in the affected areas of NWPF.
name: Azad Kashmir

title: China grants $1 million for flood relief in AJK Punjab
description: On September 30, 2014, the Chinese government agreed to grant $1 million USD for flood relief in AJK Punjab. On October 15, 2014, China handed over the $1 million grant, according to the Government of Pakistan Ministry of Finance, Revenue, and Economic Affairs. The implementing agency is National Disaster Management Authority (Pakistan).
name: Azad Kashmir

title: China Eximbank provides $143.85 preferential buyer’s credit for Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 1 (Linked to Project ID#71792)
description:
On June 18, 2009, China Eximbank signed two different preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements: a $143.85 million PBC loan agreement for Urban Infrastructure Development (UDP) Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) Package 1 and a $156.15 million PBC loan agreement for Urban Infrastructure Development (UDP Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) Package 2. The first PBC loan is captured in this project. The second PBC loan is captured in Project ID#71792. Their Government of Pakistan loan ID numbers are PBC20091274 and PBC20091375, respectively. These loans were reportedly provided on the following terms: 20-year maturities and 1.5% interest rates. 
 
 The AJK Urban Development Programme (Packages 1 and 2) aimed to provide safe housing, improved city environment, and modern physical and social infrastructure in the earthquake affected areas with Azad Jammu and Kashmir Province. The AJK Urban Development Programme (Packages 1 and 2) involved 235 urban development works (sub-projects) in the earthquake-affected areas of Muzaffarabad, Bagh (also known as Bagh City), Rawalakot within Azad Jammu and Kashmir Province. 90 rehabilitation sub-projects (worth $190 million) were to take place in Muzaffarabad. 50 rehabilitation projects (worth $123 million) were to take place in Bagh. 30 rehabiltation projects (worth $38.83 million) were to take place in Rawalakot. 
 
 As of October 2013, 10 sub-projects had been completed, 47 were under construction, and 178 were yet to be started. China Xinjiang Beixin Construction & Engineering Co. Ltd. and China International Water & Electric Corp. were the contractors responsible for implementation of the Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 1 Project and the Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 2 Project. Both projects and contractors were overseen by Pakistan’s Earthquake Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Authority (ERRA). The projected end date for both projects was December 31, 2016. Both projects were completed, but the exact dates of completion are unknown.
name: Azad Kashmir

title: China Eximbank provides $448 buyer’s credit loan for the 969 MW Neelum-Jhelum Hydroelectric Project (Linked to project #54087) (non-CPEC, IPP)
description:
On May 22, 2013, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a $448 million buyer’s credit loan agreement [ID# CN-BCL-2013-01] for the 969MW Neelum-Jhelum Hydropower Project. Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Company (Pvt) Ltd (NJHPC) is a project company that was created to design, construct, own, operate and maintain the Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Project, which is a 969 MW run-of-the-river project in the State of Azad Jammu and Kashmir. Pakistan’s Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA) claims that it is the largest hydropower project undertaken by WAPDA since the completion of Mangla, Tarbela and Ghazi Barotha Hydropower Projects. 
 
 The project was designed to divert the water from river Neelum through a tunnel. The tunnel intake is at Nauseri 41 km northeast of Muzaffarabad and the underground powerhouse is being constructed at Chatter Kalas, 22 km south of Muzaffarabad. The diverted water will produce electric power by passing through the turbines and thereafter this water will be released back into the River Jhelum, about 4 km south of ChatterKalas. The project was expected to produce 5.15 billion units of electricity annually. 
 
 According to a March 2018 tariff petition that NJHPC submited to Pakistan’s National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA), the total project cost of 506,579 million Pakistani rupees (PKR) is being financed according to a debt-equity-grant ratio of 79:9:11. The total amount of debt financing amounts to PKR 401,416 million Pakistani rupees (PKR), which is roughly equivalent to $3.823 billion. Foreign sources of debt financing include $358 million from the Islamic Development Bank, $181 million from the Saudi Fund for Development, $81 million from the OPEC Fund for International Development, $74 million from the Kuwait Fund for Arabic Economic Development, and $1.024 billion from China Eximbank. 
 
 Two separate loans were secured from China Eximbank: a $448 million China Eximbank buyer’s credit loan (this record) in 2013 and a $576 million preferential buyer’s credit loan (Project ID#54087) in 2016. The terms of the buyer’s credit loan (BCL) were as follows: 20 year maturity. 8 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (0.409%) plus a 2.8% margin, 0.75% management fee, 0.5% commitment fee. The Government of Pakistan used the proceeds of the BCL to on-lend to Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Company (Pvt) Ltd (NJHPC) at an interest rate of 15%. The terms of the preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan were as follows: 20 year maturity. 8 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (1.058%) plus 2.8% margin, 0.75% management fee, 0.5% commitment fee. 
 
 The Government of Pakistan used the proceeds of the PBC loan to on-lend to Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Company (Pvt) Ltd (NJHPC) at an interest rate of 12%. As of June 30 2017, the PBC loan had been fully disbursed and the $191.067 million of the BCL had been disbursed. The EPC contractor for this project was a Chinese consortium called CGGC-CMEC. It was comprised of Gezhouba Group and China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation. 
 
 In January 2008, a letter of commencement was issued to the EPC contractor. Project implementation then began on February 9, 2008. According to WAPDA, 90% of the construction works were completed by March 2018. The project was officially completed on April 13, 2018. The project was expected to achieve its commercial operation date (COD) by December 2018. However, it is unclear if the project achieved this goal. By April 11, 2019, the project had injected 2,400 GWh of energy into the national grid. This project was also plagued by controversy. Transparency International Pakistan alleged that the procurement of tunnel-boring machines (TBM), which were meant to speed up the excavation of the remaining tunnels, resulted in $74 million in kickbacks. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 巴尼勒姆杰勒姆水电站.
name: Azad Kashmir

title: China Eximbank provides $156.15 preferential buyer’s credit for Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 2 (Linked to Project ID#53872)
description:
On June 18, 2009, China Eximbank signed two different preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements: a $143.85 million PBC loan agreement for Urban Infrastructure Development (UDP) Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) Package 1 and a $156.15 million PBC loan agreement for Urban Infrastructure Development (UDP) Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) Package 2. The first PBC loan is captured in Project ID#53872. The second PBC loan is captured in this project. Their Government of Pakistan loan ID numbers are PBC20091274 and PBC20091375, respectively. These loans were reportedly provided on the following terms: 20 year maturities and 1.5% interest rates. 
 
 The AJK Urban Development Programme (Packages 1 and 2) aimed to provide safe housing, improved city environment, and modern physical and social infrastructure in the earthquake affected areas with Azad Jammu and Kashmir Province. The AJK Urban Development Programme (Packages 1 and 2) involved 235 urban development works (sub-projects) in the earthquake-affected areas of Muzaffarabad, Bagh (also known as Bagh City), Rawalakot within Azad Jammu and Kashmir Province. 90 rehabilitation sub-projects (worth $190 million) were to take place in Muzaffarabad. 50 rehabilitation projects (worth $123 million) were to take place in Bagh. 30 rehabiltation projects (worth $38.83 million) were to take place in Rawalakot. 
 
 As of October 2013, 10 sub-project had been completed, 47 were under construction, and 178 were yet to be started. China Beixin Construction & Engineering Company and China International Water & Electric Corp. were the contractors responsible for implementation of the Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 1 Project and the Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 2 Project. Both projects and contractors were overseen by Pakistan’s Earthquake Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Authority (ERRA). The projected end date for both projects was December 31, 2016. Both projects were completed but their exact dates of completion are unknown.
name: Azad Kashmir

title: Syndicate of Chinese banks provides $1.6 billion buyer’s credit loan for 1124 MW Kohala Hydropower Project (Linked to project #54014) [CPEC]
description:
In 2017, a group of Chinese banks (including China Development Bank) signed a $1,642,300,000 syndicated buyer’s credit loan agreement with Kohala Hydro Company (Private) Limited (KHCL) for the 1124 MW Kohala Hydropower Project. Kohala Hydro Company (Private) Limited (KHCL) is a project company (or special purpose vehicle) responsible for financing, designing, implementation, and maintaining the 1124 MW Kohala Hydropower Project. KHCL has a single shareholder: China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Ltd (CSAIL), which is an investment holding company formed by China Three Gorges Corporation on September 30, 2011 in the Cayman Islands to acquire, develop, build, own and operate renewable power generation projects in Pakistan. 
 
 The 1124 MW Kohala Hydropower Project is part of China–Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) initiative and it is being implemented on a Build-Own-Operate-Transfer (BOOT) basis and financed with a 70:30 debt-to-equity ratio. The total project cost is $2,760,170,000,000. A syndicate of Chinese banks is covering 85% ($1,642,300,000) of the total cost of the debt financing for the project ($1,932,120,000). The terms of the syndicated buyer’s credit loan agreement with China Development Bank and other Chinese banks are as follows: 18.5 year maturity, 6.5 year grace period, and an interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (0.6%) plus a 4.60% margin. A syndicate of local Pakistani banks is covering 15% of the total cost of the debt financing for the project. 
 
 The remaining cost of the project is to be covered through an $828.05 equity contribution from CSAIL. To date, a $31.03 million equity contribution has been injected in KHCL by CSAIL (see project #54014). The 1124 MW Kohala Hydropower Project consists of a dam on River Jhelum, with twin 17.4 km long headrace tunnels which will end in the power house downstream on the River Jhelum. The curved concrete gravity dam with a crest elevation of 910 m, will have a maximum height of 69 meters and a top length of 270 meters. The main power station will be equipped with 4 vertical Francis turbine generator units, each of which has a capacity of 275 MW. An additional 24 MW will run on the ecological flow of the river downstream of the dam. The dam site is located in Siran Village on the Jhelum River, about 3 km downstream of the Kohala Bridge. The power plant is located in Barsala in District Muzafarabad. The catchment area of the dam site is 14,060 km2, with an average annual discharge of 302 m3/s and average annual runoff is 9.52 billion m3. The total installed capacity of the hydropower station will be 1,124 MW, comprising 1,100 MW installed capacity for the main power station and 24 MW (2 x 12 MW) installed capacity for the ecological flow power station. 
 
 A consortium of Yangtze Three Gorges Technology & Economy Development Co. Ltd, & China Three Gorges Project Development Co. Ltd was selected as the EPC contractor. Project construction began on September 6, 2018 and the project is expected to reach its commercial operation date (COD) on December 31, 2025. The project company will eventually sell all of the power that it generates to a Pakistani state-owned enterprise — called Central Power Purchasing Agency (Guarantee) Limited — under a 30-year power purchase agreement (PPA). 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The commitment year has been coded as 2017 as the involvement of CDB is confirmed in a EPC Stage Tariff Proposal submitted to NEPRA on June 23, 2017. The Chinese name of this project is 巴基斯坦科哈拉水电项目 (1100MW). As the identity of the other Chinese banks is unclear, the transaction amount is removed, as commercial banks may be involved.
name: Azad Kashmir

title: Chinese Banks loan 945 Million USD for 720 MW Karot hydropower project (Linked to project #54012, #53675, and #54317) (BRI, CPEC, IPP)
description: Karot Power Company (KPCL) obtained a letter of interest early in May 2007 from the Private Power Infrastructure Board (PPIB) to develop the Karot Hydropower Project. In October 2009, the PPIB approved the Feasibility Study Report of the project and in November 2013, National Electric Power Regulatory Authority granted KPCL a generation license to develop a 720 MW hydro-based generation facility at Karot village, District Rawalpindi, in Punjab province. The project is located on Jhelum River, near Karot Bridge. It is the 4th among 5 Cascade HPPs to be developed along Jhelum River. KPCL is 93% owned by China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Limited, a subsidiary of China Three Gorges Corporation, and 7% owned by Pakistan's Associated Technologies. On January 9, 2015, KPCL completed a EPC Tender evaluation and awarded the EPC contract to Yangtze Three Gorges Technology & Economy Development Co., Ltd (TGDC) and China Machinery Engineering Corporation Consortium. The project will be undertaken on a build-own-operate-transfer basis. Construction began in 2015 and is expected to be completed in 2021. The project is designated a priority project under the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor, and a flagship project under Belt and Road Initiative. Project is part of the $2 billion Karot power projects, focusing on hydro and wind power, under the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor reported to be completed by 2018. The project will feature a single power generation complex with an installed capacity will be 720-megawatts with four units of 180-megawatts each. The power structure layout will include a roc-filled dam, spillway, powerhouse, diversion tunnels, head-race power tunnels and a tail-race tunnel end. The project itself is distributed as 80% in Punjab (powerhouse) and 20% in Azad Jammu and Kashmir (reservoirs). According to an interview with the chief accountant from China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Limited, the total cost of the project is 1.75 billion USD, with a debt-equity ratio of 80:20. The project achieved financial closure on February 22, 2017. According to IJGlobal, the 80% debt component was financed by loans from China Development Bank, China Exim Bank, China Silk Road Fund and International Finance Corporation (IFC), each one worth 315 Million USD, along with an additional 100 Million USD loan from IFC. This project records the loans from the Chinese banks. For the equity component, China Three Gorges Corporation invested 316.20 Million USD, while Associated technologies invested 23.90 Million USD (captured in #54012). Sinosure provided loan insurance for the Chinese bank loans. The IMF puts the loan interest rate at 5.11%, with a maturity period of 12 years and a grace period of 5 years. It was additionally reported that there is a 30-year concession period. On April 20, 2015, China's $40 billion Silk Road Fund signed a memorandum of understanding with China Three Gorges Corporation and the PPIB on the development of Pakistan's hydropower project, pledging to finance the project through equity investment in China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Limited, and participating in a loan syndicate made up of Chinese banks. As of 2017, the Silk Road Fund has disbursed 1.65 Billion USD. The Silk Road Fund also owns 15% of China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Company as of 2017. On March 14, 2017, IFC announced that it will invest $100 million in the Karot Hydropower Project, and reported that it acquired a 15% stake in China Three Gorges South Asia Investment Limited in 2015. IFC stated that this investment is its first major collaboration with the China Export Import Bank, China Development Bank, and Silk Road Fund. The first unit is projected to begin power generation in 2020, coming online prior to its deadline. The Chinese firm in charge of the project will hand over this project to Pakistani government after the 30-year concession period has ended. Staff_Note: This project is linked to two China Development Bank loans for Karot Wind Power projects under the same $2 billion USD deal (captured in #53675 and #54317).
name: Azad Kashmir

title: China Eximbank provides $576 million preferential buyer's credit for the 969 MW Neelum-Jhelum Hydroelectric Project (Linked to project #35266) (non-CPEC, IPP)
description:
On September 29, 2016, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a $576 million preferential buyer’s credit loan agreement for the Neelum-Jhelum Hydropower Project. Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Company (Pvt) Ltd (NJHPC) is a project company that was created to design, construct, own, operate and maintain the Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Project, which is a 969 MW run-of-the-river project in the State of Azad Jammu and Kashmir. Pakistan’s Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA) claims that it is the largest hydropower project undertaken by WAPDA since the completion of Mangla, Tarbela and Ghazi Barotha Hydropower Projects. 
 
 The project was designed to divert the water from river Neelum through a tunnel. The tunnel intake is at Nauseri 41 km northeast of Muzaffarabad and the underground powerhouse is being constructed at Chatter Kalas, 22 km south of Muzaffarabad. The diverted water will produce electric power by passing through the turbines and thereafter this water will be released back into the River Jhelum, about 4 km south of Chatter Kalas. The project was expected to produce 5.15 billion units of electricity annually. According to a March 2018 tariff petition that NJHPC submitted to Pakistan’s National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA), the total project cost of 506,579 million Pakistani rupees (PKR) was financed according to a debt-equity-grant ratio of 79:9:11. The total amount of debt financing amounts to PKR 401,416 million Pakistani rupees (PKR), which is roughly equivalent to $3.823 billion. Foreign sources of debt financing include $358 million from the Islamic Development Bank, $181 million from the Saudi Fund for Development, $81 million from the OPEC Fund for International Development, $74 million from the Kuwait Fund for Arabic Economic Development, and $1.024 billion from China Eximbank. 
 
 Two separate loans were secured from China Eximbank: a $448 million China Eximbank buyer’s credit loan (this record) in 2013 and a $576 million preferential buyer’s credit loan (Project ID#54087) in 2016. The terms of the buyer’s credit loan (BCL) were as follows: 20 year maturity. 8 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (0.409%) plus a 2.8% margin, 0.75% management fee, 0.5% commitment fee. The Government of Pakistan used the proceeds of the BCL to on-lend to Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Company (Pvt) Ltd (NJHPC) at an interest rate of 15%. The terms of the preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan were as follows: 20 year maturity. 8 year grace period, interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (1.058%) plus 2.8% margin, 0.75% management fee, 0.5% commitment fee. The Government of Pakistan used the proceeds of the PBC loan to on-lend to Neelum Jhelum Hydropower Company (Pvt) Ltd (NJHPC) at an interest rate of 12%. As of June 30, 2017, the PBC loan had been fully disbursed and the $191.067 million of the BCL had been disbursed. 
 
 The EPC contractor for this project was a Chinese consortium called CGGC-CMEC. It was comprised of Gezhouba Group and China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation. In January 2008, a letter of commencement was issued to the EPC contractor. Project implementation then began on February 9, 2008. According to WAPDA, 90% of the construction works were completed by March 2018. The project was officially completed on April 13, 2018. The project was expected to achieve its commercial operation date (COD) by December 2018. However, it is unclear if the project achieved this goal. By April 11, 2019, the project had injected 2,400 GWh of energy into the national grid. This project was also plagued by controversy. Transparency International Pakistan alleged that the procurement of tunnel-boring machines (TBM), which were meant to speed up the excavation of the remaining tunnels, resulted in $74 million in kickbacks. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 巴尼勒姆杰勒姆水电站.
name: Azad Kashmir

title: China grants Pakistan 100 thousand USD for flood relief
description: On 15 February 2005, the Chinese government donated 100,000 USD to Pakistan as a contribution to flood relief operations. On behalf of the Chinese government, Chinese ambassador Zhang Chunxiang transferred a check to Pakistani Cabinet Secretary Ejaz Rahim in Islamabad.
name: Baluchistan

title: China grants Pakistan 5 million USD for drought relief (Linked to #35075)
description: In response to a drought crisis, China granted the Pakistani government 5 million USD for drought relief effort in Sindh and Balochistan.
name: Baluchistan

title: China gives grant of US$50000 to Pakistan for the drought victims of Sind and Baluchistan (Linked to #39087)
description: China has donated US$50000 to Pakistan for the drought victims of Sind and Baluchistan. A check was presented on 23 May 2000 to the secretary-general of Pakistan Red Crescent Society by the Chinese charge d'affaires in Pakistan, Mr Lian Cheng.
name: Baluchistan

title: Chinese Government provides $1.5 million cash grant for earthquake relief activities in Balochistan (Linked to Project ID#54186)
description: On September 25, 2013, the Chinese Government announced that it would provide emergency relief assistance to the Pakistani government in the aftermath of an earthquake in Balochistan. It agreed to provide a $1.5 million cash grant and supplies worth RMB 30 million (captured in Project ID#54186). The handover certificate for the $1.5 million cash grant was issued on November 29, 2013 and the funds were transferred to an account designated by the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP).
name: Baluchistan

title: China donates USD 1 million to Pakistan for quake relief
description: On 30 October 2008 China donated 1 million US dollars to Pakistan as a contribution to quake relief operations. Chinese ambassador to Pakistan Luo Zhaohui presented a check to Pakistani President Asif Ali Zardari in the presidential house.
name: Baluchistan

title: Chinese bank syndicate provides $1.496 billion loan for 2×660MW coal fired units and a dedicated jetty terminal to import coal in Balochistan Province
description:
On October 24, 2017, China Power Hub Generation Company (Pvt.) Ltd. (CPHGC) signed a $1,496,000,000 syndicated loan agreement with a consortium of banks — including China Development Bank (lead arranger), the Export-Import Bank of China (co-lead arranger), the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, China Construction Bank Corporation, and Bank of Communications Co. Limited — for the construction of 2×660MW coal fired units and a dedicated jetty terminal to import coal at Hub, Mouza Kund, Tehsil Gadani, Lasbella District, and Balochistan Province. Each bank reportedly contributed equal amount to the loan syndicate (~$300 million each). 
 
 The estimated terms of the syndicated loan (based on CPHGC's upfront tariff application to Pakistan’s National Electric Power Regulatory Authority) are as follows: 14 year maturity, 4 year grace period, and 4.95% interest rate (the 6-month LIBOR rate of 0.45% plus 450 basis points). The total cost of this independent power project (IPP) is $1.995 billion and it is being financed according to a 75:25 debt-to-equity ratio. CPHGC is a project company and joint venture of China Power International Holding Ltd (CPIH) and the Hub Power Company Limited (HUBCO) that was established to finance, design, and implement this 1320 MW imported coal based power project. CPIH has a 74% ownership stake and HUBCO has a 26% ownership stake in CPHGC. CPHGC was granted a generation license by Pakistan’s National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA) on September 8, 2016. 
 
 The term of the license is 30 years from the date of the commencement of commercial operations. CPHGC also submitted an application for an upfront tariff determination with NEPRA, which was approved on February 12, 2016. Then, on January 25, 2017, the Implementation Agreement (IA) and Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) were signed. Northwest Electric Power Design Institute Co. Ltd. (NWEPDI) and Tianjin Electric Power Construction Company Limited are the EPC contractors for this projectA groundbreaking ceremony took place on March 21, 2017, and on April 10, 2018, CPHGC entered into Operation and Maintenance (O&M) contract with a consortium that consists of CEEC Tianjin (Pakistan) Electric Power Construction (Private) Limited, China Energy Engineering Group, Tianjin Electric Power Construction Company Limited, and China Energy Engineering Group Science and Technology Development Company Limited to provide operation and maintenance service for the coal-fired electric power generation plant. The project reached its commercial operation date (COD) on August 17, 2019. Its expected commercial operation date was August 31, 2018. It is expected that this power plant will provide 9 billion kWh electricity to Pakistan’s national grid each year, thereby meeting the electricity needs of 4 million Pakistani households. 
 
 Staff Note: CPIH is a wholly-owned subsidiary of State Power Investment Corporation (SPIC), which is one of the top five electricity producers in China. CPIH mainly engages in the development, construction, operation, overseas investment and financing, and capital operation of power generation projects. Hubco is the largest Independent Power Producer (IPP) in Pakistan, with total power generation capacity of over 1600 MW. The company’s assets include a residual fuel oil-fired thermal plant situated at Mouza Kund, Hub, which supplies the national grid. 
 
 Staff Note: The Chinese name of this project is 巴基斯坦中电胡布燃煤发电项目（1320MW)
name: Kalat

title: CDB provides $54 million loan for Duddar Lead-Zinc Mine Project
description:
On March 22, 2002, China Metallurgical Construction Group Corp (MCC) signed an Memorandum of Understanding with Pakistan Minerals Development Company (PMDC) on the project development. On November 3, 2003, an agreement for the development of the Duddar zinc-lead project was signed, with a total investment worth US$72.64 million. The agreement stipulated that PMDC would be responsible for the construction of external roads leading to the project site. In addition, the Pakistan government would convert the Duddar zinc-lead mine area into an export processing zone (EPZ). 
 
 On March 5, 2004, PMDC transferred its stake in the contract to MCC Resources Development Limited (MRD), which is a wholly owned subsidiary of MCC, authorized to register in Pakistan by the Ministry of Commerce of PRC. In order to manage the project more efficiently, MCC entered into an agreement with several other Chinese companies. With the approval of the Ministry of Commerce of PRC, MCC Duddar Minerals Development Company Pvt. Limited (MDMD), a joint venture of the 3 companies, was registered on November 23, 2004. The consortium was composed of MCC (51%), Hunan Zhuzhou Non-ferrous Metals Smelter Co. Ltd. (34%), and Hunan Huangshaping Lead and Zinc Mine Co. (15%). 
 
 On January 6, 2005, the company signed a financing agreement with China Development Bank. The consortium signed a contract to borrow US$54 million from the China Development Bank to finance the development of the Duddar lead and zinc mine in Pakistan. The loan was expected to fund 80% of the total investment of $72.6 million in the project. The offer has been made by a visiting delegation of China Development Bank, headed by its Provincial Chief, Mei Jia Xiang in a meeting with Managing Director, Pakistan Mineral Development Corporation (PMDC) Brig. Khalid Sajjad Khokhar in Islamabad.
 
 The Duddar project has a designed annual processing capacity of 660,000 tons of ores, including mining and concentration processes. Its final products will be zinc and lead concentrates. The mines have a depth limit of 900 meters underground. The project officially started construction in January 2005 and will continue operations until 2023. Multiple sources refer to the project as being completed.
 
 Staff_Note: The Duddar Lead-Zinc Mine Project is located in Duddar in the Kanraj Valley of Balochistan, which is approximately 135 km north of Karachi, the largest city in Pakistan. Location: 26°13'24"N, 66°50'11"E. The mining area is approximately 1,500 acres.
name: Kalat

title: [CPEC] China funds the Khuzdar-Basima Road in Pakistan
description: In 2016, the Pakistan-China Joint Cooperation Committee approved the Khuzdar-Basima Road project costing USD$200 million. The 110 kilometers long road project includes objectives such as the road contributing to the economic and social development of Balochistan, serving mineral rich Sandak and Rekodek areas, and linking the National Highways N-85, N-25 and Motorway M-8. However, the other two sources report the cost to be USD$80 million. It is possible that the $80m is contributed by China but this likelihood cannot be confirmed. During January 2017, it was reported that Pakistan's Under Communication Division contributed 310 million Pakistani rupee towards the 110 km section. In December 2017, the funding from China was temporarily paused. After that, no further information can be found about the relaunch of the project. CPEC website confirms the estimated cost of US$80 million. It also suggests that reports on Feasibility and PC-I have been completed and LOI forwarded to Chinese side. According to CPEC website as of Nov 2018, procedural formalities to be completed shortly. The Pakistan Ministry of Finance economic survey for 2018 reports the project is planned to be completed by 2020. A Pakistani government Finance Ministry annual project status report in May from 2017-18 does not specify the total loan commitment, but records that in May from 2017-18 China fulfilled part of the loan at the amount of 11.374 million USD, meaning the project is likely to have started or at least committed.
name: Kalat

title: China Eximbank provides $32 million concessional loan for Gwadar Port Free Zone and Export Processing Zone Construction Project
description: In 2016, China Eximbank provided a $32 million government concessional loan (GCL) for the Gwadar Port Free Zone and Export Processing Zone Construction Project. The Gwadar Port Free Zone and Export Processing Zone Construction Project involved infrastructure construction around the Gwadar Port and the establishment of an economic free zone. As of November 2018, the following areas had been set aside for this project: 2,280 acres for the Gwadar port free zone; 3,000 acres for the GIEDA industrial zone; and 1,000 acres for the EPZA export processing zone. The Zone is to be operated by China Overseas Port Holding Company (COPHCL). This project was initiated on September 7, 2016 and was was completed and inaugurated on January 29, 2018.
name: Makran

title: Chinese Government provides $230 million grant for New Gwadar International Airport Construction Project
description:
In January 2015, the Chinese Government announced that it would soon begin construction of the New Gwadar International Airport in Pakistan. The Government of Pakistan then allocated 3000 acres of land 26km to the northwest of the current Gwadar International Airport for the construction of the new airport. On May 13, 2017, the Chinese Government signed letters of exchange for a $230 million grant for the construction of the New Gwadar International Airport. Upon completion, the airport will reportedly be capable of handling a combination of ATR 72, Airbus A-380, Boeing B-737 and Boeing B-747 for domestic and international routes. 
 
 Covering an area of 18 square km, the new airport will also be the second largest airport in Pakistan. The airport is located in Gurandani area, some 26 km northeast of Gwadar city of Balochistan province. The contractor responsible for project implementation is China Airport Construction Group Corporation (CACC). The groundbreaking ceremony for the New Gwadar International Airport took place on March 29, 2019. Construction then began on October 31, 2019. Upon completion, the airport will link Pakistan's fast-rising southwest Gwadar port city with the rest of the world. The airport is located in Gurandani area, some 26 km northeast of Gwadar city of Balochistan province. 
 
 Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 巴基斯坦瓜达尔新国际机场. China’s MOFCOM reports that this project is China's largest development assistance project in Pakistan.
name: Makran

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 240 million grant for China-Pakistan Friendship Hospital Construction Project in Gwadar (Linked to project ID#72695)
description: In 2015, the Chinese Government agreed to fund a 300-bed China-Pakistan friendship hospital with a cost of Rs.9.96 billion in Gwadar district, Balochistan. The project involved the construction of a state-of-the-art medical facility in the port city of Gwadar. After completing a feasibility study (recorded in project #72695), China agreed to RMB 240 million of grant financing for the project. The project is to be completed in three stages - the first was simply the existing 50 bed hospital, the second is an expansion to 150 beds, and the third involves a final expansion to 300 beds. The 150 bed upgrade was completed on December 16, 2019, when an inauguration ceremony was held. The construction contract was awarded to Gansu Provincial Construction Investment (Holdings) Group Corporation, and construction was overseen by the Gwadar Development Authority (GDA). STAFF_NOTE: The construction project is linked to a feasibility study project before the beginning of hospital construction, which was captured by project ID#72695.
name: Makran

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 20 million grant to address climate change in the Gwadar Region
description: On April 20, 2015, the Chinese Government signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to provide an RMB 20 million grant to the Government of Pakistan to address climate change in the Gwadar Region. On December 29, 2016, a supplementary agreement was signed, committing the grant agreement to Pakistan. The project has almost likely entered implementation since its RMB 20 million value is listed the 'utilized' rather than 'unutilized' column of a table of Chinese Government grant-financed projects published by Government of Pakistan's Economic Affairs Division.
name: Makran

title: China Eximbank provides a RMB 503 million government concessional loan for Gwadar Port Project (Linked to #38995, #35124, #72688, and #72689)
description: During the visit of Chinese Prime Minister Zhu Rongji to Pakistan in May 2001, the Gwadar port was a key item of discussion. Pakistani Finance Minister Shaukat Aziz said China has agreed to help fund the construction of phase one of the $250 million Gwadar Port project. China provided $248 million for the project in various forms of funding. On March 24, 2002, China Eximbank committed an RMB 502,690,200 government concessional loan (GCL), which was captured by project ID#38996. Further funding was provided through a $60 million China Eximbank buyer's credit loan (BCL) captured by project ID#38995, a $31 million Chinese Government grant captured by project ID#35124, an $18 million Chinese Government grant captured by project ID#72689, and an interest-free loan from the Chinese Government worth $31 million captured by project ID#72688. Gwadar, located about 350 kilometers west of Karachi on the Arabian Sea coast, is considered the nearest warm water port for the Central Asian states for their trade with Europe, East Asia, and the Americas. Prime Minister Shaukat Aziz inaugurated the deep-sea port on March 20, 2007. The Gwadar Port was taken over by China Overseas Ports Holding Company Limited (COPHC) on May 16, 2013, for 40 years. STAFF_NOTE: One source suggests that the face value of the BCL may have been downwardly revised to $22.26 million (at a 3% interest rate) after the initial BCL agreement was signed. This project is located at Gwadar Port. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Gwadar+Sea+Port/@25.1104955,62.339648,15z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0xc8622abf840e0dac!8m2!3d25.1104955!4d62.339648 and https://latitude.to/articles-by-country/pk/pakistan/8128/gwadar-port.
name: Makran

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 28.6 million grant for Gwadar Smart Port City Master Plan
description:
On September 9, 2016, the Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan signed letters of exchange for the development of Gwadar Smart Port City Master Plan that would transform the existing city into a modern port of international standards and a smart, sustainable city that can drive local, national and regional growth in the coming decades. The Chinese Government committed RMB 28.6 million in grant funding for this project. A contract agreement was then signed on May 15, 2017. Fourth Harbour Design Institute (FHDI) is the contractor responsible for implementation of the Gwadar Smart City Master Plan. 
 
 The company began working on the project plan in 2017, and it was sent to the federal government for approval after completion in December 2018. FHDI reportedly recommended the application of Chinese city of Shenzen’s model laws and regulations over the entire area of 1,201 square kms in Gwadar Special Economic District (SED) instead of Pakistani laws and regulations. In January 2019, local media sources reported that Chinese companies were frustrated over delays in the final approval of the plan by Pakistan's government. These companies reportedly warned that increased costs due to these delays would be the responsibility of the Government of Pakistan
name: Makran

title: Chinese Government provides $140 million interest-free loan for Gwadar Eastbay Expressway Construction Project
description:
Gwadar deep-sea port is currently connected by a narrow 16 feet wide thoroughfare of Gwadar town at the West-Bay. The Gwadar Eastbay Expressway will consist of a new 6-lane expressway and a 30 meters-wide railway corridor that will connect Gwadar Port to Makran Coastal Highway (or National Highway N–10 or Makran沿海公路（N-10). The project is being developed as part of the 'Early Harvest' scheme of China Pakistan Economic Corridor, and it is part of a wider 170.667 billion Pakistani rupee ($1.6 billion) development package for the city and Port of Gwadar. 
 
 On May 13, 2017, China’s Ministry of Commerce signed an interest-free loan agreement worth $140 million (or 14.7 billion Pakistani rupees) for the construction of Gwadar East Bay Expressway. China Communications Construction Engineering Company is the contractor responsible for project implementation. Its work is being overseen by the Gwadar Port Authority. 
 
 On November 22, 2017, the construction of the expressway began. As of November 2018, project completion was expected to occur by October 2020.
 
 Staff Note: Different sources record different financial amounts for this project: Pakistani Ministry of Finance Economic Affairs Division yearbook reports the project has a total interest-free loan of $168 million. The Shahid Javed Burki Institute of Public Policy at NetSol records a committment amount amount of US$141 million. The 2016 Government of Pakistan Bond Prospectus lists the estimated project cost as $140 million. We use the most conservative of these estimates for the time being.
name: Makran

title: China government grants USD 31 million for Pakistan Gwadar Port Project (Linked to #38995, #38996, #72688, and #72689)
description: During the visit of Chinese Prime Minister Zhu Rongji to Pakistan in May 2001, the Gwadar port was a key item of discussion. Pakistani Finance Minister Shaukat Aziz said China has agreed to help fund the construction of phase one of the $250 million Gwadar Port project. China provided $248 million for the project in various forms of funding: On August 10, 2001, the Chinese government granted $31 million USD for the Gwadar Port project. Additional financing came from an RMB 502,690,200 China Eximbank government concessional loan (GCL), which was captured by project ID#38996, a $60 million China Eximbank buyer's credit loan (BCL) captured by project ID#38995, an $18 million Chinese Government grant captured by project ID#72689, and an interest-free loan from the Chinese Government worth $31 million captured by project ID#72688. Gwadar, located about 350 kilometers west of Karachi on the Arabian Sea coast, is considered the nearest warm water port for the Central Asian states for their trade with Europe, East Asia, and the Americas. Prime Minister Shaukat Aziz inaugurated the deep-sea port on March 20, 2007. The Gwadar Port was taken over by China Overseas Ports Holding Company Limited (COPHC) on May 16, 2013, for 40 years. STAFF_NOTE: One source suggests that the face value of the BCL may have been downwardly revised to $22.26 million (at a 3% interest rate) after the initial BCL agreement was signed. This project is located at Gwadar Port. More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Gwadar+Sea+Port/@25.1104955,62.339648,15z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0xc8622abf840e0dac!8m2!3d25.1104955!4d62.339648 and https://latitude.to/articles-by-country/pk/pakistan/8128/gwadar-port.
name: Makran

title: China government grants RMB 900,000 for the feasibility study of Hospital of Gwadar Construction Project (Linked to project ID#52542)
description: On April 20, 2015, China signed a Letter of Exchange on Feasibility Study for Hospital of Gwadar Construction Project. Under the agreement, China government provided RMB 900,000 for the feasibility study. After the completion of this feasibility study, the Chinese Government agreed to provide an RMB 240 million grant for the China-Pakistan Friendship Hospital Construction Project in Gwadar (see Project ID#52542). This project involves the upgrading of the hospital from 50 to 150 beds, and then a final extension to 300. The 150 bed upgrade was completed on December 16, 2019, when an inauguration ceremony was held.
name: Makran

title: China Exim Bank provides a US$22.26 million Eximbank buyer's credit loan for Pakistan Gwadar Port Project (Linked to #35124, #38996, #72688, and #72689)
description:
During the visit of Chinese Prime Minister Zhu Rongji to Pakistan in May 2001, the Gwadar port was a key item of discussion. Pakistani Finance Minister Shaukat Aziz said China has agreed to help fund the construction of phase one of the $250 million Gwadar Port project.
 
 On August 10, 2001, the Chinese government signed the financial agreement for development of Phase I of the Gwadar Port Project. Under this agreement, China provided $248 million for the project in various forms of funding:
 an RMB 502,690,200 China Eximbank government concessional loan (GCL), which was captured by project ID#38996
 a $60 million China Eximbank buyer's credit loan (BCL) captured in this project
 a $31 million Chinese Government grant captured by project ID#35124
 an $18 million Chinese Government grant captured by project ID#72689
 an interest-free loan from the Chinese Government worth $31 million captured by project ID#72688
 
 The $60 million BCL was downwardly revised to $22.26 million (at a 3% interest rate) after the initial BCL agreement was signed. On March 24, 2006, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan and China signed a $22.26 million preferential buyer's credit (PBC) agreement for the Gwadar Port Channel Deepening Project. The PBC agreement was signed by Pakistan’s Ambassador to China, Salman Bashir, and Liang Xiang, Assistant President of China Eximbank.
 
 This project involved the dredging of the Gwadar port to 14.5 metres. The objective of the project was to enable 50000 DWT vessels to use the port. China Harbour Engineering Company Ltd (CHEC) -- a subsidiary of China Communications Construction Company Limited -- was the contractor responsible for project implementation.
 
 The project is an extension to Phase I of the Gwadar Port Project, which comprised three multi-purposes berths of 602-metre total length and also accommodated roll-on roll-off vessels, a 100-meter service berth, 4.25-kilometer approach channel dredged to 11.5 meter-12.5 meter and demarcated with buoys and turning lights. The channel was successfully deepened to 14.5 meters in February 2007.
 
 Gwadar, located about 350 kilometers west of Karachi on the Arabian Sea coast, is considered the nearest warm water port for the Central Asian states for their trade with Europe, East Asia, and the Americas. Prime Minister Shaukat Aziz inaugurated the deep-sea port on March 20, 2007. The Gwadar Port was taken over by China Overseas Ports Holding Company Limited (COPHC) on May 16, 2013, for 40 years. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Gwadar+Sea+Port/@25.1104955,62.339648,15z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0xc8622abf840e0dac!8m2!3d25.1104955!4d62.339648 and https://latitude.to/articles-by-country/pk/pakistan/8128/gwadar-port.
name: Makran

title: China government grants USD 18 million for Pakistan Gwadar Port Project (Linked to project ID#38995, #38996, #35124, and #72688)
description: https://www.google.com/maps/place/Gwadar+Sea+Port/@25.1115358,62.3334356,13.58z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0xc8622abf840e0dac!8m2!3d25.1104955!4d62.339648; https://www.google.com/maps/place/Gwadar+Sea+Port/@25.1001293,62.3562962,13z

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 87 million grant for Pak-China Technical and Vocational Institute Construction Project
description: The Pak-China Technical and Vocational Institute in Gwadar is a vocational school set up by the Pakistani government at an estimated cost of 943 million Pakistani rupees. In 2015, the Chinese Government provided RMB 87 million in grant funding for this project. The purpose of this project was to impart specialized skills to Pakistanis, so that they may be employed at the Gwadar Port, which is being expanded as part of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor. The project was executed by Gwadar Port Authority and supervised by Pakistan's Ministry of Maritime Affairs. The project was originally slated for completion by March 2016; however, it faced various delays and was still under construction as of 2018. The foundation stone for the Pak-China Technical and Vocational Institute was laid at an inauguration ceremony on December 16, 2019. Staff Note: According to one official sources, the Pakistani government agreed to allocate approximately 200 million Pakistani rupees to the project while the remaining 743 million Pakistani rupees was to be financed by the Government of China through a grant. The official China-Pakistani Economic Corridor (CPEC) website states that that total cost of the project is 1,235,500,000 Pakistani rupees. A 2016 bond prospectus issued by the Government of Pakistan Bond Prospectus identifies the transaction amount as $10 million.
name: Makran

title: China donates computers and books to Pakistan
description: In 2000, the Chinese Embassy in Pakistan donated computers and books to Pakistan. Some organizations that received this aid include, All Pakistan China Friendship Association, the University of Punjab, KRL General Hospital, Pakistan National Arts Council, Baluchistan Arts Council, Economic Affairs Division, National Defense College, and the National Agricultural Research Center. The financial value of this aid is unknown.
name: Quetta

title: [CPEC] China funds Dera Ismail Khan-Zhob Project in Pakistan
description: In 2016, the Pakistan-China Joint Cooperation Committee approved the Dera Ismail Khan-Zhob project. According to the express tribune report, the western route of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), including the Khan-Zhob project, is going to be completed by the end of 2018 along with other 11 mega projects which were initiated in 2015-16. In January 2017, Pakistan's Under Communications Division provided 120 million Pakistani rupees for the Zhob Mughal Kot road. The division also contributed 40 million Pakistani rupees for the rehabilitation of DI Khan Mughal Kot road. As of Nov 2018, CPEC website only indicates that Feasibility and PC-I have been completed and the LOI has been forwarded to Chinese side. No other progress is indicated. A second CPEC website puts the project cost at US$195 million. It also suggests that the project is an 'upgradation of D.I.Khan - Zhob Phase I.' It is unclear whether the transaction amount is provided solely by China and in what form the fund is provided. The Pakistan Ministry of Finance Estimates of Foreign Assistance for FY 2017/18 lists this project as a 'Dualization of Yarik - Mughal Kot-Zhob Section of N-50'. It includes the Zhob Bypass. Cross-checking with the CPEC website confirms they are the same project. According to the source, Pakistan received no loan assistance in FY 2016/17 for the project, and are estimating loans of 4,000 million Pakistan rupees in FY 2017/18.
name: Zhob

title: China Gives Pakistan USD $10m for Internal Displaced Person Rehabilitation Program (linked to #72697)
description: According to the Pakistani National Assembly records, in July 2015, China signed an agreement with Pakistan to provide a special grant in cash to support the rehabilitation program for thousands of internally displaced people who were affected by the military operation in Pakistan's northwestern restive tribal region. The agreement, involving a grant of 10 million U.S. dollars, was signed by Chinese Ambassador to Pakistan Sun Weidong and Secretary of Pakistan's Economic Affairs Division Muhammad Saleem Sethi in Islamabad. The funds were used to support efforts to rehabilitate people of Federally Administered Tribal Areas and promote social development. Specific funding Chinese agency is unknown The agreement commits a total of $129 million USD (RMB 800 million) to be utilized for the Temporarily Displaced Persons (TDPs) and social sector projects in terrorism affected areas of FATA region (captured in #72697). The USD 129 million grant amount included cash grant of USD 10 million for supporting the Pakistani government in rehabilitation of residents in FATA area, while the remaining USD 119 million remained unfulfilled, as projects with FATA Secretariat were being identified for the purpose of reconstruction and rehabilitation in FATA region. These projects include reconstruction, rehabilitation, improvement of schools, irrigation system, highways, electricity, livelihood/ agriculture etc. The special assistance earmarked for rehabilitation of TDPs were recorded as fulfilled. US$ 5 million was received in September, 2015 and remaining US$ 5 million in April, 2016. China disbursed an estimated 1,541.63 million Pakistani rupees, or 11.01 million USD, to Pakistan in 2015-2016, according to the Pakistan Ministry of Finance Estimates for Foreign Assistance for 2016-2017. The funds were separated into one special grant of 509.150 million Pakistan rupees and a grant to support GoP in TDP FATA of 1,032.480 million Pakistani rupees.
name: F.A.T.A.

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 99.97 million for Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA) School Project
description: In 2015, during a visit to Pakistan, President Xi Jinping announced that China would build over 50 girls schools in Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA). On August 13, 2017, the Chinese government fulfilled this pledge through a 99.97 million RMB grant to the government of Pakistan. According to the 2017-2018 Status Report, the project closing date was recorded as August 31, 2018. During the war on terror 1,195 girls schools were affected in the tribal areas, out of which 555 were completely destroyed. Thus far, about 895 schools have been rehabilitated and construction of remaining schools is under process. The Chinese government funding will be used for the construction of 50 new schools.
name: F.A.T.A.

title: China grans $1m USD to WFP to assist FATA (linked to #54372)
description: In November 2017, the 'China South-South Cooperation Assistance Fund' provided $1 million USD to the World Food Program in order to support humanitarian initiatives in Pakistan's Federally Administered Tribal Area (FATA). This donation will enable food and nutrition assistance to an estimated 158,000 vulnerable and displaced people. This is the first project supported by the fund. The second is a $4m USD initiative to provide housing and commodity assistance, as well as help with the rebuilding of schools in the region.
name: F.A.T.A.
