title: China government grants RMB 800 million for IDPs/TDPs and Social Sector Projects of FATA (linked to project #52649)
description: On April 20, 2015, China government signed an agreement with Pakistan government to provide missing an RMB 800 million grant commitment for internally displaced persons (IDPs) and temporarily displaced persons (TDPs) and social sector projects in the Federally Administered Tribal Area (FATA). This region had been the site of clashes between the Pakistani Military and the Taliban, and over 1.5 million people were displaced. It was followed by an additional US$10 million donation (project #52649).
name: F.A.T.A.

title: China donates 800 books to Pakistan National Library
description: In December 2009 China, represented by the Chinese Embassy to Pakistan, donated 800 books to the National Library of Pakistan (NLP). The books, covering a wide range of subjects on Chinese culture, arts, medicines, religions and other related topics, have been handed over to Mazharul Islam, Director General Department of Libraries, by Yang Linhai, Chinese Cultural Counsellor.
name: Islamabad

title: Chinese Embassy in Pakistan donates office supplies to the Pakistani capital police department
description:
On June 2, 2010, the Embassy in Pakistan donated a batch of office supplies to the Pakistani Capital Police. 
 Chinee Ambassador Luo Zhaohui and other diplomats of the Embassy, ​​and Kalim, as well as the director of the Pakistani Police Department, attended the donation ceremony.
name: Islamabad

title: China donates books to Pakistan
description: In 2010, the Chinese Cultural Counsellor Yang Linhai presented a huge quantity of books to National University of Modern languages on behalf of the Embassy of China. The books were presented to Prof Dr Aziz Ahmad Khan, Rector NUML at a ceremony which was also attended by a large number of diplomats from the Embassy of China. The books are mostly about the Chinese culture, folk art and craft, traditional medicines etc.
name: Islamabad

title: China donates 500,000 doses of H1N1 vaccine to Pakistan
description: On March 15, 2010, China donated 500,000 doses of Influenza A (H1N1) vaccine to Pakistan on an emergency basis to assist Islamabad in dealing with the influenza pandemic.
GEO_sources: Links did not work - coded from project description
name: Islamabad

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 486.3 million loan for a Non-Intrusive Vehicle X-Ray Inspection System (NVIS) Project
description: On December 17, 2010, the Chinese Government to the Government of Pakistan provided an RMB 486,339,000 loan for a Non-Intrusive Vehicle X-Ray Inspection System (NVIS) Project. This loan carried the following terms: 25 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and a 2.5% interest rate. This project involved the acquisition of 24 mobile scanners in an effort to strengthen security arrangements and fight terrorism. These scanners are designed to detect explosives and weapons. However, this project was plagued by various problems and delays. In 2010, the Pakistani authorities delayed the installation of the x-ray scanners in Islamabad after experts declared them 'a health hazard' due to high radiation levels. Then, after some scanners arrived in Karachi, they could not be brought to Islamabad until December 2014 due to a dispute over the payment of customs duties. This project reached completion, but its exact date of completion is unknown. According to the Monthly disbursement of foreign economic assistance for the month of June 2014-2015, the project was completed on March 17, 2016. Staff Note: The Government of Pakistan identification number for this loan is CHINA-2010-308.
name: Islamabad

title: China donates 510 books to Pakistan International Islamic University Islamabad
description: China donated 510 books on history, sports, society, calligraphy, opera, medicines, heritage and folks arts to the students of International Islamic University Islamabad (IIUI). Some books were on Chinese Culture. For the help of students, China has also donated CDs and films. Cultural Counsellor of People's Republic China handed over these books, CDs and films to IIUI's Chief Librarian.
name: Islamabad

title: Mayor of Beijing donates 50000 USD for flood relief in Pakistan
description: On 7 September 2010, the Mayor of Beijing, one of the sister cities of Islamabad, gifted Islamabad a grant of 50,000 $ for flood relief operations. The Ambassador of China in Pakistan handed over a cheque to the Chairman CDA, Imtiaz Inayat Elahi Monday at CDA Headquarters. The grant would have been submitted to the Prime Ministers Relief Fund.
name: Islamabad

title: China donates computers and books to Pakistan
description: In 2000, the Chinese Embassy in Pakistan donated computers and books to Pakistan. Some organizations that received this aid include, All Pakistan China Friendship Association, the University of Punjab, KRL General Hospital, Pakistan National Arts Council, Baluchistan Arts Council, Economic Affairs Division, National Defense College, and the National Agricultural Research Center. The financial value of this aid is unknown.
name: Islamabad

title: Chinese Ministry of Culture gave in-kind grant of 150000 Chinese Yuan worth of office equipment to Pakistan
description: On December 8, 2009, the Chinese Ministry of Culture gave an in-kind grant of 150000 Chinese Yuan worth of office equipment to its Pakistani counterpart. Chinese Cultural Counselor Yang Linhai and Pakistans Culture Secretary Moinul-Islam Bukhari signed documents for the handing-over of equipment at a ceremony at the Ministry of Culture in Pakistan.
name: Islamabad

title: China donates 10.5 million Rs of office equipment to Pakistan
description: On 11 June 2005, the Chinese government granted office equipment worth 10.5 million Rs to the Pakistani government to facilitate offices with modern facilities. A ceremony for the signing of an agreement on the handover of the equipment was held in Islamabad, with Chinese Ambassador Zhang Chunxiang and Pakistani Economic Affairs Division Secretary Khalid Saeed inking the document on behalf of their respective governments. The office equipment, including 145 computers, printers, scanners, fax machines and photocopiers, was provided under the grant assistance agreement on economic and technical cooperation between Pakistan and China signed in 2001.
name: Islamabad

title: Chinese Embassy establishes US$29k 'Chinese Ambassador Scholarship' at Quaid-i-Azam University
description: On December 8, the establishment ceremony of the 'Chinese Ambassador Scholarship' was held for undergraduate and MPhil Students at the School of Politics and International Relations (SPIR), Quaid-i-Azam University (QUA), Islamabad. The scholarship has a reported worth of US$29,500. In an academic year, each of the ten selected students will receive Rs 150,000 on need and merit basis. The scholarship was established to help QUA students with financial difficulties and foster Pakistan-China relations.
name: Islamabad

title: China opens Confucius Institute in National University of Modern Languages (NUML), Pakistan (Linked to project #72682)
description: In April 2005, Confucius Institute was founded by The Office of Chinese Language Council International (Hanban), Beijing Language and Culture University, and National University of Modern Languages in Islamabad. It is the first Confucius Institute based on the all-weather strategic partnership between China and Pakistan, and also it is the first Confucius Institute in Islamic world. In April 2005, the OCLCI(Hanban) and NUML signed the agreement for establishing Confucius Institute in NUML, and held the ritual to reveal its nameplate. In April, 2007, the opening ceremony of Confucius Institute Islamabad was held. This project is linked to #72682, which records scholarships that were awarded by the Chinese Embassy in connection with the Confucius Institute.
name: Islamabad

title: China Donates 2.3 million CNY worth of equipment to National Art Gallery of Pakistan
description: In July 2007, China donated equipment worth 2.3 million yuan (over $300,000) to the National Art Gallery of Pakistan. The equipment includes elevators, film projectors, security monitors, tape recorders, computers, printers, fax machines and various books and magazines about China. Chinese Ambassador Luo Zhaohui and Pakistani Cultural Minister G.G. Jamal signed the handing-over certificate on behalf of their respective governments. The donation was made to express the friendly sentiments of the Chinese government and people to Pakistan in view of the two countries' all-weather friendship.
name: Islamabad

title: China provides facilities and assistance for DNA lab in Pakistan
description: In March 2006 Pakistan established its first DNA test laboratory in Islamabad, with the assistance of China, to investigate complicated terrorism and criminal cases. The Chinese government had provided training for scientists in the facility.
name: Islamabad

title: Chinese government provides RMB 33.1 million grant for F-9 Park Solar Power Supply Project in Islamabad
description:
Under the F-9 Park Solar Power Supply Project, the city authorities in Islamabad installed 3,400 solar panels on a 2.5-hectare parcel of the 750-acre “F-9 Park”, at a cost of approximately $4.8 million. The system aims to provide a constant power supply to one of the city's key recreational attractions at a time when power cuts remain a major problem due to shortfalls on the grid. The solar installation, which produces 870 kilowatts of electricity ─ enough to power the equivalent of 450 homes ─ runs water pumps and sprinkler systems for the park, and provides power for the offices of the Islamabad Metropolitan Corporation (IMC) and Capital Development Authority (CDA), both located within the park. 
 
 The initiative, financed with a RMB 33.1 million grant from the Chinese government, uses batteries to store solar energy to meet lighting and other electricity needs 24 hours a day. The project was officially completed and handed over to the the National Assembly Secretariat on December 15, 2016. China Railways 17th Bureau Group was the contractor responsible for project implementation. It completed the project two months before its date on completion. The plant has an installed capacity of 0.85 MW, which will be used to power streetlights in the park, lights in the children’s play area, the tennis court, cricket ground and a tube well installed in the park. China Railways 17th Bureau Group is also responsible for maintaining the plant for five years. The plant is comprised of 3,400 solar panels. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: This project is also known as the F-9 Park Solar Lighting Project and the Fatima Jinnah Park Solar Lighting Project. The Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division (EAD) records an RMB 45 million commitment value in its fiscal year 2015/16 year book; however, it downwardly revised this figure to RMB 33.1 million in its fiscal year 2016/17 year book.
name: Islamabad

title: Chinese Embassy donates computers and printers to Pakistan's Ministry of Culture
description: On 18 January 2006, the Chinese Embassy donated nine sets of computers and nine printers to Pakistan's Ministry of Culture, Sports and Youth affairs. The Chinese Ambassador Zhang Chunxiang handed over the equipments to Cultural Secretary Jalil Abbas at the Pakistani Ministry. Present at the handing over ceremony were Chinese Cultural Counsellor Shan Baoxiang, Additional Cultural Secretary Khalid Saeed Haroon, Executive Director of the Lok Virsa museum Uxi Mufti and other senior officials from both sides.
name: Islamabad

title: Chinese Embassy to Pakistan donates materials to Lok Virsa Museum of Islamabad Pakistan
description: On 13 March 2008, the Chinese Embassy donated a Stage Subtitler, a 16 mm film projector and 477 Chinese film archives to the Ethnology Museum of Lok Virsa of Islamabad. The equipment was presented by Chinese Ambassador, Lou Zhaohui and Cultural Councillor of Chinese Embassy, Shan Baoxiang to the Executive Director of Lok Virsa Uxi Mufti, while Secretary, Ministry of Culture, Shahid Rafi was also present on the occasion.
name: Islamabad

title: China pledged grant of US$400000 to Pakistan Human Development Fund for Chinese Learning Centre
description: China pledged a grant of US$400000 to the Pakistan Human Development Fund to establish a Chinese Learning Centre in Islamabad. The centre would be established by National Commission on Human Development (NCHD). NCHD Chairman Dr Nasim Ashraf announced this on 2 April, 2005. Dr Nasim Ashraf was addressing a press conference with the United Front of Chinese Communist Party Central Committee Vice Minister Hu Deping, UNDP country representative Onder Yucer and UNDP resident representative Khalid Malik. The donation was made through China's Guangcai Programme.
name: Islamabad

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 850 million government concessional loan for Safe City Islamabad Project
description:
In December 2010, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed an RMB 850 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement on the Islamabad 'Safe City' (平安城市) Project. The loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and 2% interest rate. The contractor responsible for project implementation was Huawei Technologies. This project supported the installation of 1,950 surveillance (CCTV) cameras in Islamabad. 
 
 In coordination with Pakistan’s National Database and Registration Authority (NADRA), all the videos and recorded data from the 1,900 surveillance cameras are used to ensure real-time monitoring of people and vehicles at important buildings, roads, key points and major portions of the city’s residential areas. All the data as received from installed surveillance cameras across the city are also transferred to a command and control centre and all of the suspicious people and vehicles monitored in the surveillance cameras are checked in the big data with coordination of NADRA’s data bank. Then, if suspects are confirmed to be dangerous, the command centre promptly conveys instructions to ‘Rapid Response Force’ and allocates forces to the site within three minutes to minimize the possible destruction caused by suspect and to avert any terrorists activity. The Safe City Islamabad project was completed on March 29, 2016.
name: Islamabad

title: China grants RMB 240 million for China-Pakistan Friendship Center
description:
The China-Pakistan Friendship Center was built in Islamabad through a grant offered by the Chinese government. The Government of Pakistan provided land for the Center, while the Chinese government constructed, equipped and provided human resources for it. The expected utilization by June 2008 was Rs 275.0 million, although the cost increased up to 3 billion rupees. According to the website of Chinese embassy in Pakistan, China granted 240 million RMB for the project.
 
 The Pakistan-China Friendship Center was designed by China Zhongyuan International Engineering Corporation and constructed by Shanghai Construction Group Corporation. It officially started in 2008 and was completed in September 2010. The center is 125 meters long and 94 meters wide, with a total construction area of ​​more than 20,000 square meters and a real total area of ​​more than 50,000 square meters. It is a comprehensive building with multiple functions such as conferences, exhibitions, theatrical performances, cultural exchanges, catering and accommodation.
name: Islamabad

title: China provides 13,000 tents to quake-hit Pakistan
description: Following the flood that hit Pakistan, China donated 13,000 tents as a contribution to flood relief operations. The materials reached Peshawar on 17 November 2005 through a convoy of 163 trucks which had been travelling via Karakoram Highway. The materials were handed over to Pakistan Army: A 13-member Chinese delegation handed over relief goods to military authorities at Besham. 7000 tents were dispatched to the quake hit areas of Azad Kashmir whereas 6000 tents will be distributed in the affected areas of NWPF.
name: N.W.F.P.

title: China donates the 1st batch of humanitarian aid worth of RMB 10 million to flood-hit Pakistan (Linked to projects #38551, #36809 and #36801, and #54097.)
description: In August 2010, following the flood that hit Khyber Pakhtunkhwa region, China donated 10 million yuan to Pakistan in humanitarian aid. The grant was announced on August 01 by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce. The materials were gathered by the China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) within 48 hours after the government's pledge. The PLA Air Force deployed three Il-76 carriers to transport the materials. The aircraft departed for Pakistan from Shijiazhuang and Nanjing on August 4.The aid included relief materials such as 30 tonnes of medicines and water purifiers, 1,000 tents and 50 power generators, according to China's Ministry of National Defence. The representatives of the two countries involved in the aid transfer were the Chinese Ambassador in Islamabad Liu Jian for China, and Nadeem Ahmed, Chairman of National Disaster Management Authority, for Pakistan. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service records that the Chinese-donated in-kind emergency relief materials amount to 80 tons, including tents, electricity generators, medicine and water purification equipments, and are worth CNY10 million. STAFF_NOTE: Two more batches of in-kind assistance were subsequently sent in late August and early September of 2010. Linked to Projects #38551, #36809 and #36801. Also linked to #54097.
name: N.W.F.P.

title: Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries donates USD 10,000 to All Pakistan China Friendship Association for quake relief
description: In October 2005, following the eartquake in Azad Kashmir and NWFP, the Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries donated to Pakistan US$ 10,000. Shan Bao-xiang, cultural counsellor of the Embassy of the Peoples Republic of China presented a cheque of US $10,000 to Main Habib Ullah, Acting President, All Pakistan China Friendship Association during a meeting in Islamabad. STAFF_NOTE: The project is coded ODA, as the Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries (CPAFFC) is officially affiliated.
name: N.W.F.P.

title: China donates 5 million Pakistani Rupee for resettlement of internal displaced persons in Pakistan
description: On July 9, 2014, the Chinese Ambassador to Pakistan, Sun Weidong, presented a donation of 5 million Pakistani Rupees to a Pakistani official on behalf of the Chinese embassy for the resettlement of internal displaced persons in Pakistan. The check was accepted by Abdul Qadir Baloch, minister of Pakistan's Ministry of States and Frontier Regions (SAFRON) for the resettlement of the internally displaced persons (IDPs) from North Waziristan The surge in internally displaced population was caused by Operation Zarb-e-Azb, a military campaign launched by the Pakistani armed forces on June 15 against domestic local militant groups hiding in North Waziristan tribal regions. SAFRON officials reported that more than 833,000 people have been registered as IDPs as a result of the operation.
name: Bannu

title: [CPEC] China funds Dera Ismail Khan-Zhob Project in Pakistan
description: In 2016, the Pakistan-China Joint Cooperation Committee approved the Dera Ismail Khan-Zhob project. According to the express tribune report, the western route of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), including the Khan-Zhob project, is going to be completed by the end of 2018 along with other 11 mega projects which were initiated in 2015-16. In January 2017, Pakistan's Under Communications Division provided 120 million Pakistani rupees for the Zhob Mughal Kot road. The division also contributed 40 million Pakistani rupees for the rehabilitation of DI Khan Mughal Kot road. As of Nov 2018, CPEC website only indicates that Feasibility and PC-I have been completed and the LOI has been forwarded to Chinese side. No other progress is indicated. A second CPEC website puts the project cost at US$195 million. It also suggests that the project is an 'upgradation of D.I.Khan - Zhob Phase I.' It is unclear whether the transaction amount is provided solely by China and in what form the fund is provided. The Pakistan Ministry of Finance Estimates of Foreign Assistance for FY 2017/18 lists this project as a 'Dualization of Yarik - Mughal Kot-Zhob Section of N-50'. It includes the Zhob Bypass. Cross-checking with the CPEC website confirms they are the same project. According to the source, Pakistan received no loan assistance in FY 2016/17 for the project, and are estimating loans of 4,000 million Pakistan rupees in FY 2017/18.
name: Dera Ismail Khan

name: F.A.T.A.

title: China government grants RMB 800 million for IDPs/TDPs and Social Sector Projects of FATA (linked to project #52649)
description: On April 20, 2015, China government signed an agreement with Pakistan government to provide missing an RMB 800 million grant commitment for internally displaced persons (IDPs) and temporarily displaced persons (TDPs) and social sector projects in the Federally Administered Tribal Area (FATA). This region had been the site of clashes between the Pakistani Military and the Taliban, and over 1.5 million people were displaced. It was followed by an additional US$10 million donation (project #52649).
name: F.A.T.A.

title: China sends to Pakistan a 49 member medical team for quake relief
description: In October 2005 China sent a medical team to Pakistan to contribute to the quake relief operations. It reached Chaklala Airbase in Islamabad on Friday 28 Octobers, where it was received by Minister of State for Overseas Division Senator Tariq Azim and Chinese Ambassador Zhang Chunxiang. The team was made up of 49 members, including 8/9 female doctors (depending on the Chinese/Pakistani source considered). It brought along medical equipment, and was destined to Balakot area.
name: Hazara

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 60 million grant for construction of hospital and school in Baffa after 2005 earthquake (Linked to Project ID#53903)
description: After the earthquake that struck Pakistan in 2005, the Chinese Government pledged to help with reconstruction efforts. On November 24, 2006, the Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan signed an RMB 80 million grant agreement, which provided 60 million RMB for the construction of a hospital and school in Baffa. The project involved the construction of a 6,525-square-meter high school (GHSS Baffa) that would cost Rs 487.5 million and a small hospital of 4,400 square meters (THQ Baffa) that would cost Rs 412.5 million. The school would be designed to accommodate 720 students. At the beginning of 2011, an advance team of 6 people from the Shandong Expressway Qilu Construction Group arrived in Baffa and began the project preparation work. Construction started on July 2, 2011. Then, from December 16-22, 2011, a mid-term quality inspection team organized by the Economic Cooperation Bureau of China's Ministry of Commerce inspected and accepted the project. STAFF_NOTE: In 2015, Chinese Government agreed to update the school and hospital buildings by installing waste management and drainage systems, etc. This project is captured in Project ID#53903. The additional 20 million RMB in the 2006 grant agreement was used for emergency flood relief in 2010 (captured in #73381).
name: Hazara

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 1.273 billion grant for Post Flood (N-35, N-5, N-55) Road Rehabilitation Project
description:
In 2011, the Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan signed letters of exchange (LOE) for the Post Flood Rehabilitation Project. Then, on December 5, 2012, China’s Ambassador to Pakistan, Liu Jian, attended the signing ceremony for the Post Flood Rehabilitation Project. The project involved the rehabilitation of 460 kilometers of road along the N-35, N-5, N-55 highways that were damaged by floods. 
 
 According to the Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division (Fiscal Year 2015/16 Yearbook), the Chinese Government provided an RMB 1,273,000,000 grant for this project. China Railway 17th Bureau Co., Ltd. and China Yunnan Sunshine Road Bridge Co., Ltd. were the contractors responsible for project implementation. Approximately $65 million of the proceeds from this grant agreement were set aside for the rehabilitation and improvement of the Thakot-Raikot Section (N-35) of the Karakoram Highway. 
 
 This sub-project commenced on September 15, 2013 and its planned completed date was December 20, 2016. China Railway 17th Bureau Group Co. Ltd was the contractor responsible for the rehabilitation and improvement of the 147km Thakot-Raikot section (N-35) of the Karakoram Highway. China Yunnan Sunshine Road Bridge Co., Ltd. was responsible for the rehabilitation of 163 km of road along the N-5 and N-55. Most of these road segments fall within Sindh Province and they include the Sehwan-Dadu City, Khairpur Nathan Shah-Mehar of Indus Highway and Hala-Moro, Pano Aqil-Ghottki, Ghotki-Sarhad and Sarhad-Dharki Sections of N-5. 
 
 Staff Note: One source identifies the size of the grant commitment amount as RMB 1340 million. We use the more conservative of the the two estimates. Note that the Thakot-Raikot section of N-35 is also known as the Shikarpur-Ghouspur & Thakot Bridge to Raikot Section of N-35 and the Post Flood Rehabilitation Project is also known as the Rehabilitation of National Highway Authority (NHA) Road Network Project.
name: Hazara

title: First Chinese International Rescue Team (CIRT) to quake-hit Pakistan
description: A 49-member Chinese International Rescue Team comprising 23 rescuers, 8 medical staff, 18 seismological experts and reporters with six sniffing dogs and eight tons of search equipment reached Pakistan on Oct. 9, 2005 and had worked in Balakot for eight days. As the first team to enter the town of Balakot, it succeeded in saving three Pakistani victims and offered medical treatment to 591 local people. Entrusted by the UN relief coordination center at Muzafarabad, the Chinese team served as a UN sub-coordinator at Balakot and enjoyed very good cooperation with teams from UAE, Germany, Switzerland, Jordan, WHO, etc. The team returned to Beijing on October 20.
name: Hazara

title: China Eximbank provides $164.4 million buyer’s credit loan for Phase II (Thakot-Havelian Section) of the KKH Highway Repair Project (Linked to Project ID #52525 and #54424)
description:
On February 19, 2014, China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC), a subsidiary of China Communication Construction Co. Ltd., and the Pakistan Ministry of Communications signed a memorandum of understanding on the Phase II Reconstruction and Expansion of the Karakoram Highway (Raikot-Islamabad). Shortly thereafter, CRBC submitted the engineering feasibility study report and preliminary design for the project to Pakistan’s National Highway Authority. Due to the large amount of project and the high total cost of the 487-kilometer Raikot-Islamabad project, China and Pakistan have decided to divide the project into three sections. The first section is Thakot-Havelian section, the second section is the Havelian to Islamabad section, and the third section is the Thakot-Raikot section. 
 
 Then, on April 28, 2016, China Eximbank signed three different loan agreements with the Government of Pakistan for the Phase II (Thakot-Havelian Section) of the KKH Highway Repair Project: a $966.19 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement, a $164.4 million buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement, and an RMB 1.2 billion government concessional loan. The maturities, grace periods, and interest rates of these loans are unknown. The PBC loan agreement is captured in Project ID#54424. The BCL agreement is captured in Project ID#54423. The GCL agreement is captured in Project ID#52525. Their Government of Pakistan loan agreement numbers are PBC169397-CPEC, BCL-CPEC-2016, and GCL16-6575-CPEC, respectively.
 
 This project involved the rehabilitation of a 118 km road segment that runs from Thakot to Havelian on the Karakoram Highway in the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province. China Communication Construction Co. Ltd. was the contractor responsible for project implementation. It work was overseen by Pakistan’s National Highway Authority. A groundbreaking ceremony for the project took place on April 28, 2016. Construction then began on September 1, 2016. The project was completed on November 18, 2019. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is KKH二期项目（赫韦利扬-曼塞赫拉). The second proposed section of the highway from Havelian to Islamabad is captured in Project ID #52719. The third proposed section of the highway from Thakot to Raikot is captured in Project ID #53713.
name: Hazara

title: [CPEC] China Eximbank provides an RMB 1.2 billion government concessional loan for Phase II (Thakot-Havelian Section) of the KKH Highway Repair Project (Linked to Project ID#54423 and #54424)

More locational details can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/kkh-thakot-havelian-section-phase-ii-improvement/681f9d39-0252-44ab-96f5-d1302400a471/.
name: Hazara

title: China Eximbank provides $37.4 government concessional loan for Pak-China Optical Fiber Cable Project
description:
The Pak-China Optical Fiber Cable Project (or Pak-China OFC Project) involved the laying a 820 km fiber optic cable line from the Khunjerab Pass on the China-Pakistan border to the city of Rawalpindi via Mansehra, Chilas, Danyore (Gligit), Karimabad and Sust. 466.54 kilometers of the route is located in Gilgit-Baltistan, while 287.66 kilometers of the route is located in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, 47.56 kilometers of the route is located in Punjab province, and 18.2 kilometers of the route is locted in in Islamabad Capital Territory. The line connects the Transit Europe-Asia Terrestrial Cable Network with that of Pakistan, which currently transmits its telecom and internet traffic through four undersea fiber optic cables, with another three undersea fiber optic cables under construction. 
 
 The project also involved the installation of 172 km of aerial fiber optic cable from Karimabad to Khunjerab to supplement in landslide prone areas. It provides 26 high capacity microwave links as backup to OFC network and 9 node centers in different locations along Rawalpindi-Khunjerab belt. The total cost of the project was $44 million and China Eximbank financed 85% of the total project cost ($37.4 million) -- through a government concessional loan agreement [ID#GCL-2014-519] at an interest rate of 2%. The project was a collaboration between Special Communications Organization, China Telecom Global, and Pakistan Telecommunication Company. The groundbreaking ceremony project took place on May 19, 2016. The project was scheduled to be completed in November, 2017. The project was then completed on July 13, 2018. 
 
 Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 中巴跨境光缆项目.
name: Hazara

name: Hazara

title: Second Chinese International Rescue Team (CIRT) to quake-hit Pakistan (linked to #35345)
description: On October 29, 2005, the second Chinese International Rescue Team of 38 members arrived in Balatok. The team comprised 28 medical staff, 8 rescue members and 2 seismologists. During the 20-day mission, the team set up a mobile hospital in Balatok area and provided medical care for over 2000 people. The team returned to Beijing on November 17.
name: Hazara

title: Chinese Government provides Rs 94 million grant for sanitation facilities at earthquake-affected school and hospital in Baffa (Linked to Project ID#55836)
description:
In 2006, the Chinese Government agreed to build the Baffa Tehsil Headquarters Hospital (THQ Baffa) and Government Higher Secondary School Baffa (GHSS Baffa) in Baffa within Mansehr District, in the Khyber-Pukhtoonkhwa (KPK). It started construction in 2012. Then, in 2014, the Chinese government agreed to provide Rs 94 million in additional grant funding to Pakistan’s Earthquake Reconstruction, Rehabilitation Authority (ERRA) to upgrade the THQ Baffa and GHSS Baffa buildings with additional facilities and equipment. These upgrades were to include a Waste Water Treatment Unit, Medical Waste Burning Facility (Hospital), Drainage for the hospital, Provision for Voltage Stabilizer in the hospital and provision for Voltage Stabilizer in the school. 
 
 An MoU on the project was signed on November 21, 2014. Then, a construction contract was signed on December 18, 2015. Anhui Construction Engineering Group, a Chinese company, was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project handover ceremony was held on November 2, 2017. In its fiscal year 2016/17 yearbook, the Government of Pakistan’s Economic Affairs Division Year Book records the value of the grant commitment as RMB 5.8 million, which is roughly the equivalent of the Rs94 million (referenced above). 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: For details of the construction of the original buildings, see Project ID #55836.
name: Hazara

title: Chinese Embassy donated computers and printers to a quake-hit city in Pakistan
description: In Pakistan's quake-hit Balakot, Ambassador Zhang Chunxiang and Pakistani Senator Mohammad Afridi attended a ceremony in a college campus and cut the ribbon together. Ambassador Zhang, on behalf of the Embassy, also donated six computers and six HP printers to the college representatives.
name: Hazara

name: Hazara

title: Chinese Banks loan 1.41 billion USD for 870 MW Suki Kinari Hydropower Project in Pakistan (Linked to #54309 and #54319) (CPEC, IPP)
description: The 870 MW Suki Kinari hydropower project developed by Suki Kinari Hydro (Private) Limited will be located on River Kunhar, District Mansehra, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa. The project achieved financial close on January 9, 2017. The EPC Contractor is China Gezhouba group Company Ltd. On April 20, 2015, ICBC Chairman Jiang Jianqing signed power project financing agreements for four energy power projects in the presence of Chinese President Xi Jinping and Pakistani Prime Minister Sharif. The four energy power projects include Suki Kinari hydropower project, Dawood wind power project, Sahiwal coal-fired power plant, and Thar coal-power integrated project. According to the World Bank, the total project cost is 1.8 billion USD, financed through a debt equity ratio of 75:25. China Exim Bank and ICBC each provided a loan of 708.1 Million USD. A Tariff Determination Petition document in 2014 puts the interest rate of the loan at 4.91%, the repayment period at 12 years, and the grace period at 5 years. The construction activities at the site of the project had already commenced and the project was expected to start injecting 3,081GWh million clean reliable and affordable units of electricity each year to the national grid by 2022. The equity financing of the project was to be arranged by the shareholders of Suki Kinari Hydro (Private) Limited, and according to IJGlobal, China Gezhouba Group Corporation, Al Jomaih and Eden each invested 160.09 Million USD. Update: The first Sahiwal coal-fired power plant was reported as successfully completed and inaugurated May 2017 by the Prime Minister of Pakistan. The second plant is scheduled to begin energy production in June 2017. Project also received a No Objection Certificate (NoC) from Pakistan's Environment Protection Department.
name: Hazara

name: Malakand

title: Grant for internally displaced persons of Malakand Division, Pakistan
description: In October 2009 the Pakistani government declared to have received $14.2 million from China for dispaced persons of the Malakand province.
name: Malakand

title: China provides in-kind grant of 30 million Chinese Yuan worth of relief material to Pakistan for internally displaced persons (Linked to project #39088)
description: To help Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) of Swat and adjoining areas, the Chinese government has announced further assistance of 30 million Chinese yuan worth of relief materials, Pakistan's Ambassador to China Masood Khan on May 23, 2009. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Ma Zhaoxu explained that the first batch would be airlifted to Pakistan on 27 May 2009.The grant includes water purification equipment, power generator and medicine. More than 1.6 million people had fled from the Swat Valley in Pakistan's North West Frontier Province, where government forces had been battling armed Islamic militants for weeks. In addition, about 215017 internally displaced persons have been staying at 17 relief camps. More than 1.4 million affected people were registered outside the camps. STAFF_NOTE: Previously, China had already given one million U.S. dollars cash in emergency humanitarian aid to Pakistan for the PM's Special Fund for the Victims of Terrorism. For details of this project, see #39088.
name: Malakand

title: China grants 2 million RMB to Afghan refugees in Pakistan
description: In April, 2001, China pledged 2 million RMB yuan to support Afghan refugees living in Peshawar, Pakistan, which was then officially donated in July of that year. On 6th April 2001, in Islamabad, An Min (visiting Chinese vice Minister for Trade & Economic Cooperation) and Nawid Ahsan (Secretary of Economic affairs division) signed and exchanged letters for donation of relief items worth RMB Yuan 2.0 million for the Afghan Refugees in Pakistan. On 5th July 2001, Lu Shulin (Chinese Ambassador to Pakistan) and Abbas Sarfaraz Khan (Minister for Kashmir Affairs, Northern Areas, States and Frontier Regions) signed and swapped the hand-over certificates for humanitarian aid worth 2 million RMB. The donations include tents, generators, cooking utensils and other necessities.
name: Peshawar

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 27.5 million interest-free loan for Advanced Technical Training Centre (ATTC) Construction Project
description: In December 2000, the Chinese Government and the Government of Pakistan signed an RMB 27.5 million interest-free loan agreement for the construction of the Advanced Technical Training Center (ATTC). The purpose of the centre is to provide advance training facilities to the people of the Northwestern Frontier Province (NWFP) in field of industrial electronics, specialized welding techniques, computer maintenance and other mechanical training. The project was implemented on a turnkey basis. A foundation-laying ceremony took place on January 25, 2002. Then, on July 16, 2003, the Chinese and Pakistani governments signed a certificate for the official handing over of the centre to Pakistan. The ATTC is located in the district of Peshawar in the Hayatabad Industry Area.
name: Peshawar

title: China provides 2 million yuan to Pakistan for Afghan refugee aid (Linked to #35130)
description: In August 2000, China donated aid worth 2 million yuan to Afghan refugees in Peshawar, Pakistan. The relief included medicine, tents, blankets, and clothes and was delivered to the UNHCR office in Peshawar. The signing ceremony was held by Chinese Ambassador to Pakistan, Lu Shulin, and Chief of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) Afghan Mission in Pakistan.
name: Peshawar

title: China provides 10 million RMB for anti-terror actions
description: In October 2001 China donated to the Pakistani government emergency aid worth 10 million RMB. The humanitarian aid, including tents and blankets, left on October 22, 2001, for the Pakistani city of Peshawar from Urumqi in northwest China's Xinjiang region which borders Pakistan and Afghanistan. Earlier, on October 1, President Jiang Zemin had declared that China would provide 10 million yuan in emergency aid to Pakistan, in support to the country's anti-terror actions. China had also expressed its willingness to cooperate with Pakistan in counter-terrorism efforts.
name: Peshawar

title: China donates relief goods worth RMB 12 million to Afghan Refugees in Pakistan
description: In November, 2001, the Chinese government donated relief goods worth 12 million RMB to be used for Afghan refugees in Pakistan. A handover ceremony took place and the goods donated included tents, blankets, quilts, tarps and other materials that were transported to Peshawar on November 5.
name: Peshawar

title: Chinese Embassy donates $2 million to flood-stricken areas in Pakistan
description: On 1 August 2005, the Chinese Ambassador Zhang Chunxiang made a special trip to the provincial capital Peshawar and Lahore provinces, and contributed 2 million dollars to both governments, to go towards the reconstruction works.
name: Peshawar

title: China Eximbank provides $143.85 preferential buyer’s credit for Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 1 (Linked to Project ID#71792)
description:
On June 18, 2009, China Eximbank signed two different preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreements: a $143.85 million PBC loan agreement for Urban Infrastructure Development (UDP) Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) Package 1 and a $156.15 million PBC loan agreement for Urban Infrastructure Development (UDP Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK) Package 2. The first PBC loan is captured in this project. The second PBC loan is captured in Project ID#71792. Their Government of Pakistan loan ID numbers are PBC20091274 and PBC20091375, respectively. These loans were reportedly provided on the following terms: 20-year maturities and 1.5% interest rates. 
 
 The AJK Urban Development Programme (Packages 1 and 2) aimed to provide safe housing, improved city environment, and modern physical and social infrastructure in the earthquake affected areas with Azad Jammu and Kashmir Province. The AJK Urban Development Programme (Packages 1 and 2) involved 235 urban development works (sub-projects) in the earthquake-affected areas of Muzaffarabad, Bagh (also known as Bagh City), Rawalakot within Azad Jammu and Kashmir Province. 90 rehabilitation sub-projects (worth $190 million) were to take place in Muzaffarabad. 50 rehabilitation projects (worth $123 million) were to take place in Bagh. 30 rehabiltation projects (worth $38.83 million) were to take place in Rawalakot. 
 
 As of October 2013, 10 sub-projects had been completed, 47 were under construction, and 178 were yet to be started. China Xinjiang Beixin Construction & Engineering Co. Ltd. and China International Water & Electric Corp. were the contractors responsible for implementation of the Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 1 Project and the Urban Infrastructure Development AJK Package 2 Project. Both projects and contractors were overseen by Pakistan’s Earthquake Reconstruction and Rehabilitation Authority (ERRA). The projected end date for both projects was December 31, 2016. Both projects were completed, but the exact dates of completion are unknown.
name: Northern Areas

title: China Road and Bridge Corporation sends personnel to clear the KKH after mudslide
description: The China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC), which is already involved in the project of expansion of the KKH, provided personnel to clear the highway following a mudslide in the Hunza Valley. The CRBC worked jointly with a team of specialists from Ministry of Water Resources of China, Chinese Academy of Chengdu Institute of Mountain Hazards and Environment. The construction work on KKH has restarted
name: Northern Areas

title: China Eximbank provides $37.4 government concessional loan for Pak-China Optical Fiber Cable Project
description:
The Pak-China Optical Fiber Cable Project (or Pak-China OFC Project) involved the laying a 820 km fiber optic cable line from the Khunjerab Pass on the China-Pakistan border to the city of Rawalpindi via Mansehra, Chilas, Danyore (Gligit), Karimabad and Sust. 466.54 kilometers of the route is located in Gilgit-Baltistan, while 287.66 kilometers of the route is located in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, 47.56 kilometers of the route is located in Punjab province, and 18.2 kilometers of the route is locted in in Islamabad Capital Territory. The line connects the Transit Europe-Asia Terrestrial Cable Network with that of Pakistan, which currently transmits its telecom and internet traffic through four undersea fiber optic cables, with another three undersea fiber optic cables under construction. 
 
 The project also involved the installation of 172 km of aerial fiber optic cable from Karimabad to Khunjerab to supplement in landslide prone areas. It provides 26 high capacity microwave links as backup to OFC network and 9 node centers in different locations along Rawalpindi-Khunjerab belt. The total cost of the project was $44 million and China Eximbank financed 85% of the total project cost ($37.4 million) -- through a government concessional loan agreement [ID#GCL-2014-519] at an interest rate of 2%. The project was a collaboration between Special Communications Organization, China Telecom Global, and Pakistan Telecommunication Company. The groundbreaking ceremony project took place on May 19, 2016. The project was scheduled to be completed in November, 2017. The project was then completed on July 13, 2018. 
 
 Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 中巴跨境光缆项目.
name: Northern Areas

title: China donates RMB 30 million of humanitarian aid to flood-hit Pakistan (linked to #38551, #36722)
description: On 19 August 2010, China provided Pakistan with additional humanitarian aid worth 30 million yuan, first part of the 'second batch' of aid. After having provided a 'first batch' worth 10 million yuan, at the beginning of the month (project ID #36722), China offered Pakistan additional relief materials, referred to as a 'second batch', meant to provide relief to the North-West region, in particular to the population of the Hunza Lake. The overall value of this second batch was 50 million dollars and it was delivered in two stages. The first part of this second batch, worth 30 million-RMB, arrived in Islamabad, capital of Pakistan, on 19 and 20 of August. Liu Jian, China's ambassador to Pakistan, and Mr. Sibtain Fazal Halim, Secretary of the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Statistics, attended the handover ceremony at the airport. The materials were trasported to Pakistan by the PLA airforces and handed to to Pakistan's armed forces. The supplies mainly included tents, compressed food, carpets, generators, and medicine, mineral water, and water purifiers etc. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service records that the second batch of Chinese-donated in-kind emergency relief materials amount to CNY50 million, corroborating the total amount of the two parts of this second batch (the other part captured in project #38551). This project is linked to project ID #36722 and project ID #38551.
name: Northern Areas

title: China provides USD16,310,011 loan for 18 MW Naltar Hydropower Plant-IV
description:
According to the 2006-2007 Foreign Economic Assistance Status Report on Commitments and Disbursements, the loan agreement for the 18 MW Naltar Hydropower project was signed in December 2001, with a commitment of $16,310,011. Disbursement has been completed as of 30 June 2007. The feasibility study had been completed in 2000. The project was finished in October 2007. The executing agency is KANA. China has taken up at least four other hydropower projects in these areas—Bhunji including the Naltar project and then smaller projects in places like Phendar, Harpo and Yurlbo. 
 
 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: Found on "P" tab of Status Report.
name: Northern Areas

title: China Exim Bank provided USD259 million preferential buyer's credit (PBC) for Phase-I realignment of Karakoram Highway at Attabad Lake in Pakistan (linked to #35739 and #72395)
description:
On December 21, 2010, Pakistan's National Highway Authority (NHA) signed a contract with China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) for the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Realignment Project. This project, which was also known as the Realignment of KKH at Attabad Lake Project and the KKH Barrage Lake Line Reconstruction Project, had a total length of 24 kilometers and involved the realignment of a portion of the highway that was submerged under water during the Attabad landslide in 2010. The project included the realignment of roads, construction of 5 tunnels with total length of 7.12 km, 78 culverts and 2 bridges (471.8 meters). 
 
 On December 23, 2011, China Eximbank signed a $259 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [PBC-2011-35-186] with the Government of Pakistan for the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Realignment Project. On the same day, China Eximbank signed an RMB 585 million government concessional loan agreement [GCL-2011-47-397] with the Government of Pakistan for the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Realignment Project. The terms of the PBC (Project ID#39030) are unknown. The terms of the GCL (Project ID#72395) are also unknown. Construction began on July 26, 2012. The project was completed on September 14, 2015. 
 
 Staff Note: The Chinese project title is KKH堰塞湖改线项目 or 喀喇昆仑公路（简称KKH). This project is linked to #35739, which captures a PBC loan for the Raikot-Khunjerab section of the KKH.
name: Northern Areas

title: RMB 585 million government concessional loan [GCL-2011- 47-397] from China Eximbank to the Government of Pakistan for the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Realignment Project (Linked to project #39030 and #35739)
description:
On December 21, 2010, Pakistan's National Highway Authority (NHA) signed a contract with China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) for the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Realignment Project. 
 
 On December 23, 2011, China Eximbank signed a $259 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [PBC-2011-35-186] with the Government of Pakistan for the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Realignment Project. On the same day, China Eximbank signed an RMB 585 million government concessional loan agreement [GCL-2011-47-397] with the Government of Pakistan for the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Realignment Project. The terms of the PBC (Project ID#39030) are unknown. The terms of the GCL (Project ID#72395) are also unknown.
 
 This project, which was also known as the Realignment of KKH at Attabad Lake Project and the KKH Barrage Lake Line Reconstruction Project, had a total length of 24 kilometers and involved the realignment of a portion of the highway that was submerged under water during the Attabad landslide in 2010. The project included the realignment of roads, construction of 5 tunnels with total length of 7.12 km, 78 culverts and 2 bridges (471.8 meters). Construction began on July 26, 2012. The project was completed on September 14, 2015.
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is KKH堰塞湖改线项目 or 喀喇昆仑公路（简称KKH). This project is linked to #35739, which captures a PBC loan for the Raikot-Khunjerab section of the KKH. This project involved the realignment of a 24 km road section along the Karakoram highway near Atta Abad Barrier Lake. More detailed locational information can be found at http://www.na.gov.pk/cpec/sites/default/files/presentations/20151026-Presentation-For-Parliamentary-Commitee-on-CPEC.pdf.
name: Northern Areas

title: China government grants the supply of machinery worthing RMB 45.5 million for Attabad Lake (Linked to #72694)
description: On June 19, 2012, China government signed a letter of exchange (LOE) with government of Pakistan to provide the supply of machinery worthing RMB 45.5 million for the road and bridge construction work undertaken as part of the Karakoram Highway Project at Attabad Lake. The initial project agreement was approved on December 17, 2010. STAFF_NOTE: The supply assistance includes two batches of machinery grants, one is the supply of machinery worthing RMB 45.5 million, captured in this project, the other is the supply of machinery worthing RMB 20 million, captured by project ID#72694.
name: Northern Areas

title: Chinese government grants 8.1 million RMB worth of winter fuel in Honza
description: On November 27, 2010, China handed over winter fuel worth 8.1 million RMB to civilians in Honza, Pakistan. The donation included 2998.66 tons of coal, 74.86 tons of diesel, and 15.12 tons of gasoline.
name: Northern Areas

title: Chinese government granted RMB 20 Million for supply of food items to stranded people of Hunza
description: On March 6, 2013, the Chinese government signed letters of exchange to provide 20 million RMB worth of food supplies to stranded people in Hunza.
name: Northern Areas

title: China Eximbank provides $327.74 million preferential buyer’s credit for Karakoram Highway Improvement (Raikot-Khunjerab Section) Project (Linked to Project ID #39030 and #72395)
description:
On January 18, 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of Pakistan signed a $327,740,000 loan agreement [ID#320080001] for the Karakoram Highway Improvement (Raikot-Khunjerab Section) Project. The loan carried the following terms: 12 year maturity and an unknown interest rate and grace period. 
 
 This project, which is also known as the Karakoram Highway (KKH) Upgrade Project, involved the upgrading of a 335 km segment of the Karakoram Highway runs from Raikot to Khunjerab. This segment was widened from 10 to 30 meters, making it suitable for heavy and long vehicles and allowing it to remain functional throughout the year. The project also involved the construction of 32 new bridges and rehabilitate 27 existing bridges. Its total cost was $491 million. China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) and the Pakistan National Highway Authority (NHA) were responsible for implementation of the project. National Engineering Services Pakistan (Nespak) served as a consultant for the project. 
 
 A groundbreaking ceremony was held on February 16, 2008. Construction began on August 1, 2008. The project was successfully completed on November 30, 2013. The road work was designed and constructed in accordance with China’s three-level highway standard. Final inspection of the project was was carried out by NHA Inspection Wing. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 喀喇昆仑公路改扩建项目 or 喀喇昆仑公路（简称KKH). Some ancillary works were also undertaken by CRBC to realign the highway due to a landslide that happened in 2010. For details on the realignment work on the highway, see Project ID #39030 and #72395. Note that the upgrading and realignment works on the road are jointly called the Phase-I project of KKH Highway.
name: Northern Areas

title: China government grants the supply of machinery worth RMB 20 million for Attabad Lake (Linked to #72693)
description: On June 19, 2012, the Chinese government signed a letter of exchange (LOE) with government of Pakistan to supply machinery worth RMB 20 million for the road and bridge construction work undertaken as part of the Karakoram Highway Project at Attabad Lake. The initial project agreement was originally approved on December 17, 2010. Staff_Note The supply assistance includes two batches of machinery grants, one is the supply of machinery worth RMB 45.5 million, captured by project ID#72693, the other is the supply of machinery worth RMB 20 million, captured by this project.

title: Ningxia Province donates RMB 500,000 to flood-hit Pakistan (linked to #36830)
description: On Saturday 28 August 2010, Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Jiang Yu declared that the Northwest China’s Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region donated RMB 500,000 in cash to Punjab Province, as flood relief.
name: Punjab

title: Sichuan Province donates RMB 100,000 to flood-hit Pakistan (linked to #36828)
description: On Saturday 28 August 2010, Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Jiang Yu declared that the Southwest China’s Sichuan Province donated RMB 100,000 in cash to Punjab Province as part of flood relief.
name: Punjab

title: Chinese embassy donates 1 million rupees to Pakistan to fight Dengue Fever
description: On 15 September, Embassy in Pakistan political counselor Huang, met the Chief Minister of Pakistan's Punjab province representatives, to pass a letter of sympathy and a 1 million rupee check in donation to combat Dengue Fever. The Chinese Embassy had decided to donate 1 million rupees in hopes of fighting the fever, and believes that the provincial government, with its strong leadership, would be able to be victorious in the struggle to fight the dengue epidermic.
name: Punjab

title: China Export-Import Bank commits supplier's credit of US$102 million to Pakistan for white oil pipeline
description:
In 2002, China Petroleum Engineering and Construction Company (CPECC) provided a $102 million supplier's credit to Pak-Arab Pipeline Company Ltd. (PAPCO) for the White Oil Pipeline Project. Pak-Arab Pipeline Company (PARCO/PAPCO) and China Petroleum Engineering Construction Corporation (CPECC) signed an agreement, under which the Chinese firm would supply equipment and materials for the construction of white oil pipeline from Port Qasim, Karachi to Mahmud Kot, Multan. 
 
 This project involved the construction of a 786 km, 26-inch diameter, high-speed diesel oil pipeline that runs from Karachi to Mahmoodkot. A joint venture company (special purpose vehicle) called Pak-Arab Pipeline Company Ltd. (PAPCO) was created to finance, design, implement, and maintain this project. Pak-Arab Refinery Ltd. (PARCO ) -- a joint venture company between Government of Pakistan and the Emirate of Abu Dhabi -- holds a 51% majority share in PAPCO, while Shell, PSO and TOTAL PARCO Marketing Limited hold 26%, 12% and 11% equity shares, respectively. 
 
 On August 7, 2001, Pak-Arab Pipeline Company Ltd. (PAPCO) signed an EPC contract with the China Petroleum Engineering & Construction Corporation – Techno (Pvt) Ltd. Consortium. The total cost of the project was $480 million and it was implemented according to a 75:25 debt-to-equity ratio ($120 million of equity and $360 million of debt financing). 
 
 The project reached financial close in 2002, with China Petroleum Engineering and Construction Company (CPECC) providing a $102 supplier's credit and local banks providing additional debt financing to PAPCO. In order to provide this supplier credit to PAPCO, China Petroleum Engineering and Construction Company (CPECC) secured a $102 million export seller's credit facility with a 10-year maturity from China Eximbank. 
 
 The $481 million project would provide a safer and cost-effective alternative for both crude and refined products transportation and added with the completion of the pipeline a more comprehensive, safer, cost effective, demand responsive and eco-friendly pipeline network will be available to meet the country’s growing needs for energy. The 817 km-long and 26 inch diameter pipeline has an initial capacity of transporting eight million tons refined petroleum products, and 12 million tons white oil per annum. 
 
 The project groundbreaking ceremony was on May 31, 2001. The project reached its commercial operation date on March 1, 2005. It was official inaugurated on completed on August 26, 2005. 
 
 Out of the total cost of $481 million, the foreign component stands at $120 million, while local component stands at Rs 20.657 billion. The debt part of the foreign currency cost is being financed by export credit agencies (ECAs) from China through Engineering, Procurement and Construction (EPC) contractor. Three major banks — HBL, UBL and NBP—will arrange Rs12.5 billion of Rs29 billion White Oil Pipeline Project of PAPCO. Around Rs10 billion would be floated as TFCs (term finance certificates) and the remaining amount would be in the form of redeemable preference shares. The financing arrangement also includes bridge financing of Rs5 billion by the consortium banks to be made available for the project. In this regard, a meeting of the chief executives of NBP, HBL, UBL and PAPCO was held at the NBP office and memorandum of understanding (MoU) was also signed. The Rs29 billion ($480 million) white oil pipeline project is achieving financial close and the entire debt financing of $360 million including Rs12.5 billion in local currency is being arranged whereas equity financing of $120 million is in place. For this project NBP will also provide a foreign currency loan of $18 million and issue a bank guarantee of $102 million for China Exim Bank related to suppliers’ credit from CPECC, which have been selected as EPC contractor for the project.
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 在巴基斯坦成品油管线项目. Note that China Eximbank offers export seller’s credits to Chinese companies that are implementing overseas projects. These companies may, in turn, use the proceeds of an export seller's credit to make equity investments or provide loans to the host government or other entities in the host country. In this case, China Eximbank provided a $102 million export seller's credit to China Petroleum Engineering and Construction Company (CPECC), and CPECC then used the proceeds of the export seller's credit to lend to PAPCO. Also, note that one source identifies the face value of the export seller's credit facility as $120 million.
name: Punjab

title: China grants $1 million for flood relief in AJK Punjab
description: On September 30, 2014, the Chinese government agreed to grant $1 million USD for flood relief in AJK Punjab. On October 15, 2014, China handed over the $1 million grant, according to the Government of Pakistan Ministry of Finance, Revenue, and Economic Affairs. The implementing agency is National Disaster Management Authority (Pakistan).
name: Punjab

title: China Eximbank provides $1.79 billion preferential buyer’s credit loan for Sukkur-Multan Section of Karachi-Lahore Highway Project (Linked to Project ID #39013 and #54415)
description:
On April 28, 2016, China Eximbank signed three different loan agreements with the Government of Pakistan for the Sukkur-Multan Section of the Karachi–Lahore Motorway Project: a $361,224,000 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement, an RMB 4.8 billion government concessional loan (GCL) agreement, an a $1,790,113,000 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement. The maturities, grace periods, and interest rates of these loans are unknown. The BCL loan agreement is captured in Project ID#54415. The GCL agreement is captured in Project ID#39013. The PBC agreement is captured in Project ID#54416. Their Government of Pakistan loan agreement numbers are BCL-16MWAY-CPEC, GCL167576-CPEC, and PBC1610398-CPEC, respectively. 
 
 The Karachi–Lahore Motorway (KLM) is a 1,694 km (1,053 mile), six-lane, high-speed, limited-access motorway that connects Karachi and Peshawar through Islamabad, Lahore, Multan and Sukkur. It is considered to be a major component of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). The 387 km, six-lane Sukkur-Multan section of the motorway follows the left bank of River Indus and it involved the construction of 100 bridges, 468 underpasses, 991 culverts, 11 interchanges, six pairs of service areas, five pairs of rest areas, and 24 toll stations. A revised feasibility study was completed for this project on June 18, 2014. China State Construction and Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on August 5, 2016, and the project was completed on November 5, 2019. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 头实施的白沙瓦至卡拉奇高速公路木尔坦至苏库尔段（PKM项目). The Multan-Shujabad section of the highway was inaugurated by the Prime Minister in May 2018. A Pakistani Ministry of Finance annual status report later revised the expected closure date to 30-APR-21. Pakistani news outlet reports that M-3 section from Lahore to Abdul Hakeem was completed and delivered on March 31, 2019. More locational details can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/peshawar-karachi-motorway-multan-sukkur-section-construction/1f700a87-cdc9-414a-8353-ce68ddf9f5fd/
name: Bahawalpur

title: China Exim Bank loans RMB 100 million to 100 MW Crest Energy Pakistan Limited Solar Power Plant at Quaid-e Azam Solar Park (Linked to Project #50939, #53988 and #54284) (CPEC, IPP)
description: Crest Energy Pakistan Limited (CEPL) is a special purpose vehicle designed to facilitate the construction of a 100 MW Solar PV power plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan, District Bahawalpur in the Province of Punjab. On December 21, 2015, CEPL signed a Term Facility Agreement with China EXIM Bank and China Bohai Co Limited. Financial closure was reached on December 28, 2015. On June 27, 2015, CEPL signed Engineering, Procurement, Construction contracts with China First Metallurgical Group Co. Ltd. and MCC Ruba International Construction Company Pvt. Ltd. to build, own, and operate a 100 MW AC Solar powered electric generation facility in the Solar Park. The cumulative EPC contract value is 984 Million RMB. The Commercial Operations Date for this CEPL Solar Power plant was July 31, 2016. The total project cost is 149.457 USD Million, with a Debt-Equity ratio of 75:25. China EXIM Bank made 2 loans to CEPL - one denominated in RMB worth 100 Million (equivalent to 15.196 million USD) and another one denominated in USD, worth 40.810 Million USD (captured in #53988). China Bohai Bank made 1 loan to CEPL, denominated in USD and worth 56.190 million USD (captured in #54284). These two loans make up the 75% debt component of the overall project. The interest rate for Exim Bank's RMB denominated loan is 2.65%. The Interest rate for Exim Bank's USD denominated loan is 5.6916%, and the interest rate for China Bohai Bank's loan is 5.0958%. This projects records the RMB denominated loan from China EXIM bank. It is unclear how the equity component was financed. Staff_Note: This project is linked to #50939, an umbrella project capturing the financing for the Chinese-financed solar plants at Quaid-e Azam Solar Park.
name: Bahawalpur

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 100 million loan for 100 MW Solar PV Power Plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park (Linked to Project #50939, #53989 and #54286) (CPEC, IPP)
description: On December 21, 2015, Best Green Energy Pakistan Limited (BGEPL) signed three loan agreements with China Eximbank and Bank of Jiangsu Co Limited for the construction of a 100 MW Solar PV Power Plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan, within Bahawalpur District in the Province of Punjab. BGEPL later signed Engineering, Procurement, and Construction (EPC) contracts with China First Metallurgical Group Co. Ltd and with MCC Ruba International Construction Company (Pvt) Ltd. This $150.269 million project was implemented on a build, own and operate (BOO) basis and it was financed according to a debt-equity ratio of 81:19. China Eximbank gave 2 loans, one RMB-denominated worth 100 million that carried a 2.65% interest rate and 10 year maturity, and another denominated in USD worth $49.060 million that carried an 5.0058%. The Bank of Jiangsu gave a third loan, denominated in USD, which worth 64.440 million (5.0958% interest rate) (captured in #54286). This projects records the RMB-denominated loan from China Eximbank. Project ID#53989 records the USD-denominated loan from China Eximbank. It is unclear how the equity component was financed. The project reached its commercial operation date (COD) on July 31, 2016. Staff_Note: This project is linked to #50939, an umbrella project capturing the financing for the Chinese-financed solar plants at Quaid-e Azam Solar Park.
name: Bahawalpur

title: China Eximbank and CDB provide $62.6 million syndicated loan to 100 MW Solar PV Power Plant at the Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park (Linked to Project ID#50939 and #53985) (CPEC, IPP)
description:
On October 16, 2015, Appolo Solar Development Pakistan Limited (ASDPL) — a project company (special purpose vehicle) established by Zonergy Company Limited — signed an RMB 400 million syndicated loan agreement (project ID#53985) and a $62.6 million syndicated loan agreement (this project) with China Eximbank and China Development Bank. The RMB-denominated loan carried an interest rate of 2.65% and the USD-denominated loan carried an interest rate of 4.96%. The total project cost was $149.154 million and it was financed according to a debt-to-equity ratio of 79:21. 
 
 The project was implemented on a build-own-operate (BOT) basis and it involved the construction of a 100 MW solar PV power plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan within Bahawalpur District and the Province of Punjab. China First Metallurgical Group Co. Ltd and with MCC Ruba International Construction Company (Pvt) Ltd were the EPC contractors. This project reached its commercial operation date (COD) on May 31, 2016.
 
 Staff_Note: This 100 MW solar PV power plant is located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan within Bahawalpur District and the Province of Punjab. More detailed locational coordinates can be found at https://www.nepra.org.pk/licensing/Licences/Generation/RE-2006/Appolo%20Development%20Solar/LAG-296%20APPOLO%20SDPL%20GENERATION%20LIC%2030-06-2015%209859-65.PDF.
name: Bahawalpur

title: China Exim Bank loans $40.81 million USD to 100 MW Crest Energy Pakistan Limited Solar Power Plant at Quaid-e Azam Solar Park (Linked to Project #50939, #54283 and #54284) (CPEC, IPP)
description: Crest Energy Pakistan Limited (CEPL) is a special purpose vehicle designed to facilitate the construction of a 100 MW Solar PV power plant located at Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park at Lal Sohanra in Cholistan, District Bahawalpur in the Province of Punjab. The Commercial Operations Date for this CEPL Solar Power plant was July 31, 2016. The total project cost is 149.457 USD Million, with a Debt-Equity ratio of 75:25. China EXIM Bank made 2 loans to CEPL: one denominated in RMB worth 100 Million (equivalent to 15.196 million USD) (captured in #54283) and another one denominated in USD, worth 40.810 Million USD. China Bohai Bank made 1 loan to CEPL, denominated in USD and worth 56.190 million USD (captured in #54284). These two loans make up the 75% debt component of the overall project. The interest rate for Exim Bank's RMB denominated loan is 2.65%. The Interest rate for Exim Bank's USD denominated loan is 5.6916%, and the interest rate for China Bohai Bank's loan is 5.0958%. This projects records the USD denominated loan from China EXIM bank. It is unclear how the equity component was financed. Staff_Note: This project is linked to #50939, an umbrella project capturing the financing for the Chinese-financed solar plants at Quaid-e Azam Solar Park.
name: Bahawalpur

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 4.8 billion government concessional loan for Sukkur-Multan Section of Karachi-Lahore Highway Project (Linked to Project ID #54415 and #54416)
description:
On April 28, 2016, China Eximbank signed three different loan agreements with the Government of Pakistan for the Sukkur-Multan Section of the Karachi–Lahore Motorway Project: a $361,224,000 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement, an RMB 4.8 billion government concessional loan (GCL) agreement, an a $1,790,113,000 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement. The maturities, grace periods, and interest rates of these loans are unknown. The BCL loan agreement is captured in Project ID#54415. The GCL agreement is captured in Project ID#39013. The PBC agreement is captured in Project ID#54416. Their Government of Pakistan loan agreement numbers are BCL-16MWAY-CPEC, GCL167576-CPEC, and PBC1610398-CPEC, respectively. 
 
 The Karachi–Lahore Motorway (KLM) is a 1,694 km (1,053 mile), six-lane, high-speed, limited-access motorway that connects Karachi and Peshawar through Islamabad, Lahore, Multan and Sukkur. It is considered to be a major component of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). The 387 km, six-lane Sukkur-Multan section of the motorway follows the left bank of River Indus and it involved the construction of 100 bridges, 468 underpasses, 991 culverts, 11 interchanges, six pairs of service areas, five pairs of rest areas, and 24 toll stations. A revised feasibility study was completed for this project on June 18, 2014. China State Construction and Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on August 5, 2016, and the project was completed on November 5, 2019. 
 
 STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 头实施的白沙瓦至卡拉奇高速公路木尔坦至苏库尔段（PKM项目). The Multan-Shujabad section of the highway was inaugurated by the Prime Minister in May 2018. A Pakistani Ministry of Finance annual status report later revised the expected closure date to 30-APR-21. Pakistani news outlet reports that M-3 section from Lahore to Abdul Hakeem was completed and delivered on March 31, 2019.
name: Bahawalpur
