title: China launched 'Hundred Talents Program' for training professional technical personnel for Central-Asia Natural Gas Project (Linked to project ID##39955, #70616)
description: On October 10, 2017, Xi'an Shiyou University of China held the launching ceremony of the 'Hundred Talents Program'. In 2016, Xi'an Shiyou University successfully won the bid for the TTGP foreign employee training project. After the launching of Central-Asia Natural Gas Project (captured in #39955), according to the agreement between the governments of China and Tajikistan, China will train 90 relevant professional localized technical personnel for Tajikistan. Therefore, TTGP actively sought out Chinese partner universities to undertake the localized staff training tasks required for the construction and operation of the pipeline. According to the agreement, the company will select the first group of 30 students from Tajikistan to come to China to study Chinese language and oil and gas pipeline transportation and other professional academic education, and become the first group of students to come to China in the TTGP China-Tajikistan school-enterprise cooperation talent training project 'Hundred Talents Program'. The first thirty students to receive the training were selected from the 1,000 top students, with the assistance of National Testing Center of Tajikistan, and China National Natural Gas Pipeline Co., Ltd., under the approval of the Deputy Prime Minister of Tajikistan. The students will take Chinese language courses in Tianjin University for one year, and in Xi'an Shiyou University for another year. Then they will study the undergraduate major courses of oil and gas storage and transportation in Xi'an Shiyou University. After graduation, they will work professionally for the Line D of Central-Asia Natural Gas Project. Fifteen students out of thirty received scholarships of the 'Silk Road' Program from the Chinese Government. China-Central Asia natural gas pipeline Line D is an inter-governmental project signed by China, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan. The construction of the Tajikistan section of the 1,000-km-long line was launched in September 2014. Tajikistan has the longest section of the pipeline at about 410 km. For details on this project see #39955 and #70616.
name: Tajikistan

title: China to provide 70 million RMB technical assistance to Tajikistan
description: In 2017, China committed to grant technical facilities worth 70 million RMB to Tajikistan to strengthen its capacity of emergency response. Committee of Emergency Situations and Civil Defense secured automobiles, munitions, and special technical equipment from China through an agreement under the United Nations Development Programme. More than 100,000 people live in danger areas in Tajikistan, and 27 people have died in natural disasters in the first half of 2017. As of July, 2017, 284 areas in Tajikistan were considered dangerous for human habitation. Along with the project, the Committee will also receive $500,000 grant from Japan and $460,000 from Russia.
name: Tajikistan

title: Chinese Government provides food aid worth RMB 15 million to Tajikistan
description: On March 12, 2003, as part of a humanitarian relief package, China sent Tajikistan RMB 15 million worth of food aid. The food aid was intended to help alleviate Tajikistan's food issues, as the country is not self-sufficient in food production. The food aid included 2,340 tons of sugar, 1,200 tons of rice, and 320 tons of soybean. STAFF_NOTE: The May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS reported that the food aid was worth USD 1,812,000. This is approximately equal to RMB 15 million. The AIMS project ID is TJK/042050. The CNY amount was coded because it came from a Chinese official source from Chinese Embassy's Economic and Commercial office. The AIMS project ID is TJK/042050. This project is not to be confused with humanitarian aid provided by China in November 2002 (captured in project ID#72328).
name: Tajikistan

title: China grants RMB 10 million emergency humanitarian relief to Tajikistan
description: On July 23, 2015, Chinese Foreign Minister of China Wang Yi pledged to provide emergency humanitarian relief to Tajikistan during the meeting with his Tajik counterpart Sirojiddin Aslov. Constant high temperature since July caused glaciers to melt, leading to severe landslides in Tajikistan and causing serious casualties. On August 5, the Department of Foreign Assistance of MOFCOM delivered Tajikistan RMB10 million relief.
name: Tajikistan

title: China Grants $6M to Fight Poverty in Tajikistan
description: Summary: In 2004, China donated nearly 6 million dollars to neighboring Tajikistan to help fight poverty in the Central Asian nation. Mountainous Tajikistan has a 520-kilometer (325-mile) border with its huge eastern neighbor. The two countries inaugurated their first border crossing for vehicles, goods and people in May.
name: Tajikistan

title: Chinese Government provides an RMB 200 million grant to Tajikistan in ETCA (Linked to Project ID#40482, #69997, #40479, #72802)
description: On May 20, 2013, as a part of an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), China agreed to provide Tajikistan a grant of RMB 200 million, as one of seven agreements signed between China and Tajikistan during the official meetings and negotiations between Xi Jinping and President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon, according to Amonatbonk. The grant money comes with 'no strings attatched,' or no stipulation on usage. The other agreements signed on May 20, 2013 were: a collection of loans totaling USD 20 million to Amonatbonk (captured in project ID#72802 ), a collection of loans totaling 33 million RMB to Amonatbonk (captured in project ID#69997), an agreement for the reconstruction of Regar Substation (captured in project ID#40482), a loan to Zijin Mining for investment into the Zeravshan Gold Mine (captured in project ID#40479), a technical cooperation agreement, a fruit inspection protocol, and a sports cooperation agreement.
name: Tajikistan

title: China Granted $19,000 Worth of Aid to Tajik Emergency Ministry
description: Summary: On September 20, 2004, Chinese ambassador to Tajikistan, Wu Hongbin, presented humanitarian aid to the Tajik Ministry of Emergency Situations. The humanitarian aid consisted of tents and children's clothing. The total value of the aid is 19,000 dollars. Officials from the Tajik Ministry of Emergency Situations expressed their gratitude to embassy officials for this no-strings aid. The aid provided would be used in the event of natural disasters.
name: Tajikistan

title: China grants Tajikistan 10 buses and 25 tractors
description: Stipulated under earlier agreements, China granted Tajikistan 10 buses and 25 tractors. No further information regarding the value of the equipment was located.
name: Tajikistan

title: China grants food, tents and sheets to Tajikistan for Harsh Winter Relief
description: In April 2012, the government of China sent Tajikistan a humanitarian aid package consisting of 220 tons of rice, 120 tons of vegetable oil, tents, and sheets. It is unclear which part of the Chinese government provided the funding, and the financial value of the project is unclear. STAFF_NOTE: This project should not be confused with project #57839, the 2011 natural disaster response from China to Tajikistan. The 2012 aid package primarily seeks to address the impact of an unusually cold winter, while the 2011 aid package primarily seeks to address a flood.
name: Tajikistan

title: People's Bank of China loans $20 million to the State Savings Bank of Tajikistan (Linked to project ID#72549)
description: In September 2014, the State Savings Bank of Tajikistan, Amonatbok, and the People's Bank of China have negotiated a 20 million US concessional loan. The loan will be used for construction of the bank's new building and expansion of the bank's agricultural credit. The project's overall aim is to expand entrepreneurship and alleviate poverty in Tajikistan. The project is linked to another funding from CDB for the same construction project, which was captured in project ID#72549.
name: Tajikistan

title: China donates furniture to Tajikistan
description: In 2008, the Chinese government donated furniture worth $410,960 to Tajikistan, as reported in the May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS. The project ID is TJK/082180. STAFF_NOTE: No additional information about this project could be found.
name: Tajikistan

title: Chinese Government grants Tajikistan $732,386 for natural disaster response (Linked to project ID#40409)
description: On June 11, 2010, Chinese President Hu Jintao announced that the Chinese Government would allocate a grant in assistance to Tajikistan to eliminate the consequences of that year's natural disasters.This project corresponds to TJK/102178 in the Tajikistan AIMS, which details a grant of $732,386 USD for 'Assistance in natural disaster'. At the same day, Chinese President Hu also announced another RMB 80 million RMB to support the Tajik economy, which is captured in project ID #40409. STAFF_NOTE: The media report showed that the transaction amount is RMB 5 million. Though Chinese are denominated in RMB in most cases, $732,386 USD was coded because it came from an official source.
name: Tajikistan

title: China and Tajikistan complete joint investigation on climate change
description: In September 2015, the Tajikistan academy of sciences invited researchers from the Institute of Urumqi Desert Meteorology of the China Meteorological Administration. The groups carried out an 8-day scientific investigation of climate change and water resources. The investigation is expected to bolster regional cooperation among countries in Asia and act as a foundation for future research of climate change in Central Asia countries.
name: Tajikistan

title: China Development Bank loans $28 million to State Savings Bank of Tajikistan 'Amonatbonk' for crediting small and medium-sized businesses
description: On September 13, 2014, China Development Bank (CDB) and State Savings Bank of Tajikistan 'Amonatbonk' signed a master loan facility agreement worth $28 million. $10 million of this loan was to be spent crediting small and medium-sized businesses (see pg. 29 of English side of 'Amonatbonk 2014 Annual Report').
name: Tajikistan

title: Chinese Government grants 105 vehicles worth $2.7 million USD to Tajikistan
description: On August 1, 2008, the Chinese Government handed over a total of 105 vehicles, consisting of 80 buses, five garbage trucks, and 20 executive cars for use during the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit to Tajikistan (see 'Tajikistan gets 105 Chinese vehicles'). This project appears to correspond to project TJK/082181 in the Tajikistan AIMS database, which captures the 'supply of buses and technical equipment for community facilities.' AIMS reported that the vehicles were worth $2,739,726 USD. STAFF_NOTE: Intent was coded as 'Mixed' because the provision of executive cars was for the SCO summit.
name: Tajikistan

title: China Development Bank provides $70.6 million loan to CJSC TK Mobile for CDMA National Network Project (Linked to Project ID#71575)
description:
In December 2006, the China Development Bank (CDB) provided a US $70.6 million loan to Closed Joint-Stock Company CJSC TK Mobile (a Tajik-Chinese mobile phone operator). The loan was meant to be used to finance the CDMA National Network Project and the purchasing of equipment and services from ZTE. The loan has a maturity of 9 years. In May 2019, ZTE provided a guarantee by pledging its 51% equity interest in CJSC TK Mobile as the provision of guarantee, with a term from the date on which the Agreement on the Pledge of Equity Interests is executed and becomes effective to the date on which the debts owed by CJSC TK Mobile under the financing documents are fully repaid. 

The CDMA National Network Project entailed the purchase of telecommunications equipment, relevant software and services for the construction of the CDMA 800M national network in Tajikistan.

STAFF_NOTE: CJSC TK Mobile is a telecommunications operator established in Tajikistan in December 2003 as a joint venture by ZTE and Service Svyaz Komplect (‘‘CCK’’) with a registered capital of US$4,000,000. ZTE held a 51% ownership stake and CCK owned a 49% ownership stake (see linked project ID#71575).
name: Tajikistan

title: Chinese Government grants $20,400 to Tajikistan for Meteorological Management
description: In 2004, the Government of the People's Republic of China provided a grant of $20,400 for a project in Tajikistan for the meteorological management of the PRC, according to the Tajikistan AIMS platform (AIMS ID: TJK/042055). STAFF_NOTE: This project was listed in the Tajikistan AIMS platform, which indicates that funds did go to Tajikistan, however the source indicated that the funding was used for meteorological management of People's Republic of China.
name: Tajikistan

title: Peking University donates 100 desktop computers and related equipment to Tajikistan for hosting of International Decade for Action 'Water for Life' conference
description: On June 9, 2010, Peking University donated 100 desktop computers and related equipment to Tajikistan so it could hold the international conference for the International Decade for Action 'Water for Life', according to the Chinese Embassy to Tajikistan. After the conference, the computers were to be used in Tajik universities for teaching and scientific research. The total value of the donated computers is not known. STAFF_NOTE: 2010 was coded as the commitment year because the computers were handed over at that time; the actual year of commitment is not known, hence the Year Uncertain designation. Education was selected as CRS sector because these computers were ultimately going to Tajik universities.
name: Tajikistan

title: Chinese Embassy provides 'Ambassador Scholarships' to 25 Tajik students (Linked to Project ID#71853)
description: On November 30, 2017, during an 'Open Day' at the Chinese Embassy in Tajikistan, Chinese Ambassador Yue Bin awarded 'Ambassador Scholarships' to 25 outstanding students selected from more than 4,000 Tajikistan students who learned Chinese in Confucius School. The value of the scholarships is not known. STAFF_NOTE: This project is linked to project ID#71853, which captured a project for 25 Ambassador Scholarships presented by the Chinese Embassy during an 'Open Day' event on May 11, 2018.
name: Tajikistan

title: Chinese Government grants aid worth $640,640 to Tajik Ministry of Internal Affairs
description: In 2002, the Chinese Ministry of Public Security and the Tajik Ministry of Internal Affairs (also known as the Ministry of the Interior) signed an agreement on the fight against terrorism, extremism and separatism, which included the provision of no-strings aid to Tajikistan. The aid was handed over on March 11, 2003. The aid consisted of twenty patrol cars (Radio Free Europe suggests it was 50 vehicles), special equipment, computers, laser printers, uniforms and footwear for the ministry's special subdivisions, special crime detection equipment, communication devices, night vision binoculars, cameras, metal detectors, shields, and helmets, among other goods (see BBC's 'Tajik police get 0.7m-dollar aid from China'). Material for bomb defusal was also included. Media sources indicate that the value of the aid was $700,000. However, according to the Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS as of May 2018, the Chinese government funded 'Policemen facilities' (AIMS project ID TJK/042056) worth $483,600. Additionally, there was an additional contribution of $157,040 USD for 'Different kind of equipment' (AIMS project ID TJK/042058). Together, these two donations totaled $640,640, therefore it seems they are referencing this same project, even though transaction amounts differ slightly, so the transaction amount was coded as $640,640 USD to reflect official source information.
name: Tajikistan

title: Chinese Government provides $305,810 in grant assistance for drug trafficking seminars in Xinjiang
description:
In 2011, the Chinese Government provided grant assistance worth $305,810 to Tajikistan for seminars, as reported by the May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS. The AIMS project ID is TJK/112259. 

STAFF_NOTE: This was likely referencing the training courses and seminars provided in 2011 to 15 Tajik drug control officers entitled "Fight against Illicit Drug Trafficking" provided by the Ministry of Public Security of China and the XUAR Department for Public Security. The training took place in China’s Xinjiang-Uyghur Autonomous Region (XUAR).
name: Tajikistan

title: Chinese Government grants $500,000 USD to Tajikistan for the Ninth Meeting of the Heads of Governments of member states of SCO
description: According to the May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS, the Chinese Government provided $500,000 USD in grant assistance to Tajikistan for the Ninth Meeting of the Heads of Governments of member states of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO). The AIMS project ID is TJK/112261. However, the ninth meeting of the heads of government of SCO was held in Russia in 2009, so it seems likely that this Tajikistan AIMS project may instead meant the eighth meeting of the heads of government of SCO, which was held in Tajikistan in 2008. The commitment year has therefore been coded as 2008 and flagged as year uncertain.
name: Tajikistan

title: Chinese Government grants $2.7 million worth of equipment to the Tajik Drug Control Agency
description: On November 23, 2007, China donated mobile drug testing equipment worthing $2,739,726 to the Drug Control Agency of Tajikistan. The equipment was designed to detect illicit substances in vehicles and containers. The Development Partners Profile 2012 calls this project 'Mobile inspection and observation complex.' STAFF_NOTE: The BBC listed the total value of the equipment as $4 million. But the Flat Export of AIMS Tajikistan as of May 2018 reported a 'Mobile inspection-examination complex' project funded by the Chinese government for $2,739,726, which is the amount captured in this project.
name: Tajikistan

title: Chinese Government forgives $6.5 million loan to Tajikistan
description: In 2000, the Chinese Government forgave a $6.5 million USD loan to Tajikistan (see pg.10 of 'INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN Staff Report for the 2006 Article IV Consultation'). STAFF_NOTE: The IMF's language states that the Tajikistan's external debt from China was converted into a grant. Additionally, little is known about the loan that was forgiven, but it was mostly likely made prior to the year 2000.
name: Tajikistan

title: Chinese Government commits a RMB 5 million interest-free loan to Tajikistan
description: On April 9, 2001, the Chinese Government and the Government of Tajikistan signed an RMB 5 million interest-free loan agreement. The agreement was signed between the delegations from the Tajikistan ministry for trade and economy and the Chinese ministry for foreign trade and economic cooperation. It is not known how the proceeds of this loan were used.
name: Tajikistan

title: Chinese Government donates TV and FM transmitters worth $684,931 to Tajikistan
description: In 2008, the Chinese Government donated broadcasting equipment worth $684,931 to Tajikistan, as reported in the May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS. The AIMS project ID is TJK/082179. According to Development Partner Profiles 2012, the broadcasting equipment was specifically TV and FM transmitters. STAFF_NOTE: 'Year uncertain' box was checked because it is not confirmed that the donation of this equipment was committed in 2008. While 'Development Partner Profiles 2012' does not explain much, the timeframe, type of flow, and what was being donated showed that this was the same project captured by AIMS.
name: Tajikistan

title: China Development Bank funds 15 employees of the State Savings Bank of Tajikistan 'Amonatbonk' for Chinese university education
description:
After 2009, China Development Bank (CDB) provided funds so that 15 employees of the State Savings Bank of the Republic of Tajikistan "Amonatbonk" could enter into Chinese universities to learn the Chinese language. By November 2019, 12 selected employees had graduated, while three employees, specialists at the Head Office of Bank, were studying at the International Education College of Shandong University of Jinan (see "Вохӯрии Раиси Раёсати БДА ҶТ «Амонатбонк» бо Роҳбари Бонки давлатии Рушди Хитой дар Ҷумҳурии Тоҷикистон ва Ўзбекистон" and pg. 36-37 of English half of "Amonatbonk 2014 Annual Report"). The value of the education is unknown.

STAFF_NOTE: "Year uncertain" was selected because it is unknown exactly when this program began, only that it began "since 2009" and was active before November 2019. It appears that the 3 employees at Shandong University were agreed upon in 2014 (see pg. 36-37 of English half of "Amonatbonk 2014 Annual Report").
name: Tajikistan

title: Chinese Government provides US$2 million food aid to victims of natural disasters in Tajikistan
description: In November 2002, the Chinese Government provided humanitarian food aid to the victims of natural disasters in Tajikistan. The aid included 15 tons of rice, 10 tons of sugar and 2,000 barrels of edible oil (5 liters of oil per barrel). The value of the food aid is US$2 million. STAFF_NOTE: This project is not to be confused with food aid provided by China in March 2003 (project ID#40220).
name: Tajikistan

title: China Development Bank loans RMB 33 million to the State Savings Bank of Tajikistan 'Amonatbonk' (Linked to Project ID#40481, #40482, #40479, #72802)
description:
On May 20, 2013, several loan agreements between the State Savings Bank of Tajikistan "Amonatbonk" and China Development Bank of China (CDB) were signed (see "Пресс-релизы : Официальные переговоры на высшем уровне между Республикой Таджикистан и Китайской Народной Республикой") for on-lending activities. The RMB portion of the agreements totaled to RMB 33 million, however no breakdown of the individual agreements was found. Part of loans will be used for financing Tajik agricultural sectors. 

The loans were part of a series of investments made on May 20th during President of Tajikistan Emomalii Rahmon's visit to China. These other projects were: a collection of loans totaling USD 20 million to Amonatbonk (captured in project ID#72802 ), a 200 million RMB grant (captured in project ID#40481), an agreement for the reconstruction of Regar Substation (captured in project ID#40482), a loan to Zijin Mining for investment into the Zeravshan Gold Mine (captured in project ID#40479), a technical cooperation agreement, a fruit inspection protocol, and a sports cooperation agreement.
name: Tajikistan

title: China Eximbank provides $267.2 million preferential buyer's credit for 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project (Linked to Project ID#39984, #70910)
description:
In March 2006, the Government of Tajikistan and the Export-Import Bank of China signed a MoU for projects proposed by Tajikistan (see pg. 14 of "China as an Emerging Donor in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan"). Later, on December 21, 2006, the Export-Import Bank of China provided a $267,219,451 USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan to the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan for the 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project (for the transaction amount, see pg. 87 of "Power Utility Financial Recovery Program-for-Results (P168211) Program Technical Assessment Final Report"). The loan terms carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and an interest rate of 2% (for the loan details, see "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). 

The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend (through subsidiary loan agreement (No. BLA06015, #6015) to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik” at a 3% interest rate between December 21, 2006 and June 21, 2026. As of December 31, 2018, $2,519,773 USD was still outstanding. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy. 

The initial estimated value of the project was $281.3 million USD.The purpose of this project was to construct a 500 kV electricity transmission line that would connect the northern Sughd region to the national grid. According to Xinhua, the project also intended to realize the effective dispatching of electricity between Dushanbe and Khujand, completely solve the problem of power shortage in the south during the dry season in winter, build the transmission channel for the implementation of the Tajik Hydropower Strategy, improve the safety, stability, and reliability of the power grid, and reduce the loss of electricity through transmission from 14% to 3.2%. 

Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock (TBEA) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on September 16, 2006. The North-South transmission line has been operational since November 29, 2009, according to TBEA's report. The construction of the 325 km, 500 kV south–north power transmission line reportedly enabled Tajikistan to become independent of the Uzbek power transmission network and to distribute electricity throughout the country. 

The project is linked to project ID#70910, which captured a $51 million funding from Eximbank in 2009 for both the 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line project and a 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project (The original financing of the 220 kV project in 2006 was captured in project ID#39984). 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Строительство ЛЭП 500 кВ “Юг-Север”. The Chinese project title is 塔吉克斯坦南北220—500kV输变电成套工程. Additionally, China Eximbank indicates that this project was financed by preferential export buyer's credit in the '重大项目 Major Projects' document.
name: Tajikistan

title: China Eximbank provides $8.36 million government concessional loan for Safe City Project (Linked to Project ID#71411)
description:
On May 20, 2013, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed two loan agreements with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Safe City Project: a RMB-denominated government concessional loan (GCL) provided on highly concessional terms (20-year maturity, 11-year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate) and a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan on highly concessional terms (2% interest, 20-year maturity, 9-year grace period).

The precise face value of the GCL loan and the precise face value of the PBC loan are unknown. However, it is known that the GCL and PBC are jointly worth $20.9 million USD, and that 40% of the total debt financing from China Eximbank ($8.36 million) came from the RMB-denominated GCL and 60% of the total debt financing from China Eximbank ($12.54 million) came from the USD-denominated PBC (AidData learned this through correspondence with the IMF, see "Following Up" resource). Project ID#46215 records the GCL and project ID#71411 records the PBC. 

The loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament in June 2013 and were expected to be repaid with revenues from the traffic fines generated by this project. The total cost of the project was $22 million USD. In addition to the Chinese loans, the Government of Tajikistan contributed $1.1 million USD.

According to Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Republic of Tajikistan, the Safe City Project involved the installation of 855 CCTV cameras for round-the-clock monitoring of traffic and other movements at 75 crossroads, streets, and squares in the capital city of Dushanbe. The cameras were to record every offense committed by drivers, which would be stored and processed in a common database. Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. was responsible for project implementation. Tajik Ministry of Internal Affairs was also responsible for the undertaking of the project. 

The Safe City project and the control center were officially launched on October 31, 2013 by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. The Safe City Project was to be carried out in three stages; the second stage was expected to be finished in May 2014. The project was still on going as of December 2014. As of January 16, 2015, it had reportedly generated $4 million for the Tajik state budget via traffic fines. According to a Huawei report issued in February 2015, Huawei completed the project successfully. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Автоматическая система управления транспорта в городе Душанбе (Безопасный город). Asia Plus reported at the time that Tajikistan authorities claimed the loan would be repayable through traffic violation fines.
name: Rudaki

title: China Embassy funded the Women's Sewing Training and Production Center in Dushanbe (Linked to Project ID#53594, #54043, #53591)
description:
On January 8, 2016, Yue Bin, Ambassador of Tajikistan, attended the inauguration ceremony of the Women's Sewing Training Production Center in Sino District, Dushanbe (Chinese location name: 杜尚别市西诺区), sponsored by the Chinese Embassy. It is believed that the establishment of the training production center will definitely play a positive role in further promoting local women's employment and improving their living standards, and at the same time writing a new chapter for the friendship between the people of Tazhong.

Chinese Embassy also funded other differenct Women’s Sewing Training and Production Center in Tajikistan. Project ID#53594 captured the sewing center in Danghara. Project ID#54043 captured the sewing center in Maslozhelkomupo District, Dushanbe. Project ID#53591 captured the sewing center in Vakhsh District, Khatlon.
name: Rudaki

title: China Eximbank provides $15 million loan for Phase 1 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project (Linked to Project ID #46211, #71101, #71137)
description:
On July 4, 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China and China Development Bank (CDB) provided a $30 million USD loan for Phase 1 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project. According to Trend News Agency, the project's financing was on a 50-50 basis by the two Chinese banks to Ministry of Energy and Industry of Tajikistan. Other detailed terms of this loan are unknown. Project ID#54106 only captures the $15 million USD from China Eximbank. China Development Bank's contribution was captured in project ID#71101. Other detailed terms of this loan are unknown.

Then, in 2014, the Export-Import Bank of China provided two loans — an RMB 929,977,078 government concessional loan (GCL) (captured in project ID#46211) and a $178,969,220 USD preferential buyer’s credit loan (PBC) (captured in project ID#71137) for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project (for the GCL loan amount, see pg. 87 of "Program Appraisal Document on a Proposed Grant..."; for the PBC loan amount, see "Information on existing state investment projects"). Both of these loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. The GCL loan was contracted with the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and it carried the following terms: 25 year maturity, 11 year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate (see "РАМОЧНОЕ СОГЛАШЕНИЕ между Правительством Китайской Народной Республики и Правительством Республики Таджикистан о предоставлении Китайской Народной Республикой Республике Таджикистан льготного кредита"). The PBC loan has a 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period, and 2% interest rate (see "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). 

The Government of Tajikistan contributed $17,443,400 USD. In total, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan contracted $331,058,220 USD of China Eximbank debt for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project. The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from the GCL and the PBC loan to on-lend to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik”. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy.

The subsidiary GCL loan agreement (#TАJ 2014-028-2) was signed between Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” on December 18, 2014. It carried an interest rate of 5% and a maturity of 25 years. Its final maturity date was set to August 21, 2039. The subsidiary PBC loan agreement (#TАJ 2014-028-1) was also signed between Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” on December 18, 2014 and it carried an interest rate of 5% and a maturity of 20 years. Its final maturity date was set to June 21, 2034. 

Dushanbe 2 is a combined heat and power plant (CHP) — also known as the Dushanbe-2 Thermal Power Plant (TPS-2) — that provides heat and electricity for the residents of Dushanbe. It only operates in the winter. The 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project required two phases. Phase 1 (mainly constructed between 2012-2014) installed a capacity of 100 MW, while Phase 2 (constructed between 2014-2016) installed an additional capacity of 300 MW. TBEA was the contractor responsible for implementation of both phases. CHP-2 was to be fueled by coal, with the potential to switch to gas. According to State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council, Inner Mongolia Electric Power Survey and Design Institute Co., Ltd. was the project designer for Phase 2. According to PowerChina, Hydro Electric Power System Engineering Company was also involved in the undertaking of Phase 2 of the project.

The first phase was scheduled to be completed and put into production before the celebration of the 20th anniversary of Tajik independence in 2011 (September 9th), and the second phase was scheduled to be completed in 2013. Phase 1 of the project began on September 8, 2009 and was put into operation on November 10, 2014. Phase 2 of the project began on May 14, 2015 and was completed on December 8, 2016.

According to President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon as relayed by TBEA, the plant generates 9.6 million kWh power per day and 235 trillion Kcal heat, and provided nearly 700 stable jobs to Tajiks. 150 Tajikistan technicians went to China for training, and about 100 Tajikistan operators mastered professional know-how under the guidance of Chinese experts. According to Xinhua, the completed station met 60 percent of the power demand and enabled the restart of central heating for more than 700,000 Dushanbe residents after 15 years of suspension. The completion of the Dushanbe-2 thermal power station was also declared to be the solution to Tajikistan's long-existing issue of power shortages in winter.

This power plant is located in Dushanbe. Its exact locational coordinates are available at http://globalenergyobservatory.org/geoid/41775.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Душанбинская ТЭЦ-2. The $30 million loan from China Eximbank and China Development Bank may not have covered the full cost of Phase 1 of the project. In the Government of Tajikistan’s Aid Information Management System (AIMS), the project is referred to as "Project of construction of second in succession construction of 'TPS-2' in Dushanbe." 

Some sources suggest that major delays took place after Tajikistan contracted this loan on July 4, 2009. The ceremony for the beginning of the project was clearly on September 8, 2009, but it seems project construction did not begin in earnest until 2012, when TBEA agreed to “front” $178 million for the construction of Phase 1 by borrowing directly from China Eximbank, and, in turn, the Tajik government agreed to grant TBEA exclusive rights to explore and develop gold deposits at the Eastern Duoba mine and the Upper Kumarg mine (until TBEA could recoup its investment). The Tajik government also reportedly agreed to give TBEA the rights to further mining deposits (at an unidentified location) if the profit made from the gold deposits did not cover the cost of building the power plant.

According to Kazakhstan Newsline, Tajikistan also issued a license to TBEA for the development of coal mines (see "Chinese TBEA company says Dushanbe is ready to provide its gold mines"). Another media source, Central Asia News, said that the mineral resources were to be used to compensate the costs of the company for construction of the Dushanbe-2 in the amount of $178 million USD. It also reported that the proven reserves of 3 gold mines was to be estimated 51.7 tons of gold (see "China’s TBEA may obtain license for development of another mine in Tajikistan"). Another media source, Asia-Plus reported that the license for development of the Upper Kumargh gold deposit was granted to TBEA in 2018. It also reported that in 2013, the Tajik Government gave TBEA licenses for exploration operations at both these deposits until 2017, while also exempting TBEA from customs duties and value added tax on the import of equipment (see "China's TBEA granted licenses for development of two gold deposits in Tajikistan").

It is also important to note that the Economic and Commercial Office of the Chinese Embassy reported in 2009 that TBEA was to receive mining rights in return for the project, before this exchange took place. "The Full Story Behind China's Gold Mine-Power Plant Swap in Tajikistan" article from the Diplomat is a particularly helpful source for information on this "resource-for-infrastructure" deal.
name: Rudaki

title: Chinese Embassy donates 'Gurdaston' Women's Sewing Center in Dushanbe (Linked to project ID#53594, #53591, #53587, #54043, #71881)
description:
The Chinese Embassy to Tajikistan donated the "Gurdaston" Women's Sewing Center in Dushanbe. The opening ceremony was held on June 30, 2017. The center was intended to promote women's employment and improve the prosperity and welfare of Dushanbe, according to the embassy. The value of the donated sewing center is unknown. 

Chinese Embassy also funded other differenct Women’s Sewing Training and Production Center in Tajikistan. Project ID#53594 captured the sewing center in Danghara. Project ID#54043 captured the sewing center in Maslozhelkomupo District, Dushanbe. Project ID#53591 captured the sewing center in Vakhsh District, Khatlon. Project ID#53587 captured the sewing center in Sino District, Dushanbe. Project ID#71881 captured the sewing center in the Dzhami District, Khatlon.

STAFF_NOTE: "Year uncertain" was checked because it is not confirmed that this donation was committed in 2017. "Gurdaston" is a one translation; another was "Gulda Stone", and "Gurda Stone."
name: Rudaki

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 1.5 billion grant for Government Complex and Parliamentary Complex Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#71727)
description: On August 31, 2017, the Chinese Government agreed to provide Tajikistan with a RMB 1.5 billion grant (approx. $230 million USD) to finance the construction of a new parliament and government complex. The main building of the parliamentary complex was to be 49.7 meters high, for a total area of 42,874 square meters. The government complex involved the construction of a 15-story building and two 13-story buildings, for a total area of 10.27 hectares. The parliament complex was to be built in Dushanbe on Rudaki Avenue, and the government complex was to be built in downtown Dushanbe on Rudaki Avenue and Ismoili Somoni Avenue. On October 13, 2018, President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon and Premier of the State Council of the People's Republic of China Li Keqiang participated in a groundbreaking ceremony for the project. On June 15, 2019, Xi Jinping and President Rahmon attended a ceremony to unveil the construction models of the buildings after their talks in Dushanbe. It was expected, in September 2018, that the construction would be completed in 2020. In 2018, the Chinese Government provided an additional RMB 900 million in funding for the preparation and implementation of this project. For this project, see linked project ID#71727.
name: Rudaki

title: China Development Bank funds for new office building of the Board of the State Savings Bank of Tajikistan 'Amonatbonk' (Linked to project ID#40488)
description:
China Development Bank (CDB) provided funds for a new office building for the Board of State Savings Bank of the Republic of Tajikistan "Amonatbank". In addition to CDB's funding, Amonatbank contributed its own funds towards the project. The total cost of the construction amounted to more than 90 million Tajikistani Somonis. The project is located is located at 105 Rudaki Avenue, Dushanbe and included 10 floors and two underground floors for the parking of service cars and a warehouse. The construction term was three years. The contractor for the construction of the building was Rohat-Sokhtmon Limited Liability Company. 

The ceremony for the laying of the first stone was held on March 13, 2015, and was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon (see "Сохтмони бинои нави БДА ҶТ “Амонатбонк” оғоз гардид."). It appears that the building featured a museum and was completed by January 18, 2020, as it had visitors (see "Ташрифи собиқадорони «Амонатбонк» ба бинои нави Раёсати БДА ҶТ «Амонатбонк».")

The project is linked to another funding from People's Bank of China for the same construction project, which was captured in project ID#40488. 

STAFF_NOTE: "Year uncertain" was checked because it is not confirmed that CDB's involvement in this project was committed in 2015. CDB's exact share of the 90 million TJS and the flow type are both unknown. Three language versions of the same article exist from Amonatbonk; each were used to create this project.
name: Rudaki

title: China Friendship Foundation for Peace and Development (CFFPD) provides $300,000 USD for technical support for Tajikistan National University
description: On January 14, 2016, Ambassador Yue Bin of Tajikistan attended the handover ceremony of the multimedia audio-visual project of Tajikistan National University, which was built by the China Peace Development Foundation (PDP). At the ceremony, the China Friendship Foundation for Peace and Development (CFFPD) provided US$300,000 worth of technical assistance to Tajik National University. The modern audio-visual facilities established have created a good learning environment for Tajik students. The foundation is founded by the Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries, one of the three major foreign affairs organizations of China, and thus assumed to be an official agency.
name: Rudaki

title: Chinese Government provided a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#39989)
description:
As part of a set of high-level agreements signed at the June 15, 2006 meeting of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO), the Chinese Government offered a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (see the cited resource:"China signs Tajik loan deals"). This project was also supported by a $281.1 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan from the Export-Import Bank of China (see Project ID#39989).

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan had signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project.China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan tunnel. The project was wholly completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

The purpose of this project — also known as the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253-meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047-meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls . 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.
name: Rudaki

title: China grants construction materials and diesel generators for disaster response in Tajikistan
description: In 2009, China granted construction materials and diesel generators for disaster response in the areas in Tajikistan affected by torrential rains and mudflows. The total value of the aid was estimated at 30,000 USD by REACT (Rapid Emergency Assessment and Coordination Team). This aid was in response to the May 2009 floods in Tajikistan.
name: Rudaki

title: Chinese Government loans RMB 50 million to restructure debt for Dushanbe Cigarette Factory Project
description:
In January 1997, Xinjiang International Economic Cooperation Corporation and Tadushanbe Cigarette Factory established a Sino-Tajik joint venture cigarette factory, the Dushanbe Cigarette Factory. The Chinese accounted for 10% of the registered capital ($300,000 USD), while Tajikistan accounted for 90%. The joint venture had a period of 30 years. The joint venture used a RMB 50 million government loan provided in 1994 to technically transform the tobacco factory, and the Chinese side provided cigarette and printing production lines. After the transformation, the production capacity of the factory was 5 billion cigarettes per year. The construction officially started in November 1998 and the project was completed in February 2001, and was officially handed over to Tajikistan in November 2001. However, the project was shelved because of tariff issues until October 2002. After that, the tobacco factory began trial production; producing 80 cases (800,000 cigarettes) of cigarettes per day, according to Economic and Commercial Office of the Chinese Embassy in Tajikistan in 2003.

The joint venture was to repay the RMB 50 million loan in installments from December 1, 2002. Since the joint venture tobacco factory was in a state of intermittent operation at that time, the supply of raw materials required was not timely, and revenue was not yet generated. So, Prime Minister Akilov of the Tajik government sent a letter to Premier Zhu Rongji in 2002 to propose debt relief or extension. A loan repayment proposal was then formally proposed with a loan period of 20 years, with a grace period of 5 years, with a reduced interest rate of 1%, according to the Economic and Commercial Office of the Chinese Embassy in Tajikistan in 2003. In 2006, the Economic and Commercial Office reported that the factory was looking for a Chinese company, in the form of our shareholding or other joint venture, to partner with it and introduce technical personnel, management experience and increase its working capital, so that the factory can operate normally.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is "杜尚别卷烟厂." The Russian title is "Душанбинская табачная фабрика."
name: Rudaki

title: China sponsored an electronic classroom of the Tajik State Institute of Languages
description: On September 24, 2016, Yue Bin, Ambassador of Tajikistan, attended the opening ceremony of the electric classroom of theTajik State Institute of Languages sponsored by the Chinese Embassy in Beijing. The president of the National Language University of Raja Buzoda, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Ministry of Tajikistan, and representatives of the Ministry of Education and more than 300 students and teachers attended the event.
name: Rudaki

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 929.9 million government concessional loan for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project (Linked to Project ID #54106, #71101, #71137)
description:
On July 4, 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China and China Development Bank (CDB) provided a $30 million USD loan for Phase 1 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project. According to Trend News Agency, the project's financing was on a 50-50 basis by the two Chinese banks to Ministry of Energy and Industry of Tajikistan. Other detailed terms of this loan are unknown. Project ID#54106 only captures the $15 million USD from China Eximbank. China Development Bank's contribution was captured in project ID#71101. Other detailed terms of this loan are unknown.

Then, in 2014, the Export-Import Bank of China provided two loans — an RMB 929,977,078 government concessional loan (GCL) (captured in project ID#46211) and a $178,969,220 USD preferential buyer’s credit loan (PBC) (captured in project ID#71137) for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project (for the GCL loan amount, see pg. 87 of "Program Appraisal Document on a Proposed Grant..."; for the PBC loan amount, see "Information on existing state investment projects"). Both of these loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. The GCL loan was contracted with the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and it carried the following terms: 25 year maturity, 11 year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate (see "РАМОЧНОЕ СОГЛАШЕНИЕ между Правительством Китайской Народной Республики и Правительством Республики Таджикистан о предоставлении Китайской Народной Республикой Республике Таджикистан льготного кредита"). The PBC loan has a 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period, and 2% interest rate (see "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018").

The Government of Tajikistan contributed $17,443,400 USD. In total, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan contracted $331,058,220 USD of China Eximbank debt for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project. The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from the GCL and the PBC loan to on-lend to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik”. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy.

The subsidiary GCL loan agreement (#TАJ 2014-028-2) was signed between Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” on December 18, 2014. It carried an interest rate of 5% and a maturity of 25 years. Its final maturity date was set to August 21, 2039. The subsidiary PBC loan agreement (#TАJ 2014-028-1) was also signed between Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” on December 18, 2014 and it carried an interest rate of 5% and a maturity of 20 years. Its final maturity date was set to June 21, 2034.

Dushanbe 2 is a combined heat and power plant (CHP) — also known as the Dushanbe-2 Thermal Power Plant (TPS-2) — that provides heat and electricity for the residents of Dushanbe. It only operates in the winter. The 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project required two phases. Phase 1 (mainly constructed between 2012-2014) installed a capacity of 100 MW, while Phase 2 (constructed between 2014-2016) installed an additional capacity of 300 MW. TBEA was the contractor responsible for implementation of both phases. CHP-2 was to be fueled by coal, with the potential to switch to gas. According to State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council, Inner Mongolia Electric Power Survey and Design Institute Co., Ltd. was the project designer for Phase 2. According to PowerChina, Hydro Electric Power System Engineering Company was also involved in the undertaking of Phase 2 of the project.

The first phase was scheduled to be completed and put into production before the celebration of the 20th anniversary of Tajik independence in 2011 (September 9th), and the second phase was scheduled to be completed in 2013. Phase 1 of the project began on September 8, 2009 and was put into operation on November 10, 2014. Phase 2 of the project began on May 14, 2015 and was completed on December 8, 2016.

According to President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon as relayed by TBEA, the plant generates 9.6 million kWh power per day and 235 trillion Kcal heat, and provided nearly 700 stable jobs to Tajiks. 150 Tajikistan technicians went to China for training, and about 100 Tajikistan operators mastered professional know-how under the guidance of Chinese experts. According to Xinhua, the completed station met 60 percent of the power demand and enabled the restart of central heating for more than 700,000 Dushanbe residents after 15 years of suspension. The completion of the Dushanbe-2 thermal power station was also declared to be the solution to Tajikistan's long-existing issue of power shortages in winter.

This power plant is located in Dushanbe. Its exact locational coordinates are available at http://globalenergyobservatory.org/geoid/41775.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Душанбинская ТЭЦ-2. The $30 million loan from China Eximbank and China Development Bank may not have covered the full cost of Phase 1 of the project. In the Government of Tajikistan’s Aid Information Management System (AIMS), the project is referred to as "Project of construction of second in succession construction of 'TPS-2' in Dushanbe."

Some sources suggest that major delays took place after Tajikistan contracted this loan on July 4, 2009. The ceremony for the beginning of the project was clearly on September 8, 2009, but it seems project construction did not begin in earnest until 2012, when TBEA agreed to “front” $178 million for the construction of Phase 1 by borrowing directly from China Eximbank, and, in turn, the Tajik government agreed to grant TBEA exclusive rights to explore and develop gold deposits at the Eastern Duoba mine and the Upper Kumarg mine (until TBEA could recoup its investment). The Tajik government also reportedly agreed to give TBEA the rights to further mining deposits (at an unidentified location) if the profit made from the gold deposits did not cover the cost of building the power plant.

According to Kazakhstan Newsline, Tajikistan also issued a license to TBEA for the development of coal mines (see "Chinese TBEA company says Dushanbe is ready to provide its gold mines"). Another media source, Central Asia News, said that the mineral resources were to be used to compensate the costs of the company for construction of the Dushanbe-2 in the amount of $178 million USD. It also reported that the proven reserves of 3 gold mines was to be estimated 51.7 tons of gold (see "China’s TBEA may obtain license for development of another mine in Tajikistan"). Another media source, Asia-Plus reported that the license for development of the Upper Kumargh gold deposit was granted to TBEA in 2018. It also reported that in 2013, the Tajik Government gave TBEA licenses for exploration operations at both these deposits until 2017, while also exempting TBEA from customs duties and value added tax on the import of equipment (see "China's TBEA granted licenses for development of two gold deposits in Tajikistan").

It is also important to note that the Economic and Commercial Office of the Chinese Embassy reported in 2009 that TBEA was to receive mining rights in return for the project, before this exchange took place. "The Full Story Behind China's Gold Mine-Power Plant Swap in Tajikistan" article from the Diplomat is a particularly helpful source for information on this "resource-for-infrastructure" deal.
name: Rudaki

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 546 million government concessional loan for 500 kV Power Transmission Lines from Rogun Hydropower Plant to Dushanbe Project
description:
On September 1, 2017, the Export–Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed an RMB 546,032,200 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the 500 kV Power Transmission Lines from Rogun Hydropower Plant to Dushanbe Project. According to Avesta, the loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 25 years and 1.5% interest rate per annum. The loan agreement was ratified by the Tajik parliament in December 2017.

The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend -- through subsidiary loan agreement No. TAJ-2017-02 (BT-039), dated 29.12.2017 -- to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik” at a 3% interest rate between December 29, 2017 and August 21, 2042. As of OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy. 

The project involved the construction of two 500 kV, high voltage power transmission lines with a length of approximately 100 km from the Rogun hydropower plant in the town of Obi Garm (within the district of Rogun) to Dushanbe. The Dushanbe-Obigarm project was designed to improve reliability and quantity of supplied energy and reduce losses in the Rasht Valley of Tajikistan, where the Nurabad, Rasht, Tajikabad, Tavildara and Lakhsh districts are located. The Dushanbe-Obi Garm 500-kV power transmission line would also help increase the export of Tajik electricity to neighboring countries. The connection between the power grids of Districts of Republican Subordination and the southern power grid would also be improved. According to the 03/29/2019 Sputnik article, the transmission lines were to pass through the territories of Faizabad, Vahdat, Rudaki and Varzob. A substation, Dushanbe-500 substation, was also to be constructed as part of the project. 

Chinese company Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock Co., Ltd. (TBEA) was contracted to implement the project. In addition, according to PowerChina, Hubei Engineering Company Engineering Construction Company was involved in the project's implementation. Construction began on October 1, 2017. The project was completed and put into operation on November 16, 2018. 

STAFF_NOTE: This project is also known as the 500-kV transmission line Dushanbe-Obi Garm Project or the Project "Reconstruction and construction of 500 kV power transmission line in the republican subordination." The Russian project title is Линия электропередачи 500 кВ «Душанбе-Рогун» or  проекта реконструкции высоковольтной 500-киловольтной линии электропередачи районов республиканского подчинения. Note that Rogun Hydropower Plant is sometimes also referred to as Roghun Hydropower Plant. Additionally, some sources, including press releases from Tajik government ministries, denominated the loan amount in US dollars, as $79 million USD. However, under Eximbank's policy, the government concessional l loan was always denominated in Chinese Yuan.
name: Rudaki

title: China Grants 31 Buses Worth 10 Million Yuan to Tajikistan
description: In July 3, 2000, on the eve of President of China Jiang Zemin's official visit to Tajikistan, 31 buses were dispatched to Dushanbe from China. The buses had been provided under free technical aid (10m yuans). An official ceremony for handing over the buses was 4th July, with the participation of the Chinese government's official delegation.
name: Rudaki

title: China Eximbank provides $281.1 million preferential buyer’s credit for the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#40351)
description:
On June 15, 2006, at the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed a $281,105,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project. The PBC loan carried a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and an interest rate of 2% (see loan details at "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). 

The loan was set to disburse in 3 annual tranches. The loan disbursements were as follows (see pg.7 of "INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN Staff Report for the 2006 Article IV Consultation"):
- 2007: $112.4 million USD
- 2008: $112.4 million USD
- 2009: $56.2 million USD

The project had a total cost of $295.9 million USD. This project is linked to project ID#40351, a RMB 60 million grant offered by the Chinese Government. China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan  tunnel. The project was completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project. The purpose of the project — also known as the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253 meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047 meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.
name: Rudaki

title: Chinese Cultural Exhibition Donated to Tajikistan
description: The exhibition called The Silk Route and Chinese Culture features silk, ceramics, porcelain, and tapestry. All in all, more than 200 exhibits. Chinese Ambassador Wu Hongbin, who opened the exhibition on Wednesday, said 'the Great Silk Route that linked the cultural centres in the huge area between China, the Mediterranean and Central Asia two thousand years ago lives on'. He expressed the hope that the exhibition will help strengthen friendship, cultural ties and trade between the two countries and their people. The diplomat said all exhibits will be donated to Tajikistan's Bekhzoda National Museum.
name: Rudaki

title: China Eximbank provides $12.54 million preferential buyer's credit for Safe City Project (Linked to Project ID#46215)
description:
On May 20, 2013, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed two loan agreements with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Safe City Project: a RMB-denominated government concessional loan (GCL) provided on highly concessional terms (20-year maturity, 11-year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate) and a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan on highly concessional terms (2% interest, 20-year maturity, 9-year grace period).

The precise face value of the GCL loan and the precise face value of the PBC loan are unknown. However, it is known that the GCL and PBC are jointly worth $20.9 million USD, and that 40% of the total debt financing from China Eximbank ($8.36 million) came from the RMB-denominated GCL and 60% of the total debt financing from China Eximbank ($12.54 million) came from the USD-denominated PBC (AidData learned this through correspondence with the IMF, see "Following Up" resource). Project ID#46215 records the GCL and project ID#71411 records the PBC.

The loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament in June 2013 and were expected to be repaid with revenues from the traffic fines generated by this project. The total cost of the project was $22 million USD. In addition to the Chinese loans, the Government of Tajikistan contributed $1.1 million USD.

According to Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Republic of Tajikistan, the Safe City Project involved the installation of 855 CCTV cameras for round-the-clock monitoring of traffic and other movements at 75 crossroads, streets, and squares in the capital city of Dushanbe. The cameras were to record every offense committed by drivers, which would be stored and processed in a common database. Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. was responsible for project implementation. Tajik Ministry of Internal Affairs was also responsible for the undertaking of the project.

The Safe City project and the control center were officially launched on October 31, 2013 by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. The Safe City Project was to be carried out in three stages; the second stage was expected to be finished in May 2014. The project was still on going as of December 2014. As of January 16, 2015, it had reportedly generated $4 million for the Tajik state budget via traffic fines. According to a Huawei report issued in February 2015, Huawei completed the project successfully.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Автоматическая система управления транспорта в городе Душанбе (Безопасный город). Asia Plus reported at the time that Tajikistan authorities claimed the loan would be repayable through traffic violation fines.
name: Rudaki

title: China Donates $1,500 to Give 2870 Textbooks to Two Schools in Tajikistan
description: In August 2004, The Chinese embassy in Tajikistan donated 2,870 textbooks in Russian to two secondary schools in Dushanbe. 2,870 textbooks worth 1,500 dollars had been given to school number 51 and the presidential school.
name: Rudaki

title: China Eximbank provides $178.9 million preferential buyer’s credit for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project (Linked to Project ID #46211, #54106, #71101)
description:
On July 4, 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China and China Development Bank (CDB) provided a $30 million USD loan for Phase 1 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project. According to Trend News Agency, the project's financing was on a 50-50 basis by the two Chinese banks to Ministry of Energy and Industry of Tajikistan. Other detailed terms of this loan are unknown. Project ID#54106 only captures the $15 million USD from China Eximbank. China Development Bank's contribution was captured in project ID#71101. Other detailed terms of this loan are unknown.

Then, in 2014, the Export-Import Bank of China provided two loans — an RMB 929,977,078 government concessional loan (GCL) (captured in project ID#46211) and a $178,969,220 USD preferential buyer’s credit loan (PBC) (captured in project ID#71137) for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project (for the GCL loan amount, see pg. 87 of "Program Appraisal Document on a Proposed Grant..."; for the PBC loan amount, see "Information on existing state investment projects"). Both of these loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. The GCL loan was contracted with the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and it carried the following terms: 25 year maturity, 11 year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate (see "РАМОЧНОЕ СОГЛАШЕНИЕ между Правительством Китайской Народной Республики и Правительством Республики Таджикистан о предоставлении Китайской Народной Республикой Республике Таджикистан льготного кредита"). The PBC loan has a 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period, and 2% interest rate (see "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018").

The Government of Tajikistan contributed $17,443,400 USD. In total, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan contracted $331,058,220 USD of China Eximbank debt for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project. The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from the GCL and the PBC loan to on-lend to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik”. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy.

The subsidiary GCL loan agreement (#TАJ 2014-028-2) was signed between Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” on December 18, 2014. It carried an interest rate of 5% and a maturity of 25 years. Its final maturity date was set to August 21, 2039. The subsidiary PBC loan agreement (#TАJ 2014-028-1) was also signed between Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” on December 18, 2014 and it carried an interest rate of 5% and a maturity of 20 years. Its final maturity date was set to June 21, 2034.

Dushanbe 2 is a combined heat and power plant (CHP) — also known as the Dushanbe-2 Thermal Power Plant (TPS-2) — that provides heat and electricity for the residents of Dushanbe. It only operates in the winter. The 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project required two phases. Phase 1 (mainly constructed between 2012-2014) installed a capacity of 100 MW, while Phase 2 (constructed between 2014-2016) installed an additional capacity of 300 MW. TBEA was the contractor responsible for implementation of both phases. CHP-2 was to be fueled by coal, with the potential to switch to gas. According to State-owned Assets Supervision and Administration Commission of the State Council, Inner Mongolia Electric Power Survey and Design Institute Co., Ltd. was the project designer for Phase 2. According to PowerChina, Hydro Electric Power System Engineering Company was also involved in the undertaking of Phase 2 of the project.

The first phase was scheduled to be completed and put into production before the celebration of the 20th anniversary of Tajik independence in 2011 (September 9th), and the second phase was scheduled to be completed in 2013. Phase 1 of the project began on September 8, 2009 and was put into operation on November 10, 2014. Phase 2 of the project began on May 14, 2015 and was completed on December 8, 2016.

According to President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon as relayed by TBEA, the plant generates 9.6 million kWh power per day and 235 trillion Kcal heat, and provided nearly 700 stable jobs to Tajiks. 150 Tajikistan technicians went to China for training, and about 100 Tajikistan operators mastered professional know-how under the guidance of Chinese experts. According to Xinhua, the completed station met 60 percent of the power demand and enabled the restart of central heating for more than 700,000 Dushanbe residents after 15 years of suspension. The completion of the Dushanbe-2 thermal power station was also declared to be the solution to Tajikistan's long-existing issue of power shortages in winter.

This power plant is located in Dushanbe. Its exact locational coordinates are available at http://globalenergyobservatory.org/geoid/41775.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Душанбинская ТЭЦ-2. The $30 million loan from China Eximbank and China Development Bank may not have covered the full cost of Phase 1 of the project. In the Government of Tajikistan’s Aid Information Management System (AIMS), the project is referred to as "Project of construction of second in succession construction of 'TPS-2' in Dushanbe."

Some sources suggest that major delays took place after Tajikistan contracted this loan on July 4, 2009. The ceremony for the beginning of the project was clearly on September 8, 2009, but it seems project construction did not begin in earnest until 2012, when TBEA agreed to “front” $178 million for the construction of Phase 1 by borrowing directly from China Eximbank, and, in turn, the Tajik government agreed to grant TBEA exclusive rights to explore and develop gold deposits at the Eastern Duoba mine and the Upper Kumarg mine (until TBEA could recoup its investment). The Tajik government also reportedly agreed to give TBEA the rights to further mining deposits (at an unidentified location) if the profit made from the gold deposits did not cover the cost of building the power plant.

According to Kazakhstan Newsline, Tajikistan also issued a license to TBEA for the development of coal mines (see "Chinese TBEA company says Dushanbe is ready to provide its gold mines"). Another media source, Central Asia News, said that the mineral resources were to be used to compensate the costs of the company for construction of the Dushanbe-2 in the amount of $178 million USD. It also reported that the proven reserves of 3 gold mines was to be estimated 51.7 tons of gold (see "China’s TBEA may obtain license for development of another mine in Tajikistan"). Another media source, Asia-Plus reported that the license for development of the Upper Kumargh gold deposit was granted to TBEA in 2018. It also reported that in 2013, the Tajik Government gave TBEA licenses for exploration operations at both these deposits until 2017, while also exempting TBEA from customs duties and value added tax on the import of equipment (see "China's TBEA granted licenses for development of two gold deposits in Tajikistan").

It is also important to note that the Economic and Commercial Office of the Chinese Embassy reported in 2009 that TBEA was to receive mining rights in return for the project, before this exchange took place. "The Full Story Behind China's Gold Mine-Power Plant Swap in Tajikistan" article from the Diplomat is a particularly helpful source for information on this "resource-for-infrastructure" deal.
name: Rudaki

title: China Development Bank provides $15 million loan for Phase 1 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#46211, #54106, #71137)
description:
On July 4, 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China and China Development Bank (CDB) provided a $30 million USD loan for Phase 1 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project. According to Trend News Agency, the project's financing was on a 50-50 basis by the two Chinese banks to Ministry of Energy and Industry of Tajikistan. Other detailed terms of this loan are unknown. Project ID#54106 only captures the $15 million USD from China Eximbank. China Development Bank's contribution was captured in project ID#71101. Other detailed terms of this loan are unknown.

Then, in 2014, the Export-Import Bank of China provided two loans — an RMB 929,977,078 government concessional loan (GCL) (captured in project ID#46211) and a $178,969,220 USD preferential buyer’s credit loan (PBC) (captured in project ID#71137) for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project (for the GCL loan amount, see pg. 87 of "Program Appraisal Document on a Proposed Grant..."; for the PBC loan amount, see "Information on existing state investment projects"). Both of these loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. The GCL loan was contracted with the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and it carried the following terms: 25 year maturity, 11 year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate (see "РАМОЧНОЕ СОГЛАШЕНИЕ между Правительством Китайской Народной Республики и Правительством Республики Таджикистан о предоставлении Китайской Народной Республикой Республике Таджикистан льготного кредита"). In total, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan contracted $331,058,220 USD of China Eximbank debt for Phase 2 of the 400MW Dushanbe CHP-2 Construction Project.
