name: Rudaki

title: China grants personal computers and teaching tools to Tajik State Medical University
description: In 2008, China granted personal computers and teaching tools to Tajik State Medical University (see pg. 81 of 'Development Partner Profiles 2012'). The value of the donation is unknown. STAFF_NOTE: 'Year uncertain' box was checked because it is not confirmed that this grant was confirmed in 2008.
name: Rudaki

title: China opens Confucius Institute at Tajikistan National University
description: In 2008, Xinjiang Normal University helped established a Confucius Institute at Tajikistan's Nationality University. The Institute has operated for over 10 years now, growing from 200 students to over 4,000 students. The Institute has offered language training, cultural exchanges, and instrument training to the students.
name: Rudaki

title: Chinese Academy of Sciences builds Dushanbe Research Center for Ecology and Environment of Central Asia
description:
On September 13, 2014, Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) signed an agreement on scientific cooperation with Academy of Sciences of Tajikistan on the construction of Tajik branch of the Dushanbe Research Center for Ecology and Environment of Central Asia, as an official NGO. The center was jointly built by CAS and the Tajik Academy of Sciences, and dealt with the ecological environment, geology, and physics. The opening ceremony of the center was held on August 29, 2016. The main objective of the center is to "conduct fundamental and applied research in the field of natural Sciences". This center was the first joint scientific institution between Tajikistan and China.

STAFF_NOTE: The project is known in Chinese as "中国科学院中亚生态与环境研究中心塔吉克斯坦分中心". According to the Research Center for Ecology and Environment of Central Asia, CAS provided $2 million dollars in research equipment to joint laboratories in Central Asia, including a joint laboratory for geology and mineralogy in Tajikistan, which is probably this. However, if it's not clear if each lab received $2 million dollars in equipment, or if the combined value of equipment spread across the three labs was $2 million, so the coder did not code a transaction amount.
name: Rudaki

title: Chinese Embassy funded Gulafshon Women's Sewing Training and Production Center in Dushanbe (Linked to project ID#53594, #53591, #53587 #71883, #71881)
description:
In June 2014, the Chinese Embassy of Tajikistan helped to establish a sewing training center "Gulafshon" in Dushanbe and employs 60 women. The center is located in a small three-story building on Zalozi Street, Maslozhelkomupo District, Dushanbe, the capital of Tajikistan. 

On June 4, 2014, Zhao Xiangrong, the Chinese Ambassador to Tajikistan, attended the inauguration ceremony of the “Gulafushang” Women's Sewing Training Production Center. Others attending included Mr. Ratibov, Vice Chairman of the People’s Democratic Party of the People’s Republic of China, Kurbova, Vice Mayor of Dushanbe, Mrs. Sun Wei, the wife of the Political Counselor of the Embassy, and more than 100 representatives from the relevant departments of the tower and local women and children. Project ID#71883 captured the sewing center named "Gurdaston" in Dushanbe. Project ID#71881 captured the sewing center in the Dzhami District, Khatlon.

Chinese Embassy also funded other differenct Women’s Sewing Training and Production Center in Tajikistan. Project ID#53594 captured the sewing center in Danghara. Project ID#53591 captured the sewing center in Vakhsh District, Khatlon. Project ID#53587 captured the sewing center in Sino District, Dushanbe.

STAFF_NOTE: Transaction amount was not found.
name: Rudaki

title: Chinese Government provides $2 million grant for the Reconstruction of the Shirgovad Section of the Dushanbe-Kulma Highway
description:
On October 23, 2017, an exchange of letters between China and Tajikistan was signed that stipulated that China would help Tajikistan repair roads. According to the Tajik Ministry of Transport, the Chinese Government provided a grant of $2 million for the Reconstruction of the Shirgovad Section of the Dushanbe-Kulma Highway Project. The project aimed to restore the Shirgovad section, in the Darvaz Distrct, of the Dushanbe-Kulma Highway that had been destroyed by a flood. China Road and Bridge Construction Corporation (China Road) was the contractor. The project commenced in December 2017 and was completed in April 2018. 1.1 km of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway was restored in the project.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Восстановление участка 347 км автодороги Душанбе-Кульма (участок Ширговад Дарвазского района). The Tajik project title is Барқарорсозии қитъаи 347 км р/а Душанбе-Кулма (мавзеи Ширговади н.Дарвоз). Additionally, while the sources do not explicitly state so, this was clearly done in response to the July 2017 flooding that damaged and destroyed roadways in the Darvaz District.
name: Darvoz

title: China Eximbank provides $51 million preferential buyer’s credit to provide additional support to 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project and 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project (Linked to Project ID#39984 and #39644)
description:
On May 15, 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China and Government of Tajikistan signed a credit agreement, according to the Tajikistan Ministry of Finance. China Eximbank agreed to provide a $51,000,000 USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan to the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan (see pg. 37 of "Consolidated financial statements..."). This loan was intended to provide additional financing to the 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project and 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project. Both of these projects were supported by Export-Import Bank loans approved in 2006 (see Project ID#39984 and Project ID#39644). The terms of this PBC loan are unknown.

However, it is known that the Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend “Barqi Tojik” at a 3% interest rate between May 29, 2007 and December 21, 2028. As of December 31, 2018, $480,910 USD was outstanding. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy (pg. 15 of "Consolidated..."). 

The purpose of the 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project was to construct a 500 kV electricity transmission line that would connect the northern Sughd region to the national grid. According to Xinhua, the project also intended to realize the effective dispatching of electricity between Dushanbe and Khujand, completely solve the problem of power shortage in the south during the dry season in winter, build the transmission channel for the implementation of the Tajik Hydropower Strategy, improve the safety, stability, and reliability of the power grid, and reduce the loss of electricity through transmission from 14% to 3.2%. 

According to Asia-Plus, the purpose of the 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project was to construct a 90 km, 220 kV electricity transmission line between Dangara and Kulab. This would connect the southern region to the national grid. According to President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon, relayed by Asia-Plus, the new power transmission line would improve the power supply in the south of the Khatlon region, and create a more stable power supply. The Lolazor-Khatlon line had a capacity of approximately 4 billion kWh of electricity a year, according to Asia-Plus. The project was to provide the Khatlon region with electricity from the Sangtuda 1 and 2 hydroelectric power plants, and allow for the export of electricity to Afghanistan.

Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock (TBEA) was the contractor responsible for the implementation of both projects (see pg. 14 of "China as an Emerging Donor..."). The North-South transmission line has been operational since November 29, 2009 (see pg. 11 of "BRI in Central Asia: Energy Connectivity Projects").  According to Asia-Plus, the Lolazor-Khatlon transmission line has been operational since June 25, 2008. 

The project is linked to previous fundings of a 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line project (captured in project ID#39644) and a 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project (captured in project ID#39984) in 2006.

STAFF_NOTE: The document "Consolidated financial statements..." states the agreement for the loan was May 29, 2007, but several official sources gave May 15, 2009. It was assumed that the later was correct.
name: Kulob

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 58.4 million grant for Phase 1 of the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (Linked to Project ID#53990 and #72612)
description:
In 2013, the Chinese Government agreed to provide RMB 58.4 million of grant financing for Phase 1 of the the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (captured in project ID#71741). Then, in 2016, the Chinese Government agreed to provide RMB 59.6 million of grant financing for Phase 2 of the the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (captured in project ID#53990).

The first phase of the project involved the construction of 12 kilometers of roads in Kurgan-Tyube and Kulob and 2 automobile bridges in Kulob. The second phase of the project involved the rehabilitation of 15 streets and 4 bridges in Kurgan-Tyube and Kulob measuring 22 km in length.

China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was supervised and managed by China Railway First Survey and Design Institute Group Co.,Ltd.

The first phase officially started on April 17, 2015. The inauguration ceremony and the signing ceremony of the technology handover certificate for project was held on January 19, 2016. The second phase of construction began on December 29, 2016. It was completed on December 15, 2017, after passing inspection. The Project Qualification Certificate was signed on December 27, 2007. The inaugural ceremony for the second phase was held on January 8, 2018.

STAFF_NOTE: : This project is also known as the Road Rehabilitation Project for Two Cities in Tajikistan. The Chinese project title is 塔吉克斯坦两城市道路修复项目（第II阶段).
name: Kulob

title: China Eximbank provides $55.2 million preferential buyer's credit for 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project (Linked to Project ID#39644, #70910)
description:
In March 2006, the Government of Tajikistan and the Export-Import Bank of China signed a MoU for projects proposed by Tajikistan. Later, on December 16, 2006, the Export-Import Bank of China provided a $58,228,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan for the 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project. The loan terms carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and an interest rate of 2% (see the cited resource"List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). 

The Government of Tajikistan used nearly all of the proceeds from this loan ($55,227,590, according to pg. 87 of "Tajikistan Power Utility Financial Recovery Program") to on-lend (through subsidiary loan agreement No. BLA06016) to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik” at a 3% interest rate between December 16, 2006 and June 21, 2026. As of December 31, 2018, $520,774 USD was outstanding. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy (pg. 15 of "Consolidated..."). 

The initial value of the project was $58.1 million USD. The Government of Tajikistan contributed $2.9 million USD to the project. Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock (TBEA) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was launched in May 2006. The transmission line was planned to be commissioned by the end of December 2007, but the inclusion of the construction of an additional internal 110 kV transmission line from the Khatlon substation to the Bokhtar substation postponed the start date. The Lolazor-Khatlon transmission line was commissioned on June 25, 2008.

The purpose of this project was to construct a 90 km, 220 kV electricity transmission line between Dangara and Kulab. This would connect the southern region to the national grid. The new power transmission line would improve the power supply in the south of the Khatlon region, and create a more stable power supply. The Lolazor-Khatlon line had a capacity of approximately 4 billion kWh of electricity a year. The project was to provide the Khatlon region with electricity from the Sangtuda 1 and 2 hydroelectric power plants, and allow for the export of electricity to Afghanistan. 

The project is linked to project ID#70910, which captured a $51 million funding from Eximbank in 2009 for both the 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project and a 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project (The original financing of the 500 kV project in 2006 was captured in project ID#39644).

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is высоковольтных линий электропередач 500 кВ «Юг – Север» и 220 кВ «Лолазор –Хатлон». Some official sources identify $55,227,590 as the face value of the loan. 

Additionally, this loan was coded as export buyer's credits after much consideration. The "China as an Emerging Donor..." article indicated that China offered PBCs, Tajikistan made proposals for projects, and this project was selected. An Export-Import Bank article, although it does not explicitly name this project as a loan, states that Eximbank and Tajikistan signed preferential export buyer’s credit agreements in June 2006, close to the timeframe of the commitment of financing for this project. Because of this evidence, this loan was considered a PBC and coded as such.
name: Kulob

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 59.6 million grant for Phase 2 of the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (Linked to Project ID#71741 and #72612)
description:
In 2013, the Chinese Government agreed to provide RMB 58.4 million of grant financing for Phase 1 of the the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (captured in project ID#71741). The first phase of the project involved the construction of 12 kilometers of roads in Kurgan-Tyube and Kulob and 2 automobile bridges in Kulob. The second phase of the project involved the rehabilitation of 15 streets and 4 bridges in Kurgan-Tyube and Kulob measuring 22 km in length. 

China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was supervised and managed by China Railway First Survey and Design Institute Group Co.,Ltd. 

The first phase officially started on April 17, 2015. The inauguration ceremony and the signing ceremony of the technology handover certificate for project was held on January 19, 2016. The second phase of construction began on December 29, 2016. It was completed on December 15, 2017, after passing inspection. The Project Qualification Certificate was signed on December 27, 2007. name: Kulob

title: China-funded Takuriabu Anti-drug Branch office building
description: On March 18, 2016, Yue Bin, the ambassador to Tajikistan, attended the completion handover ceremony of the office building of the China-funded Takuriabu Anti-drug Branch office building. The project was funded by Ministry of Public Security of China and implemented by China Jing'an Import & Export Corporation. The office building aided by the Chinese side is a three-story brick-concrete structure with a construction area of ​​more than 1,000 square meters, including offices, equipment rooms, interrogation rooms, lounges.
name: Kulob

title: China Eximbank provides $49 million preferential buyer’s credit for First Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#53750, #40440)
description:
On August 18, 2009, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $49,000,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan for the First Stage of the Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project. The loan had a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 years, and an interest rate of 2%. 

The total project cost was $51,578,000, including a $2,578,000 contribution from the Government of Tajikistan. China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on August 30, 2009 after a grand commencement ceremony held on the same day and the project was completed (after passing final inspection) on October 30, 2013. 

This project supported the reconstruction of a 57.8 km road segment along the 147.64 km Dushanbe-Vahdat-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway (which is also known as the Tajikistan-China highway). It also involved the construction of new sections of road to bypass settlements and bridges. More detailed locational information can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbekulma-road-dushanbe-dangara-section-phase-2/9d21c81e-6931-4df6-9dd4-650c86518ecb/.

STAFF_NOTE: This project is linked to the China Eximbank-financed Second Stage and China Eximbank-financed Third Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (see Project ID#53750, #40440). China Eximbank reportedly provided $243.4 million of debt financing in total for all three stages of Phase 1. The Russian project title for Stage 1 of Phase 1 is Реконструкция 1-го этапа 1 фазы автодороги Душанбе-Кульма (Таджикистан - граница Китая) на участке «Душанбе-Дангара». The Chinese project title is 塔中公路一期(杜尚别—丹卡拉段)道路修复改造项目.
name: Norak

title: China Eximbank provides $143.9 million preferential buyer’s credit for Second Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID #40063, #40440)
description:
On November 27, 2010, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed a $143,925,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [China Eximbank PBC NO.2010 (025) Total No. (132)] for the Second Stage of the Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project. This loan carried an interest rate of 2%, a maturity of 20 years, and a grace period of 5 years. The total project cost was $151,500,000, including a contribution of $7,575,000 from the Government of Tajikistan. 

China Road & Bridge Corporation was awarded the implementation contract. The project is implemented in the design and construction contracting mode. The main construction content includes road reconstruction, municipal road engineering, tunnels and connecting lines, etc. The road repair project construction period is 24 months, and the tunnel and connection line construction period is 36 months. Construction began on October 15, 2010, and ths project was completed (after passing final inspection) on October 30, 2013. 

This project supported the reconstruction of a 50.5 km road segment along the 147.64 km Dushanbe-Vahdat-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway (which is also known as the Tajikistan-China highway). It also supported the construction of the 4.43 km Chormagzak Tunnel along the 147.64 km Dushanbe-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway. More detailed locational information can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbekulma-road-dushanbe-dangara-section-phase-2/9d21c81e-6931-4df6-9dd4-650c86518ecb/ at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Chormaghzak+Tunnel,+Tajikistan/@38.4771348,69.1814159,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x38b66e9dde37093f:0x45059c2b6cd21c12!8m2!3d38.4771306!4d69.1836046.” 

STAFF_NOTE: This project is linked to the China Eximbank-financed First Stage and China Eximbank-financed Third Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (see Project ID#40063, #40440). China Eximbank reportedly provided $243.4 million of debt financing in total for all three stages of Phase 1. The Russian project title for Stage 2 of Phase 1 is Реконструкция второго этапа Фаза I автомобильной дороги «Душанбе-Кульма» (Таджикистан – граница Китая) на участке «Душанбе - Дангара». The Chinese project title is 塔中公路一期(杜尚别—丹卡拉段)道路修复改造项目.
name: Norak

title: Chinese Government grants $1,223,241 for the repair of Shar-Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel Access Road (Linked to Project ID#40406, #40063, #53750, #40440)
description:
In 2013, the Chinese Government provided a $1,223,241 grant for the repair of a 6km access road to the Shar Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel. The total cost of the project was $2.185 million USD. The project included the repair of the connection line base, the road surface, and the addition of water pipe bridges. 

China Railway No.5 Engineering Group, a subsidiary company of China Railway Engineering Corporation (CREC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. SIPPR Engineering Group Co., Ltd.  was responsible for construction supervision. Construction began in September 2013, and the project was completed in September 2014.

STAFF_NOTE: A 2018 export from the Government of Tajikistan’s Aid Information Management System (AIMS) identifies the face value of the grant as $1,223,241 (see AIMS project ID# TJK/112262) (see “May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS China Specific Projects”). This project is linked to project ID #40406, which was an RMB 260 million grant for the construction of the tunnel in 2006. It also linked to a series of China Eximbank-financed road segments along the Dushanbe-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway (Project ID#40063, Project ID#53750, and Project ID#40440). 

The Russian title of this project is Ремонт подходных путей к тоннелю Озоди (Шар-Шар). The Chinese title of this project is 援塔吉克斯坦沙尔-沙尔隧道南北连接线修复项目. The Shar-Shar tunnel was renamed the Ozodi (in English: Liberty) tunnel in 2014 (see "Chormaghzak Tunnel renamed Khatlon Tunnel and Shar-Shar Tunnel renamed Ozodi Tunnel"). The provision year of the grant was assumed based on the start date of the project. Additionally, SIPPR's Chinese name translates to English as "Sixth Design and Research Institute of Machinery Industry Co., Ltd."
name: Norak

title: China Eximbank provides $50.54 million preferential buyer’s credit for Third Stage (Chormagzak Tunnel) of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID #53750, #40063)
description:
On June 5, 2012, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed a loan agreement for the provision of $50.54 million USD for the Third Stage of the Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (see "'Eximbank" to Provide Over $ 50 million for Continuing Reconstruction of Dushanbe-Kulma Road'"). The loan had a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 9 years, and an interest rate of 2%. The Government of Tajikistan contributed $2.7 million USD to this project. The Eximbank loan was unanimously ratified by the Tajik Parliament in October 2012.

China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on October 15, 2010, and the project was completed on October 1, 2013. This project supported the construction of the 4.43 km Chormagzak Tunnel along the 147.64 km Dushanbe-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway (which is also known as the Tajikistan-China highway). More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Chormaghzak+Tunnel,+Tajikistan/@38.4771348,69.1814159,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x38b66e9dde37093f:0x45059c2b6cd21c12!8m2!3d38.4771306!4d69.1836046 and https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbekulma-road-dushanbe-dangara-section-phase-2/9d21c81e-6931-4df6-9dd4-650c86518ecb/.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chormagzak Tunnel is now known as the Khatlon Tunnel. This project is linked to the China Eximbank-financed First Stage and China Eximbank-financed Second Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (see Project ID#40063, #53750). China Eximbank reportedly provided $243.4 million of debt financing in total for all three stages of Phase 1. The Russian project title for Stage 3 of Phase 1 is Реабилитация третьего этапа фазы I автомобильной дороги «Душанбе-Кульма». The Chinese project title is 塔中公路一期(杜尚别—丹卡拉段)道路修复改造项目.

Additionally, the "Data Collection Survey On a Road Between Dushanbe and Kurgan-Tyube in the Republic of Tajikistan Final Report" from the Japan International Cooperation Agency states that China Eximbank provided a $64 million USD loan for this project, but most of other sources (including Tajikistan Ministry report and ADB investigation) indicate that $50.54 would be a more precise number.
name: Norak

title: Chinese Government provides a RMB 72.98 million grant for the construction of two Nurek schools
description: In 2013, the Chinese government decided to assist two schools in Tajikistan. Yanjian Group successfully won the bid for this project. The two schools in Nurek, Tajikistan, were funded by the Chinese government. The project cost was 72.98 million yuan. The project is located in Nurek City, Tajikistan. 22-Class schools are located in the center of Nurek City, and 11-Class schools are located in the suburbs of Nurek City. The project occupies a total area of 4.28 hectares, with a construction area of 9508 square meters, and can accommodate 1124 students to school at the same time. The project started on June 6, 2014 and was successfully completed on December 6, 2015. On April 27, 2016, the completion ceremony for two Nurek schools, constructed with Chinese Government assistance, was held. President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon and Chinese Ambassador to Tajikistan Yue Bin of Tajikistan attended. The advanced design and facilities of the two Nurek schools was expected to provide a good learning environment for thousands of Tajik students. The schools featured classrooms, canteens and stadiums, according to the embassy.
name: Norak

title: China provides irrigation methods and farming techniques to Tajik communities
description: In late January 2011, the Government of Tajikistan agreed to lease out 2,000 hectares of land to the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region (XUAR). The deal was to bring 1,500 Chinese farmers to work the fields in the Qumsangir District and Bokhtar District of southern Khatlon Province. The Chinese promised to introduce drip-irrigation methods and other contemporary farming techniques to the region, and share their expertise and technology with Tajik communities (see 'Tajikistan Agrees To Allow Chinese Farmers To Till Land'). The deal was formally signed in March 2011, and Chinese farmers were already at work at that time. It was reported that the Tajik government believed the Chinese farmers would help revitalize the rural communities and boost food security (see 'Tajik land deal extends China's reach in Central Asia'). STAFF_NOTE: Intent was coded as 'Mixed' because leasing land is commercial, but there are development goals in helping the Tajik rural communities. This project is not to be confused with a 6,000 hectare land-lease in 2012 (project ID#72392).
name: Qumsangir

title: China grants construction materials and diesel generators for disaster response in Tajikistan
description: In 2009, China granted construction materials and diesel generators for disaster response in the areas in Tajikistan affected by torrential rains and mudflows. The total value of the aid was estimated at 30,000 USD by REACT (Rapid Emergency Assessment and Coordination Team). This aid was in response to the May 2009 floods in Tajikistan.
name: Shahrituz

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 58.4 million grant for Phase 1 of the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (Linked to Project ID#53990 and #72612)
description:
In 2013, the Chinese Government agreed to provide RMB 58.4 million of grant financing for Phase 1 of the the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (captured in project ID#71741). Then, in 2016, the Chinese Government agreed to provide RMB 59.6 million of grant financing for Phase 2 of the the Kurgan-Tyube to Kulob Road Rehabilitation Project (captured in project ID#53990).

The first phase of the project involved the construction of 12 kilometers of roads in Kurgan-Tyube and Kulob and 2 automobile bridges in Kulob. The second phase of the project involved the rehabilitation of 15 streets and 4 bridges in Kurgan-Tyube and Kulob measuring 22 km in length.

China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was supervised and managed by China Railway First Survey and Design Institute Group Co.,Ltd.

The first phase officially started on April 17, 2015. The inauguration ceremony and the signing ceremony of the technology handover certificate for project was held on January 19, 2016. The second phase of construction began on December 29, 2016. It was completed on December 15, 2017, after passing inspection. The Project Qualification Certificate was signed on December 27, 2007. The inaugural ceremony for the second phase was held on January 8, 2018.

STAFF_NOTE: : This project is also known as the Road Rehabilitation Project for Two Cities in Tajikistan. The Chinese project title is 塔吉克斯坦两城市道路修复项目（第II阶段).
name: Bokhtar

title: China Eximbank provides $51 million preferential buyer’s credit to provide additional support to 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project and 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project (Linked to Project ID#39984 and #39644)
description:
On May 15, 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China and Government of Tajikistan signed a credit agreement, according to the Tajikistan Ministry of Finance. China Eximbank agreed to provide a $51,000,000 USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan to the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan (see pg. 37 of "Consolidated financial statements..."). This loan was intended to provide additional financing to the 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project and 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project. Both of these projects were supported by Export-Import Bank loans approved in 2006 (see Project ID#39984 and Project ID#39644). The terms of this PBC loan are unknown.

However, it is known that the Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend “Barqi Tojik” at a 3% interest rate between May 29, 2007 and December 21, 2028. As of December 31, 2018, $480,910 USD was outstanding. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy (pg. 15 of "Consolidated..."). 

The purpose of the 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project was to construct a 500 kV electricity transmission line that would connect the northern Sughd region to the national grid. According to Xinhua, the project also intended to realize the effective dispatching of electricity between Dushanbe and Khujand, completely solve the problem of power shortage in the south during the dry season in winter, build the transmission channel for the implementation of the Tajik Hydropower Strategy, improve the safety, stability, and reliability of the power grid, and reduce the loss of electricity through transmission from 14% to 3.2%. 

According to Asia-Plus, the purpose of the 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project was to construct a 90 km, 220 kV electricity transmission line between Dangara and Kulab. This would connect the southern region to the national grid. According to President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon, relayed by Asia-Plus, the new power transmission line would improve the power supply in the south of the Khatlon region, and create a more stable power supply. The Lolazor-Khatlon line had a capacity of approximately 4 billion kWh of electricity a year, according to Asia-Plus. The project was to provide the Khatlon region with electricity from the Sangtuda 1 and 2 hydroelectric power plants, and allow for the export of electricity to Afghanistan.

Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock (TBEA) was the contractor responsible for the implementation of both projects (see pg. 14 of "China as an Emerging Donor..."). The North-South transmission line has been operational since November 29, 2009 (see pg. 11 of "BRI in Central Asia: Energy Connectivity Projects").  According to Asia-Plus, the Lolazor-Khatlon transmission line has been operational since June 25, 2008. 

The project is linked to previous fundings of a 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line project (captured in project ID#39644) and a 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project (captured in project ID#39984) in 2006.

STAFF_NOTE: The document "Consolidated financial statements..." states the agreement for the loan was May 29, 2007, but several official sources gave May 15, 2009. It was assumed that the later was correct.
name: Sovet

title: China Eximbank provides $55.2 million preferential buyer's credit for 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project (Linked to Project ID#39644, #70910)
description:
In March 2006, the Government of Tajikistan and the Export-Import Bank of China signed a MoU for projects proposed by Tajikistan. Later, on December 16, 2006, the Export-Import Bank of China provided a $58,228,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan for the 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project. The loan terms carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and an interest rate of 2% (see the cited resource"List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). 

The Government of Tajikistan used nearly all of the proceeds from this loan ($55,227,590, according to pg. 87 of "Tajikistan Power Utility Financial Recovery Program") to on-lend (through subsidiary loan agreement No. BLA06016) to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik” at a 3% interest rate between December 16, 2006 and June 21, 2026. As of December 31, 2018, $520,774 USD was outstanding. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy (pg. 15 of "Consolidated..."). 

The initial value of the project was $58.1 million USD. The Government of Tajikistan contributed $2.9 million USD to the project. Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock (TBEA) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was launched in May 2006. The transmission line was planned to be commissioned by the end of December 2007, but the inclusion of the construction of an additional internal 110 kV transmission line from the Khatlon substation to the Bokhtar substation postponed the start date. The Lolazor-Khatlon transmission line was commissioned on June 25, 2008.

The purpose of this project was to construct a 90 km, 220 kV electricity transmission line between Dangara and Kulab. This would connect the southern region to the national grid. The new power transmission line would improve the power supply in the south of the Khatlon region, and create a more stable power supply. The Lolazor-Khatlon line had a capacity of approximately 4 billion kWh of electricity a year. The project was to provide the Khatlon region with electricity from the Sangtuda 1 and 2 hydroelectric power plants, and allow for the export of electricity to Afghanistan. 

The project is linked to project ID#70910, which captured a $51 million funding from Eximbank in 2009 for both the 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project and a 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project (The original financing of the 500 kV project in 2006 was captured in project ID#39644).

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is высоковольтных линий электропередач 500 кВ «Юг – Север» и 220 кВ «Лолазор –Хатлон». Some official sources identify $55,227,590 as the face value of the loan. 

Additionally, this loan was coded as export buyer's credits after much consideration. The "China as an Emerging Donor..." article indicated that China offered PBCs, Tajikistan made proposals for projects, and this project was selected. An Export-Import Bank article, although it does not explicitly name this project as a loan, states that Eximbank and Tajikistan signed preferential export buyer’s credit agreements in June 2006, close to the timeframe of the commitment of financing for this project. Because of this evidence, this loan was considered a PBC and coded as such.
name: Sovet

name: Vose

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 191.9 million government concessional loan for the Upgrade of the Vahdat-Yavan Section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube Railway Project (Linked to Project ID#71443)
description:
On November 7, 2014, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed two loan agreements with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Upgrade of the Vahdat-Yavan Section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube Railway Project: a RMB-denominated government concessional loan (GCL) provided on highly concessional terms (20 year maturity, 11 year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate) and a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan on highly concessional terms (2% interest, 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period), each with a bank service fee of 0.2% and a reservation fee of 0.2%).

On August 13, 2013, State Unitary Enterprise “Rohi Ohani Tojikiston” had signed a contract for the survey, design and construction of tunnels and bridges of the new Dushanbe-Kurgan-Tyube railway, Vahdat-Yavan section for $59,993,900 USD. The Government of Tajikistan approved this deal on August 28, 2013, and ordered the Ministry of Finance to attract a soft loan from China Eximbank. The total cost of the project was approximately $71.993 million USD. The loans from the Export-Import Bank of China were valued at $68,992,970 USD. Tajikistan contributed $2,999,700 USD through State Unitary Enterprise "Rohi Ohani Tojikiston” (see "Information on existing state investment projects" and "Строительство мостов и тоннелей на железной дороги Душанбе-Кургантюбе, участок Вахдат-Яван" from the Ministry of Transport of the Republic of Tajikistan).

The face value of the GCL loan was RMB 191.9 million. The face value of the PBC loan was $36.9 million USD (pg.5 of “Отчет о состоянии государственного долга на 2014 год”). These loans combined are roughly equal to the reported Eximbank contribution. The loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. Project ID#40489 records the GCL and Project ID#71443 records the PBC. 

This project was to become the first railway project launched and completed under the framework of the "Silk Road Economic Belt" initiative, and was to become a hub of an international railway network connecting China, Tajikistan, Afghanistan, and Iran. China Railway 19th Bureau Group Co Ltd was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on May 15, 2015 and the project was completed on August 24, 2016. 

This project involved the construction of construction of 5 bridges and 3 tunnels along the Vakhdat-Yavan section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube railway. Additional locational details can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/vahdat-yavan-railway-construction/bde10173-33b5-4431-9ad2-19468648bcbd/.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Строительство железной дороги Душанбе-Курган-тюбе, участок Вахдат- Яван. Yavan is also spelled Yovon. Vahdat is also spelled Vakhdat.
name: Yovon

title: China Eximbank provides $35.4 million government concessional loan for Tajik Aluminum Company (TALCO) to launch three new plants (Linked to Project ID#53755)
description:
On July 24, 2014, Tajik Aluminum Company (TALCO) signed an EPC agreement with China National Heavy Machinery Corporation (CHMC) for the Fluoride Salt Project. The project included the construction of three large plants in the Yovon District of Khatlon Region: a plant for the production of aluminum fluoride with annual capacity of 18,000 tons, a plant for the production of cryolite with annual capacity of 12,000 tons, and the plant for the production of sulfuric acid with annual capacity of 130,000 tons. These three plants were sometimes referred to as three separate projects: the Cryolite Project, the Aluminum Fluoride Project, and the Sulfuric Acid Project. 

The total cost of these projects was roughly $126 million USD. TALCO itself will invest approximately $37 million in the plants. On November 7, 2014, to finance the rest of the project, during the Beijing APEC Summit and under the witness of Xi Jinping and President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon (see "塔铝项目贷款协议正式签订" from CNMC), the Export-Import Bank of China agreed to provide two loans to the Tajik Ministry of Finance for the Flouride Salt Project: a RMB-denominated government concessional loan (GCL) provided on highly concessional terms (20 year maturity, 11 year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate) and a $53.1 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan on highly concessional terms (2% interest rate, 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period).

The precise face value of the GCL loan and the precise face value of the PBC loan are unknown. However, it is known that the GCL and PBC are jointly worth $88.5 million, and AidData learned through correspondence with the IMF that 40% of the total debt financing from China Eximbank ($35.4 million) came from the RMB-denominated GCL and 60% of the total debt financing from China Eximbank ($53.1 million) came from the USD-denominated PBC. The loan agreements were finalized between Ministry of Finance and China Eximbank on November 7, 2014. Project ID#53755 records the PBC and Project ID#71391 records the GCL. They were then ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. 

The project was located in Yovon District within Khatlon Region. Its exact locational coordinates are 38° 32' 45"N, 68° 13' 31" E (see "TALCO" from Sulphuric Acid on the Web). Construction was undertaken by the EPC contractor (CHMC) and these three plants were completed and officially inaugurated by Tajikistan President Emomali Rahmon on September 6, 2016.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese name of the project is 塔铝项目. The Russian name of the project is Строительство заводов по производству криолита, фтористого алюминия и серной кислоты в рамках реконструкции и модернизации ТАЛКО. 

Aluminum fluoride is an inorganic compound used primarily in the production of aluminum. This colorless solid can be prepared synthetically, but also occurs naturally. Aluminum fluoride is an important additive for the production of aluminum by electrolysis. Together, with cryolite, it lowers the melting point to below 1000°C and increases the conductivity of the solution. Cryolite was historically used as an ore of aluminum, and later in the electrolytic processing of the aluminum-rich oxide ore bauxite. The difficulty of separating aluminum from oxygen in the oxide ores was overcome by the use of cryolite as a flux to dissolve the oxide minerals. Pure cryolite melts at 1012°C, and it can dissolve the aluminum oxides sufficiently to allow for the easy extraction of the aluminum by electrolysis. Substantial energy is still needed for both heating the materials and the electrolysis, but it is much more energy-efficient than melting the oxides themselves. Since natural cryolite is too rare to be used for this purpose, synthetic sodium aluminum fluoride is produced from the common mineral fluorite. Sulfuric acid has a wide range of applications, including domestic acidic drain cleaner, electrolyte in lead-acid batteries, and various cleaning agents. It is also a central substance in the chemical industry. Principal uses include mineral processing, fertilizer manufacturing, oil refining, wastewater processing, and chemical synthesis. It is widely produced with different methods, such as contact process, wet sulfuric acid process and some other methods (see "http://www.sulphuric-acid.com/sulphuric-acid-on-the-web/acid%20plants/TALCO.htm").

The Tajik Aluminum Company is one of the ten largest aluminum smelters in the world. It provides up to 70% of Tajikistan's foreign currency earnings while consuming 40% of its electrical power. TALCO is wholly owned by the Tajik Government. Tajikistan does not mine alumina, but imports the raw material through tolling arrangements.
name: Yovon
