title: China Development Bank provides a US$78 million long-term loan for Huaxin Cement's cement plant (Linked to Project ID#53588, #53976)
description: In 2011, China Development Bank (CDB) provided a US$78 million long-term loan for Huaxin Cement's construction of a dry process cement production line in Tajikistan. Huaxin Cement Company has built the country's first new dry-process cement production line in Tajikistan. This production line can produce 1 million tons of cement each year, which will greatly enhance Tajikistan's ability to build infrastructure. Total investment was 1.5 billion dollars. Huaxin launched a JV for the project. Huaxin's equity investment amount is vague. The equity part is captured in project ID#53976. Construction for Huaxin's first plant begun on September 15, 2011, and production begun on August 29, 2013. As early as August 2011, Huaxin Cement signed a cooperation agreement with Tajikistan, and the two parties planned to jointly build a new dry-process cement production line project with an annual output of 1 million tons. In 2014, Huaxin Cement's second and third cement production line projects in the tower were also launched. Among them, the second line is expected to be put into production in the first quarter of 2016. Huaxin Cement's second and third cement production line projects will be located in two cities in Tajikistan, tentatively named the Huzhande project and the Dangara project, and are planned to be completed and put into operation in 2015 and 2016 respectively. For the investment in the second and third cement production line projects plant by Huaxin Cement, please see linked project ID#53588.
name: Yovon

title: China Eximbank provides $36.9 million preferential buyer’s credit for the Upgrade of the Vahdat-Yavan Section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube Railway Project (Linked to Project ID#40489)
description:
On November 7, 2014, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed two loan agreements with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Upgrade of the Vahdat-Yavan Section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube Railway Project: a RMB-denominated government concessional loan (GCL) provided on highly concessional terms (20 year maturity, 11 year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate) and a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan on highly concessional terms (2% interest, 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period), each with a bank service fee of 0.2% and a reservation fee of 0.2%).

On August 13, 2013, State Unitary Enterprise “Rohi Ohani Tojikiston” had signed a contract for the survey, design and construction of tunnels and bridges of the new Dushanbe-Kurgan-Tyube railway, Vahdat-Yavan section for $59,993,900 USD. The Government of Tajikistan approved this deal on August 28, 2013, and ordered the Ministry of Finance to attract a soft loan from China Eximbank. The total cost of the project was approximately $71.993 million USD. The loans from the Export-Import Bank of China were valued at $68,992,970 USD. Tajikistan contributed $2,999,700 USD through State Unitary Enterprise "Rohi Ohani Tojikiston” (see "Information on existing state investment projects" and "Строительство мостов и тоннелей на железной дороги Душанбе-Кургантюбе, участок Вахдат-Яван" from the Ministry of Transport of the Republic of Tajikistan).

The face value of the GCL loan was RMB 191.9 million. The face value of the PBC loan was $36.9 million USD (pg.5 of “Отчет о состоянии государственного долга на 2014 год”). These loans combined are roughly equal to the reported Eximbank contribution. The loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. Project ID#40489 records the GCL and Project ID#71443 records the PBC.

This project was to become the first railway project launched and completed under the framework of the "Silk Road Economic Belt" initiative, and was to become a hub of an international railway network connecting China, Tajikistan, Afghanistan, and Iran. China Railway 19th Bureau Group Co Ltd was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on May 15, 2015 and the project was completed on August 24, 2016.

This project involved the construction of construction of 5 bridges and 3 tunnels along the Vakhdat-Yavan section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube railway. Additional locational details can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/vahdat-yavan-railway-construction/bde10173-33b5-4431-9ad2-19468648bcbd/.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Строительство железной дороги Душанбе-Курган-тюбе, участок Вахдат- Яван. Yavan is also spelled Yovon. Vahdat is also spelled Vakhdat.
name: Yovon

title: China Eximbank provides $143.9 million preferential buyer’s credit for Second Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID #40063, #40440)
description:
On November 27, 2010, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed a $143,925,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [China Eximbank PBC NO.2010 (025) Total No. (132)] for the Second Stage of the Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project. This loan carried an interest rate of 2%, a maturity of 20 years, and a grace period of 5 years. The total project cost was $151,500,000, including a contribution of $7,575,000 from the Government of Tajikistan. 

China Road & Bridge Corporation was awarded the implementation contract. The project is implemented in the design and construction contracting mode. The main construction content includes road reconstruction, municipal road engineering, tunnels and connecting lines, etc. The road repair project construction period is 24 months, and the tunnel and connection line construction period is 36 months. Construction began on October 15, 2010, and ths project was completed (after passing final inspection) on October 30, 2013. 

This project supported the reconstruction of a 50.5 km road segment along the 147.64 km Dushanbe-Vahdat-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway (which is also known as the Tajikistan-China highway). It also supported the construction of the 4.43 km Chormagzak Tunnel along the 147.64 km Dushanbe-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway. More detailed locational information can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbekulma-road-dushanbe-dangara-section-phase-2/9d21c81e-6931-4df6-9dd4-650c86518ecb/ at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Chormaghzak+Tunnel,+Tajikistan/@38.4771348,69.1814159,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x38b66e9dde37093f:0x45059c2b6cd21c12!8m2!3d38.4771306!4d69.1836046.” 

STAFF_NOTE: This project is linked to the China Eximbank-financed First Stage and China Eximbank-financed Third Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (see Project ID#40063, #40440). China Eximbank reportedly provided $243.4 million of debt financing in total for all three stages of Phase 1. The Russian project title for Stage 2 of Phase 1 is Реконструкция второго этапа Фаза I автомобильной дороги «Душанбе-Кульма» (Таджикистан – граница Китая) на участке «Душанбе - Дангара». The Chinese project title is 塔中公路一期(杜尚别—丹卡拉段)道路修复改造项目.
name: Yovon

title: China Eximbank provides $118 million USD loan for 15,000 Hectares Agricultural Industrial Park Project and 200,000 Spindle Textile Project (Linked to Project ID#54353, #71757)
description:
In June 2016 , at the 2016 Silk Road Financial Forum in Warsaw, Poland, the Xinjiang Branch of the Export-Import Bank of China signed a framework agreement with Xinjiang Zhongtai (Group) Co., Ltd for the 15,000 Hectares Agricultural Industrial Park Project and 200,000 Spindle Textile Project. Then, a commissioning ceremony for the project took place on August 31, 2016. China Eximbank provided a $118.343 million loan in 2016 to Zhongtai (Dangara) New Silk Road Textile Industry Company for the 15,000 Hectares Agricultural Industrial Park Project and 200,000 Spindle Textile Project. 

Zhongtai (Dangara) New Silk Road Textile Industry Company is the company responsible for project implementation. Zhongtai (Dangara) New Silk Road Textile Industry Co., Ltd. was founded in the Dangara District of Tajikistan's Khatlon Province in 2014 by China's Xinjiang Zhongtai Group and Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps. The Zhongtai Dangara Agriculture and Textile Industrial Park project consisted of an agricultural park with 15,000 hectares for growing cotton; a spinning plant with 110,000 spindles and manufacturing facilities for weaving, printing and garment. The groundbreaking ceremony of the entire Agricultural and Textile Project was held on December 19, 2014 ("中泰新丝路塔吉克斯坦农业纺织产业园奠基"). The second phase, including the start of the airflow of 50,000 spindles, was to be completed in 2017 (see "塔吉克斯坦总理科希尔·拉苏尔佐达一行考察中泰集团公司"). The launch ceremony of the second phase of the air spindles was held, and the third phase held its groundbreaking ceremony on November 5, 2018. The third and fourth phases started on March 18, 2019.

The Agricultural and Textile Industrial Park project was reportedly the largest agricultural and textile investment project in Tajikistan since its independence in 1991. The project included 200,000 mu of cotton agricultural park and 150,000 spinning spindles. The first phase of 150,000 mu of cotton was to be sown in 2015, and the spinning project was to be completed and put into operation on August 31, 2016. After the project is completed, the industrial park was expected to be able to produce 80,000 tons of seed cotton, 32,000 tons of lint, 24,000 tons of cotton yarn, 91.5 million meters of cotton cloth, annual sales revenue of RMB 1.525 billion, and a profit of RMB 250 million, improving the welfare of its workers and driving industrial and agricultural development in Tajikistan. 

For a RMB 1.1 billion investment by Chinese companies for industrial park, see linked to project #54353. For a RMB 200 million loan for the industrial park from the Agricultural Bank of China, please see linked project ID#71757.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 新疆中泰集团有限公司1.5万公顷农业产 业园及20万锭纺织项目. One official source ("金融论坛取得丰硕跨境务实成果") suggests that the face value of the loan was $130 million USD, but we have chosen the more conservative of the two estimates for the time being. It is unclear which phase of the project was funded by this Eximbank loan, or if it was a general loan.
name: Danghara

title: China Eximbank provides $51 million preferential buyer’s credit to provide additional support to 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project and 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project (Linked to Project ID#39984 and #39644)
description:
On May 15, 2009, the Export-Import Bank of China and Government of Tajikistan signed a credit agreement, according to the Tajikistan Ministry of Finance. China Eximbank agreed to provide a $51,000,000 USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan to the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan (see pg. 37 of "Consolidated financial statements..."). This loan was intended to provide additional financing to the 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project and 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project. Both of these projects were supported by Export-Import Bank loans approved in 2006 (see Project ID#39984 and Project ID#39644). The terms of this PBC loan are unknown.

However, it is known that the Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend “Barqi Tojik” at a 3% interest rate between May 29, 2007 and December 21, 2028. As of December 31, 2018, $480,910 USD was outstanding. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy (pg. 15 of "Consolidated..."). 

The purpose of the 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project was to construct a 500 kV electricity transmission line that would connect the northern Sughd region to the national grid. According to Xinhua, the project also intended to realize the effective dispatching of electricity between Dushanbe and Khujand, completely solve the problem of power shortage in the south during the dry season in winter, build the transmission channel for the implementation of the Tajik Hydropower Strategy, improve the safety, stability, and reliability of the power grid, and reduce the loss of electricity through transmission from 14% to 3.2%. 

According to Asia-Plus, the purpose of the 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project was to construct a 90 km, 220 kV electricity transmission line between Dangara and Kulab. This would connect the southern region to the national grid. According to President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon, relayed by Asia-Plus, the new power transmission line would improve the power supply in the south of the Khatlon region, and create a more stable power supply. The Lolazor-Khatlon line had a capacity of approximately 4 billion kWh of electricity a year, according to Asia-Plus. The project was to provide the Khatlon region with electricity from the Sangtuda 1 and 2 hydroelectric power plants, and allow for the export of electricity to Afghanistan.

Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock (TBEA) was the contractor responsible for the implementation of both projects (see pg. 14 of "China as an Emerging Donor..."). The North-South transmission line has been operational since November 29, 2009 (see pg. 11 of "BRI in Central Asia: Energy Connectivity Projects").  According to Asia-Plus, the Lolazor-Khatlon transmission line has been operational since June 25, 2008. 

The project is linked to previous fundings of a 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line project (captured in project ID#39644) and a 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project (captured in project ID#39984) in 2006.

STAFF_NOTE: The document "Consolidated financial statements..." states the agreement for the loan was May 29, 2007, but several official sources gave May 15, 2009. It was assumed that the later was correct.
name: Danghara

title: Chinese Embassy funded Danghara Women’s Sewing Training and Production Center (Linked to project ID#54043, #53587, #53591, #71883, #71881)
description:
The Chinese Embassy to Tajikistan funded Danghara Women’s Sewing Training and Production Center, located in the hometown of President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. The opening ceremony of center was held on January 11, 2017. The center was intended to improve the well-being of the Tajik people and promote the women's employment, according to the embassy. The value of the donated sewing center is unknown. 

Chinese Embassy also funded other differenct Women’s Sewing Training and Production Center in Tajikistan. Project ID#54043 captured the sewing center in Maslozhelkomupo District, Dushanbe. Project ID#53591 captured the sewing center in Vakhsh District, Khatlon. Project ID#53587 captured the sewing center in Sino District, Dushanbe. Project ID#71883 captured the sewing center named "Gurdaston" in Dushanbe. Project ID#71881 captured the sewing center in the Dzhami District, Khatlon. 

STAFF_NOTE: "Year uncertain" was checked because it is not confirmed that this donation was committed in 2017. "Dangara" is also used in the name of the center.
name: Danghara

title: China grants 79 million RMB to Tajikistan for the Shar Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel Construction Project (Linked with projects #40406, #53615)
description:
In 2007, the Chinese Government provided RMB 79 million in grant funding to support the Shar Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel Construction Project. Previously, in July 2005, China and Tajikistan reached an agreement for providing assistance for the construction of the Shar Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel. This grant funding was not only used for direct tunnel construction but for the provision of buses,  Mobile inspection and observation complex, radiotechnics and other systems, though the specific breakdown is unknown.

China Railway No.5 Engineering Group, a subsidiary of China Railway Engineering Corporation (CREC), was the contractor responsible for project implementation. CCCC Highway Consultants Co., Ltd. undertook preliminary design of the project. Xinjiang Highway Engineering Supervision Center was responsible for supervision of construction. The groundbreaking ceremony was held on October 20, 2006. The construction was scheduled to be completed in 34 months (see "Update: Construction of Shar-Shar tunnel in Khatlon officially begins"). The project was completed on August 8, 2009. A grand opening ceremony was held on August 30. In November 2010, the project won the China Construction Engineering Luban Prize.

The Shar-Shar Tunnel Project (alternatively: Sharshar) included a main tunnel with a total length of 2.23 km and a 4.91 km connection line (3.4 km for the northern connection line, 1.5 km for the southern connection line) and a 169-meter-long bridge in a mountainous and hilly area. This project aimed to promote general economic development. It also hoped to improve traffic conditions in Tajikistan, as well as strengthen business and logistics links between China and Tajikistan. Upon completion, the tunnel was to reportedly reduce the travel time from Dushanbe to Dangara, President Emomali Rahmon's hometown, by 40 minutes. 

This tunnel was located 80 km south of the capital city of Dushanbe, near the city of Kulyab in the Dangara District of Khatlon Region. It is on the Dushanbe-Vahdat-Dangara highway and was built under Shar-Shar mountain pass. More detailed locational information can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/ozodi-tunnel-construction/4c72ae7b-1c6b-4466-91b7-3092ba7ee8e4/.

This project is linked to ID#53615, which covers a Chinese Government grant to repair a 6 km access road to the Shar-Shar Tunnel, and #40406, an earlier donation for the same project

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 沙尔—沙尔隧道. The Russian project title is Ремонт подходных путей к тоннелю Озоди (Шар-Шар). The project is also known as the "Shahr-Shahr Tunnel and the North-South Link Project" (see "援塔吉克斯坦沙尔-沙尔隧道和南北连接线项目竣工典礼隆重举行"). The Shar-Shar tunnel was renamed the Ozodi (in English: Liberty) tunnel in 2014 (see "Chormaghzak Tunnel renamed Khatlon Tunnel and Shar-Shar Tunnel renamed Ozodi Tunnel"). 

The Government of Tajikistan’s Aid Information Management System (AIMS) identifies $41,664,633 as the amount of grant funding provided by the Chinese Government. This project is identified by identification number TJK/102014 in the AIMS, and its title in the AIMS is 'Construction of auto-tunnel Shar-shar'' (see "May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS China Specific Projects" resource). However, we chose to code the RMB 260 million estimate provided by the China’s Embassy in Tajikistan since the Chinese Government typically denominates its grant agreements in RMB and in a Speech of the Chancellery of the Adviser for Trade and Economic Issues of the PRC, the grant was denominated in RMB.
name: Danghara

title: China Eximbank provides $55.2 million preferential buyer's credit for 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project (Linked to Project ID#39644, #70910)
description:
In March 2006, the Government of Tajikistan and the Export-Import Bank of China signed a MoU for projects proposed by Tajikistan. Later, on December 16, 2006, the Export-Import Bank of China provided a $58,228,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan for the 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project. The loan terms carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and an interest rate of 2% (see the cited resource"List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). 

The Government of Tajikistan used nearly all of the proceeds from this loan ($55,227,590, according to pg. 87 of "Tajikistan Power Utility Financial Recovery Program") to on-lend (through subsidiary loan agreement No. BLA06016) to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik” at a 3% interest rate between December 16, 2006 and June 21, 2026. As of December 31, 2018, $520,774 USD was outstanding. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy (pg. 15 of "Consolidated..."). 

The initial value of the project was $58.1 million USD. The Government of Tajikistan contributed $2.9 million USD to the project. Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock (TBEA) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was launched in May 2006. The transmission line was planned to be commissioned by the end of December 2007, but the inclusion of the construction of an additional internal 110 kV transmission line from the Khatlon substation to the Bokhtar substation postponed the start date. The Lolazor-Khatlon transmission line was commissioned on June 25, 2008.

The purpose of this project was to construct a 90 km, 220 kV electricity transmission line between Dangara and Kulab. This would connect the southern region to the national grid. The new power transmission line would improve the power supply in the south of the Khatlon region, and create a more stable power supply. The Lolazor-Khatlon line had a capacity of approximately 4 billion kWh of electricity a year. The project was to provide the Khatlon region with electricity from the Sangtuda 1 and 2 hydroelectric power plants, and allow for the export of electricity to Afghanistan. 

The project is linked to project ID#70910, which captured a $51 million funding from Eximbank in 2009 for both the 220 kV Lolazor-Khatlon Transmission Line Project and a 500 kV North-South Power Transmission Line Project (The original financing of the 500 kV project in 2006 was captured in project ID#39644).

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is высоковольтных линий электропередач 500 кВ «Юг – Север» и 220 кВ «Лолазор –Хатлон». Some official sources identify $55,227,590 as the face value of the loan. 

Additionally, this loan was coded as export buyer's credits after much consideration. The "China as an Emerging Donor..." article indicated that China offered PBCs, Tajikistan made proposals for projects, and this project was selected. An Export-Import Bank article, although it does not explicitly name this project as a loan, states that Eximbank and Tajikistan signed preferential export buyer’s credit agreements in June 2006, close to the timeframe of the commitment of financing for this project. Because of this evidence, this loan was considered a PBC and coded as such.
name: Danghara

title: China Eximbank provides $49 million preferential buyer’s credit for First Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#53750, #40440)
description:
On August 18, 2009, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $49,000,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan for the First Stage of the Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project. The loan had a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 years, and an interest rate of 2%. 

The total project cost was $51,578,000, including a $2,578,000 contribution from the Government of Tajikistan. China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on August 30, 2009 after a grand commencement ceremony held on the same day and the project was completed (after passing final inspection) on October 30, 2013. 

This project supported the reconstruction of a 57.8 km road segment along the 147.64 km Dushanbe-Vahdat-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway (which is also known as the Tajikistan-China highway). It also involved the construction of new sections of road to bypass settlements and bridges. More detailed locational information can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbekulma-road-dushanbe-dangara-section-phase-2/9d21c81e-6931-4df6-9dd4-650c86518ecb/.

STAFF_NOTE: This project is linked to the China Eximbank-financed Second Stage and China Eximbank-financed Third Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (see Project ID#53750, #40440). China Eximbank reportedly provided $243.4 million of debt financing in total for all three stages of Phase 1. The Russian project title for Stage 1 of Phase 1 is Реконструкция 1-го этапа 1 фазы автодороги Душанбе-Кульма (Таджикистан - граница Китая) на участке «Душанбе-Дангара». The Chinese project title is 塔中公路一期(杜尚别—丹卡拉段)道路修复改造项目.
name: Danghara

title: China provides an RMB 260 million grant for the Shar Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel Construction Project (Linked to Project IDs #53615, #72465)
description:
In 2006, the Chinese Government provided RMB 260 million in grant funding to support the Shar Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel Construction Project. Previously, in July 2005, China and Tajikistan reached an agreement for providing assistance for the construction of the Shar Shar (Ozodi) Tunnel. 

China Railway No.5 Engineering Group, a subsidiary of China Railway Engineering Corporation (CREC), was the contractor responsible for project implementation. CCCC Highway Consultants Co., Ltd. undertook preliminary design of the project. Xinjiang Highway Engineering Supervision Center was responsible for supervision of construction. The groundbreaking ceremony was held on October 20, 2006. The construction was scheduled to be completed in 34 months (see "Update: Construction of Shar-Shar tunnel in Khatlon officially begins"). The project was completed on August 8, 2009. A grand opening ceremony was held on August 30. In November 2010, the project won the China Construction Engineering Luban Prize.

The Shar-Shar Tunnel Project (alternatively: Sharshar) included a main tunnel with a total length of 2.23 km and a 4.91 km connection line (3.4 km for the northern connection line, 1.5 km for the southern connection line) and a 169-meter-long bridge in a mountainous and hilly area. This project aimed to promote general economic development. It also hoped to improve traffic conditions in Tajikistan, as well as strengthen business and logistics links between China and Tajikistan. Upon completion, the tunnel was to reportedly reduce the travel time from Dushanbe to Dangara, President Emomali Rahmon's hometown, by 40 minutes. 

This tunnel was located 80 km south of the capital city of Dushanbe, near the city of Kulyab in the Dangara District of Khatlon Region. It is on the Dushanbe-Vahdat-Dangara highway and was built under Shar-Shar mountain pass. More detailed locational information can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/ozodi-tunnel-construction/4c72ae7b-1c6b-4466-91b7-3092ba7ee8e4/.

This project is linked to ID#53615, which covers a Chinese Government grant to repair a 6 km access road to the Shar-Shar Tunnel, and #72465, a follow up grant in 2007.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 沙尔—沙尔隧道. The Russian project title is Ремонт подходных путей к тоннелю Озоди (Шар-Шар). The project is also known as the "Shahr-Shahr Tunnel and the North-South Link Project" (see "援塔吉克斯坦沙尔-沙尔隧道和南北连接线项目竣工典礼隆重举行"). The Shar-Shar tunnel was renamed the Ozodi (in English: Liberty) tunnel in 2014 (see "Chormaghzak Tunnel renamed Khatlon Tunnel and Shar-Shar Tunnel renamed Ozodi Tunnel"). 

The Government of Tajikistan’s Aid Information Management System (AIMS) identifies $41,664,633 as the amount of grant funding provided by the Chinese Government. This project is identified by identification number TJK/102014 in the AIMS, and its title in the AIMS is 'Construction of auto-tunnel Shar-shar'' (see "May 2018 Flat Export from Tajikistan AIMS China Specific Projects" resource). However, we chose to code the RMB 260 million estimate provided by the China’s Embassy in Tajikistan since the Chinese Government typically denominates its grant agreements in RMB and in a Speech of the Chancellery of the Adviser for Trade and Economic Issues of the PRC, the grant was denominated in RMB.
name: Danghara

title: Chinese Government provides 1.4 million USD grant for 42nd Public School Water Supply Project in Dangara District
description:
On October 31, 2017, the groundbreaking ceremony of the 42nd Public School Water Supply Project in Dangara District, aided by the Chinese Government to the tune of 1.4 million USD, was held. Chinese Ambassador Yue Bin attended. This water supply project intended to provide clean water for the teachers and students of the 42nd School in Dangara District, and also solve the long-standing water-supply problem that has plagued local residents. An unspecified Chinese contractor was expected to be able to complete the project's construction on-time and deliver high-quality results. Dangara District is the hometown of President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon (see "驻塔吉克斯坦大使岳斌出席丹加拉区第42学校供水工程开工典礼" from the Chinese Embassy). TAG news Tajikistan reported that the project was funded by a $1.4 million USD grant from China, and involved the construction of a 5 km pipeline. The expected completion date was August 2018.

STAFF_NOTE: "Year uncertain" box was checked because it is not confirmed that this project was committed in 2017.
name: Danghara

title: China Eximbank provides $143.9 million preferential buyer’s credit for Second Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID #40063, #40440)
description:
On November 27, 2010, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed a $143,925,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [China Eximbank PBC NO.2010 (025) Total No. (132)] for the Second Stage of the Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project. This loan carried an interest rate of 2%, a maturity of 20 years, and a grace period of 5 years. The total project cost was $151,500,000, including a contribution of $7,575,000 from the Government of Tajikistan. 

China Road & Bridge Corporation was awarded the implementation contract. The project is implemented in the design and construction contracting mode. The main construction content includes road reconstruction, municipal road engineering, tunnels and connecting lines, etc. The road repair project construction period is 24 months, and the tunnel and connection line construction period is 36 months. Construction began on October 15, 2010, and ths project was completed (after passing final inspection) on October 30, 2013. 

This project supported the reconstruction of a 50.5 km road segment along the 147.64 km Dushanbe-Vahdat-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway (which is also known as the Tajikistan-China highway). It also supported the construction of the 4.43 km Chormagzak Tunnel along the 147.64 km Dushanbe-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway. More detailed locational information can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbekulma-road-dushanbe-dangara-section-phase-2/9d21c81e-6931-4df6-9dd4-650c86518ecb/ at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Chormaghzak+Tunnel,+Tajikistan/@38.4771348,69.1814159,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x38b66e9dde37093f:0x45059c2b6cd21c12!8m2!3d38.4771306!4d69.1836046.” 

STAFF_NOTE: This project is linked to the China Eximbank-financed First Stage and China Eximbank-financed Third Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (see Project ID#40063, #40440). China Eximbank reportedly provided $243.4 million of debt financing in total for all three stages of Phase 1. The Russian project title for Stage 2 of Phase 1 is Реконструкция второго этапа Фаза I автомобильной дороги «Душанбе-Кульма» (Таджикистан – граница Китая) на участке «Душанбе - Дангара». The Chinese project title is 塔中公路一期(杜尚别—丹卡拉段)道路修复改造项目.
name: Danghara

title: Chinese Government grants RMB 60 million for feasibility study of the construction of a school in Dangara
description: In 2009, the Chinese Government and the Government of Tajikistan signed a technical economic agreement for China to provide grant aid of RMB 60 million to conduct a feasibility study on the construction of a school in Dangara District, Khatlon Province (see pg.79 of 'Development Partner Profiles 2014'). STAFF_NOTE: The agreement for this grant is called 'Technical Economic Agreement for feasibility study on the project of construction of a school in Dangara district in Khatlon province' by the Government of Tajikistan's AIMS system, project ID TJK/102179. Additionally, the RMB 60 million was used instead of $8,788,633 USD because Chinese Government grants tend to distribute RMB grants.
name: Danghara

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 8 million grant for provision of switches in the Danghara region and equipment related to CDMA projects by ZTE
description: According to the Economic and Commercial Office of the Chinese Embassy in Tajikistan, sometime before July 2003, China provided a RMB 8 million grant to Tajikistan. As agreed by China and Tajikistan, the aid was to be used to provide switches to the Danghara region and to provide equipment for the implementation of CDMA projects. ZTE was responsible for its implementation, and as of July 2003, the project was progressing smoothly in its implementation phase.
name: Danghara

title: Agricultural Bank of China loans RMB 200 million to Zhongtai (Dangara) New Silk Road Textile Industry Company for the Agricultural and Textile Industrial Park Project (Linked to Project ID#46222, #54353)
description:
On September 29, 2017, the Agricultural Bank of China, Xinjiang Corps Branch, "successfully handled" a loan of RMB 200 million for Agricultural and Textile Industrial Park Project in Tajikistan. The loan was intended to support the construction of the project in Tajikistan by the Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps (see "农行兵团分行为塔吉克斯坦农业产业园项目提供亿元资金支持"). 

The Agricultural and Textile Industrial Park project was reportedly the largest agricultural and textile investment project in Tajikistan since its independence in 1991 (see pg.64 of "2018 Corporate Social Responsibility Report"). The project included 200,000 mu of cotton agricultural park and 150,000 spinning spindles. The first phase of 150,000 mu of cotton was to be sown in 2015, and the spinning project was to be completed and put into operation in 2016.  After the project is completed, the industrial park was expected to be able to produce 80,000 tons of seed cotton, 32,000 tons of lint, 24,000 tons of cotton yarn, 91.5 million meters of cotton cloth, annual sales revenue of RMB 1.525 billion, and a profit of RMB 250 million, improving the welfare of its workers and driving industrial and agricultural development in Tajikistan. 

For a $118 million USD loan from the Export-Import Bank of China for the industrial park, see linked project ID#46222. For a RMB 1.1 billion investment by three Chinese companies in the industrial park, please see linked project ID#54353.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 为塔吉克斯坦农业产业园 or 中泰新丝路塔吉克斯坦农业纺织产业园. The groundbreaking ceremony of the entire Agricultural and Textile Project was held on December 19, 2014. The project was commissioned and the zone started operation on August 31, 2016. Thus, this loan could not be for the first phase construction. It is possible, if not likely, they were intended for the second or third phases (See " 驻塔吉克斯坦大使岳斌与塔总统共同出席中资企业在塔投资项目投产仪式").
name: Danghara

title: Chinese Embassy donates Women's Sewing Training and Production Center in Dzhami District (Linked to Project ID#53594, #53591, #53587, #54043, #71883)
description:
The Chinese Embassy to Tajikistan donated a Women's Sewing Training Center in the Dzhami District. The opening ceremony was held on November 22, 2017. The center was intended to improve the vocational skills of local women and promote women's employment, according to the embassy. The value of the donated sewing center is unknown. 

Chinese Embassy also funded other differenct Women’s Sewing Training and Production Center in Tajikistan. Project ID#53594 captured the sewing center in Danghara. Project ID#54043 captured the sewing center in Maslozhelkomupo District, Dushanbe. Project ID#53591 captured the sewing center in Vakhsh District, Khatlon. Project ID#53587 captured the sewing center in Sino District, Dushanbe. Project ID#71883 captured the sewing center named "Gurdaston" in Dushanbe. 

STAFF_NOTE: "Year uncertain" was checked because it is not confirmed that this donation was committed in 2017. Translations state that this center was in the Khatlon Region "Zhami" or Tazami District", neither of which exist. After investigation, it became clear that those were different spellings for the "Dzhami District."
name: Jomi

title: China grants construction materials and diesel generators for disaster response in Tajikistan
description: In 2009, China granted construction materials and diesel generators for disaster response in the areas in Tajikistan affected by torrential rains and mudflows. The total value of the aid was estimated at 30,000 USD by REACT (Rapid Emergency Assessment and Coordination Team). This aid was in response to the May 2009 floods in Tajikistan.
name: Khuroson

title: Chinese Government grants $764,526 of humanitarian aids for natural disaster relief in Tajikistan
description: In 2011, Chinese Government granted $764,526 USD to Tajikistan in the form of humanitarian aid for flooding and other natural disasters, according to the May 2018 Flat Export of the Tajikistan AIMS, 'Humanitarian aid for flood and other disasters', AIMS project ID is TJK/112260. Though the Flat Export does not tie this project to a specific disaster, it is possible that the referenced flooding was a series of June 2011 floods and mudslides in Sughd Province (see 'Tajikistan: Floods and Mudslides - Jun 2011'). STAFF_NOTE: This project should not be confused with project ID#40441, the 2012 natural disaster response from China to Tajikistan. The 2012 aid package primarily sought to address the impact of an unusually cold winter, while the 2011 aid package primarily sought to address the impact of a flood.
name: Leninabad

title: Chinese Government provided a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#39989)
description:
As part of a set of high-level agreements signed at the June 15, 2006 meeting of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO), the Chinese Government offered a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (see the cited resource:"China signs Tajik loan deals"). This project was also supported by a $281.1 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan from the Export-Import Bank of China (see Project ID#39989).

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan had signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project.China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan tunnel. The project was wholly completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

The purpose of this project — also known as the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253-meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047-meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls . 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.
name: Matchin

title: China Development Bank provides $140 million loan for Technological Innovation of ZGC Gold Mine (Linked to Project ID#72389, #72802, #40482, #40481, #69997)
description:
On May 19, 2013, China Development Bank (CDB) and Zijin Mining Group signed a loan agreement with JV Zeravshan LLC (formerly known as Zervashan Gold Company) -- a special purpose vehicle -- worth $140 million USD, according to the Times of Asia. The proceeds from the loan were to be used for the Technological Innovation of ZGC Gold Mine in Tajikistan, a project that aimed to expand the production capacity of a gold mine in the town of Panjakent within Zarafshon in northern Tajikistan.

According to pg. 37 of the 2013 Annual Report from Zijin (published March 28, 2014), the project had entered implementation and achieved the following objectives: (1) The stripping of infrastructure of Jilao open-pit mine and Taror openpit mine had been completed for over 90% and 80%, respectively; (2) The reformation of industrial pilot production processing technology of Taror oxide ore processing plant had been completed; and (3) The Jilao 10,000 tonnes processing plant project had entered into civil engineering construction and installation stage. Upon completion, the project was to increase the mine's production to 3.5 tonnes of gold per year.

This project was one of many signed during the same visit of the President of Tajikistan to China from May 19th 2013 to May 20th 2013. The other projects were: Loans totaling 33 million RMB to Amonatbonk (captured in project ID#69997), a 200 million RMB grant (captured in project ID#40481), an agreement for the reconstruction of Regar Substation (captured in project ID#40482), loans totaling 20 million USD to Amonatbonk (captured in project ID#72802), a technical cooperation agreement, a fruit inspection protocol, and a sports cooperation agreement. 

The project is linked to another Zijing Group stake acquisition project (captured in project ID#72389).

STAFF_NOTE: In 1994, Zeravshan Gold Company (ZGC) was launched as a joint venture with Nelson Resources Ltd (44%) and the Tajik Government (51%) and the IFC (5%). In September 2002, Avocet signed a heads of agreement to acquire the Tajik gold assets of Toronto-based Nelson Resources Ltd held through Nelson’s subsidiary, Commonwealth and British Minerals Ltd, including its 44% interest in ZGC. In November 2004, Avocet increased its equity interest in ZGC from 49% to 75%. In 2007, Zijin paid $429.8 million HKD to acquire Avocet's stake. In February 2018, Zijin Mining, sold 5% of its shares in JV Zarafshon (its new name) to the Tajik government for $1.00 USD. With this, Zijin's share decreased to 70% ($16,974,364 USD), while the Tajik government's share rose to 30% ($7,274,724 USD) (see "China’s Zijin Mining sells 5 percent of shares in JV Zarafshon to Tajik government for…1.00 USD").
name: Pandjakent

title: China Eximbank provides $281.1 million preferential buyer’s credit for the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#40351)
description:
On June 15, 2006, at the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed a $281,105,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project. The PBC loan carried a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and an interest rate of 2% (see loan details at "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). 

The loan was set to disburse in 3 annual tranches. The loan disbursements were as follows (see pg.7 of "INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN Staff Report for the 2006 Article IV Consultation"):
- 2007: $112.4 million USD
- 2008: $112.4 million USD
- 2009: $56.2 million USD

The project had a total cost of $295.9 million USD. This project is linked to project ID#40351, a RMB 60 million grant offered by the Chinese Government. China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan  tunnel. The project was completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project. The purpose of the project — also known as the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253 meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047 meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.
name: Shahriston

title: Chinese Government provided a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#39989)
description:
As part of a set of high-level agreements signed at the June 15, 2006 meeting of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO), the Chinese Government offered a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (see the cited resource:"China signs Tajik loan deals"). name: Shahriston

title: China Eximbank provides $35 million preferential buyer’s credit for 220 kV Khujand-Ayni Power Transmission Line Project
description:
On November 25, 2010, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and the Export-Import Bank of China signed credit agreement No. N0.2010 (024) TOTAL N0. (131). In it, Eximbank agreed to provide the Tajik Ministry of Finance with a $35,055,003 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the 220 V Khujand-Ayni Power Transmission Line Project. The PBC loan carried the following terms: a 20-year maturity, 5-year grace period, and 2% interest rate (see "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). Total cost of the project was $36.9 million USD.

The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend to OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” (through a subsidiary loan agreement -- No. 2010 (024) TOTAL (170) – 029 BT) at a 3% interest rate between December 15, 2010 and September 21, 2031. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” is a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan that is responsible for the generation, transmission and distribution of electricity and thermal energy. 

The 220kV Khujand-Ayni Power Transmission Line Project involved the construction of the Ayni and Shakhristan substations and the construction of a 118km, 220kV power transmission line from Khujand to Ayni that connects the Zarafshon Valley to the unified power system through the 500kV South-North power grid. TBEA was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 8, 2010. The power transmission line was expected to be finished by the 20th anniversary of Tajikistan’s independence, on September 9, 2011 and the transmission line was inaugurated and put into operation on September 26, 2011. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Строительство высоковольтной линии электропередачи 220 кВ «Худжанд - Айни». The AIMS project ID is TJK/112014.

name: Spitamen

title: Chinese Government provided a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#39989)
description:
As part of a set of high-level agreements signed at the June 15, 2006 meeting of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO), the Chinese Government offered a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (see the cited resource:"China signs Tajik loan deals"). This project was also supported by a $281.1 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan from the Export-Import Bank of China (see Project ID#39989).

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan had signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project.China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan tunnel. The project was wholly completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

The purpose of this project — also known as the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253-meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047-meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls . 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.
name: Spitamen

title: China Construction Bank provides $20 million loan to China Nonferrous Gold Limited for working capital and restoring the production of Pakrut Gold Project (Linked to Project ID#54361, #70174, #70220, #70319, #70324, #70354, #70367, #70430)
description:
On May 24, 2012, China Nonferrous Metals International Mining Co. Ltd (CNMIM) provided a secured loan facility on commercial terms to Kryso Resources PLC — the mineral exploration and development company developing the Pakrut Gold Project — for $10 million and RMB 530 million to finance the development of the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70174 and #70319). Then, on June 19, 2014, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Macau) Limited provided a $120 million term loan facility to China Nonferrous Mining Group for the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70220). Then, on May 6, 2016, China Nonferrous Mining Group obtained a loan facility $120 million from CNMC International Capitals Company Limited (“CNMC”)— an associate of CNMIM — to refinance the loan facility that it contracted with Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Macau) Limited on June 19, 2014 for the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70324). On June 27, 2016 the China Nonferrous Mining Group obtained another loan, worth $19,114,809, from CNMIM for working capital purposes related to the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70354). Then, on July 1, 2016, China Construction Bank Corporation Macau Branch (CCBC) provided a loan facility of $100 million to China Nonferrous Mining Group to refinance its 2012 loan agreement with CNMIM (see linked Projects IDs #70367).

It was announced on October 30, 2017 that China Construction Bank Corporation Macau Branch agreed to provide China Nonferrous Gold with a loan facility of up to $20 million. The loan facility was for a maximum of one year and repayable 12 months after the first drawdown. The loan included an annual interest rate of 1.3% plus 3-month LIBOR and was governed by the law of Macau. The average 3-month LIBOR rate in October 2017 was 1.361%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as 1.361+1.3=2.661%. The facility was secured by a standby letter of credit from China Construction Bank Corporation Beijing Branch, for the aggregate amount of $20,618,556.70, which expired 12 months after the date of first drawdown (1-year maturity). A standby letter of credit fee of 1.15% was payable per annum. The CCBC Loan was expected to be drawn down shortly after its signing and was to be used for working capital and to fund the restoration of production of the Pakrut gold mine (see "Financial Update" from October 30, 2017).

LLC Pakrut, a mine that is 100% owned by Kryso Resources Ltd, was first established in 2003 and it operates the Pakrut deposit located on the southern slope of the Gissar range, 107 km from the city of Dushanbe. The geological exploration at Pakrut deposit started in 2004. The pre-gold reserves at the deposit, approved by the State Reserves Committee (CRC) of the Republic of Tajikistan, were 28.1 tons. The reserves of Pakrut gold mine are currently estimated to be 100 tons. In November 2011, the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan issued a mining licence to LLC Pakrut. Construction started in September 2012. The project went into production on June 5, 2016. In February 2017, high levels of snowfall caused significant damage to the facilities and equipment, and interrupted the construction, which was restarted in the second half of 2017. All construction work was expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2018 and production was expected to be recommenced in April 2018.

This mining project is located in Vahdat District, Republic of Tajikistan, about 80 km northeast (“NE”) in a straight line (112 km by road) from Dushanbe, the country’s capital city. It sits on the southern slope of the Gissar range. More detailed locational information can be found at http://www.cnfgold.com/Managed/Resources/docs/Downloads/srk_report.pdf. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is "塔吉克斯坦帕克鲁特金矿."

name: Ayni

title: CNMIM provides $10 million loan for Pakrut Gold Project (Linked to Project ID#54361, #70220, #70319, #70324, #70354, #70367, #70407, #70430)
description:
On May 24, 2012, China Nonferrous Metals International Mining Co. Ltd (CNMIM) and Kryso Resources PLC signed a Shareholder Loan Agreement for a loan made on commercial terms to Kryso Resources PLC — the mineral exploration and development company developing the Pakrut Gold Project.

The secured loan facility consisted of two tranches; a tranche for RMB 530 million and a tranche for $10 million USD. It was to be used exclusively for the design, construction, operation and administration of the Pakrut Gold Project, including operating costs, capital expenditure, and general working capital. The USD tranche was disbursed by CNMIM transferring the funds into a designated bank account of the Kryso. The term of the loan went from the date of the first advance until May 31, 2017. The annual fixed interest rate was 9% for both tranches and a management fee at 0.5% on the total amount of the loan was paid within 30 days of the first advance. Default interest of 13.5% per annum was payable on overdue amounts on the tranches. The Group was to repay all amounts of principal and interest in respect in USD at the fixed exchange rate of $1 USD to 6.30 RMB. The repayment dates were May 31, 2015, November 11, 2015, May 31, 2016, November 11, 2016, and May 31, 2017 for both tranches. November 30, 2014 was the end of the loan availability period. Kryso had drawn down $10 million USD under the USD tranche. Kryso pledged its 100% equity interest in LLC Pakrut to CNMIM as security for repayment of the loan. 

This project only captures the USD tranche of the loan facility. For the RMB tranche, please see Project ID #70319.

LLC Pakrut, a mine that is 100% owned by Kryso Resources Ltd, operates the Pakrut deposit located on the southern slope of the Gissar range, 112 km from the city of Dushanbe (see "Final Results and Notice of AGM"). Relevant geological exploration at the Pakrut deposit began in 2004 (see pp.iii "Independent Technical Report of the Pakrut Gold Project  in Vahdat Region, Republic of Tajikistan. According to the 2018 report published on Bloomberg, in November 2011, the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan issued a mining license to LLC Pakrut. According to SRK, at a gold cut-off of 1.0 g/t, the JORC Code compliant Proved Ore Reserves for Pakrut were estimated at 15,721 thousand tonnes (“kt”) averaging 3.1 g/t of gold. The JORC Code compliant Probable Ore Reserves were estimated at 2,787 kt averaging 2.5 g/t of gold. Construction started in September 2012. The project went into production on June 5, 2016. In February 2017, high levels of snowfall caused significant damage to the facilities and equipment, and interrupted the construction, which was restarted in the second half of 2017. All construction work was expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2018 and production was expected to be recommenced in April 2018. 


This mining project is located in Vahdat District, Republic of Tajikistan, about 80 km northeast (“NE”) in a straight line (112 km by road) from Dushanbe, the country’s capital city. It sits on the southern slope of the Gissar range. More detailed locational information can be found at http://www.cnfgold.com/Managed/Resources/docs/Downloads/srk_report.pdf.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is "塔吉克斯坦帕克鲁特金矿.”

name: Ghafurov

title: China opens Confucius Institute at Mining and Metallurgy Institute of Tajikistan
description: In 2014, Tajikistan's President Rahmon signed an agreement on the creation of a Confucius Institute at the Mining and Metallurgy Institute of Tajikistan. The agreement was signed in the presence of Xi Jinping and the Chief Executive of Confucius Institutes, Xu Lin. The Institute was formally created in 2015. The Institute provides lessons in Chinese and offers lessons in Chinese culture and music. It also offers scholarships to students in Tajikistan.

The PBC loan carried the following terms: a 20-year maturity, 5-year grace period, and 2% interest rate (see "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). Total cost of the project was $36.9 million USD.

The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend to OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” (through a subsidiary loan agreement -- No. 2010 (024) TOTAL (170) – 029 BT) at a 3% interest rate between December 15, 2010 and September 21, 2031. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” is a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan that is responsible for the generation, transmission and distribution of electricity and thermal energy. 

The 220kV Khujand-Ayni Power Transmission Line Project involved the construction of the Ayni and Shakhristan substations and the construction of a 118km, 220kV power transmission line from Khujand to Ayni that connects the Zarafshon Valley to the unified power system through the 500kV South-North power grid. TBEA was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 8, 2010. The power transmission line was expected to be finished by the 20th anniversary of Tajikistan’s independence, on September 9, 2011 and the transmission line was inaugurated and put into operation on September 26, 2011. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Строительство высоковольтной линии электропередачи 220 кВ «Худжанд - Айни». The AIMS project ID is TJK/112014.

name: Ghonchi

title: China Eximbank provides $281.1 million preferential buyer’s credit for the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#40351)
description:
On June 15, 2006, at the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed a $281,105,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project. The PBC loan carried a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and an interest rate of 2% (see loan details at "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). 

The loan was set to disburse in 3 annual tranches. The loan disbursements were as follows (see pg.7 of "INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN Staff Report for the 2006 Article IV Consultation"):
- 2007: $112.4 million USD
- 2008: $112.4 million USD
- 2009: $56.2 million USD

The project had a total cost of $295.9 million USD. This project is linked to project ID#40351, a RMB 60 million grant offered by the Chinese Government. China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan  tunnel. The project was completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project. The purpose of the project — also known as the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253 meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047 meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.
name: Ghonchi

title: China Eximbank provides $26.4 million preferential buyer’s credit for Unified Power System in Northern Tajikistan Project
description:
On July 20, 2011, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $26,463,789 USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan for the Unified Power System in Northern Tajikistan Project. This loan carried a 20-year maturity, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and a 2% interest rate (see "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). The entire project had a cost of $27,857,000 million USD. The Government of Tajikistan contributed $1.4 million USD to the project.

The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend — through subsidiary loan agreement No. 2011(19) TOTAL (170) – 030 BT, dated July 20, 2011 — to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik” at a 3% interest rate between July 20, 2011 and March 21, 2031. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy.

According to Asia-Plus, the loan was to be used to finance the construction of a new substation, Sughd-500, because the operating substation, Khujand-500, was not able to ensure regular electricity supplies to northern Tajikistan through the 550 kV South-North power transmission line (also Chinese-financed, project ID #39644 and #70910). Construction of the Sughd-500 substation was also intended to promote the implementation of the Central Asia South Asia Electricity Trade and Transmission Project (CASA 1000), which aimed to establish the necessary transmission and trading infrastructure and systems to enable a trade of surplus electricity from Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan to Afghanistan and Pakistan.

Chinese company TBEA was responsible for implementation. According to Asia-Plus, the project was to begin in October 2011 and be finished by the end of the year. However, the completed project was not accepted by Tajikistan until March 15, 2013 (approved by the government on October 4, 2013) (see "Постановление Правительства Республики Таджикистан от 4 октября 2013 года, № 444...").

This project involved the construction of a unified power system/single power grid through the construction of a new substation, Sughd-500, in the north of Tajikistan, near Jamoat Lolazor in Devashtich District. More locational details can be found at https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/project-documents/52122/52122-001-rp-en.pdf.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Проект создания единой электрической системы севера Республики Таджикистан. In English, it is also sometimes referred to as the Sughd 500/220 kV Substation/ single power grid for the north of Tajikistan. The AIMS project ID is TJK/112373. 

Additionally, in October 2011, Minister of Finance Safarali Najmiddinov said that the loan had an annual interest rate of 2.0 percent for 33 years with a seven-year grace period, as relayed by Asia-Plus. However, according to the IMF in 2018, this loan had a maturity of 20 years, a grace period from 5 to 7 years, and an annual interest rate of 2% interest rate. With all this in mind, the interest rate was coded as 2%, the maturity period was coded 20 years, and the grace period was coded as missing.
name: Ghonchi

title: Chinese Government provided a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#39989)
description:
As part of a set of high-level agreements signed at the June 15, 2006 meeting of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO), the Chinese Government offered a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (see the cited resource:"China signs Tajik loan deals"). This project was also supported by a $281.1 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan from the Export-Import Bank of China (see Project ID#39989).

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan had signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project.China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan tunnel. The project was wholly completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

The purpose of this project — also known as the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253-meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047-meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls .
