name: Jabor Rasulov

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 546 million government concessional loan for 500 kV Power Transmission Lines from Rogun Hydropower Plant to Dushanbe Project
description:
On September 1, 2017, the Export–Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed an RMB 546,032,200 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the 500 kV Power Transmission Lines from Rogun Hydropower Plant to Dushanbe Project. According to Avesta, the loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 25 years and 1.5% interest rate per annum. The loan agreement was ratified by the Tajik parliament in December 2017.

The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend -- through subsidiary loan agreement No. TAJ-2017-02 (BT-039), dated 29.12.2017 -- to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik” at a 3% interest rate between December 29, 2017 and August 21, 2042. As of OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy. 

The project involved the construction of two 500 kV, high voltage power transmission lines with a length of approximately 100 km from the Rogun hydropower plant in the town of Obi Garm (within the district of Rogun) to Dushanbe. The Dushanbe-Obigarm project was designed to improve reliability and quantity of supplied energy and reduce losses in the Rasht Valley of Tajikistan, where the Nurabad, Rasht, Tajikabad, Tavildara and Lakhsh districts are located. The Dushanbe-Obi Garm 500-kV power transmission line would also help increase the export of Tajik electricity to neighboring countries. The connection between the power grids of Districts of Republican Subordination and the southern power grid would also be improved. According to the 03/29/2019 Sputnik article, the transmission lines were to pass through the territories of Faizabad, Vahdat, Rudaki and Varzob. A substation, Dushanbe-500 substation, was also to be constructed as part of the project. 

Chinese company Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock Co., Ltd. (TBEA) was contracted to implement the project. In addition, according to PowerChina, Hubei Engineering Company Engineering Construction Company was involved in the project's implementation. Construction began on October 1, 2017. The project was completed and put into operation on November 16, 2018. 

STAFF_NOTE: This project is also known as the 500-kV transmission line Dushanbe-Obi Garm Project or the Project "Reconstruction and construction of 500 kV power transmission line in the republican subordination." The Russian project title is Линия электропередачи 500 кВ «Душанбе-Рогун» or  проекта реконструкции высоковольтной 500-киловольтной линии электропередачи районов республиканского подчинения. Note that Rogun Hydropower Plant is sometimes also referred to as Roghun Hydropower Plant. Additionally, some sources, including press releases from Tajik government ministries, denominated the loan amount in US dollars, as $79 million USD. However, under Eximbank's policy, the government concessional l loan was always denominated in Chinese Yuan.
name: Tadzhikistan Territories

title: China Eximbank provides $50.54 million preferential buyer’s credit for Third Stage (Chormagzak Tunnel) of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID #53750, #40063)
description:
On June 5, 2012, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed a loan agreement for the provision of $50.54 million USD for the Third Stage of the Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (see "'Eximbank" to Provide Over $ 50 million for Continuing Reconstruction of Dushanbe-Kulma Road'"). The loan had a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 9 years, and an interest rate of 2%. The Government of Tajikistan contributed $2.7 million USD to this project. The Eximbank loan was unanimously ratified by the Tajik Parliament in October 2012.

China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on October 15, 2010, and the project was completed on October 1, 2013. This project supported the construction of the 4.43 km Chormagzak Tunnel along the 147.64 km Dushanbe-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway (which is also known as the Tajikistan-China highway). More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Chormaghzak+Tunnel,+Tajikistan/@38.4771348,69.1814159,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x38b66e9dde37093f:0x45059c2b6cd21c12!8m2!3d38.4771306!4d69.1836046 and https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbekulma-road-dushanbe-dangara-section-phase-2/9d21c81e-6931-4df6-9dd4-650c86518ecb/.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chormagzak Tunnel is now known as the Khatlon Tunnel. This project is linked to the China Eximbank-financed First Stage and China Eximbank-financed Second Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (see Project ID#40063, #53750). China Eximbank reportedly provided $243.4 million of debt financing in total for all three stages of Phase 1. The Russian project title for Stage 3 of Phase 1 is Реабилитация третьего этапа фазы I автомобильной дороги «Душанбе-Кульма». The Chinese project title is 塔中公路一期(杜尚别—丹卡拉段)道路修复改造项目.

Additionally, the "Data Collection Survey On a Road Between Dushanbe and Kurgan-Tyube in the Republic of Tajikistan Final Report" from the Japan International Cooperation Agency states that China Eximbank provided a $64 million USD loan for this project, but most of other sources (including Tajikistan Ministry report and ADB investigation) indicate that $50.54 would be a more precise number.
name: Fayzobod

title: China Eximbank provides $49 million preferential buyer’s credit for First Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#53750, #40440)
description:
On August 18, 2009, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan and the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $49,000,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan for the First Stage of the Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project. The loan had a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 years, and an interest rate of 2%. 

The total project cost was $51,578,000, including a $2,578,000 contribution from the Government of Tajikistan. China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on August 30, 2009 after a grand commencement ceremony held on the same day and the project was completed (after passing final inspection) on October 30, 2013. 

This project supported the reconstruction of a 57.8 km road segment along the 147.64 km Dushanbe-Vahdat-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway (which is also known as the Tajikistan-China highway). It also involved the construction of new sections of road to bypass settlements and bridges. More detailed locational information can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbekulma-road-dushanbe-dangara-section-phase-2/9d21c81e-6931-4df6-9dd4-650c86518ecb/.

STAFF_NOTE: This project is linked to the China Eximbank-financed Second Stage and China Eximbank-financed Third Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (see Project ID#53750, #40440). China Eximbank reportedly provided $243.4 million of debt financing in total for all three stages of Phase 1. The Russian project title for Stage 1 of Phase 1 is Реконструкция 1-го этапа 1 фазы автодороги Душанбе-Кульма (Таджикистан - граница Китая) на участке «Душанбе-Дангара». The Chinese project title is 塔中公路一期(杜尚别—丹卡拉段)道路修复改造项目.
name: Fayzobod

title: China Eximbank provides $35 million loan for Regar Substation Reconstruction Project (Linked to projects #40481, #40479, #72802, #69997)
description:
On May 20, 2013, the Export-Import Bank of China provided a $35,043,319 USD loan to the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan for the Regar Substation Reconstruction Project . The loan carried a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period from 5 to 7 years, and an interest rate of 2%. The loan agreement was ratified by the Tajik parliament in June 2013. The total cost of the project was $36.9 million USD. The Government of Tajikistan contributed $1.8 million USD to the project.

The Government of Tajikistan used the proceeds from this PBC loan to on-lend — through subsidiary loan agreement Subsidiary Agreement No. TAJ-2013(22) TOTAL No.(266) BT-025, dated July 31, 2011 — to Open Joint Stock Holding Company (OHSHC) “Barqi Tojik” at a 6% interest rate between July 31, 2013 and November 21, 2033. OHSHC “Barqi Tojik” was a state-owned enterprise in Tajikistan responsible for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electricity and thermal energy. 

This project involved the reconstruction of Regar substation, which is located near the city of Tursunzoda about 50km west of Dushanbe. Construction began on November 22, 2012. The substation was put into operation on June 1, 2016. According to Avesta Information Agency, Chinese company Tebian Electric Apparatus Stock Co., Ltd. (TBEA) implemented this project.

This project was one of many signed during the same visit of the President of Tajikistan to China from May 19th 2013 to May 20th 2013. The other projects were: Loans totaling 33 million RMB to Amonatbonk (captured in project ID#69997), a 200 million RMB grant (captured in project ID#40481), a loan to Zijin Mining for investment into the Zeravshan Gold Mine (captured in project ID#40479), loans totaling 20 million USD to Amonatbonk (captured in project ID#72802), a technical cooperation agreement, a fruit inspection protocol, and a sports cooperation agreement. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Regar substation supplies electricity to the China Eximbank-financed Talco aluminium plant (captured in project ID#53755), according to Avesta. The Russian project title is Реконструкция подстанции Регар -500 кВт.
name: Tursunzoda

title: China grants construction materials and diesel generators for disaster response in Tajikistan
description: In 2009, China granted construction materials and diesel generators for disaster response in the areas in Tajikistan affected by torrential rains and mudflows. The total value of the aid was estimated at 30,000 USD by REACT (Rapid Emergency Assessment and Coordination Team). This aid was in response to the May 2009 floods in Tajikistan.
name: Tursunzoda

title: China Construction Bank provides $100 million loan to refinance 2012 CNMIM loan to China Nonferrous Gold Limited for Pakrut Gold Project (Linked to Project ID#54361, #70174, #70220, #70319, #70324, #70354, #70407, #70430)
description:
On May 24, 2012, China Nonferrous Metals International Mining Co. Ltd (CNMIM) provided a secured loan facility on commercial terms to Kryso Resources PLC — the mineral exploration and development company developing the Pakrut Gold Project — for $10 million and RMB 530 million to finance the development of the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70174 and #70319). Then, on June 19, 2014, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Macau) Limited provided a $120 million term loan facility to China Nonferrous Mining Group for the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70220). Then, on May 6, 2016, China Nonferrous Mining Group obtained a loan facility $120 million from CNMC International Capitals Company Limited (“CNMC”)— an associate of CNMIM — to refinance the loan facility that it contracted with Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Macau) Limited on June 19, 2014 for the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70324). On June 27, 2016 the China Nonferrous Mining Group obtained another loan, worth $19,114,809, from CNMIM for working capital purposes related to the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70354).

Then, on July 1, 2016, China Construction Bank Corporation Macau Branch (CCBC) provided a loan facility of $100 million to China Nonferrous Mining Group to refinance its 2012 loan agreement with CNMIM (see linked Projects IDs #70174 and #70319) and also for working capital purposes. The CCBC loan was for a maximum of 5 years (5-year maturity) and was repayable 60 months from the date of first drawdown. The annual interest rate was 3-month LIBOR plus a 2.1% margin (see "Interim Results" from September 30, 2016). The average 3-month LIBOR rate in July 2016 was 0.696%. Therefore, the interest rate was coded as 0.696+2.1=2.796%.

According to "CNG: China Nonferrous Gold Limited: Annual Report and Account" published on July 1, 2019, the loan was secured by Standby Letter(s) of Credit issued by China Construction Bank Corporation, Beijing Branch, and guaranteed by CNMC under the terms of the loan agreement, for an aggregate amount of not less than US$103,092,783.51, with validity of not less than 60 months in favor of CCB. The loan was fully drawn down in 2016. 

The loan was repayable in 8 installments commencing 18 months from the drawdown date. The repayment schedule was as follows, denominated in USD (taken from "CNG: China Nonferrous Gold Limited: Annual Report and Account" on Bloomberg):
- December 31, 2017 – $5,000,000 (payment made in January 2018)
- June 30, 2018 – $5,000,000
- December 31, 2018 – $5,000,000
- June 30, 2019 – $5,000,000
- December 31, 2019 – $5,000,000
- June 30, 2020 – $5,000,000
- December 31, 2020 – $5,000,000
- June 30, 2021 (or 14 working days prior to the expiry date of relevant Standby Letter(s) of Credit – whichever is earlier)

LLC Pakrut, a mine that is 100% owned by Kryso Resources Ltd, was first established in 2003 and it operates the Pakrut deposit located on the southern slope of the Gissar range, 107 km from the city of Dushanbe. The geological exploration at Pakrut deposit started in 2004. The pre-gold reserves at the deposit, approved by the State Reserves Committee (CRC) of the Republic of Tajikistan, were 28.1 tons. The reserves of Pakrut gold mine are currently estimated to be 100 tons. In November 2011, the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan issued a mining licence to LLC Pakrut. Construction started in September 2012. The project went into production on June 5, 2016. In February 2017, high levels of snowfall caused significant damage to the facilities and equipment, and interrupted the construction, which was restarted in the second half of 2017. All construction work was expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2018 and production was expected to be recommenced in April 2018.

This mining project is located in Vahdat District, Republic of Tajikistan, about 80 km northeast (“NE”) in a straight line (112 km by road) from Dushanbe, the country’s capital city. It sits on the southern slope of the Gissar range. More detailed locational information can be found at http://www.cnfgold.com/Managed/Resources/docs/Downloads/srk_report.pdf.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is "塔吉克斯坦帕克鲁特金矿."
name: Vahdat

title: China Eximbank provides $36.9 million preferential buyer’s credit for the Upgrade of the Vahdat-Yavan Section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube Railway Project (Linked to Project ID#40489)
description:
On November 7, 2014, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed two loan agreements with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Upgrade of the Vahdat-Yavan Section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube Railway Project: a RMB-denominated government concessional loan (GCL) provided on highly concessional terms (20 year maturity, 11 year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate) and a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan on highly concessional terms (2% interest, 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period), each with a bank service fee of 0.2% and a reservation fee of 0.2%).

On August 13, 2013, State Unitary Enterprise “Rohi Ohani Tojikiston” had signed a contract for the survey, design and construction of tunnels and bridges of the new Dushanbe-Kurgan-Tyube railway, Vahdat-Yavan section for $59,993,900 USD. The Government of Tajikistan approved this deal on August 28, 2013, and ordered the Ministry of Finance to attract a soft loan from China Eximbank. The total cost of the project was approximately $71.993 million USD. The loans from the Export-Import Bank of China were valued at $68,992,970 USD. Tajikistan contributed $2,999,700 USD through State Unitary Enterprise "Rohi Ohani Tojikiston” (see "Information on existing state investment projects" and "Строительство мостов и тоннелей на железной дороги Душанбе-Кургантюбе, участок Вахдат-Яван" from the Ministry of Transport of the Republic of Tajikistan).

The face value of the GCL loan was RMB 191.9 million. The face value of the PBC loan was $36.9 million USD (pg.5 of “Отчет о состоянии государственного долга на 2014 год”). These loans combined are roughly equal to the reported Eximbank contribution. The loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. Project ID#40489 records the GCL and Project ID#71443 records the PBC.

This project was to become the first railway project launched and completed under the framework of the "Silk Road Economic Belt" initiative, and was to become a hub of an international railway network connecting China, Tajikistan, Afghanistan, and Iran. China Railway 19th Bureau Group Co Ltd was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on May 15, 2015 and the project was completed on August 24, 2016.

This project involved the construction of construction of 5 bridges and 3 tunnels along the Vakhdat-Yavan section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube railway. Additional locational details can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/vahdat-yavan-railway-construction/bde10173-33b5-4431-9ad2-19468648bcbd/.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Строительство железной дороги Душанбе-Курган-тюбе, участок Вахдат- Яван. Yavan is also spelled Yovon. Vahdat is also spelled Vakhdat.
name: Vahdat

title: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Macau) provides $120 million loan for Pakrut Gold Project (Linked to Project ID#54361, #70174, #70319, #70324, #70354, #70367, #70407, #70430)
description:
In 2012, China Nonferrous Metals International Mining Co. Ltd (CNMIM) provided a secured loan facility on commercial terms to Kryso Resources PLC — the mineral exploration and development company developing the Pakrut Gold Project —  for $10 million and RMB 530 million to finance the development of the Pakrut Gold Project (see linked Project ID#70174 and #70319).

Then, on June 19, 2014, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (Macau) Limited provided a $120 million term loan facility to China Nonferrous Mining Group for the Pakrut Gold Project.
The loan was secured by standby letters of credit. The loans advanced under the facility could not exceed 95% of the value of the standby letters of credit. Standby letters of credit were issued on June 24, 2014 and June 18, 2015 in order to enable China Nonferrous Mining Group to drawdown $80 million and $40 million respectively under the facility. The principal loan repayments commenced on January 30, 2016. As of December 31, 2015, China Nonferrous Mining Group had fully drawn down the loan facility extended (see pg.29 of "Annual Report and Financial Statements for the Year Ended 31 December 2015"). The loan availability period ran from July 9, 2014 until June 19, 2015. If the facility was not fully drawn down within the loan availability period, the principal repayments were to be reduced in inverse order of the repayment schedule. In the event of default, ICBC had the right to demand full repayment of the outstanding loan and charge default interest at 3% over the contracted interest rate. The loan was secured by China Nonferrous. 

The interest rate on the loan was 2.90% per annum over the quarterly (3-month) LIBOR rate (average 3-month LIBOR rate in June 2014 was 0.231%). Therefore, the interest rate was coded as 2.90+.231=3.131%. The loan was repayable in USD. The principal loan repayment commenced on January 30, 2016 (see pg.29-30 of "Annual Report and Financial Statements for the Year Ended 31 December 2015").

The repayment schedule was as follows, denominated in USD (see pg.46 of "Annual Report and Financial Statements for the Year Ended 31 December 2015"):
- January 30, 2016 – $5,000,000
- July 30, 2016 – $10,000,000
- January 30, 2017 – $10,000,000
- July 30, 2017 – $15,000,000
- January 30, 2018 – $20,000,000
- July 30, 2018 – $20,000,000
- January 30, 2019 – $20,000,000
- June 8, 2019 – $20,000,000

LLC Pakrut, a mine that is 100% owned by Kryso Resources Ltd, operates the Pakrut deposit located on the southern slope of the Gissar range, 112 km from the city of Dushanbe (see "Final Results and Notice of AGM"). Relevant geological exploration at the Pakrut deposit began in 2004 (see pp.iii "Independent Technical Report of the Pakrut Gold Project in Vahdat Region, Republic of Tajikistan. 

According to the 2018 report published on Bloomberg, in November 2011, the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan issued a mining license to LLC Pakrut. According to SRK, at a gold cut-off of 1.0 g/t, the JORC Code compliant Proved Ore Reserves for Pakrut were estimated at 15,721 thousand tonnes (“kt”) averaging 3.1 g/t of gold. The JORC Code compliant Probable Ore Reserves were estimated at 2,787 kt averaging 2.5 g/t of gold. Construction started in September 2012. The project went into production on June 5, 2016. In February 2017, high levels of snowfall caused significant damage to the facilities and equipment, and interrupted the construction, which was restarted in the second half of 2017. All construction work was expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2018 and production was expected to be recommenced in April 2018.

This mining project is located in Vahdat District, Republic of Tajikistan, about 80 km northeast (“NE”) in a straight line (112 km by road) from Dushanbe, the country’s capital city. It sits on the southern slope of the Gissar range. More detailed locational information can be found at http://www.cnfgold.com/Managed/Resources/docs/Downloads/srk_report.pdf.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is "塔吉克斯坦帕克鲁特金矿."
name: Vahdat

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 191.9 million government concessional loan for the Upgrade of the Vahdat-Yavan Section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube Railway Project (Linked to Project ID#71443)

These loans combined are roughly equal to the reported Eximbank contribution. The loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. Project ID#40489 records the GCL and Project ID#71443 records the PBC. 

This project was to become the first railway project launched and completed under the framework of the "Silk Road Economic Belt" initiative, and was to become a hub of an international railway network connecting China, Tajikistan, Afghanistan, and Iran. China Railway 19th Bureau Group Co Ltd was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on May 15, 2015 and the project was completed on August 24, 2016. 

This project involved the construction of construction of 5 bridges and 3 tunnels along the Vakhdat-Yavan section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube railway. Additional locational details can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/vahdat-yavan-railway-construction/bde10173-33b5-4431-9ad2-19468648bcbd/.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Строительство железной дороги Душанбе-Курган-тюбе, участок Вахдат- Яван. Yavan is also spelled Yovon. Vahdat is also spelled Vakhdat.
name: Vahdat

title: CNMIM provides RMB 530 million loan for Pakrut Gold Project (Linked to Project ID#54361, #70174, #70220, #70324, #70354, #70367, #70407, #70430)
description:
On May 24, 2012, China Nonferrous Metals International Mining Co. Ltd (CNMIM) and Kryso Resources PLC signed a Shareholder Loan Agreement for a loan made on commercial terms to Kryso Resources PLC — the mineral exploration and development company developing the Pakrut Gold Project. 

The secured loan facility consisted of two tranches; a tranche for RMB 530 million and a tranche for $10 million USD. It was to be used exclusively for the design, construction, operation and administration of the Pakrut Gold Project, including operating costs, capital expenditure, and general working capital. The RMB tranche was disbursed by CNMIM entering into contracts with third parties on behalf of Kryso or LLC Pakrut as their agent and transferring amounts to the bank accounts of such parties. The term of the loan went from the date of the first advance until May 31, 2017. The annual fixed interest rate was 9% for both tranches and a management fee at 0.5% on the total amount of the loan was paid within 30 days of the first advance. Default interest of 13.5% per annum was payable on overdue amounts on the tranches. The Group was to repay all amounts of principal and interest in respect in USD at the fixed exchange rate of $1 USD to 6.30 RMB. The repayment dates were May 31, 2015, November 11, 2015, May 31, 2016, November 11, 2016, and May 31, 2017 for both tranches. November 30, 2014 was the end of the loan availability period. Kryso had drawn down RMB 384,802,696 (equivalent to $61,079,793 USD at the fixed repayment exchange rate) under the RMB tranche. Kryso pledged its 100% equity interest in LLC Pakrut to CNMIM as security for repayment of the loan (see pg.45-46 of "Annual Report and Financial Statements for the Year Ended 31 December 2015").

This project only captures the RMB tranche of the loan facility. For the USD tranche, please see Project ID #70174.

LLC Pakrut, a mine that is 100% owned by Kryso Resources Ltd, operates the Pakrut deposit located on the southern slope of the Gissar range, 112 km from the city of Dushanbe (see "Final Results and Notice of AGM"). Relevant geological exploration at the Pakrut deposit began in 2004 (see pp.iii "Independent Technical Report of the Pakrut Gold Project  in Vahdat Region, Republic of Tajikistan. According to the 2018 report published on Bloomberg, in November 2011, the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan issued a mining license to LLC Pakrut. 

According to SRK, at a gold cut-off of 1.0 g/t, the JORC Code compliant Proved Ore Reserves for Pakrut were estimated at 15,721 thousand tonnes (“kt”) averaging 3.1 g/t of gold. The JORC Code compliant Probable Ore Reserves were estimated at 2,787 kt averaging 2.5 g/t of gold. Construction started in September 2012. The project went into production on June 5, 2016. In February 2017, high levels of snowfall caused significant damage to the facilities and equipment, and interrupted the construction, which was restarted in the second half of 2017. All construction work was expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2018 and production was expected to be recommenced in April 2018. 

This mining project is located in Vahdat District, Republic of Tajikistan, about 80 km northeast (“NE”) in a straight line (112 km by road) from Dushanbe, the country’s capital city. It sits on the southern slope of the Gissar range. More detailed locational information can be found at http://www.cnfgold.com/Managed/Resources/docs/Downloads/srk_report.pdf.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is "塔吉克斯坦帕克鲁特金矿.”
name: Vahdat

title: China Eximbank provides $143.9 million preferential buyer’s credit for Second Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID #40063, #40440)
description:
On November 27, 2010, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed a $143,925,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement [China Eximbank PBC NO.2010 (025) Total No. (132)] for the Second Stage of the Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project. This loan carried an interest rate of 2%, a maturity of 20 years, and a grace period of 5 years. The total project cost was $151,500,000, including a contribution of $7,575,000 from the Government of Tajikistan. 

China Road & Bridge Corporation was awarded the implementation contract. The project is implemented in the design and construction contracting mode. The main construction content includes road reconstruction, municipal road engineering, tunnels and connecting lines, etc. The road repair project construction period is 24 months, and the tunnel and connection line construction period is 36 months. Construction began on October 15, 2010, and ths project was completed (after passing final inspection) on October 30, 2013. 

This project supported the reconstruction of a 50.5 km road segment along the 147.64 km Dushanbe-Vahdat-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway (which is also known as the Tajikistan-China highway). It also supported the construction of the 4.43 km Chormagzak Tunnel along the 147.64 km Dushanbe-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway. More detailed locational information can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbekulma-road-dushanbe-dangara-section-phase-2/9d21c81e-6931-4df6-9dd4-650c86518ecb/ at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Chormaghzak+Tunnel,+Tajikistan/@38.4771348,69.1814159,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x38b66e9dde37093f:0x45059c2b6cd21c12!8m2!3d38.4771306!4d69.1836046.” 

STAFF_NOTE: This project is linked to the China Eximbank-financed First Stage and China Eximbank-financed Third Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (see Project ID#40063, #40440). China Eximbank reportedly provided $243.4 million of debt financing in total for all three stages of Phase 1. The Russian project title for Stage 2 of Phase 1 is Реконструкция второго этапа Фаза I автомобильной дороги «Душанбе-Кульма» (Таджикистан – граница Китая) на участке «Душанбе - Дангара». The Chinese project title is 塔中公路一期(杜尚别—丹卡拉段)道路修复改造项目.
name: Vahdat

title: China Eximbank provides $50.54 million preferential buyer’s credit for Third Stage (Chormagzak Tunnel) of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID #53750, #40063)
description:
On June 5, 2012, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed a loan agreement for the provision of $50.54 million USD for the Third Stage of the Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (see "'Eximbank" to Provide Over $ 50 million for Continuing Reconstruction of Dushanbe-Kulma Road'"). The loan had a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 9 years, and an interest rate of 2%. The Government of Tajikistan contributed $2.7 million USD to this project. The Eximbank loan was unanimously ratified by the Tajik Parliament in October 2012.

China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on October 15, 2010, and the project was completed on October 1, 2013. This project supported the construction of the 4.43 km Chormagzak Tunnel along the 147.64 km Dushanbe-Dangara section of the Dushanbe-Kulma highway (which is also known as the Tajikistan-China highway). More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.google.com/maps/place/Chormaghzak+Tunnel,+Tajikistan/@38.4771348,69.1814159,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x38b66e9dde37093f:0x45059c2b6cd21c12!8m2!3d38.4771306!4d69.1836046 and https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbekulma-road-dushanbe-dangara-section-phase-2/9d21c81e-6931-4df6-9dd4-650c86518ecb/.

STAFF_NOTE: The Chormagzak Tunnel is now known as the Khatlon Tunnel. This project is linked to the China Eximbank-financed First Stage and China Eximbank-financed Second Stage of Phase 1 of the Dushanbe-Dangara Road Reconstruction Project (see Project ID#40063, #53750). China Eximbank reportedly provided $243.4 million of debt financing in total for all three stages of Phase 1. The Russian project title for Stage 3 of Phase 1 is Реабилитация третьего этапа фазы I автомобильной дороги «Душанбе-Кульма». The Chinese project title is 塔中公路一期(杜尚别—丹卡拉段)道路修复改造项目.

Additionally, the "Data Collection Survey On a Road Between Dushanbe and Kurgan-Tyube in the Republic of Tajikistan Final Report" from the Japan International Cooperation Agency states that China Eximbank provided a $64 million USD loan for this project, but most of other sources (including Tajikistan Ministry report and ADB investigation) indicate that $50.54 would be a more precise number.
name: Vahdat

title: Chinese Embassy Supports Guldasta Sewing Center in Varzob District
description: On December 10, 2014 the Chinese embassy in Tajikistan assisted in the opening of the 'Guldasta' sewing center in teh Varzob District, located 25 km north of Tajikistan's capital. Zhao Syanzhun, wife of the Chinese Ambassador participated in the opening ceremony along with the chairman of the Varzob district and a representative from the People's Democratic Party. The embassy donated 20 sewing machines, scissors sets, irons, and other necessary equipment. STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese embassy press release specified that this is the second sewing training center donated to Tajikistan. The project needs to be distinguished from the first center that was transferred in June 2014 (project 54043).
name: Varzob

title: Chinese Government provided a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#39989)
description:
As part of a set of high-level agreements signed at the June 15, 2006 meeting of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO), the Chinese Government offered a RMB 60 million grant for the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project (see the cited resource:"China signs Tajik loan deals"). This project was also supported by a $281.1 million USD preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan from the Export-Import Bank of China (see Project ID#39989).

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan had signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project.China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan tunnel. The project was wholly completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

The purpose of this project — also known as the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253-meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047-meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls . 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.
name: Varzob

title: China Eximbank provides $281.1 million preferential buyer’s credit for the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#40351)
description:
On June 15, 2006, at the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) summit, the Export-Import Bank of China and the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed a $281,105,000 preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement for the 1st Stage of the Dushanbe-Khujand-Chanak Road Construction Project. The PBC loan carried a maturity period of 20 years, a grace period of 5 to 7 years, and an interest rate of 2% (see loan details at "List of Chinese Government-Financed Projects in Tajikistan from the Ministry of Finance via the IMF May 2018"). 

The loan was set to disburse in 3 annual tranches. The loan disbursements were as follows (see pg.7 of "INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN Staff Report for the 2006 Article IV Consultation"):
- 2007: $112.4 million USD
- 2008: $112.4 million USD
- 2009: $56.2 million USD

The project had a total cost of $295.9 million USD. This project is linked to project ID#40351, a RMB 60 million grant offered by the Chinese Government. China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on July 11, 2006. The construction period was planned to be 38 months. The highway was commissioned in 2010, but work continued on the Shahristan  tunnel. The project was completed on October 27, 2012, with an opening ceremony for the Shahristan tunnel that was attended by President of Tajikistan Emomali Rahmon. 

Earlier, in March 2006, China and Tajikistan signed a Memorandum of Understanding that stated the terms of preferential credits issuance for promotion of economic and social development of SCO members. One of the financing projects identified was this road project. The purpose of the project — also known as the Tajikistan-Uzbekistan Highway Rehabilitation/Reconstruction Project — was to reconstruct the 354 km highway connecting Dushanbe with Khujand, the center of the northern province, and the town of Chanak on the border with Uzbekistan. The project also involved the construction of the 5253 meter Shahristan tunnel (at a cost of $88,424), the 1047 meter Dusti tunnel, the Maikhura tunnel, 39 big and small bridges, and 6 km of avalanche defenses. More detailed locational information is available at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/carec-dushanbe-chanak-highway-including-shahristan-and-dusty-tunnels-rehabilitation/d0fdfa30-2790-41ab-8462-fb056c335c52/.

The project reportedly reduced driving times from 12 hours to 4 hours and the Shahristan tunnel was reportedly the longest tunnel in Central Asia when it completed, according to China Global Television Network. To help repay the loan and cover the costs of maintaining the road, the Tajik Government made the highway a toll road in 2010 and allowed the private company Innovative Road Solutions to collected tolls. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is реабилитацию автомобильной дороги «Душанбе – Чанак». The Chinese project title is 塔乌（乌兹别克斯坦）公路.
name: Varzob

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 191.9 million government concessional loan for the Upgrade of the Vahdat-Yavan Section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube Railway Project (Linked to Project ID#71443)
description:
On November 7, 2014, the Ministry of Finance of the Republic of Tajikistan signed two loan agreements with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Upgrade of the Vahdat-Yavan Section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube Railway Project: a RMB-denominated government concessional loan (GCL) provided on highly concessional terms (20 year maturity, 11 year grace period, and 1.5% interest rate) and a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan on highly concessional terms (2% interest, 20 year maturity, 9 year grace period), each with a bank service fee of 0.2% and a reservation fee of 0.2%).

On August 13, 2013, State Unitary Enterprise “Rohi Ohani Tojikiston” had signed a contract for the survey, design and construction of tunnels and bridges of the new Dushanbe-Kurgan-Tyube railway, Vahdat-Yavan section for $59,993,900 USD. The Government of Tajikistan approved this deal on August 28, 2013, and ordered the Ministry of Finance to attract a soft loan from China Eximbank. The total cost of the project was approximately $71.993 million USD. The loans from the Export-Import Bank of China were valued at $68,992,970 USD. Tajikistan contributed $2,999,700 USD through State Unitary Enterprise "Rohi Ohani Tojikiston” (see "Information on existing state investment projects" and "Строительство мостов и тоннелей на железной дороги Душанбе-Кургантюбе, участок Вахдат-Яван" from the Ministry of Transport of the Republic of Tajikistan).

The face value of the GCL loan was RMB 191.9 million. The face value of the PBC loan was $36.9 million USD (pg.5 of “Отчет о состоянии государственного долга на 2014 год”). These loans combined are roughly equal to the reported Eximbank contribution. The loans were ratified by the Tajik Parliament on January 14, 2015. Project ID#40489 records the GCL and Project ID#71443 records the PBC. 

This project was to become the first railway project launched and completed under the framework of the "Silk Road Economic Belt" initiative, and was to become a hub of an international railway network connecting China, Tajikistan, Afghanistan, and Iran. China Railway 19th Bureau Group Co Ltd was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction began on May 15, 2015 and the project was completed on August 24, 2016. 

This project involved the construction of construction of 5 bridges and 3 tunnels along the Vakhdat-Yavan section of the Dushanbe-Kurgantube railway. Additional locational details can be found at https://reconnectingasia.csis.org/database/projects/vahdat-yavan-railway-construction/bde10173-33b5-4431-9ad2-19468648bcbd/.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Строительство железной дороги Душанбе-Курган-тюбе, участок Вахдат- Яван. Yavan is also spelled Yovon. Vahdat is also spelled Vakhdat.
name: Rudaki

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 10 million grant to finance the training of Turkmen specialists in China (Linked to project ID#69355)
description:
In March 2005, the governments of China and Turkmenistan signed an intergovernmental agreement in which the Government of China agreed to provide a RMB 10 million grant to the Government of Turkmenistan to finance the training of Turkmen technicians in China. It was reported that the training grants were so the Turkmen specialists could use Chinese equipment.

The project was linked to a grant project ID#69355 for modernization of Turkmenistan's telecommunications network, which is also signed during an official visit of Zhang Zhigang, China‚Äôs vice minister for commerce (MOFCOM), to the republic, the Ashgabat correspondent of Turkmenistan in 2005.
name: Turkmenistan

title: China Donated Inspection System to Turkmenistan
description: On June 22, China agreed to provide a mobile inspection system to the Turkmenistan government. The chairman of the State Customs Service of Turkmenistan, [Myratberdi] Annalyyew, from the Turkmen side, and Vice President of the Nuktek Company, Ms Wen Hwan, from the Chinese side, signed the contract. The mobile inspection system was handed over on April 3, 2006. STAFF_ NOTE: Neither resource indicates any terms associated with the mobile inspection system, so it is coded as a grant.
name: Turkmenistan

title: CNPC Amu Darya provides training for 10 Turkmen employees to learn Chinese and professional skills at China University of Petroleum - Beijing
description: In 2013, Amu Darya River Gas Company of China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) provided the opportunity for ten of its Turkmen employees to study at China University of Petroleum - Beijing. There, they took a 185-day training course on the Chinese language and on professional skills. STAFF_NOTE: This appears to be distinct from the scholarships CNPC Amu Darya provides for high school graduates (see linked project ID#70737). Additionally, 'provided an opportunity' was assumed to imply a flow.
name: Turkmenistan

title: China granted 80 refrigerated car to Turkmenistan
description: In February 2017, the 80 refrigerated cars were given to Turkmenistan by Xi Jinpin, the Chairman of PRC, as a gift. The refrigerated cars were ordered by Ministry of Commerce of PRC, produced by Yutong Heavy Industries, and shipped by General Logistics Company.
name: Turkmenistan

title: China Exim Bank loans 400 million RMB to Turkmenneft for the supply of oil, gas equipment, and tubular goods
description: The China Exim Bank implemented a 400 million RMB credit to supply Turkmenneft for the supply of oil, gas equipment, and tubular goods. As of 2011, the project was still being implemented. STAFF_NOTE: The original commitment year of the loan is unclear, but 2011 is the first found source that lists the project.
name: Turkmenistan

title: China EXIM Bank Loans 200 million yuan to Turkmengaz for supply of oil and gas equipment and pipe products
description: In 2011, China's EXIM Bank continued to implement a loan of 200 million yuan to Turkmengaz. The commitment year of this loan is unclear. Turkmengaz will use the funds to purchase oil, gas, and pipeline equipment for their operations. STAFF_NOTE: Use the most current Turkmenistan's country report in the resources - previous researcher used the 2011 annual report, which mistakenly reported the amount as 200 billion yuan.
name: Turkmenistan

title: China provides an RMB 10 million grant for the transformation of the sericulture farms in Turkmenistan
description:
In 1999 and 2000, Chinese government provided an RMB 10 million free assistance to the Turkmenistan Ministry of Textile Industry for the comprehensively transformation of the sericulture farms in Turkmenistan. Jiangsu International Economic and Technical Cooperation Corporation (also known as China Jiangsu International) provided sericulture equipment and materials. After the transformation, the annual output of the silkworm breeding farm in Turkmenistan reached 150,000 boxes annually.

name: Turkmenistan

title: China grants Turkmenistan 15 million RMB for mechanical plant (Linked to project #40169)
description: On Dec. 26, 2003, State officials of China and Turkmenistan signed an agreement for a grant of 15 million RMB (1.8 million USD) and an interest-free credit of 30 million USD (see project #40169). The grant was to be used by Turkmengaz to purchase equipment and spare parts for its repair mechanical plant. Current project status is unknown. More info can be found at https://global-factiva-com.proxy.wm.edu/redir/default.aspx?P=sa&an=TRENDE0020150507eb57001e3&cat=a&ep=ASE
name: Turkmenistan

title: CNPC Amu Darya provides scholarships for 133 Turkmen students to study at China University of Petroleum since 2008
description: Since 2008, Amu Darya River Gas Company of China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) has sponsored the higher education of 133 Turkmen high school students at the China University of Petroleum - Beijing (CUPB). In their first year of study abroad, the students study Chinese. After they pass the necessary examinations, the students then decide to study either petroleum engineering, chemical technology, geology, or another major. After four years of coursework, they receive their bachelor's degree. 76 of the students who received the scholarship went to work in the oil and gas industry after their studies, while 57 students were studying at China University of Petroleum in July 2019. In 2019, ten Turkmen high school graduates received the scholarship. STAFF_NOTE: 2008 was coded as the commitment year because these scholarships began that year; however, 'Year uncertain' box was checked because it is not confirmed that CNPC committed to these scholarships in that. Amu Darya River Gas Company of China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC), which has many alternative names, appears to be a wholly-owned subsidiary of CNPC.
name: Turkmenistan

title: Chinese Government provides interest-free loan to Turkmenistan for purchase of Chinese drilling rigs for natural gas exploration and development
description: During the visit of President of Turkmenistan Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedow to China on July 17 and 18, 2007, the Chinese Government provided Turkmenistan with an interest-free loan for the purchase of Chinese drillings rigs. These rigs were intended to be used for the exploration and development of natural gas fields. STAFF_NOTE: Further loan details are unknown.
name: Turkmenistan

title: China Exim Bank 450 Million RMB loan to supply telecommunication equipment to Ministry of Communication (linked to #40214)
description: China Eximbank is providing 450 million RMB for the supply of telecommunications equipment to the Turkmenistan Ministry of Communication. As of 2012, the project was still being implemented, according to a Turkmenistan State Bank Annual Report. This project is part of a committed line of credit worth 650 million RMB to Turkmenistan for communications in 2005 (#40214) along with 200 million RMB export credits for telecommunications in 2006 (#40332). STAFF_NOTE: The original commitment date is unclear. The umbrella project of 650 million RMB was committed in 2005 and the 200 million RMB project was committed in 2006. The year is marked as 2006 to better reflect the transaction amount.
name: Turkmenistan

title: China provides a 100 million CNY loan to finance the purchase of Chinese drilling and hoist equipment
description: On July 5-7, 2000, during the visit of Chinese President Jiang Zemin to Turkmenistan, he held talks with Turkmenistan President Niyazov and signed the China-Turkmenistan Joint Declaration. Chinese Minister of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Shi Guangsheng signed a framework agreement with Turkmenistan's Deputy Prime Minister Kandymov on China's provision of a 100 million yuan concessional loan to Turkmenistan. In 2000, China loaned 100 million RMB to Turkmenistan to finance the purchase of Chinese drilling and hoist equipment for the Turkmenneft and Turkmengas, which are state-owned enterprises.
name: Turkmenistan

title: China Development Bank provides RMB 300 million interest-free loan for unspecified purposes
description: Between 2002 and 2013, the State Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of Turkmenistan reported that it received loans from the China Development Bank each year. The first loan may have been issued on July 2, 2002; however, subsequent reports identified an amended issue date of July 16, 2005. This loan carried an interest rate of 0% and a maturity date of December 31, 2024. It is not known how the proceeds of this loan were used. The loan was disbursed between 2012 and 2016 according to the following schedule: 44,825 Thousand TMT in 2012, 43,673 Thousand TMT in 2013, 40,445 Thousand TMT in 2015, 42,065 Thousand TMT in 2015, and 14,108 Thousand TMT in 2016. These disbursements sum to approximately RMB 300 million. Staff Note: The commitment year is currently based on the July 16, 2005 loan issue date.
name: Turkmenistan

title: China loans interest-free 30 million RMB for mechanical plant (Linked to project ID#40168)
description: On Dec. 26, 2003, State officials of China and Turkmenistan signed an agreement for an interest free loan of 30 million RMB ($3.6 million USD) and a grant of 15 million RMB (see project #40168). The loan has a maturity of 20 years. The funding was to be used by Turkmengaz to purchase equipment and spare parts for its repair mechanical plant. Current project status is unknown.
name: Turkmenistan

title: China Eximbank provides loan for unspecified purposes
description: On August 16, 2001, the Government of Turkmenistan and China Eximbank signed a loan agreement for unspecified purposes. The loan's maturity date is identified as March 21, 2030 and the interest rate is 2.5%. Disbursements were made through this loan according to the following schedule: 554,854,000 in 2010 TMT, 862,389,000 TMT in 2011, 943,210,000 TMT in 2012, 912,483,000 TMT in 2013, 849,387,000 TMT in 2014, 961,718,000 TMT in 2015, and 845,805,000 TMT in 2016. Staff Note: We estimate the face value of the loan (5,929,846,000 TMT) based on the six loan disbursements that were made between 2010 and 2016. One official source indicates that the China Eximbank loan was issued on December 17, 2001, which suggests that the August 16, 2001 loan agreement may have been revised. Some official sources also suggest that the loan's maturity date was March 21, 2032, which again suggests a revision to the August 16, 2001 loan agreement.
name: Turkmenistan

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 328.45 million for the acquisiton of 113 railway passenger cars
description:
In 2007, China Eximbank and the Government of Turkmenistan signed an RMB 328.45 million export buyer's credit loan for the purchase of 113 railway passenger cars. Loan details are unknown.

The proceeds from this loan were used to support a January 27, 2007 contract between CITIC Construction and the Turkmenistan's Ministry of Railways. The first batch of 104 passenger cars was successfully delivered in June 2008.

title: Chinese Government provides an RMB 50 million interest-free loan in ETCA to Turkmenistan for supply and installment of equipment in the construction of a velvet factory (Linked to Project ID#69310)
description:
In 2006, the Chinese Government agreed to issue an RMB 50 million interest-free loan, captured by this project, and a RMB 40 million grant, captures in project ID#69310, to Turkmenistan for the supply and installation of technological equipment and accessories by Shanxi Zhongxu International Trade Industrial Co., Ltd (Chinese title is " Â±±Ë•ø‰∏≠Êó≠") for a velvet factory under construction in the Ruhabat District. The agreement was made in accordance with a long-term Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) between the Turkmen and Chinese government. 

The facility was planned to be commissioned in October 2007, and was expected to have a capacity of 1 million meters of velvet annually. The project was completed on October 22, 2008 in a ceremony attended by President of Turkmenistan Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedov. The factory provided employment for 550 people, and its velvet capacity was expected to meet domestic and foreign demand. The total cost of the project was 28.75 million USD. In addition to China's contributions, the oil and gas industry of Turkmenistan provided $12.6 million USD.

title: Chinese Government provides an interest-free loan to Turkmenistan for the Turkmenistan Silk Production Complex (Linked to Project ID#73037)
description:
On December 22, 2001, the Chinese and Turkmen governments signed an exchange of letters for China to provide interest-free loans and free assistance to Turkmenistan. Then, in 2002, the Chinese Government provided an interest-free loan (captured by this project) and grant (captured by linked project ID#73037) to reconstruct the Turkmenistan Silk Production Complex in T√ºrkmenabat. The T√ºrkmenabat factory, built during the Soviet era, featured outdated technology, an incomplete production, and a low production level before the implementation of this project. Shanxi Zhongxu International Trade Industrial Co., Ltd. implemented this project. The factory, a joint venture, began production on October 24, 2003.

title: Chinese Government provides a 2 million USD interest-free loan to Turkmenistan for reconstruction of Ashgabat Silk Factory
description:
The Chinese Government provided a 2 million USD interest-free loan for the reconstruction of Ashgabat Silk Factory, the oldest silk production enterprise in Turkmenistan (also known as the Ashkhabad Filature). The loan was provided in 2002, 2003, or 2004. The factory, built during Soviet rule, had outdated technology, incomplete production processes, and a low production level before the project began. Shanxi Zhongxu International Trade Industrial Co., Ltd. implemented the project. The project was completed in a ceremony attended by President of Turkmenistan Saparmurat Niyazov and Ambassador Lu Guicheng on February 12, 2004.

title: China Eximbank provides a 60.6 million USD loan for construction of Ashgabat Glass Factory (Linked to Project ID#40330, #69497)
description:
On August 22, 2006, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a $300 million USD preferential export buyer's credit framework agreement with the Government of Turkmenistan (see umbrella project ID#40330). The loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an annual interest rate of 3.0%.

On January 30, 2007, China National Machinery Industry Corporation, Capital-Longqji Sci-Tech Co., Ltd, signed a commercial contract with the Government of Turkmenistan for the construction and renovation of the Ashgabat Glass Factory under the USD 300 million preferential export buyer‚Äôs credit framework.

Then, on November 3-4, 2007, China and Turkmenistan signed for two subsidiary loans with the same terms as the framework agreement: a loan of 60,642,000 USD was allocated for the construction of the Ashgabat Glass Factory, a glass-manufacturing plant (captured by this project) and a loan of 239,358,000 USD for the construction of new facilities and reconstruction of MaryAzot Production Association (captured in project ID#69497). To secure these loans, the Central Bank of Turkmenistan agreed to deposit 50 million USD from the State Fund for Development of the Oil and Gas Industry and Mineral Resources of Turkmenistan.

The Ashgabat Glass Factory was located in the northern part of Ashgabat. It was expected to become the largest plant in the region when completed, and was to be fitted with modern equipment and mainly use locally produced raw materials. Additionally, it was expected to produce 5.8 million square meters of glass (4 mm thick), 85 million units of various glass containers, nd 300,000 square meters of double-glazing units, including toned glass units, annually. A silica sand enrichment plant capable of producing 100,000 tons annually was also included in the project. China National Machinery Industry Corporation (Sinomach) and Capital-Lonqji Sci-Tech Co., Ltd were contracted to implement the project. The plant was to be commissioned in February 2009. The entire project was reported to cost $67.38 million USD, so there were likely non-Eximbank financiers. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese title of the project is ÂúüÂ∫ìÊõºÊñØÂù¶ÁéªÁíÉÂéÇÂª∫ËÆæÈ°πÁõÆ.
name: Aşgabat

title: Chinese Government provides an RMB 100 million grant for modernization of Turkmenistan's telecommunications network (Linked to project ID#73056)
description:
In March 2005, an RMB 100 million contract was signed between Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. and the Turkmen Ministry of Telecommunications for the supply and deliver of equipment for the modernization of Turkmenistan‚Äôs telecommunication network. This contracted included the provision of digital switching equipment with a total capacity to 140,312 lines. 

According to the Turkmen Ministry of Communications, the Chinese Government financed this a state-of-the-art digital telephone station, ETS-460D, was installed in Ashgabat by Huawei and Turkmen specialists in February 2005. This station provided cellular radio-telephone services in CDMA.

The project was linked to a grant project ID#73056 for the training of Turkmen specialists in China, which is also signed during an official visit of Zhang Zhigang, China‚Äôs vice minister for commerce (MOFCOM), to the republic, the Ashgabat correspondent of Turkmenistan in 2005.

STAFF-NOTE: The Atlantic article states that financing for the CDMA grid was provided "by grants and interest-free loans", while other official sources (reported by media sources) said that the project was financed through a grant. The later was chosen. "Year uncertain" box was checked because it is not clear year this grant was committed to.

title: Chinese Government provides a grant to Turkmenistan for reconstruction of silkworm factory in Mary (Linked to Project ID#69430)
description:
In 2002, the Chinese Government provided an interest-free loan, which is captured by linked project ID#69430, and a grant , which is captured by this project, to allow Turkmenistan to technically transform the Mary silkworm breeding farm from 2002 to 2004. name: Mary

title: China Development Bank provides $3 billion loan for Galkynysh (South Yolotan‚ÄìOsman) Gas Field Phase I Project (Linked to Project ID#41905 and #43168)
description:
On June 25, 2009, China Development Bank signed a $3 billion loan agreement with Turkmengaz (the national natural gas company of Turkmenistan) for Phase 1 of the Galkynysh Gas Field Project (also known as South Yolotan‚ÄìOsman Field Project). The loan is secured by natural gas exports to China.

This loan was given to help develop the Galkynysh Gas Field (also known as South Yolotan‚ÄìOsman Field) while Turkmenistan will supply China with up to 40 billion cubic meters/year of gas for 30 years. They include a supplementary agreement covering CNPC's exploration and production activities at Bagitiyarlik, where the company has a license to produce up to 30 Bcm/year, and a separate contract under which state-owned Turkmengaz will deliver 10 Bcm/year to CNPC. The fact that Turkmengaz and CNPC signed a contract for the delivery of an additional 10 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year at the same time that the loan agreement was finalized suggests that Turkmengaz will use the revenue it earns from this supply contract for natural gas as collateral for the loan.  Few other details about the terms of the loan, including the price at which the natural gas is sold to CNPC, are publicly available.

The first phase of the project began on February 28, 2011 and it was completed on September 4, 2013.   Then, in April 2013, China signed an additional $4.1 billion loan agreement with the Government of Turkmenistan for the second phase of the Galkynysh Gas Field Project. The loan will be disbursed over 3 years, and in return Turkmenistan will reportedly supply natural gas to China for 10 years (see project ID #41905).

Staff Note: The Phase 1 of the Galkynysh Gas Field project is part of the umbrella project captured in project #43168.
name: Mary

title: China Development Bank provides $4.1 billion loan Galkynysh Gas Field Phase II Project (Linked to Project ID#40393 and #43168)
description:
In April 2011, China Development Bank signed an loan-for-gas framework agreement with Turkmengaz (the national natural gas company of Turkmenistan) for Phase 2 of the Galkynysh Gas Field Project (also known as South Yolotan‚ÄìOsman Field Project or the Ioujno-Elotenshoie Gas Field Project).

Then, in September 2013, China Development Bank and Turkmengaz signed a $4.1 billion loan agreement for this project. The CDB loan is reportedly secured by natural gas exports to China. Turkmengaz will use the revenue it earns from a supply contract for natural gas as collateral for the loan. The loan will be disbursed over 3 years, and in return Turkmengaz will reportedly supply natural gas to China for 10 years.

CNPC is the contractor responsible for project implementation. The purpose of phase II of this project was to build facilities at the Galkynysh Gas Field that will process 30 billion cubic meters (bcm) per year. The project entered implementation on May 8, 2014.

Staff Note: This project is part of the umbrella project captured in project #43168 and it is considered to be part of the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). Phase I of the Galkynysh Gas Field is captured in #40393.
name: Mary

title: China Eximbank provides a 239.3 million USD loan for reconstruction of MaryAzot Production Association plant (Linked to Project ID#69498, #40330)
description:
On August 22, 2006, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a 300 million USD preferential export buyer's credit framework agreement with the Government of Turkmenistan, which is captured in project ID#40330). The loan carried the following terms: a maturity period of 20 years and an annual interest rate of 3.0%.

On January 27, 2007, CITIC International Cooperation Corporation and Turkey National Fertilizer Co., Ltd. signed the contract for the construction and renovation of the MaryAzot Production Association plant under the 3 billion U.S. dollars referential export buyer's credit framework.

Then, on November 3-4, 2007, China and Turkmenistan signed for two subsidiary loans with the same terms as the framework agreement: a loan of 60,642,000 USD was allocated for the construction of the Ashgabat Glass Factory, a glass-manufacturing plant (captured by linked project ID#69498) and a loan of 239,358,000 USD for the construction of new facilities and reconstruction of MaryAzot Production Association (captured by this project). To secure these loans, the Central Bank of Turkmenistan agreed to deposit $50 million USD from the State Fund for Development of the Oil and Gas Industry and Mineral Resources of Turkmenistan.

The project consisted of a reconstruction of the MaryAzot Production Association and the construction of a carbamide plant with a planned capacity of 400,000 tons in the town of Mary. China Eximbank's loan constituted 90% of the financing necessary for the 266 million USD reconstruction project, while Turkmendokun joint-stock company covered the remaining 10%. CITIC International was responsible for implementing the project.
