title: Confucius Institute Donated Language Lab to the Tashkent State Institute of Oriental Studies
description: On March 29, 2016, Confucius Institute donated the language lab to the Tashkent State Institute of Oriental Studies. Ambassador Sun and President Mannarov jointly cut the ribbon for the voice lab. The lab contains 36 teaching equipment.
name: Tashkent City

title: China provides a $300,000 USD grant for the purchase of new computing equipment for several Uzbek ministries (linked to projects #71501, #72568, #72567, #72571, #72570, and #72564)
description: In 2014, China committed to a US$300,000 grant to Uzbekistan for the purchase of new specialized computing equipment for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Public Education, and the Ministry of Higher and Secondary Specialized Education. The purchase came with the goal to improve the material and technical base of these ministries. The acquisition was part of a push by Uzbekistan to attract grant aid for its education system. It was reported that Uzbekistan attracted $225.6 million of grant aid for this purpose, some of which was provided by the People's Republic of China. As such, this project is linked to several other Chinese donations to the education sector during this timeframe: #71501 for the allocation of multimedia packages to classrooms grades 1st-4th #72568 for the purchase of 740 pcs of computer equipment for special needs students #72567 for the purchase of new equipment for the Center for the Development of Multimedia General Education Programs (CDMEP) #72570 for the equipping of children's centers 'Barkamol Avlod' with 434 sets of computer equipment #72571 for the purchase of new stage equipment for the Republican Center for Children's Artistic Creativity #72564 for the allocation of multimedia packages to classrooms grades 5th-9th
name: Tashkent City

title: Shanghai University completes Institute of Public Diplomacy research center at Tashkent University
description: Universities in Uzbekistan further pursue their curriculum on both Chinese language and culture. Uzbekistan will hire more trained teachers from China, and Shanghai University also opened up more opportunities in their exchange programs.
name: Tashkent City

title: China Eximbank provides $26.3 million loan for 220kv and 110kv Tashkent External Power Supply Facilities Project
description:
In 2009, China Eximbank loaned $26,354,900 USD to Uzbekistan for the 220kv and 110kv Tashkent External Power Supply Facilities Project. This loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, 2% interest rate, 0.3% commitment fee, 0.3% management fee.

The project involved the construction of a 220 kV transmitting station “Keles” with high-voltage line of 220 kV, a “Navoi” transmission substation of 110 kV, and a “Sayilgoh” transmission station of 110 kV with cable line of 110 kV. It entered implementation on September 4, 2009. 

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 建设塔什干外部供电设施.
name: Tashkent City

title: Chinese Embassy in Uzbekistan Donated Computer Equipment to Uzbekistan's University of World Economy and Diplomacy
description: On May 17, 2016, Ambassador Sun Lijie attended the Chinese Embassy in Uzbekistan to donate computer equipment to the Uzbekistan's University of World Economy and Diplomacy. Approximately 100 people attended the ceremony, including Jumanov, the president of Uzbekistan's University of World Economy and Diplomacy, directors, professors, and student representatives of the University. The transaction value of this donation is unknown.
name: Tashkent City

title: China grants 5 seismological stations worth 300K USD
description: In 2003, China Seismological Bureau gave 5 seismological stations that worth 300,000 dollars to the Uzbek Academy of Sciences. This aid is based on an agreement signed between these two parties in 2001. China also sent specialists to provide the assistance with setting up and using the equipment. Four of these stations were installed in Tashkent, and one was installed in central Uzbekistan. This donation aims to modernize Uzbekistan's capacity to register and study earthquakes.
name: Tashkent City

title: China Eximbank provides $60.5 million loan to Uzbekistan Railways in 2017 for Tashkent City Subway Project (Yunusabad line)
description:
In 2017, China Eximbank provided $60.5 million loan to Uzbekistan Railways for the Tashkent City Subway Project (Yunusabad line). This loan carries the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and 2% interest rate. 

On May 19, 2017, the project for the construction of an electrified high-speed ring railway in Tashkent was approved by the President of Uzbekistan. The construction period, taking into account the preparatory period, is four years (2017-2021). The preliminary cost of the project is US$422.3 million. The ring line of the metro will pass through the territory of Yashnabad, Yakkasaray, Uchtepinsky, Shaikhantakhur, Almazar, Yunusabad, Chilanzar and Sergeli districts. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project name I s Строительство кольцевой надземной линии метрополитена в городе Ташкенте. The Chinese project title is 尤努萨巴特区地铁支线建设项目.
name: Tashkent City

title: China opens Confucius Institute in Tashkent
description:
On 2005/5/7, China opened the first Confucius Institute in Tashkent, Uzbekistan.The Confucius Institute in Tashkent is not only the first Confucius Institute in Uzbekistan, but also the first in Central Asia. It was formed according to the agreement between the Ministry of higher and secondary specialized education of the Republic of Uzbekistan and Ministry of education of People’s Republic of China.

Nowadays at the institute work 15 teachers of Chinese language, 7 of them are volunteers from China and 8 of them are the teachers of Tashkent State University of Oriental Studies. There are more than 550 students’ studies at Uzbek-Chinese Confucius Institutes.
name: Tashkent City

title: Chinese Government grants $2.2 million for the provision of high-tech medical equipment
description:
In 2014, the Chinese Government agreed to grant $2.2 million USD for the provision of high-tech medical equipment to an emergency hospital in Tashkent. 

The grant is under a project for equipping the Clinical Emergency Hospital in Tashkent. The Uzbek Ministry of Health was responsible for the project. The government of Uzbekistan undertook the financing of the construction and repair works for the project.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Оснащение Клинической больницы скорой медицинской помощи г. Ташкента.
name: Tashkent City

title: China aids in the construction of the Central Asian Center of Drug Discovery and Development Center
description: On November 23, 2018, the inauguration ceremony of the Central Asian Drug Research and Development Center of the Chinese Academy of Sciences was held in Tashkent, the capital of Uzbekistan. The research focuses on the R&D of natural product drugs with regional characteristics of Central Asia. The project is financed by the Chinese government. The Central Asia Drug Research and Development Center is an important project of the Chinese Academy of Sciences' 'Science and Education Cooperation Expansion Project for Developing Countries' in Central Asia and is one of the nine overseas scientific and educational institutions built by the Chinese Academy of Sciences. The projects constructed under the Central Asia Drug Research and Development Center in 2017 include: 1) Natural medicine extraction pilot technology platform: The repair work for the 3,500 square meter workshop has been completed, and the equipment installation is in progress. The trial operation was expected by June 2017; the purchased RMB 5 million domestic extraction equipment was shipped to Tashkent. 2) Achievement transformation technology platform: Funded by Xinjiang Institute of Physics and Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 7,450 square meters of land was purchased in Tashkent, and projects including oral preparation GMP workshops, comprehensive laboratory buildings and expert apartments are under construction. 3) International Joint Laboratory: Two jointly funded laboratories with a total area of 400 square meters have been established in cooperation with the Uzbekistan Academy of Sciences; more than RMB 2 million of equipment has been purchased to initially set up the separation and analysis of chemical components, biomacromolecule preparation and biological activity of Central Asian characteristic medicinal materials Evaluation platform.
name: Tashkent City

title: China to expand Tashkent Confucius Institutes Uzbekistan
description:
15 July 2015 <uz.chineseembassy.org>

The Confucius Institute at Tashkent State University will increase the number of Chinese teachers. Prospects of development of cooperation between China and Uzbekistan in the sphere of higher education were discussed on July 8 in the Ministry of Higher and Secondary Special Education at a meeting with Chinese Ambassador Sun Lizi. As reported by "Gazete.uz" in the ministry, the meeting was attended by the Minister of Higher and Secondary Special Education Alisher Vakhabov, rector of the Tashkent State Institute of Oriental Abdulrahim Mannonov and Rector of the Uzbek State University of World Languages Shukhrat Kayumov. During the discussion of activities of the Institute named after Confucius at the Tashkent State Institute of Oriental Studies and Samarkand State Institute of Foreign Languages ​was agreed to increase the number of Chinese language teachers in the Confucius Institute at Tashkent State University.
This project is part fo the SREB plan

May be linked to project #53997 and #53998 where China​ pledges to modernize​ Soviet-era​ railway and provide 300 scholarships to Uzbekistan students, respectively.
name: Tashkent City

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project name I s Строительство кольцевой надземной линии метрополитена в городе Ташкенте. The Chinese project title is 尤努萨巴特区地铁支线建设项目.
name: Tashkent City

title: China Eximbank provides $42.17 million loan for Electric Locomotive Acquisition Project (linked to #40070)
description:
In 2012, China Eximbank agreed to loan $42,170,520.21 in export buyer's credits to National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Electric Locomotive Acquisition Project. The proceeds from this loan were used to support a $47.3 million contract (that was finalized in December 2011) between Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC and a consortium consisting of China National Technical Import & Export Corporation (CNTIC) and CNR Dalian Locomotive and Rolling Stock Co. Ltd (CNR DLRC) for the purchase of 11 electric freight locomotives. The China Eximbank loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, interest rate of 2.25%, commitment fee of 0.3%, and management fee of 0.3%. The Government of Uzbekistan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan.

On February 11, 2014, CNTIC and CNR DLRC delivered the 11 electric freight locomotives to Uzbekiston Temir Yollari State Joint-Stock Railway Company (Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC). The locomotives were customized for use around Uzbekistan's capital of Tashkent (and on the Marakand-Qarshi-Termez railway line), where temperatures can drop to minus 20 degrees Celsius in winter. The cars can withstand temperatures as low as minus 30 degrees Celsius. They are produced in line with the Russian gauge of 1,520 mm, featuring high tractive power and environmentally friendly operation with a design speed of 120 km per hour.

This is the second locomotive acquisition project in Uzbekistan. The first project is captured in #40070.

Staff_Note: The Russian name of this project is "Обновление парка локомотивов ГАЖК "Узбекистон темир йуллари”. There are some sources that suggest the face value of the loan amount may have been revised upward from $42.17 to $42.75 million. We use the more conservative estimate for the time being.
name: Tashkent City

title: Chinese Government grants $4.7 million for the provision of medical equipment to 5 regional rehabilitation centers
description: In 2016, the Chinese government agreed to grant $4.7 million USD to the Ministry of Health of Uzbekistan for the provision of modern medical equipment to regional rehabilitation centers for the disabled. The grant was distributed to equip 5 rehabilitation centers (Namangen, Navoi, Jizzakh, Samarkand and Tashkent regions) for the disabled with laboratories and medical equipment, including modern diagnostic and physiotherapy equipment, X-ray diagnostic equipment, exercise therapy equipment, and laboratory equipment. According to the Review.Uz article, the MRI scanners were delivered to Uzbekistan in 2018.
name: Tashkent

title: Chinese Government grants $14 million for the supply of medical equipment to Uzbekistan
description:
In 2016, the Chinese government agreed to grant $14 million USD for the supply of 22 MRI units to 4 city hospitals in Tashkent, 5 regional multidisciplinary medical centers (for adults) in Tashkent, Ferghana, Jizzakh, Khorezm and Syrdarya regions, and 13 regional children's multidisciplinary medical centers.

According to the Review.Uz article, the MRI scanners were delivered to Uzbekistan in 2018.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Оснащение областных детских и взрослых многопрофильных медицинских центров магнитно-резонансным томографом.
name: Tashkent

title: China Eximbank loans $25 million for Tuyabuguz-Bekabad Interregional Water Supply System Construction Project
description:
In 2008, China Eximbank provided a $25 million loan to the Government of Uzbekistan for the Tuyabuguz-Bekabad Interregional Water Supply System Construction Project. Loan details are unknown.

The total cost of the construction project was $60 million. The project intended to provide qualified drinking water in Tuyabuguz-Bekabad areas and to improve the sanitary and epidemiological situation in the rural regions. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian name of this project is Строительство межрегионального водопровода Туябугуз-Бекабад." The local implementing agency for the project is Агентство “Узкоммунхизмат”, Хокимият Ташкентской области.
name: Bekobod

title: CDB provides $12.58 million loan for a Fastener Production Project in Uzbekistan
description:
In June 2017, China Development Bank and the National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan signed a $12.58 million loan agreement for a Fastener Production Project. The loan carried the following terms: 6.5 year maturity, 1.5 year grace period, and interest rate of 6-month LIBOR (1.432%) + a 7.1% margin. The National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan used the proceeds from this CDB loan to on-lend to Uzmetkombinat JSC, an Uzbek metal products manufacturer. 

This project involved the construction of a fastener production complex. The capacity of the new complex will reportedly be 5,000 tons of fasteners per year. Uzmetkombinat JSC (Uzbekistan Iron and Steel Works) will assemble the production complex with equipment from Sytco A. G., Berkshire Establishment LLP, and INOXIHP. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian name of this project is "Организация производства крепежных деталей для машиностроительной промышленности”.
name: Bekobod

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 126 million grant for railway container scanning equipment
description:
On June 18, 2016, the Chinese Government and the Government of Uzbekistan signed letters of exchange for an RMB 126 million grant to acquire railway container scanning equipment. The grant proceeds were drawn from an Economic and Technical Coooperation Agreement (ECTA) that was finalized on August 19, 2014.

The equipment included four large-sized inspection and examination complexes and 10 sets of scanning systems for use at the Chukursay Railway Station. Through this grant agreement, the Chinese Government also agreed tho carry out the installation and maintenance of the equipment and the training of specialists to operate the equipment. On August 3, 2018, the handover ceremony was held. The railway container scanning equipment was to be used at border posts at Bekabad in the Tashkent region, Khojedavlat in the Bukhara region, and Sariasiya in the Surkhandarya region. 

Staff Note: The Russian name of this project is «Проект поставки сканирующих оборудований для таможни».
name: Bekobod

name: Qibray

title: China Development Bank provides $220 million loan for 370MW Tashkent Combined Cycle Power Plant Modernization Project
description:
On August 8, 2012, Uzbekenergo State Joint Stock Company (SJSC) secured a loan agreement (agreement #6510201201100000066) from China Development Bank worth $220 million to finance for the 370MW Tashkent Combined Cycle Power Plant Modernization Project. The loan carried the following terms: 15 year maturity, 3 year grace period, and an interest rate equal to six month LIBOR rate plus a 3.6% margin (with an average six month LIBOR rate of .687 % for the year of 2012). The Government of Uzbekistan provided a sovereign guarantee for the loan.

This project involved a 370 MW steam-gas installation. The total project cost was $511.8 million. This project was not only financed by the CDB loan, but also by Uzbekistan's Reconstruction and Development Fund ($76.2 million), Synecta a.s. ($68.9 million), Uzbekenergo ($117.7 million), Uzpromstroybank ($26.9 million), and Japan International Cooperation Agency ($2.037 million). Construction began in 2012. This project was completed on or around January 19, 2016. 

Staff Note: The Russian name of this project is "Строительство парогазовой установки мощностью 370 МВт на Ташкентской ТЭС". This project is sometimes also referred to as the 370 MW CCGT Construction on Tashkent Thermal Power Plant (TPP).
name: Qibray

title: Chinese government loans $19.9 million for expansion and reconstruction of sewage treatment plants of Chirchik
description: In 2008, China provided a government loan of $19.9 million to Uzbekistan for the expansion and reconstruction of the sewage treatment plants of Chirchik. Total investments for the project were $20.9 million. Current project status and loan details are unknown. STAFF_NOTE: Project was recorded in Uzbekistan's 2008 IMF report but loan could have been committed earlier, so year is marked uncertain. Project could not be confirmed with any additional sources.
name: Qibray

name: Quyichirchiq

title: China Eximbank loans $58.5 million to Turonbank for four hydropower projects (linked to #54143)
description: On November 30, 2017, Turonbank of Uzbekistan secured a loan of $58.5 million from the Export-Import Bank of China with a term of 20 years. The funds were raised for a four projects: A hydropower plant on the Tuyabuguz reservoir in Urta Chirchik district, Tashkent Region. The total cost of the project is $15,900,000, but the amount of the Eximbank loan is unknown. The power station will have a capacity of 12 MW and the implementation dates are 2017-2019. Construction on the project began in June-August 2017, and the plant is expected to be commissioned at the end of 2018, but was not formally opened until March 2019. A cascade on the Big Fergana Canal in Namangan Region, Uchkurgan district (reported by the State Investment Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan). The total cost of the project is $25,900,000, but the contribution of the Eximbank is unknown. The station will have a capacity of 12 MW and the dates of implementation are 2017-2019. Construction began in June-August 2017, and completed in July 2019. Kamchik small hydropower station on the Akhangaran River in Pap district, Namangan region (reported by the State Investment Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan). The project cost is $27,200,000, but the amount of the Eximbank loan is unknown. The station will have a capacity of 18 MW and the dates of implementation are 2018-2021. According to MarketWatch, construction began in June-August 2017. Zarchob cascade of small HPPs on the Tupolang River in Sariasiya district, Surkhandarya region (reported by the State Investment Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan). The project cost is $80,390,000, but the amount provided by the Eximbank is unknown. The stations will have a capacity of 69 MW, and the dates of implementation are 2017-2020. According to MarketWatch, construction began in June-August 2017. Loan details are unknown. In June 2018, another loan agreement was signed between China Eximbank and Turonbank for HPP financing (captured in #54143).
name: Toshkent

description: In 2008, China provided a $19.1 million government loan in 2008 for reconstruction of the water intake facility WF-1, WF-3 for water supply to the rural population of Chinaz, and part of Yangy-Uyl rayon of Tashkent oblast. Current project status and loan details are unknown. STAFF_NOTE: Project reported in 2008 Uzbekistan IMF report, but exact commitment year is uncertain. Project could not be confirmed with any additional sources.

On February 11, 2014, CNTIC and CNR DLRC delivered the 11 electric freight locomotives to Uzbekiston Temir Yollari State Joint-Stock Railway Company (Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC). The locomotives were customized for use around Uzbekistan's capital of Tashkent (and on the Marakand-Qarshi-Termez railway line), where temperatures can drop to minus 20 degrees Celsius in winter. The cars can withstand temperatures as low as minus 30 degrees Celsius. They are produced in line with the Russian gauge of 1,520 mm, featuring high tractive power and environmentally friendly operation with a design speed of 120 km per hour.

This is the second locomotive acquisition project in Uzbekistan. The first project is captured in #40070.

Staff_Note: The Russian name of this project is "Обновление парка локомотивов ГАЖК "Узбекистон темир йуллари”. There are some sources that suggest the face value of the loan amount may have been revised upward from $42.17 to $42.75 million. We use the more conservative estimate for the time being.
name: Zangiota

title: China EXIM Bank Provides Loan of US$33 million for 500 kV overhead line “TSS Syrdarya – TSS Novo Angren" in Uzbekistan
description:
In 2012, the Export-Import Bank of China signed a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with Uzbek Industrial and Construction Bank (JSC Uzpromstroybank) worth $33,019,250 for the construction of 130km 500 kV overhead transmission line (OHL) from the Syrdarya Thermal Power Plant (TPP) to the Novo-Angren Thermal Power Plant (TPP). The terms of the PBC were as follows: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, 2% interest rate. The Government of Uzbekistan provided a sovereign guarantee for the loan.

This project was expected to run from 2014-2016. Xian Electric Engineering was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The total cost of the project was estimated at $93 million; funds not provided by the China Eximbank will be provided by Uzbekenergo. 

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 建设锡尔河电站至新安格连电站500千伏高压线路. Syrdarya may also be spelled 'Sirdaryo' or 'Sirdarya.' The project was also referred to as 'Syrdarya TPS – Novo-Angren TPS
name: Bo'ka

title: China Eximbank provides $60.5 million loan to Uzbekistan Railways in 2017 for Tashkent City Subway Project (Yunusabad line)
description:
In 2017, China Eximbank provided $60.5 million loan to Uzbekistan Railways for the Tashkent City Subway Project (Yunusabad line). This loan carries the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and 2% interest rate. 

On May 19, 2017, the project for the construction of an electrified high-speed ring railway in Tashkent was approved by the President of Uzbekistan. The construction period, taking into account the preparatory period, is four years (2017-2021). The preliminary cost of the project is US$422.3 million. The ring line of the metro will pass through the territory of Yashnabad, Yakkasaray, Uchtepinsky, Shaikhantakhur, Almazar, Yunusabad, Chilanzar and Sergeli districts.

Ltd (CNR DLRC) for the purchase of 11 electric freight locomotives. title: China Eximbank loans $25 million for Tuyabuguz-Bekabad Interregional Water Supply System Construction Project
description:
In 2008, China Eximbank provided a $25 million loan to the Government of Uzbekistan for the Tuyabuguz-Bekabad Interregional Water Supply System Construction Project. Loan details are unknown.

The total cost of the construction project was $60 million. The project intended to provide qualified drinking water in Tuyabuguz-Bekabad areas and to improve the sanitary and epidemiological situation in the rural regions.

title: China Eximbank provides a $5.93 million in export credits to equip Akangaran Hydropower Plant (Linked to Project ID#53683)
description:
On June 26, 2006, China Eximbank and the National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan signed a loan for $5,909,200 in export buyer's credits for equipment delivery to a small 50 MW hydroelectric power plant (HPP) at the Akhangaran water reservoir. The loan carried the following terms: 15 year maturity, 5 year grace period, 3.5% interest rate, 0.3% commitment fee, and 0.3% management fee. 

The National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan then used the proceeds of this loan to on-lend to an entity called "Специализированнымобъединением «Узсувэнерго»". The Ahangaran Hydropower Plant was launched as a joint venture between China National Electric Equipment Corp (CNEEC) and the Uzbek Agriculture and Water Management Ministry in 2007. Based on this agreement, CNEEC was to provide equipment and assemble the plant. Under this same agreement, the Andijian Hydropower station was also initiated (Project ID#53683). 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Поставка оборудования из КНР для МГЭС при Ахангаранском водохранилище.
name: Ohangaron

title: China Eximbank provides $113.8 million loan for Conversion of Units 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 of Novo‐Angren Thermal Power Plant Project.
description:
On June 9, 2010, China Eximbank signed a $113,835,650 loan agreement with Uzbek Industrial and Construction Bank (JSC Uzpromstroybank) for the Conversion of Units 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 of Novo‐Angren Thermal Power Plant Project. The terms of the China Eximbank loan were as follows: 2.5% interest, 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, 0.5% commitment fee, and 0.5% management fee. The total cost of the project was $213.7 million USD, financed with loans from China Eximbank ($113.8 million) and the Fund for Reconstruction and Development of Uzbekistan ($52.8 million), as well as own funds from Uzbekenergo ($47.1 million).

The purpose of this project was to switch five generating units of the Novo‐Angren Thermal Power Plant (TPP) to year-round coal burning and modernize the Angren coal mine. The project sought to increase coal production at the mine two-fold -- to 6.4 million tons a year. The Novo-Angren TPP is one of two power stations in Uzbekistan partly operating on coal (in winter – during the heating season). Its installed capacity is 2,100 megawatts. The power plant provides electricity to major industrial facilities and to the population of the Tashkent region. The general contractor of the project was Sino Coal International Engineering. This project was completed on January 20, 2014. 

Staff Note: Another English name of this project is the Angren Coal Mine Modernization Project. The Russian name of this project is «Перевод энергоблоков №№ 1—5 Ново-Ангренской ТЭС на круглогодичное сжигание угля (I этап) с модернизацией разреза «Ангренский».
name: Ohangaron

title: China Eximbank provides preferential buyer's credit for Tire Plant Project in Angren Special Economic Zone
description:
In August 2014, China Poly Group Corporation Limited signed a contract with Uzbekistan National Chemical Company to oversee the engineering, procurement and construction of a $213.9 million tire plant in the Angren Special Economic Zone. This project was partially funded by a $156.37 million preferential buyer's credit (PBC) from China Eximbank. The PBC carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and a 2% interest rate. The Government of Uzbekistan issued a sovereign guarantee for this loan.

The Tire Plant Project in Angren Special Economic Zone was reportedly financed according to a debt-equity ratio of about 70:30, with China Eximbank funding the debt portion. The Fund for Reconstruction and Development of Uzbekistan, O'zimyosanoat, O'zavtosanoat, the Navoi Mining and Smelting Plant, and Almalyk Mining and Smelting Plant reportedly funded the equity portion, although the breakdown of the $57.53 million equity portion is unknown. For the purpose of Project ID#54149, only the $156.37 million PBC from China Eximbank has been recorded.  

China Poly Group Corporation Limited and CITIC Construction Co., Ltd. were the contractors responsible for project implementation. Construction began on August 28, 2015 and was expected to last 34 months. The first tire was produced on trial on September 1, 2017, and production gradually increased during the end of 2017. The project was officially completed on July 25, 2018. The plant's initial production capacity is 3 million car tires, 200,000 agricultural tires and 100,000 linear meters of conveyor belts for cleaning equipment per year. All production equipment and processes were sourced from China. 

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 了乌兹别克斯坦安格连橡胶厂项目. The borrower of the China Eximbank PBC is unknown.
name: Ohangaron

title: China Eximbank provides $165.6 million for 150 MW Angren Thermal Power Plant Project
description: On September 9, 2011, China Eximbank and Uzbek Industrial and Construction Bank of Uzbekistan (JSC Uzpromstroybank) signed an agreement for a $165.6 million loan for the Angren Thermal Power Plant Modernization project. The loan was provided on the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, 2% interest rate. The Government of Uzbekistan also provided a sovereign guarantee for the China Eximbank loan. The total cost of the project was $242.6 million, with Uzbekenergo funding the remaining $75.1 million. Harbin Electric was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The EPC contract was signed between Harbin Electric and Uzbekenergo on September 26, 2012. The EPC contract came into force on December 31, 2013. A groundbreaking ceremony was held on May 3, 2014. The Angren TPP was successfully connected to the power grid on August 21, 2016.
name: Ohangaron

title: China Eximbank provides a $5.1 million loan for the purchase of 60-65 excavators (linked to #39956)
description:
On November 11, 2004, China Eximbank signed a General Loan Agreement for a 300 million USD preferential buyer's credit to Uzbekistan (#39956). Under this agreement, China Eximbank allocated $5.1 million USD in export buyer's credits for the purchase of 60-65 excavators to improve of the reclamation state of irrigated lands in the Bukhara, Navoi and Kashkadarya regions. Uzbekistan Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources undertook the project. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian name of this project is Улучшение мелиоративного состояния земель Бухарской, Навоийской и Кашкадарьинской областей. Loan details are unknown.
name: Bukhoro

title: China EXIM Bank loans Uzbekistan 50 million USD for the purchase of 63 excavators and 10 bulldozers from China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation
description: In 2010, China Eximbank loaned Uzbekistan 50 million USD for the acquisition of water and soil improvement equipment in Bukhara Oblast. The equipment purchased consisted of 63 excavators and 10 bulldozers from China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation. According to Uzbekistan's 'National Guidelines for Soil Improvement of Irrigated Lands for 2008-2012', by the end of 2008, Uzbekistan will construct and renovate 40 land improvement projects. At present, Uzbekistan has used Chinese loans to purchase water conservancy and soil improvement equipment worth US$50 million. Loan details are unknown.
name: Bukhoro

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 126 million grant for railway container scanning equipment
description:
On June 18, 2016, the Chinese Government and the Government of Uzbekistan signed letters of exchange for an RMB 126 million grant to acquire railway container scanning equipment. The grant proceeds were drawn from an Economic and Technical Coooperation Agreement (ECTA) that was finalized on August 19, 2014.

The equipment included four large-sized inspection and examination complexes and 10 sets of scanning systems for use at the Chukursay Railway Station. Through this grant agreement, the Chinese Government also agreed tho carry out the installation and maintenance of the equipment and the training of specialists to operate the equipment. On August 3, 2018, the handover ceremony was held. The railway container scanning equipment was to be used at border posts at Bekabad in the Tashkent region, Khojedavlat in the Bukhara region, and Sariasiya in the Surkhandarya region. 

Staff Note: The Russian name of this project is «Проект поставки сканирующих оборудований для таможни».
name: Bukhoro

title: Chinese Government provides $8.1 million for the Kuy-Mazar Pumping Station Rehabilitation Project
description:
In 2008, Chinese Government committed $8.1 million to the Government of Uzbekistan for the rehabilitation of the pumping station "Kuy-Mazar" in Bukhara oblast (Kuy-Mazar Pumping Station Rehabilitation Project). This project is now complete. 

STAFF_NOTE: Some sources indicated that this project was also supported by OPEC Fund for International Development. The Russian project title is Проект «Реабилитация насосной станции «Кую-Мазар» or Реабилитация насосных станций «Алат» и «Кую-Мазар» в Бухарской области.

title: China Eximbank provides $70.11 million loan for purchase of Chinese electric locomotives (Linked to #40131)
description:
In November 2007, the Chinese Government and the Government of Uzbekistan signed an MOU in which China pledged to offer concessional loans to Uzbekistan for the acquisition of electric locomotives from China.

In May 2009, Uzbekiston Temir Yollari State Joint-Stock Railway Company (Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC) signed a contract with CSR Zhuzhou Electric Locomotive Company for the supply of 15 electric locomotives. The total cost of the project was $75.53 million. China Eximbank loaned $70,110,000 in Preferential Buyer's Credits to the National Bank for Foreign Economic Activity of Uzbekistan to support this contract. The loan carried the following terms:  20 year maturity,  5 year grace period, 2% interest rate, 0.3% commitment fee, and 0.3% management fee. Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC covered the remaining cost of the project.

The projected speed of the electric locomotives was 160 km per hour, which would allow to double passenger turnover at the electrified railway roads of Uzbekistan. The new locomotives were to be used on the Samarkand-Khojidavlet railway line and Navoi-Samarkand line.  All 15 electic locomotives were delivered to Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC by the end of 2010.  

Staff Note: The Russian name of this project is «Узбекистон темир йуллари». Закупки пассажирских электровозов».
name: Bukhoro

title: Chinese Government grants $20 million for the acquisition of 20 dredgers and 2 towing boats (linked to #40111)
description:
On March 11, 2014, the Chinese Government and the Government of Uzbekistan signed an agreement to grant $20 million USD to Uzbekistan for the acquisition of 20 dredgers and 2 towing boats. The purpose of this project was to improve the irrigation system and to increase water availability and productivity of land in Uzbekistan. In total, 20 dredgers and 2 towing boats were delivered to Uzbekistan under this project. Project implementation facilities are located in Karakalpakstan, Khorezm, Bukhara and Kashkadarya regions. This project was completed on October 10, 2018.

STAFF NOTE: The Russian project name is  "Поставка земснарядов и комплектующих лодок в Узбекистан за счет грантовых средств правительства КНР”. This project is linked to Phase I of the Amu Darya (Amudarya) river clean up (captured in #40111).
name: Bukhoro

title: China's Exim Bank Loans to Create Food Transport Center in Bukhara (Linked to #54125)
description: In 2016, China's Xinjiang Silu Changlong Investment Co., Ltd committed to implementing, with the Ministry of Economy of Uzbekistan, a food transport center in Bukhara, Uzbekistan for the production, processing, and exportation of agricultural products. Total foreign financing will be $28.7 million; news sources report that this consists of investment by Xinjiang Silu Changlong Investment Co., Ltd. (project #54125) and a loan from the Eximbank of China, captured in this project. The breakdown of this financing is unclear. For the purpose of this project, $28.7 million has been coded as the transaction amount for the linked project, so as not to be double counted. The project will include a modern logistics center; 2 plants for processing of fruits, vegetables, meat and dairy products; a factory for the production of cardboard and plastic boxes; 4 refrigerators; energy efficient green houses; plant orchards using intensive technologies; and 20 refrigerated MAN trucks. The initial capacity of the project will be 10,000 products annually, and all fruits & vegetables will be exported.
name: Buxoro

title: Chinese Government provided RMB 50 million to the Government of Uzbekistan through an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ECTA) for the Karakul Pumping Station Reconstruction Project
description:
In 2009, Chinese Government provided a RMB 50 million interest-free loan for Karakul Pumping Station Reconstruction Project. On June 27, 2009, the Chinese Government committed RMB 60 million to the Government of Uzbekistan through an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ECTA). Using RMB 50 million of the proceeds from this ECTA, the Government of Uzbekistan obtained an interest-free loan for the Karakul Pumping Station Reconstruction Project. To support this loan agreement, an inter-bank agreement was signed between China Development Bank and the National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan on May 28, 2010. 

The Karakul Pumping Station Reconstruction Project sought to reconstruct a Karakul district pumping station in Bukhara region (oblast). It did so by, among other things, facilitating the acquisition of pump equipment. China IPPR International Engineering Corporation was the contractor. This pump station is responsible for the irrigation of nearly 30,000 hectares of land in the Karakul region and the water supply for 769 livestock farms. During the slack season, the pump station is used to wash saline-alkali soil. The primary and auxiliary Karakul pump stations have been operating for over 40 years and 25 years, respectively, and long exceeded the normal service life of mechanical and electrical equipment. The poorly serviced equipment were no longer able to satisfy the local irrigation needs. The successful completion and operation of the Karakul Pump Station Reconstruction Project on schedule further expanded the irrigation coverage of the pump station, not only restoring and improving the agricultural irrigation and drainage conditions, but also effectively improving the salinealkali soil environment. The Karakul region, one of the most important cotton production areas of Uzbekistan, had an excellent harvest of cotton in that very year. In 2012, both the region’s irrigated cotton plantation area and output ranked second across the country and the cotton festival, which had been abandoned for over a decade, was revived, attracting over 200,000 visitors.  

This project was initiated in 2006 and completed on January 13, 2013.  

Staff Note: The Russian project title is "Реконструкция насосной станции "Каракуль" в Бухарской области”.
name: Qorako'l

title: Bank of China provides a $178 million loan for the implementation of the Gas Condensate Field Khojadavlat Project (Linked to #54069, #39659, and #39658)
description:
In 2017, the Bank of China (Paris Branch) provided a $178 million loan to New Silk Road Oil and Gas — an Uzbek-Chinese joint venture (special purpose vehicle) — for the implementation of the Gas Condensate Field Khojadavlat Project (also known as New Silk Road Project). The project is funded by a $177.7 million USD loan agreement with the Bank of China, under the guarantee of CNPC. The total cost of the project is $377.5 million USD.

The Chinese National Petroleum Company (CNPC) and Uzbekneftegaz began developing three gas condensate fields in the Bukhara-Khiva region of Uzbekistan (Dengizkul, Kojadavlat, and Sharky Alat). When the three fields are developed, they will produce 869.6 million cubic meters of natural gas for exportation and 6,400 tons of gas condensate for domestic markets annually. The project was scheduled to begin in 2014, but construction began on May 30th, 2017.

The project will be implemented by three CNPC subsidiary companies: China Petroleum Engineering & Construction Corporation (CPECC) will develop the fields, designs, logistics, construction, and commissioning of facilities for the project; XIBU Drilling Engineering Company Ltd. will drill 10 production wells; and China National Logging Corporation will repair 6 wells and test production wells. 

In December 2017, the New Silk Road Oil and Gas Company Ltd (NSROG) founded as a joint venture by the CNPC and Uzbekneftegaz to oversee the project, started gas production in the Dengizkul field after the drilling of 2 new wells and repairing of 3 wells. NSROG announced that the Kojadavlat and Sharky Alat, specifically the 8 new wells and 3 damaged wells within these fields, were still under construction. A projected end date for the project has not been announced; however, construction was still occurring in September 2018.

Leading up to the 2017 development of these fields, the China National Oil and Gas Exploration and Development (CNODC), a subsidiary of CNPC, conducted a 5 year geologic oil survey for 359 million USD in 2006 (#54069), drilled 13 exploratory wells worth 260.2 million USD in 2011 (#39659), and 14.9 million USD for further oil exploration in 2012 (#39658).

STAFF_NOTE: The Chinese project title is 西莎、西吉和东阿拉特气田开发. Spelling was a little different in each source for site names, specifically Sharky Alat vs. Sharqiy Alat and Dengizkul vs. Khojasayat (the name of the overall region). Role of the JV unclear as Chinese companies both funded and implemented the project. Terms of the loan are unclear.
name: Qorako'l

title: Chinese Government provides $500,000 grant for earthquake relief
description:
On July 20, 2011, the Chinese Government pledged to provide the Government of Uzbekistan with a $500,000 grant for emergency relief after an earthquake.

On December 26, 2011, Chinese ambassador Zhang Wei and Uzbekistan’s Deputy Minister of Finance Jorkin Tulsonov signed an intergovernmental transfer certificate for the Uzbek government’s $500,000 foreign exchange humanitarian assistance project in Tashkent.
name: Ferghana

title: Chinese Government grants $14 million for the supply of medical equipment to Uzbekistan
description:
In 2016, the Chinese government agreed to grant $14 million USD for the supply of 22 MRI units to 4 city hospitals in Tashkent, 5 regional multidisciplinary medical centers (for adults) in Tashkent, Ferghana, Jizzakh, Khorezm and Syrdarya regions, and 13 regional children's multidisciplinary medical centers.

According to the Review.Uz article, the MRI scanners were delivered to Uzbekistan in 2018.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Оснащение областных детских и взрослых многопрофильных медицинских центров магнитно-резонансным томографом.
name: Ferghana

title: China Eximbank provides $8.48 million loan for improvement of the meliorative network of arable land in central Ferghana
description:
On February 14, 2008, China Eximbank provided a $8.48 million loan to the National Bank for Foreign Economic Activity of Uzbekistan for improvement of the meliorative network of arable land in central Ferghana. The loan had a maturity of 20 years, a grace period of 5 years, and an interest rate of 2%. The total budget for the project was $20.5 million.

China National Machinery Import and Export Corporation was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The current status of the project is unknown. 

Staff Note: the Russian project title is «Улучшение мелиоративной сети пахотных земель Центральной Ферганы»
name: Ferghana

title: China Eximbank provides $44.97 million loan for construction of water pipeline for the cities of Fergana, Margilan, and Andizhan
description:
In November 2007, China Eximbank and the National Bank for Foreign Economic Activity of Uzbekistan signed a loan agreement worth $44.97 million for the construction of a water pipeline in Uzbekistan. The terms of the loan were as follows: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and 2% interest rate.

The purpose of the project is to construct the improvement of potable water supply at 100,000 cubic meters per day, a number of booster pump stations, and a big-caliber 120-km water transmission pipeline for the Uzbek cities of Fergana, Margilan, and Andizhan. China National Chemical Engineering Co., Ltd.,  was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction was completed on November 30, 2011. 

Staff Note: The Russian name of this project is "Коренное улучшение водоснабжения городов Ферганы, Маргилана и прилегающих к водоводу населенных пунктов". Some sources refer to this project as an inter-regional water supply project.
name: Toshloq

title: China Development Bank provides $8.48 million loan for reconstruction of the AM-76 ammonia production unit
description:
In 2007, China Development Bank and National Bank for Foreign Economic Activity of Uzbekistan signed a $8,489,500 loan agreement for the reconstruction of the AM-76 ammonia production unit at OJSC Ferganaazot. The terms of the loan were as follows: 11 year maturity, 2 year grace period, interest rate of LIBOR + a 1.5% margin, commitment fee of 0.5%, and management fee of 0.5%.

This project was completed on January 15, 2010. Ferghanaazot OJSC is located in the city of Fergana within the Ferghana region. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian name of this project is «Реконструкция с элементами капитально- восстановительного ремонта производства аммиака АМ-76 на ОАО «Ферганаазот».
name: Farg'ona

title: China Eximbank provides $44.97 million loan for construction of water pipeline for the cities of Fergana, Margilan, and Andizhan
description:
In November 2007, China Eximbank and the National Bank for Foreign Economic Activity of Uzbekistan signed a loan agreement worth $44.97 million for the construction of a water pipeline in Uzbekistan. The terms of the loan were as follows: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and 2% interest rate.

The purpose of the project is to construct the improvement of potable water supply at 100,000 cubic meters per day, a number of booster pump stations, and a big-caliber 120-km water transmission pipeline for the Uzbek cities of Fergana, Margilan, and Andizhan. China National Chemical Engineering Co., Ltd.,  was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Construction was completed on November 30, 2011.

name: Farg'ona

title: Chinese Government grants $4.7 million for the provision of medical equipment to 5 regional rehabilitation centers
description: In 2016, the Chinese government agreed to grant $4.7 million USD to the Ministry of Health of Uzbekistan for the provision of modern medical equipment to regional rehabilitation centers for the disabled. The grant was distributed to equip 5 rehabilitation centers (Namangen, Navoi, Jizzakh, Samarkand and Tashkent regions) for the disabled with laboratories and medical equipment, including modern diagnostic and physiotherapy equipment, X-ray diagnostic equipment, exercise therapy equipment, and laboratory equipment. According to the Review.Uz article, the MRI scanners were delivered to Uzbekistan in 2018.
name: Jizzakh

title: Chinese Government grants $14 million for the supply of medical equipment to Uzbekistan
description:
In 2016, the Chinese government agreed to grant $14 million USD for the supply of 22 MRI units to 4 city hospitals in Tashkent, 5 regional multidisciplinary medical centers (for adults) in Tashkent, Ferghana, Jizzakh, Khorezm and Syrdarya regions, and 13 regional children's multidisciplinary medical centers.

According to the Review.Uz article, the MRI scanners were delivered to Uzbekistan in 2018.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Оснащение областных детских и взрослых многопрофильных медицинских центров магнитно-резонансным томографом.
name: Jizzakh

title: China Eximbank provides $42.17 million loan for Electric Locomotive Acquisition Project (linked to #40070)
description:
In 2012, China Eximbank agreed to loan $42,170,520.21 in export buyer's credits to National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Electric Locomotive Acquisition Project. The proceeds from this loan were used to support a $47.3 million contract (that was finalized in December 2011) between Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC and a consortium consisting of China National Technical Import & Export Corporation (CNTIC) and CNR Dalian Locomotive and Rolling Stock Co. Ltd (CNR DLRC) for the purchase of 11 electric freight locomotives. The China Eximbank loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, interest rate of 2.25%, commitment fee of 0.3%, and management fee of 0.3%. The Government of Uzbekistan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan.

On February 11, 2014, CNTIC and CNR DLRC delivered the 11 electric freight locomotives to Uzbekiston Temir Yollari State Joint-Stock Railway Company (Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC). The locomotives were customized for use around Uzbekistan's capital of Tashkent (and on the Marakand-Qarshi-Termez railway line), where temperatures can drop to minus 20 degrees Celsius in winter. The cars can withstand temperatures as low as minus 30 degrees Celsius. They are produced in line with the Russian gauge of 1,520 mm, featuring high tractive power and environmentally friendly operation with a design speed of 120 km per hour.

This is the second locomotive acquisition project in Uzbekistan. The first project is captured in #40070.

Staff_Note: The Russian name of this project is "Обновление парка локомотивов ГАЖК "Узбекистон темир йуллари”. There are some sources that suggest the face value of the loan amount may have been revised upward from $42.17 to $42.75 million. We use the more conservative estimate for the time being.
name: Zarbdor

name: Jizzax

title: Chinese government loans $40 million for improvement of water supply of Jizzakh
description: In 2008, China provided a $40 million government loan to Uzbekistan for improvement of the water supply of Jizzakh. Total investments for the project were 42.1 million. Current project status and loan details are unknown. STAFF_NOTE: Project is recorded in 2008 IMF report but loan could have been committed earlier, so commitment year is marked uncertain. Project could not be confirmed with any additional sources.
name: Jizzax

title: China Development Bank loans $50 million USD to Uzbekistan for high tech park in Jizzakh
description: In November 2011, the State Development Bank of China and National Bank of Uzbekistan for Foreign Economic Activity signed a loan agreement for $50 million USD to create a high tech park in the Jizzakh region of Uzbekistan. This high-tech industrial park aimed to be formally established by March 2013 and would be the third of the sort to be established in Uzbekistan, after those in Navoi and Angren. Deputy Minister for Foreign Economic Relations, Investments and Trade of Uzbekistan Shavkat Tulyaganov confirmed this at the Uzbek-Chinese Business Forum in Tashkent on March 31, 2012 and stated that construction would begin in the first half of 2013.
name: Jizzax

title: China loans $14.3 million for development of the water pipe network in the Republic of Karakalpakstan
description: China provided a government loan of $14.3 million to Uzbekistan for the development of the water pipe network in the cities and settlements of the Republic of Karakalpakstan, an autonomous region within Uzbekistan, as reported by Uzbekistan's 2008 IMF country report. Current project status and loan details are unknown. STAFF_NOTE: Project was recorded in Uzbekistan's 2008 IMF report but loan could have been committed earlier, so year is marked uncertain. This project could not be confirmed by any other sources.
name: Karakalpakstan

description:
On March 11, 2014, the Chinese Government and the Government of Uzbekistan signed an agreement to grant $20 million USD to Uzbekistan for the acquisition of 20 dredgers and 2 towing boats. The purpose of this project was to improve the irrigation system and to increase water availability and productivity of land in Uzbekistan. In total, 20 dredgers and 2 towing boats were delivered to Uzbekistan under this project. Project implementation facilities are located in Karakalpakstan, Khorezm, Bukhara and Kashkadarya regions. This project was completed on October 10, 2018.

STAFF NOTE: The Russian project name is  "Поставка земснарядов и комплектующих лодок в Узбекистан за счет грантовых средств правительства КНР”. This project is linked to Phase I of the Amu Darya (Amudarya) river clean up (captured in #40111).
name: Karakalpakstan

title: CDB participates in $2.54 billion syndicated loan to Uz-Kor Gas Chemical LLC for the Ustyurt Natural Gas and Petrochemicals Complex at Surgil Gas Field Project
description: In May 2012, a consortium of banks including the China Development Bank provided a $2.54 billion syndicated loan to Uz-Kor Gas Chemical LLC for the Ustyurt Gas Chemical Complex Project (also known as Ustiurt Gas-Chemical Complex or Ustyurt Gas-Chemical Complex). Uz-Kor Gas Chemical LLC is an joint venture (special purpose vehicle) between Uzbekneftegaz and Kor-Uz, a consortium of Korean firms, that created in May 2008. The $4 billion mega-project is located in the Surgil Gas field. The complex consists of a gas separation plant, units producing 400,000 tonnes per year of high-density polyethylene, 100,000 tonnes of polypropylene, and 110,000 tonnes of pryolised gasoline beginning in 2016. Based on information from IJGlobal Project Finance & Infrastructure Journal, the project's debt-equity ratio was about 65:35, with the debt portion amounting to USD 2.539 billion. China Development Bank provided about 10% of the total debt contract for the project (approximately USD 250 million) with a maturity of 16 years. For the purposes of this project record, only the USD 250 million loan from CDB has been recorded. The breakdown of the remaining 90% of the debt portion is as follows: 1. USD 700 million (28%) from Export-Import Bank of Korea 2. USD 125 million (5%) from Asian Development Bank 3. USD 800 million (31%) from a KSure covered tranche loan. Under this tranche loan, USD 500 million came from Korea Finance Corporation, USD 225 million from Korea Development Bank, USD 25 million from ING Group, and USD 50 million from Credit Suisse. 4. USD 100 million (4%) from National Bank of Uzbekistan 5. USD 300 million (12%) from a Kexim covered tranche loan. Under this tranche loan, USD 75 million came from Korea Development Bank, USD 75 million from ING Group, USD 25 million from Credit Suisse, USD 75 million from Siemens Financial Services, USD 10 million from BayernLB, and USD 40 million from SEK. 6. USD 140 million (6%) from an EKN covered tranche loan. Under this tranche loan, USD 60 million came from Nordea, USD 60 million from ING Group, and USD 20 million from SEK. 7. USD 124 million (5%) from a Hermes covered tranche loan. Under this tranche loan, USD 64 million came from KfW and USD 60 million from BayernLB. The equity portion of this project's financing amounts to USD 1.4 billion, and the investors are as follows: Uzbekneftegaz (50%), Lotte Chemical Corporation (17.5%), Korea Gas Corporation (17.5%), SK Group (5%), STX (5%) and LG Corporation (5%). The project was completed on May 21, 2016 (ahead of schedule). This natural gas and petrochemicals complex is located at the Surgil gas field in Akchalak on the Ustyurt Plateau. A detailed map of the project area can be found at https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/project-document/60114/44944-01-uzb-sa.pdf
name: Karakalpakstan

title: China Eximbank provides $28.5 million preferential buyer's credit to faciliate the acquistion of dredgers (linked to #70581)
description: On April 19, 2011, China Eximbank and the Government of Uzbekistan signed a $28.5 million preferential buyer's credit (PBC) loan agreement to facilitate the acquisition of dredgers. The PBC carries the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and 2% interest rate. The loan proceeds were to be used to purchase 30 dredgers to clean the banks of Amudarya River and its channels. This project is Phase I of the Amudarya River clean-up. Phase II of the project is recorded in project #70581.
name: Karakalpakstan

title: ICBC provides $29.2 million export buyer's credit loan for Kungrad Soda Ash Plant Project (Linked to Project ID#54832)
description:
In 2003, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) signed a $29.23 million export buyer's credit loan agreement with Uzbek Industrial and Construction Bank (JSC Uzpromstroybank) for the construction of the Kungrad Soda Ash Plant in Uzbekistan within the autonomous republic of Karakalpakstan. The loan carried an interest rate of LIBOR + 1.5%. Sinosure provided insurance.

CITIC Group and Uzkimyosanoat were responsible for project implementation. Under the terms of its contract, Citic Pacific Ltd. designed and constructed the plant on a turnkey basis (in which CITIC would turn over the plant after a certain number of years of its operation) at a cost of $32.3 million. The plant was officially commissioned in August 2006.  This project sought to achieve a production capacity of 100,000 tons of soda ash per year  — by mining limestone from the Jamansay (Dzhamansay) quarry and the Barsakelmes field salt field in Karakalpakstan (an autonomous republic in north-western Uzbekistan). The main consumers of soda plant are Uzbek enterprises that produce household chemicals and building materials, including various types of glass.

In 2012, the capacity of the plant was expanded to 200,000 tons per year, which was partially financed by a loan from China's Eximbank (see Project ID #54832). 

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 乌兹别克斯坦昆格勒纯碱厂. "
name: Qo'ng'irot

title: China Eximbank provides the National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan with RMB 112 million for the acquisition of excavators, bulldozers and dredgers (linked to #39957)
description:
On June 15, 2004, China Eximbank signed an agreement to provide a 300 million RMB concessional loan to the Republic of Uzbekistan for various projects (captured in #39957). On July 18, 2005, China Eximbank agreed to allocate RMB 112 million from the concessional loan to the National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan for the acquisition of excavators, bulldozers and dredgers to increase the supply of irrigated water in the Republic of Karakalpakstan and the Khorezm region.

On July 18, 2005, the National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan and China Eximbank signed a loan agreement for the acquisition of excavators, bulldozers and dredgers to increase the supply of irrigated water in the Republic of Karakalpakstan and the Khorezm region. The loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, 2% interest rate, 0.2% commitment fee, and 0.2% management fee. The contractor responsible for project implementation was China National Machinery and Equipment Import and Export Corporation. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian name of this project is Приобретение экскаваторов, бульдозеров и земснарядов для мелиоративного улучшения и повышения водообеспеченности орошаемых земель Республики Каракалпакстан и Хорезмской области.
name: Qo'ng'irot

title: China Eximbank provides a $73.85 million for Kungrad Soda Ash Plant Expansion Project (Linked to Project ID#39943)
description:
On September 12, 2012, China Eximbank issued a loan of $73.85 million to Uzbek Industrial and Construction Bank (JSC Uzpromstroybank) for the expansion of the Kungrad Soda Ash Plant in the Karakalpakstan region of Uzbekistan. The China Eximbank loan was provided on the following terms: maturity of 20 years, 5 year grace period, interest rate of Euribor + 2% margin.

The Kungrad Soda Ash Plant Expansion Project sought to expand the plant's capacity from 100,000 to 200,000 tons per year — by mining limestone from the Jamansay (Dzhamansay) quarry and the Barsakelmes field salt field in Karakalpakstan (an autonomous republic in north-western Uzbekistan). The main consumers of soda plant are Uzbek enterprises that produce household chemicals and building materials, including various types of glass. The total cost of the project cost $110 million, financed by China Eximbank, the Fund for Reconstruction and Development of Uzbekistan, and state Joint Stock Company (JSCJ) Uzkimyosanoat.

Project implementation was overseen by State Joint-Stock Company Uzhimprom. CITIC Co, Ltd. designed and supplied equipment for the project. Project implementation began on January 10, 2013. It was completed in January 19, 2016.  

This project is linked to Project ID #39943, an ICBC loan in 2003 for the construction of the plant.

Staff Note: The Russian project title is Строительство II-очереди объектов Кунградского СЗ. Some sources identify the face value of the China Eximbank as $77 million. However, we use the face value reported by the borrower of the loan: Uzbek Industrial and Construction Bank (JSC Uzpromstroybank)
name: Qo'ng'irot

title: China provides a 100,000 USD grant for the purchase of new stage equipment at a children's arts center in Uzbekistan (Linked with projects #71501, #72568, #72567, #72569, #72570, and #72564)
description: In 2014, China committed to a grant of US$100,000 to Uzbekistan for the purchase of new stage equipment for the purchase and supply of modern special stage equipment to the Republican Center for Children's Artistic Creativity in Nukus. The acquisition was part of a push by Uzbekistan to attract grant aid for its education system. It was reported that Uzbekistan attracted $225.6 million of grant aid for this purpose, some of which was provided by the People's Republic of China. As such, this project is linked to several other Chinese donations to the education sector during this timeframe: #71501 for the allocation of multimedia packages to classrooms grades 1st-4th #72568 for the purchase of 740 pcs of computer equipment for special needs students #72567 for the purchase of new equipment for the Center for the Development of Multimedia General Education Programs (CDMEP) #72569 for the purchase of computer hardware and computer equipment #72570 for the equipping of children's centers 'Barkamol Avlod' with 434 sets of computer equipment #72564 for the allocation of multimedia packages to classrooms grades 5th-9th
name: Nukus

title: Chinese Government grants $20 million for the acquisition of 20 dredgers and 2 towing boats (linked to #40111)
description:
On March 11, 2014, the Chinese Government and the Government of Uzbekistan signed an agreement to grant $20 million USD to Uzbekistan for the acquisition of 20 dredgers and 2 towing boats. The purpose of this project was to improve the irrigation system and to increase water availability and productivity of land in Uzbekistan. In total, 20 dredgers and 2 towing boats were delivered to Uzbekistan under this project. Project implementation facilities are located in Karakalpakstan, Khorezm, Bukhara and Kashkadarya regions. This project was completed on October 10, 2018.

STAFF NOTE: The Russian project name is  "Поставка земснарядов и комплектующих лодок в Узбекистан за счет грантовых средств правительства КНР”. This project is linked to Phase I of the Amu Darya (Amudarya) river clean up (captured in #40111).
name: Kashkadarya

title: China Eximbank provides a $5.1 million loan for the purchase of 60-65 excavators (linked to #39956)
description:
On November 11, 2004, China Eximbank signed a General Loan Agreement for a 300 million USD preferential buyer's credit to Uzbekistan (#39956). Under this agreement, China Eximbank allocated $5.1 million USD in export buyer's credits for the purchase of 60-65 excavators to improve of the reclamation state of irrigated lands in the Bukhara, Navoi and Kashkadarya regions. Uzbekistan Ministry of Agriculture and Water Resources undertook the project. 

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian name of this project is Улучшение мелиоративного состояния земель Бухарской, Навоийской и Кашкадарьинской областей. Loan details are unknown.
name: Kashkadarya

title: China Eximbank provides $42.17 million loan for Electric Locomotive Acquisition Project (linked to #40070)
description:
In 2012, China Eximbank agreed to loan $42,170,520.21 in export buyer's credits to National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Electric Locomotive Acquisition Project. The proceeds from this loan were used to support a $47.3 million contract (that was finalized in December 2011) between Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC and a consortium consisting of China National Technical Import & Export Corporation (CNTIC) and CNR Dalian Locomotive and Rolling Stock Co. Ltd (CNR DLRC) for the purchase of 11 electric freight locomotives. The China Eximbank loan carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, interest rate of 2.25%, commitment fee of 0.3%, and management fee of 0.3%. The Government of Uzbekistan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan.

On February 11, 2014, CNTIC and CNR DLRC delivered the 11 electric freight locomotives to Uzbekiston Temir Yollari State Joint-Stock Railway Company (Uzbekistan Railways SJSRC). The locomotives were customized for use around Uzbekistan's capital of Tashkent (and on the Marakand-Qarshi-Termez railway line), where temperatures can drop to minus 20 degrees Celsius in winter. The cars can withstand temperatures as low as minus 30 degrees Celsius. They are produced in line with the Russian gauge of 1,520 mm, featuring high tractive power and environmentally friendly operation with a design speed of 120 km per hour.

This is the second locomotive acquisition project in Uzbekistan. The first project is captured in #40070.

Staff_Note: The Russian name of this project is "Обновление парка локомотивов ГАЖК "Узбекистон темир йуллари”. There are some sources that suggest the face value of the loan amount may have been revised upward from $42.17 to $42.75 million. We use the more conservative estimate for the time being.
name: Chiroqchi

name: Dehqonobod

title: Chinese Government provides an RMB 7 million grant for a feasibility study for the Dehkanabad Potash Fertilizer Plant Project (Linked to Project ID#40128 and #40129)
description: On November 11, 2004, the Chinese Government agreed to grant RMB 7 million for a feasibility study for the Dehkanabad Potash Fertilizer Plant Project. After the Chinese Government provided an RMB 7 million grant for a feasibility study for this project, China Eximbank provided two loans for first and second phases of project implementation (Linked to Project ID#40128 and Project ID#40129). STAFF_NOTE: The Dehkanabad Potash Fertilizer Plant is located north of Chuchukquduq, close to Dehqonobod Raz'ezd in the Kashkadarya region of Uzbekistan. More detailed locational information can be found at https://mapcarta.com/35552246.
name: Dehqonobod

title: China Eximbank provides $41.7 million loan for Phase I of Dehkanabad Potash Fertilizer Plant Project (Linked to #72169 and #40128)
description:
In 2007, China Eximbank provided a $41.705 million loan to Uzbek Industrial and Construction Bank (JSC Uzpromstroybank) for Phase I of Dehkanabad Potash Fertilizer Plant Project. The terms of the loan are as follows: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and 2% interest rate. This project involved the construction of the Dehkanabad potash plant located at the Tyubegatan deposit.  

Construction of phase 1 of the plant started in 2010. The total cost of the project is $123.7 million. In addition to the China Eximbank funding, the Fund for Reconstruction and Development of Uzbekistan allocated a $61.9 million loan, and Uzkimyosanoat also directed its own funds to finance the construction. This project sought to increase the capacity of the plan to produce 200,000 tonnes of potash per year. In 2008, SJSC Uzkimyosanoat concluded contracts with ZAO UK Zapadouralsky Machine-Building Concern (Russia) and CITIC Pacific Ltd. (China) for the turnkey construction of the facility. Construction began in 2007 and the first phase of the project was completed on October 5, 2010.

This project is linked to Project ID#40128, a second China Eximbank loan for Phase II of Dehkanabad Potash Fertilizer Plant Project. On November 11, 2004, the Chinese government funded a feasibility study for this project (captured in #72169).

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 乌兹别克斯坦钾肥加工厂. The Russian project title is xСтроительство ДЗКУ 1-очередь.
name: Dehqonobod

title: China Eximbank provides $110.5 million preferential buyer’s credit loan for Phase II of Dehkanabad Potash Fertilizer Plant Project (Linked to #72169 and #40129)
description:
On September 22, 2011, China's Eximbank and Uzbek Industrial and Construction Bank (JSC Uzpromstroybank) signed a preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement worth $110.5 million to build the second phase of the Dehkanabad potash fertilizer plant. The terms of the PBC are as follows: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and 2% interest rate. The Government of Uzbekistan provided a sovereign guarantee for this loan.

CITIC Construction was responsible for the construction of the plant. The project will also be funded by FRD (62 million USD) and Uzkimyosanoat (22 million USD) for a total of 126 million USD. The second phase of the project was meant to triple capacity — to at least 600,000 tons of potash per year, 350,000 tons of which was planned to be exported. This project was completed on March 18, 2014.

On November 11, 2004, the Chinese government funded a feasibility study for this project (captured in #72169). Phase I of the Dekhanabad potash fertilizer plant is captured in #40129.

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 乌兹别克斯坦钾肥加工厂 or 德赫卡纳巴德钾肥厂（二期. The Russian project title is "Строительство ДЗКУ 2-очередь.
name: Dehqonobod

name: G'uzor

title: China Development Bank provides $1.2 billion loan to Uzbekneftegaz for the Oltin Yo’l gas-to-liquid (GTL) processing plant at the Shurtan petrochemical complex
description:
In 2018, a consortium of banks provided a $2.3 billion syndicated loan to Uzbekistan GTL LLC (UzGTL), which is a wholly-owned subsidiary of JSC ‘Uzbekneftegaz’ (Uzbekistan’s national oil and gas company), for development, design, engineering, construction and operation of a first gas-to-liquids (‘GTL’) plant at the Shurtan petrochemical complex in Guzar district, Qashgadaryo Region of Uzbekistan. The Oltin Yo’l GTL plant will seek to produce synthetic liquid fuels based on purified methane from Shurtan Gas Chemical Complex. The total cost of the plant is US$3.7 billion.

The Xinjiang Branch of China Development Bank (CDB) reportedly contributed $1.2 billion of debt for this project in 2017.  However, some sources indicate that the CDB also participated in the $2.3 billion syndicated loan. The costs of the project that are not covered by CDB will reportedly be covered by Uzbekneftegaz and a consortium of international financial institutions, including Export-Import Bank of Korea, Korea Trade Insurance Corporation K-SURE, Gazprombank, Russian export credit agency EXIAR, Credit Suisse, and Japanese banks MUFG, SMBC and Mizuho. Uzbekistan GTL LLC is the owner and operator of the project, while a South Korean consortium led by Hyundai Engineering & Construction company is serving as the general contractor.

The project began construction in January 29, 2017, and is expected to eventually the capacity to produce 743,500 tons of diesel fuel, 311,000 tons of aviation kerosene, 431,100 tons of naphtha and 20,900 tons of liquefied gas per year. Shurtan Gas Chemical Complex will supply the GTL plant with 3.6 billion cubic meters of methane per year. The plant is scheduled to begin service in 2020. 

STAFF_NOTE: Region also spelled as Kashkadarya Region. Year marked uncertain CDB loan was reportedly contracted in 2017, but some sources indicated that the broader syndicated loan was not finalized until 2018 or 2019.
name: G'uzor

title: CDB provides $85 million loan for Mubarek Gas Chemical Complex Project
description:
In 2009, China Development Bank and the National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan signed an $85 million loan agreement for the construction of a propane-butane mixing unit at the Mubarek Gas Processing Plant. This loan carried the following terms: 9 year maturity, 2 year grace period, 6.2% interest rate, 1.5% management fee, and 0.5% commitment fee.  

Uzpromstoybank JSC provided a guarantee for the loan.  Zeromax GmbH (Switzerland) was the contractor responsible for project implementation. The gas chemical complex is located in the city of Muborek within the Kashkadarya (also spelled as Qashqadaryo) region of Uzbekistan. The plant was eventually expected to produce 492,000 tons of polyethylene, 66,000 tons of condensate gas and tonnes of pyrolized petroleum a year. Its work was supervised by Uzbekneftegaz. This project was completed on May 14, 2013.

Staff Note: The Chinese project title is 穆巴列克天然气加工厂合. The Russian project title is «Строительство установки пропан-бутановой смеси для увеличения производства сжиженного газа на УДП «Мубарекский ГПЗ». As this project neared completion, a joint venture (special purpose vehicle) called UzIndoramaGasChemical was established by Uzbekneftegas NHC and Singapore's Indorama Group for continued investment in Mubarek Gas Processing Plant Project.  In May 2012, Uzbekneftegaz and Indorama Group (Singapore) established the joint venture. Then, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) signed an MOU with this joint venture in September 2013 in order to participate in the gas chemical project, but its involvement in the project did not become official in 2014. 

Staff Note: This project is also known as the Mubarek Gas Chemical Complex Project. It is not clear if the National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan used the proceeds of the CDB loan to on-lend to UzIndoramaGasChemical.
name: Muborak

title: China Eximbank provides $28.5 million preferential buyer's credit to faciliate the acquistion of dredgers (linked to #70581)
description: On April 19, 2011, China Eximbank and the Government of Uzbekistan signed a $28.5 million preferential buyer's credit (PBC) loan agreement to facilitate the acquisition of dredgers. The PBC carries the following terms: 20 year maturity, 5 year grace period, and 2% interest rate. The loan proceeds were to be used to purchase 30 dredgers to clean the banks of Amudarya River and its channels. This project is Phase I of the Amudarya River clean-up. Phase II of the project is recorded in project #70581.
name: Khorezm

title: Chinese Government grants $14 million for the supply of medical equipment to Uzbekistan
description:
In 2016, the Chinese government agreed to grant $14 million USD for the supply of 22 MRI units to 4 city hospitals in Tashkent, 5 regional multidisciplinary medical centers (for adults) in Tashkent, Ferghana, Jizzakh, Khorezm and Syrdarya regions, and 13 regional children's multidisciplinary medical centers.

According to the Review.Uz article, the MRI scanners were delivered to Uzbekistan in 2018.

STAFF_NOTE: The Russian project title is Оснащение областных детских и взрослых многопрофильных медицинских центров магнитно-резонансным томографом.
name: Khorezm

title: China Eximbank provides the National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan with RMB 112 million for the acquisition of excavators, bulldozers and dredgers (linked to #39957)
description:
On June 15, 2004, China Eximbank signed an agreement to provide a 300 million RMB concessional loan to the Republic of Uzbekistan for various projects (captured in #39957). On July 18, 2005, China Eximbank agreed to allocate RMB 112 million from the concessional loan to the National Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs of the Republic of Uzbekistan for the acquisition of excavators, bulldozers and dredgers to increase the supply of irrigated water in the Republic of Karakalpakstan and the Khorezm region.
